Attempts at shocking the reader with sudden episodes of gruesomeness are frequently overcooked, lending the book something of the air of a third-rate horror flick.For a supposedly brilliant man, Commandant Servaz makes some amazingly stupid mistakes, while both he and Ziegler display such a stunning lack of professional judgement at times that it is often hard to take either of them seriously.  The villains of the piece are so patently obvious throughout to everyone except the book's protagonists that often one feels one is reading the book more to find out how the various murders were committed rather than to find out who perpetrated them. (Sadly, this is, in fact, never revealed; I'm sorry if that's a spoiler.)For all its faults, however, there remains a certain promise and a gleam of something original that shines through the storytelling here which could break out into something exciting if the author would but back away from the tried and tested ideas of others. I look forward with interest to the second volume in this series, "A Song for Drowned Souls".

The "Arca Protective Carrying Case" from Case Logic is a robust semi-hard shelled carrying case designed specifically at the 11.6" Chromebook but pitched by Amazon at any similarly sized tablet PC. Despite the illustrative photo on the product packaging showing an Apple Macbook in it, I found that neither my MacBook Pro nor my wife's MacBook Air were a good fit to the bag, the former being a tight fit, the later slopping around altogether too loosely for real peace of mind.  This is a shame, because the "Arca" looks like it would otherwise be a good alternative to those occasions when you'd like to give your treasured laptop rather more protection than afforded by the lighter, neoprene sleeve type of carrying case.I also didn't like the way the case unzips on three sides allowing it to be opened up fully. Although this makes for fairly easy insertion and removal of its cargo, I have found that with this design it is all too easy to leave one side of the case unzipped, resulting in the contents sliding out unexpectedly -- and expensively!The case is supplied with a tough carrying strap, making it easy to carry slung over a shoulder but no other carrying handle. It has no side or internal pockets or pouches, though, so nowhere to carry any small extras such as USB drives, papers or power supply.In conclusion, then, although this product is of a high construction quality, its design limits both its usefulness and its versatility. Hence my fairly parsimonious rating of it.

Ivy Pochoda's "Visitation Street" is a lovely read. Partly a mystery story, partly a portrait of a community, the book paints a complex tapestry from the interwoven stories of several individual lives. It explores the many aspects of guilt and loss, recrimination and regret, blame and forgiveness, grieving and growth from which all lives are ultimately constructed.  The author writes poetic prose that imbues the ageing housing projects of Manhattan with a patina of pathos and its denizens with a glow of humanity, turning the district's grime into gold dust that sparkles in the light of the Ivy Pochoda's literary search-light.  Despite the story's essentially tragic nature, the book nevertheless carries a feel-good factor that should win over all but the most hard-hearted of readers. It cries out to be dramatised and filmed.Recommended.

In "The Day is Dark", Icelandic novelist, Yrsa Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, invokes fresh scenery for the fourth of her 'Th√≥ra Gudmundsd√≥ttir murder mysteries' by setting the bulk of the book's action not in Iceland but in the even bleaker environs of Greenland, in March.  For all of its novel setting, however, the author never really manages to inject any new life into either her characters or her storyline. In this tale, Th√≥ra does even less sleuthing than in any of the earlier books of the series and events are left to pretty much play themselves out until eventually the culprit more or less simply confesses to the crime and everyone gets to go home.  For once, Th√≥ra isn't plagued by her usual attendant domestic issues, whilst even her law firm's irritating secretary, Bella, is only used occasionally to impart a little contrasting colour here and there, rather than providing her usual begrudging assistance.The book does provide the reader with quite a few things to puzzle over, although most of these are not exactly brain-taxing, especially as the author likes to leave many of the clues out in plain view from early in in her books. The novel's main value, though, lies in its evocative portrayal of Greenland -- its nature and its society, both of which contribute to the dark and brooding undercurrent to the storyline.  In many ways, the book foreshadows some of the elements of Melanie McGrath's "The Bone Seeker", although without coming anywhere close to that novel's levels of complexity and depth of intrigue.Originally published in 2008 in Icelandic as "Au√∞nin (Veins of Ice)", this English language translation by Philip Roughton dates from 2012. Whilst idiomatic, the English version is far from sophisticated -- something that is quite common in translations of contemporary Icelandic writing, it would seem.For established fans of the author, this volume will probably not disappoint. It might even win over some new converts.Irritatingly, the Kindle edition lacks a table of contents, for some reason.

"The Last Rite" is the fifth and final part of Jasper Kent's "Danilov Quintet", bringing to a conclusion a story that spans more than a century of Russian history from Napoleon's Russian campaign of 1812 (in "Twelve") through to the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917. (The intermediary volumes in this series are, in order, "Thirteen Years Later", "The Third Section" and "The People's Will".)Initially, this concluding part gives the impression of being something of a rerun of its immediate forerunner, "The People's Will". For once, however, the author manages to pull off a complete surprise in the middle, though, suddenly turning the tale completely on its head and in the process, providing a real quandary for its protagonist.  As a result, the book becomes both a fun and a tantalising read, with its progress and conclusion being far from obvious, even for those who already know the real events of this time.In many ways, this is the best volume in the series since the first one, with the narration capturing many of the conflicting motivational tensions that underpinned that earlier story -- only this time with a very clever twist.  The book also closes out some left-over narrative threads from the earliest volume that many may well have forgotten about.  The book is essential reading for anyone who has followed the story this far; it does not disappoint.

Garnier's "Ultimate Blends Sleek Restorer Shampoo" smells like something that would be more appropriately poured over waffles or pancakes than rubbed into one's hair, its coconut oil and cocoa butter mixture being appetisingly well balanced! The product itself is the colour and consistency of good quality maple syrup!In use (in the shower, that is, not the kitchen!) the shampoo lathers up quickly and effectively but beware, it pours readily and it is very easy to apply too much.  It feels good in use, though -- even if it does engender a craving for pancakes afterwards!I've never really had much problem with "fly-away" hair, nor do I think that I ever had much "sleek" to restore so really cannot comment on Garnier's claims for the benefits of the this shampoo  but it certainly left my hair and scalp feeling good, even without resorting to any conditioner.  Its lingering fragrance is pleasant and not overpowering or cloying. Nice.

Kerstin Rodgers (aka MsMarmiteLover) is a popular vegan food blogger and professional chef. In "V is for Vegan", she presents a wide range of vegan recipes which vary from quick and simple snacks to complex dishes requiring considerable shopping and preparation time commitments.  Her emphasis in selecting recipes for inclusion seems to be based mostly on flavour, with appearance also high up on the list; Kerstin is obviously on a mission to put the lie to the popular misconception that vegan food is necessarily both bland and brown.  The author is also determined to reconnect her readers with what they eat through deliberately involving them more intensively in its preparation -- probably no bad thing in today's culture of "heat, eat and go!"The book is copiously illustrated but is hard on the eyes throughout, owing to the publishers opting to print every page with a different garish background colour against which the old fashioned typewriter and faux Letraset heading fonts stand out only poorly.  Maybe this is another attempt to move the idea of veganism away from old notions of it mostly being for sandal-wearing hippies, and make it appear more vibrant and contemporary. And, I guess, sometimes tofu needs all the help it can get when it comes to image make-overs!Look beyond the garish presentation of the book, however, and you will find some delicious little (and some not so little) treasures lurking within these pages. Be warned, however, that you may have to hunt a little harder than usual for many of the ingredients.

"Little Black Lies" is a new stand-along thriller from the pen of Sharon Bolton, author of the Lacey Flint Series of novels.  It is set in the Falkland Isles, in 1994, at a time when the war between Britain and Argentina over sovereignty of the islands a decade earlier is still fresh in the minds of the islanders and those who visit it.This remote South Atlantic setting gives the book an unusual slant and provides the author with a great deal of scope for building an unsettling atmosphere, in which the tensions present in small, tightly-knit communities can be fully utilised to build suspense and drama, whilst also playing to the readers' lack of familiarity with the locale. In this regard, the book has something in common with the Edie Kiglatuk Arctic Crime Series of Melanie McGrath, only set at the other polar extreme.The book utilises multiple person perspectives -- each with a subtly distinctive voice -- to play out a series of inter-connected but essentially personal story-lines set against a central mystery of a series of child disappearances on the islands.  The author does an excellent job of keeping the reader guessing about many aspects of the story, although the central mystery isn't all that difficult to work out.All in all, this is a well-written and very clever story, cast in a refreshing setting and presented in an entirely credible way (for the most part, at least). I suspect that real Falkland Islanders won't find much that they immediately recognise here but equally, I doubt that anyone will mind about that at all. Highly recommended for all mystery and thriller lovers.

"What Remains" is the sixth of Tim Weaver's series of 'David Raker' thrillers. After a somewhat shaky start with "Chasing the Dead" and "The Dead Tracks", this series has gone from strength to strength, through "Vanished" and "Never Coming Back" to "Fall From Grace".  With this latest instalment, the author has really excelled himself; the story-telling is slick, the action well-paced and exciting, the plot every bit as tangled and unpredictable as one could hope for without credulity ever being stretched beyond acceptable limits, as some of the earlier books required.Existing fans of these novels should love this release. It contains all of the hallmark 'David Raker' shocks, surprises and bizarre mysteries, clever misdirection and jaw-dropping plot twists, as well as adrenaline-pumping suspense and gooseflesh-inducing atmospherics.  In addition, this volume finally resolves a story thread which has been running throughout just about the whole series, so providing some closure not only for its characters but also for long-time readers.  As a consequence, of course, while this book could be read in isolation, it will be enjoyed most if you have reading at least some (and preferably all) of its forerunners.  Either way, though, one thing it won't do is disappoint.Unreservedly recommended.

"A Brief History of Iceland", by Gunnar Karlsson, professor of history at the University of Iceland, was originally published in 2000 (in Icelandic) as a collection of some 30+ double-spread chapters which provide a concise, if shallow, synopsis of the main social, political and economic events in the history of this island nation from its earliest colonisation in the late ninth century to the turn of the second millennium of the Christian Era. The English translation is by Anna Yates has a few oddities -- it appears to be pitched largely for a British readership and yet slips occasionally into US-oriented phraseology and terminology (using "sidewalk" rather than "pavement", for instance) which is odd but never disturbing.This revised second edition extends the original publication with a new chapter covering the banking collapse of 2010, as well as additional material in the chapter on 'Liberated Women' to include the election of J√≥hanna Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir as Iceland's first female Prime Minister in February 2009.The book is comprehensive without becoming too detailed or complex (although, oddly perhaps, no mention is made anywhere of Iceland's history of tolerance of and support for gay rights, nor of it having the distinction of having had the world's first openly lesbian head of government.) As an academic historian, the author steers well clear of most Icelanders' tendency to over romanticise -- or even fictionalise -- events in its history but manages to keep the tone pitched perfectly for a general, novice audience. As a result, the book is provides an ideal overview of the full span of Icelandic history and would make either an excellent introduction to more detailed study, or else provide the interested tourist with a basic understanding of how this island nation became what it is today.  Given the current speed of change in Iceland, however, it will may soon be in need of yet further expansion and revision.

"Let the Devil Sleep" is the third of John Verdon's novels featuring retired New York detective, Dave Gurney, and follows on from the earlier "Think of a Number" and "Shut Your Eyes Tight".  The marked improvement in plot construction and tension building that was evident in the second of these novels is carried through into this third, making this the author's best novel yet.Pacing is excellent throughout the book, which is mercifully free of any annoying side interludes. In addition, Dave Gurney's personal issues are much better integrated into this story than into either of the other two and don't interfere at all with the story flow but rather add to it quite considerably.  Although the plot is complex, the reader is provided with more than enough clues to identify the killer long before Gurney himself gets there, which, whilst not saying much for John Verdon's view of America's finest does at least make for a satisfying read.As is generally the case in these novels, the final showdown is terribly over the top but makes for a tense and exciting wrap-up to the tale.  I am looking forward to the next outing, "Peter Pan Must Die".

A man called Ove is a cantankerous old soul -- in that way old souls generally become cantankerous when they are surrounded by imbeciles and incompetents who can't so much as obey a simple sign, or climb a ladder to unstick a window without falling off, and who don't even know how to repair a bicycle or reverse a trailer any more."A Man Called Ove" is also one of the most hilariously poignant reads you are ever likely to encounter any side of old age. In this, his first novel, Swedish blogger, Fredrik Backmann, has managed to capture to perfection the feelings and attitudes that sixty years of honest toil in the face of life's vicissitudes so often engenders. In Ove, the author has created the perfect grumpy old man who wants nothing more than to get on with the business of dying, while the rest of the world has completely different ideas about what he needs to be doing. For an author so young, the book is written with great insight not only into people's personalities and how these affect their inter-relations, but also into the nature of growing old and of the human condition generally, albeit one tempered here with a dusting of comic simplicity. Additionally, the book has an air of farce that offsets the underlying serious message and ensures that it delivers poignancy without any tendency towards cloying melancholy.The book is a funny and entertaining read from start to finish, beautifully structured to reveal just as much of Ove's past as you need at any moment to understand and appreciate his actions and attitudes in the present. In the process, you'll come to love Ove as you would a favorite dotty uncle.Highly recommended.

"My Heart and Other Black Holes" is the d√©but novel of American author, Jasmine Warga. Aimed at the young adult market, it tackles the sensitive issues of teenage depression, low self-esteem and thoughts of suicide in a moving, enlightening and uplifting way. It deals with the matters of loss, feelings of individual weirdness, isolation and alienation, and of the salvation that comes about through relationships. And above all, it deals with love, the basic human need for it, and the difficulty that we sometimes have in recognising it for what it is.The book is a captivating read, achieving just the right balance of humour and pathos, with quirky but endearing and believable characters, and a storyline that is tensioned to perfection. Whilst most readers will see quite early on where the tale is heading and are not likely to encounter many surprises along the way, the urge to read on nevertheless remains strong throughout the book. Initially, it is the intriguing individuality of the narrative that keeps the pages turning but the book's protagonist so quickly wins over the heart of the reader that it isn't long before you are reading on because of how much you've come to care about the outcome.For all of its deadly serious subject matter, the tone remains light and entertaining, even through the darkest passages. Jasmine Warga manages to display a rare talent, in writing in a realistic and singular teenage voice to which readers of all ages should have no difficulty whatsoever relating. The book has a host of well-rounded characters, it avoids all stereotyping and, indeed, does much to break them down. The story is both heart-rending and heart-warming (oh yes, and nail-biting). It is wholeheartedly recommended to readers of all ages.

Anyone who has ever spent any time at all travelling by train -- especially anyone who has routinely travelled the same line as a commuter -- will immediately recognise the starting premise of Paula Hawkins' d√©but crime triller, "The Girl on the Train". Surely no-one can resist peering into the back yards and gardens or through the windows of kitchens, dining rooms,  conservatories and bedrooms of suburban track-side homes and wondering about the lives that are glimpsed there? For Rachel, on her daily journey in and out of London, it is easier than for most to imagine what is going on, because she used to live in one of the houses she sees into by the side of the tracks where her train stops briefly at a signal each day. Her ex-husband and his new wife live there now but Rachel is no longer a part of that life any more, except as passive observer -- she is merely the Girl on the Train now.  Until, that is, one day she observes from her passing train something that changes her world forever, and which throws her into a terrifying tangle of murder, intrigue and despair; one made even more frightening by the fact that Rachel has a problem remembering things clearly at times, as well as separating reality from fantasy -- a problem that puts her in far more danger than she realises.From this premise, Paula Hawkins constructs a clever and convincing tale of obsession, deceit and guilt -- as well as of modern day suburban mundanity and the baggage that it carries. Masterfully written and well paced throughout, this book is one of the best thrillers to have come my way in a long time. Told from a three-person perspective, almost in daily journal format, the tale slowly reveals the various facets of the main characters in a way that forces a constant reassessment of circumstances and keeps the reader guessing at the outcome right until the very end.Dreamworks have already acquired the rights for Marc Platt to produce the film version even before the book has been published; it will probably make for a cracking movie. It already makes for a stunning and completely unputdownable read.

Whilst the name Charles Darwin is universally associated with the formulation of the theory of evolution of biological species through the operation of the forces of natural selection, the figure of Alfred Russel Wallace lurks more as a spectre behind the scenes of Victorian natural history and scientific endeavour -- if, that is, he is even known about at all. Lacking in any formal education beyond the age of 14 and of poor, working-class background (in contrast to Darwin's own wealthy status and possession of Cambridge degree) Alfred Wallace struggled for much of his life against the prejudices of the privileged-class members of Britain's scientific societies, who passed off much of his hard-won achievements and accomplishments as mere amateur field naturalism lacking the rigours of the scientific approach, or the discipline of academic focus.In reality, Wallace was a dedicated -- some might even say fanatical -- collector of natural specimens and a fastidious documenter of all that he collected, saw or encountered and who explored areas into which few, if any, white men had previously dared venture. In his early twenties, he spent four years exploring, mapping and collecting wildlife in the Amazon rainforest; later, between 1854 and 1862, aged 31-39, he travelled extensively around the Malay Archipelago (now Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia) where he amassed some 126,000 specimens of mammals, birds, insects (including more than 80,000 beetles alone). Several thousand of the species he collected and described were entirely new to science at that time.  In 1869, Wallace published an account of his time in the far east ("The Malay Archipelago") which became one of the most popular accounts of scientific exploration ever published; it has never been out of print. The most important work that Wallace undertook during those years and which made him famous in his time is largely forgotten today.Whilst Wallace was exploring and gathering specimens throughout the archipelago, he became fascinated by the vast array of animal and plant species that he encountered and puzzled over the often subtle differences which distinguished the species populating one island from those of another. His deliberation on these differences and their distribution led him independently to his own theory about natural selection as the driving force behind the emergence of new species. Mindful of his lack of standing within the scientific establishment, in 1858 he sent a draft article outlining his theory to Darwin for his opinion, and asking that Darwin share the article with Charles Lyell for his judgement also.For Darwin, the knowledge that another had hit upon the very theory that he himself had been developing for publication for some time (but which, by his own admission at that time still required "many more years' work") was sufficient catalyst for him to rethink his own plans for how his ideas on evolution needed to be prepared for public consumption. Unbeknown to Wallace, his 'draft' essay, together with a paper by Darwin himself, were presented by Charles Lyell to a special meeting of the Linnean Society of London in July 1858. Both men were credited with independently arriving at the same idea at the same time. Following the meeting, Darwin speedily prepared his "On the Origin of Species " for publication in 1859. Wallace, out of touch throughout this time in the wilds of Irian Jaya, remained ignorant of these developments until 1860. He did not return to London and civilisation until 1862, by which time Darwin had spent four years alone in the limelight and the rest, as they say, is pretty much history as far as public recognition of the originator of the theory goes.It is testimony to the character of Wallace that he never exhibited or expressed any rancour over what many at the time and since have perceived as a gross unfairness to him. Every now and then, another article or book emerges trying to rectify things by examining afresh the man, his achievements and his contributions to the advancement of evolutionary theory and bio-geography. The latest addition to this pantheon is "The Evolutionist" by Canadian writer, Avi Sirlin. Rather than risk a potentially dry biography (and thereby have to compete with Peter Raby's fairly definitive "Alfred Russel Wallace", or even Wallace's own account, "My Life: A Record of Events and Opinion".) Avi Sirlin's approach has been to dramatise the events of Wallace's life and present matters in the form of a novel. In order to do this effectively, he admits that he has to invent new characters as composites of real ones, imagine meetings and encounters that probably never took place, as well as to reorder somewhat the chronology of his subject's life.The author has also invented a faux Victorian literary style in which to convey his narrative, presumably in order to evoke something of Wallace's own writing style. Sadly, I found it imbued with too many trans-Atlantic grammar, terminology and spelling lapses for it to feel in anyway authentic. To me, it is merely lumbering and ponderous; it may put many readers off altogether, as it is far from being an easy read. Writing styles aside, though, the book itself is both engaging and absorbing, if also a little lurching in its structure -- how sad that real lives so rarely follow the most satisfying narrative arc!I have no idea how authentic Avi Sirlin's portrayal of Wallace's odd mix of naivety, misplaced self-confidence and rank humility may be, but the author certainly makes a convincing job of it. The books many faults make it hard to give this particular publication wholehearted endorsement but any volume which makes Wallace's name better known (even if potentially for the wrong things) has to be welcomed, even with so many already out there.

Mike Hulme is Professor of Climate and Culture at King's College London, UK, and founder of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research. His latest book on climate change, "Can Science Fix Climate Change?", is a relatively slim volume (150 pages + index) laying out the arguments against climate engineering through deliberate atmospheric modification, particularly through the use of stratospheric injection technologies or other methodologies for implementing a so-called planetary thermostat. The first four chapters of the book present cogently argued reasons why it is unethical, reckless and pointless even to research such technologies, let alone contemplate their deployment. The fifth (and final) chapter wraps up the subject by giving some pointers as to how scientific and engineering endeavours might be better focused by reframing the entire question of managing climate change by concentrating on pragmatic goals more attuned to serving the (global) public good.As an invective against the hubristic and megalomaniacal techno-fix that climate engineering undoubtedly is, the book works well. Where it fails, however, is as a balanced overview of the contributions that science can make to an understanding of the issues that societies generally need to tackle around climate change. Throughout the book, the author generally tars all scientists with the same brush, appearing unable to recognise that whilst would-be climate engineers all operate within the scientific community this does not mean that all scientists are would-be climate engineers or even that they must inevitably be in favour of an engineered approach to climate change avoidance. In reality, of course, the number of advocates for climate engineering in general represents only a small minority of the world's climate scientists, whilst those who openly advocate or pursue research into stratospheric modification -- the geoclique, as Mike Hulme brands them -- is an even smaller group (albeit it one with a disturbing disproportionate degree of influence on the policy making of powerful Western governments).The author does a good job of keeping his text non-specialist in its subject matter. Most readers will, I suspect, find that the is text overly repetitive in places, with many of the author's points being heavily laboured. That said, however, the book should prove an interesting read for anyone interested in knowing the ins and outs of why climate engineering is such an incredibly stupid idea, regardless of whether climate change is real, or even anthropogenic in nature. Anyone actually interested in finding an answer to the question posed in the book's title will, sadly, need to read more widely.

Rock Jaw's "Arcana V2" in-ear headphones are a good pair of in-ear headphones with integral microphone for use with almost any of today's portable devices that require such. They are supplied with a total of four outer plastic buds, across a total of three different sizes overall, which should be a sufficiently wide range of fits to suit most purchasers. It is worth taking the time to fit the correct size buds for your ears, as this makes quite a difference to both the overall comfort levels as well as sound quality, especially with regard to the amount of audio pick-up and feedback from within the wearer's own head, as the headphones easily pick up and amplify breathing and swallowing sounds, for instance.  When used with the correct size buds, they are quite a comfortable fit, with fairly low levels of feedback.The manufacturers make much of the fact that these headphones are constructed from rosewood and aluminium, making them fairly robust but at the same time very lightweight, as well as richer in tone. I doubt whether most users will notice any significant difference from most all-metal or even plastic models, to be honest, except in a fairly small number of usage scenarios. Rock Jaw also claim that the twisted pair cables are less tangle prone than conventional multicore cables. Again, I can't say that I really noticed any improvement here over any other pair of headphones I've tried; they seemed to knit themselves into an impressive knot of Gordian proportions every time I looked away from them. They do seem to transmit a fair amount of handling and movement noise, however, which is a pity.Sonically, the 'phones appear to offer a nice flat frequency response, with good separation across the frequency range, working well to deliver a good clear soundfield from a wide range of listening sources. Those who like a heavyweight bass injected directly to brain may be a tad disappointed but personally I rather like the natural balance they deliver. Unlike many in-ear headphones these days, these do not offer any noise cancelling functionality; sonic purists will no doubt regard this as a good thing.My main gripes about the "Arcana V2" headphones are that the two earpieces are not labelled in any way to distinguish left from right; there are times when this matters and having to work out and remember which side has the microphone push-switch is a bit of a pain. Secondly, they are supplied without a carrying pouch or such-like. Instead, they some in a relatively large and flashy display case which consists principally of a heavy duty slip sleeve with a foam insert to hold the headphones, cable and the three unused pairs of outer plastic buds. This arrangement appears to be mostly about making the product look more professional than models distributed in standard blister-packaging. In reality, it offers nothing of use, merely lumbering you with a lot of extraneous packaging without providing any storage or carrying potential. (To be fair, though, it is a lot easier to get into than most blister packs!)All in all, these "Arcana V2" offers a fairly high quality of discrete mobile listening, albeit at a fairly high price. Much of the extra price seems to go towards supporting the manufacturers' hyped-up presentation of the product, rather than towards any tangible quality of the headphones themselves, although it has to be said that sonically they are far from disappointing.

John Urry is Distinguished Professor of Sociology at Lancaster University in North West England. Not surprisingly, therefore, his latest book, "Offshoring", is an academically rigorous and thoroughly researched summary of the sociological as well as economic effects of the comparatively recent global phenomenon of 'offshoring' -- i.e. the circumventing of regulatory or legislative restrictions on particular activities by moving those activities overseas to some other location with laxer laws or more 'relaxed' attitudes.  Offshoring as a practice is not particularly new, but, as this book demonstrates, it has really flourished since the rise of financial neo-liberalism from the mid 1980s on.For most people, offshore business is most likely to be associated with the exploitation of cheap, non-unionised labour markets -- most commonly in the provision of customer service call-centres -- or in the burgeoning use of overseas tax havens.  It is clear from this book, however, that corporate tax avoidance and worker exploitation are but the tip of a huge iceberg of socially unacceptable or immoral outcomes of routine undertakings of the rich and the powerful. Such undertakings are invariably at the expense of the poor and less powerful and, as the author shows, ultimately indeed, of the very planet itself.For many, John Urry's book will be a truly eye-opening and frightening read. In it, he chronicles the entire gamut of activities that, while central to today's interconnected world, nevertheless escape crucial regulation for the common good by being undertaken in offshore localities. Such activities are usually conducted in secret, often hidden behind faÁades of respectability (which further prevent too much inspection from prying eyes) and invariably kept comfortably out of the sight of the masses and thus well and truly out of mind.The list is far longer and all-encompassing and the harm greater than you might think. Most commonly reported in the media these days and at least somewhat in the public spotlight is the routine offshoring of wealth and finance. This not only deprives societies generally of vast quantities of essential tax revenues but also leaves financial speculators free to gamble on money markets and other ephemera such as derivatives, rather than invest in real assets, and in the process risks bringing about complete global economic collapse. Similarly, offshoring of labour is known to damage workers' health and wellbeing in order to keep the richer parts of the world supplied with cheap consumer goods and services, the demand for which has been largely engineered by the offshoring businesses themselves.Less obviously open to offshoring, perhaps, but shown in this book to be no less significant in their impact are: - leisure activities, with overseas locations often sought as vacation destinations in order to legitimise otherwise illegal pleasure-seeking activities such as gambling, drug taking or sexual exploitation of (usually) women or children. - energy provision, with the reliance on oil and gas driving drilling operations into ever more inhospitable and risky environments, increasing the chances of irreparable damage to fragile and vital ecosystems - waste disposal, with ever increasing quantities of toxic and hazardous material discarded by rich consumers being shipped over the horizon, out of sight and out of mind, to pollute the lands and endanger of the lives of those make a living from processing the detritus of moden consumer-based living - transportation, with the need to transport cheaply the growing volumes of (offshored) manufactured goods, energy sources and discarded waste, filling the oceans' shipping lanes with dangerously substandard cargo vessels registered under flags of convenience, frequently imperilling the lives of poorly paid crews and risking ecological mishap - state security, with activities such as 'extraordinary rendition' supposedly legitimising the use of torture and other extreme means of extracting the knowledge supposedly required to separate friend from (often imaginary) 'enemy' -- often creating new, very real, enemies in the process.The final chapters of the book demonstrate the wider harm that offshoring in general perpetuates -- widening inequalities; squandering of vital resources; irreversible environmental impact; loss of democracy; undermining of global security and the sacrificing of real freedoms for the illusory freedoms of the relentless consumer. It builds a potent argument for a reversal of the offshoring process, suggesting some potential avenues which might bring this about. (Some may regard the book as a clarion call to revolution, a declaration that it is time to topple the powerful from their positions. To read it this way though is to miss one of its central tenets: that the powerful are already beyond the reach of revolution, except on a truly global scale, as their seats of power are themselves largely offshored, making them inherently unreachable by the masses.)The book is not without its faults: the author has a tendency towards repetition, which makes some sections a little tedious to read. I feel also that he takes the oceanic metaphor of offshoring a little too far (and I am not at all convinced of his assertion that 'salted away' is an original offshoring or sea-related expression either -- it doesn't mean 'hidden away' so much as 'preserved in case of need'.)  These faults are neither major nor serious, however, and need not deter any potential reader; its message is too important to disregard.

John Urry is Distinguished Professor of Sociology at Lancaster University in North West England. Not surprisingly, therefore, his latest book, "Offshoring", is an academically rigorous and thoroughly researched summary of the sociological as well as economic effects of the comparatively recent global phenomenon of 'offshoring' -- i.e. the circumventing of regulatory or legislative restrictions on particular activities by moving those activities overseas to some other location with laxer laws or more 'relaxed' attitudes.  Offshoring as a practice is not particularly new, but, as this book demonstrates, it has really flourished since the rise of financial neo-liberalism from the mid 1980s on.For most people, offshore business is most likely to be associated with the exploitation of cheap, non-unionised labour markets -- most commonly in the provision of customer service call-centres -- or in the burgeoning use of overseas tax havens.  It is clear from this book, however, that corporate tax avoidance and worker exploitation are but the tip of a huge iceberg of socially unacceptable or immoral outcomes of routine undertakings of the rich and the powerful. Such undertakings are invariably at the expense of the poor and less powerful and, as the author shows, ultimately indeed, of the very planet itself.For many, John Urry's book will be a truly eye-opening and frightening read. In it, he chronicles the entire gamut of activities that, while central to today's interconnected world, nevertheless escape crucial regulation for the common good by being undertaken in offshore localities. Such activities are usually conducted in secret, often hidden behind fa√ßades of respectability (which further prevent too much inspection from prying eyes) and invariably kept comfortably out of the sight of the masses and thus well and truly out of mind.The list is far longer and all-encompassing and the harm greater than you might think. Most commonly reported in the media these days and at least somewhat in the public spotlight is the routine offshoring of wealth and finance. This not only deprives societies generally of vast quantities of essential tax revenues but also leaves financial speculators free to gamble on money markets and other ephemera such as derivatives, rather than invest in real assets, and in the process risks bringing about complete global economic collapse. Similarly, offshoring of labour is known to damage workers' health and wellbeing in order to keep the richer parts of the world supplied with cheap consumer goods and services, the demand for which has been largely engineered by the offshoring businesses themselves.Less obviously open to offshoring, perhaps, but shown in this book to be no less significant in their impact are: - leisure activities, with overseas locations often sought as vacation destinations in order to legitimise otherwise illegal pleasure-seeking activities such as gambling, drug taking or sexual exploitation of (usually) women or children. - energy provision, with the reliance on oil and gas driving drilling operations into ever more inhospitable and risky environments, increasing the chances of irreparable damage to fragile and vital ecosystems - waste disposal, with ever increasing quantities of toxic and hazardous material discarded by rich consumers being shipped over the horizon, out of sight and out of mind, to pollute the lands and endanger of the lives of those make a living from processing the detritus of moden consumer-based living - transportation, with the need to transport cheaply the growing volumes of (offshored) manufactured goods, energy sources and discarded waste, filling the oceans' shipping lanes with dangerously substandard cargo vessels registered under flags of convenience, frequently imperilling the lives of poorly paid crews and risking ecological mishap - state security, with activities such as 'extraordinary rendition' supposedly legitimising the use of torture and other extreme means of extracting the knowledge supposedly required to separate friend from (often imaginary) 'enemy' -- often creating new, very real, enemies in the process.The final chapters of the book demonstrate the wider harm that offshoring in general perpetuates -- widening inequalities; squandering of vital resources; irreversible environmental impact; loss of democracy; undermining of global security and the sacrificing of real freedoms for the illusory freedoms of the relentless consumer. It builds a potent argument for a reversal of the offshoring process, suggesting some potential avenues which might bring this about. (Some may regard the book as a clarion call to revolution, a declaration that it is time to topple the powerful from their positions. To read it this way though is to miss one of its central tenets: that the powerful are already beyond the reach of revolution, except on a truly global scale, as their seats of power are themselves largely offshored, making them inherently unreachable by the masses.)The book is not without its faults: the author has a tendency towards repetition, which makes some sections a little tedious to read. I feel also that he takes the oceanic metaphor of offshoring a little too far (and I am not at all convinced of his assertion that 'salted away' is an original offshoring or sea-related expression either -- it doesn't mean 'hidden away' so much as 'preserved in case of need'.)  These faults are neither major nor serious, however, and need not deter any potential reader; its message is too important to disregard.

If you have not already encountered the deliciously raw and violent world of Daniel Polansky's Low Town and its laconic and somewhat nefarious Warden, then "A Drink Before We Die: A Low Town Short" serves as an excellent -- and clever -- introduction. This short story provides an intoxicating -- if gory -- vignette which perfectly encapsulates all that makes the Low Town trilogy ("Low Town: The Straight Razor Cure", "Tomorrow, the Killing", and "She Who Waits") such an addictive read.For those already hooked, the timing of this release is perfect, delivering a much-needed fix whilst we wait for the author's next novel, "Those Above (The Empty Throne)", to hit the shelves. This Kindle-only release gives some appearance of being hurried to 'press' -- I spotted a couple of typos in it -- but at least no Daniel Polansky fan needs to suffer cold turkey this Christmas!

David Mitchell's "The Bone Clocks" is like so many of this author's books -- mind-blowing in its complexity and dazzling in its genre-bending propensities.  Superficially, it has some similarities with the earlier "Cloud Atlas" in that its narrative is propelled through erratic leaps between multiple protagonists across large time gaps -- and with just as many seeming subject changes.  This latest book differs from its forerunner, however, in being simultaneously more tightly integrated in its storylines and more rambling in its delivery. It is also infinitely more convoluted (labyrinthine, even) in its formulation -- offering something of the literary equivalent of a Mandlebrot Set in the self-referential nature of its unfolding.In some regards, this latest book has more in common with "The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet". It not only reintroduces -- three times -- one of that book's characters but also shares its constant shifts of narrative direction and focus, possesses the same drawn-out perambulatory pacing, and concludes on a similar extended coda with little real relevance to the central story.Where this book deviates from either of its immediate stablemates, however, is in the depth of humour which pervades almost every sentence and yet in a way that remains forever veiled and subtextual rather than overtly stated. (I wonder how many readers, for instance, will even spot the joke embedded with the very title of the book's final section, which is not exposed until the story's closing twist.)For all of its brilliance -- and the fact that this is a book that is a consistently fun and at times very funny read -- there remained for me at least, a feeling that much of what the author attempts in this book has, in fact, been better delivered in works such as Nick Harkaway's "Angelmaker" or even Sheri S. Tepper's "Beauty". And, by and large, I found travelling to be considerably more rewarding than arrival at the book's eventual destination.  That said, the book remains very good indeed and well worth a read. It could well blow your mind!

Philip Ziegler's biography of the father of Britain's current Queen Elizabeth, "George VI: The Dutiful King", is a slim addition to the 'Penguin Monarchs' series, offering just six chapters over fewer than 80 pages of a hardbound duodecimo format (approx 7" x 5") publication, sporting an odd three-quarter height dust sleeve.  In addition to a collection of photographs of the king at various stages of this life, the book also has an index, notes regarding source materials for each of the chapters, plus suggestions for further reading. The main text itself is an easy and undemanding read, offering a fairly comprehensive survey of the life and reign of Britain's last king.The book's size is probably commensurate with the biography of a monarch who reined for just 16 years and who didn't live beyond his 57th year. Nevertheless, one can't help feeling that it does little more than scrape the surface of its subject matter, for all that the author does his utmost to reassure his readers that George VI was in no way a deep or complicated man. Something about this book left me strangely unsatisfied, all the same.Another problem is that Philip Ziegler constantly assumes that his readers will be familiar with most of the book's additional cast and so provides them with no introduction and precious little gloss. Whilst it is perhaps a reasonable assumption that figures such as Winston Churchill and Neville Chamberlain need no such introduction, it may be asking a bit much for younger readers especially to know just who Herbert Morrison, Hugh Dalton or even Ernest Bevin might be.  The text can also be confusing at times, principally because of the things it fails to explain for those who are unaware of the complications of, for instance, the naming of royal personages. It is never made clear, for examnple, just why 'Prince Berty', as he is referred to throughout the book, should later be crowned as King George VI, or why 'his brother David' became (briefly) Edward VIII. Or what it means that Prince Philip of Greece "had no name".These minor faults and irritations notwithstanding, the book does a good job of dispelling many of the rumours and myths which have over the years surrounded George VI and his actions, setting the record straight once and for all regarding his attitudes both to various of his family members and to his duties and responsibilities in general. More than anything, the book does an excellent job of emphasising the sense of duty that George displayed throughout his life, and how important was the role he (and his wife) played in humanising the role of the Crown and securing a place for the monarchy in the hearts of the British public for generations afterwards.In short: an interesting, if not an exactly riveting read.

"The Assassin's Blade" is a collection of five "prequel novellas" (or, more accurately, advertising teasers) for Sarah J. Maas' teen romance/fantasy novel, "Throne of Glass". Four of the novellas ("The Assassin and the Pirate Lord", "The Assassin and the Desert", "The Assassin and the Underworld" and "The Assassin and the Empire") were previously released in ebook form on the run-up to the release of the first novel of the main series. The entire collection is here available in a single binding, in both physical and ebook forms, joined by a newly written and otherwise unavailable fifth story, "The Assassin and the Healer" which sits, chronologically, as second in the new ordering.Together, these five short stories cover a relatively short period of Celaena Sardothien's life immediately prior to the events of the main "Throne of Glass" story, essentially chronicling the period of her ill-fated relationship with Sam Cortland.Established fans of this series of books will love this collection, as it provides lots of additional detail to the Celaena Sardothien's back-story and offers some tantalising hints as to how the main novels may yet develop in future. Anyone coming afresh to the stories and wondering whether to read the prequels first or not need not hesitate -- they give a great feel for the main novels and give away no surprises, but neither are they required reading for a better understanding of the other books, so it doesn't matter at all which order you plump for.All five stories here are very short; each can easily be read in an evening or less. The writing quality does vary across the series, suggesting that they've actually been written either at speed or over a collection of different times. The newcomer to the set, "The Assassin and the Healer", whilst the shortest is also the best written of them all, showing a maturity of writing style that is sadly missing from the others. It has clearly been added to give this new omnibus addition some additional content over and above the previously released material (a move that may annoy those fans who bought the four other stories separately long ago but who now feel that they have to fork out again to acquire the new tale). It adds little the events already chronicled in the earlier stories but is, in fact, worth having as it paints an interesting vignette of a single short episode which nevertheless adds volumes to the complexity of the character of the Assassin of Adarlan.

"The Assassin and the Empire" concludes the series of "prequel novellas" (or, more accurately, pre-release advertising teasers) for Sarah J. Maas' teen romance/fantasy novel, "Throne of Glass". It neatly wraps up all of the prequel threads and also sets things up perfectly for the opening of the main novel.Anyone who has already read the main novel will be fully aware of the outcomes and events which unfold here and it is to the author's credit that she does nothing to string things out or attempt any surprises along the way. Instead, she cranks up the tension by having events roll steadily and relentlessly towards their inexorable conclusion, making this easily the most gripping of the prequel stories.Established fans will love this story, as it provides lots of additional detail to the Celaena Sardothien's back-story and provides some tantalising hints as to how the main novels may yet develop in future. Anyone coming afresh to the stories by reading the prequels first will not be disappointed here, either.  It cannot, of course, really be recommended on its own, needing the reader to be familiar with the earlier novellas ("The Assassin and the Pirate Lord", "The Assassin and the Desert" and "The Assassin and the Underworld" all being heavily referenced.)Since the release of the omnibus edition of all five 'Throne of Glass' novellas, "The Assassin's Blade", it has become pointless buying each of the stories separately -- especially as the second tale in the prequel sequence, "The Assassin and the Healer", is only available as part of the omnibus collection.

"The Assassin and the Underworld" is the penultimate of five "prequel novellas" (or, more accurately, pre-release advertising teasers) for Sarah J. Maas' teen romance/fantasy novel, "Throne of Glass", following straight on from  "The Assassin and the Desert".In it, we see Celaena Sardothien revert to her usual role of vain and pampered spoilt brat, more concerned about her split ends and smudges to her make-up, and living it up at all-night parties than she is about living up to her position as Assassin of Adarlan. In short, this particular novella reverts to the normal form of at least the first two volumes of the main series, "Throne of Glass" and "Crown of Midnight", by being principally a teen romance placed within a fantasy setting,  aimed pretty much at a female teenager market.  As such, it gives a good feel for the main novels (and provides some additional more-of-the-same reading for fans who have consumed those and who still want more) and also supplies additional background detail for the main story.Fans of the main series should not be too disappointed adding this to their collection (especially those keen to know more about Celaena's and Sam's relationship). The biggest disappointment will probably be its length -- the book is only about 70 pages long. Be aware too, that this particular novella cannot really be recommended on its own, being very much a continuation of the story told in earlier ones, so if you are at all interested, you would be well advised to buy the omnibus edition of all of the 'Throne of Glass' novellas, "The Assassin's Blade", rather than acquire each of the stories separately (especially as that way you get an overwise unavailable 'bonus' fifth novella, "The Assassin and the Healer" included too).In summary, this is a 'must-have' addition to the collection of the established fan; anyone just wanting a taster of these books is advised to sample "The Assassin and the Pirate Lord" first of all.

"The Assassin and the Desert" is the third of five "prequel novellas" (or, more accurately, pre-release advertising teasers) for Sarah J. Maas' teen romance/fantasy novel, "Throne of Glass". (It was originally published as the second, to follow on from "The Assassin and the Pirate Lord"; the collected omnibus edition of the novellas, "The Assassin's Blade", inserts a new additional story, "The Assassin and the Healer", between these two.)This story is much better conceived and executed than its predecessor, with fewer sillinesses and a more believable, slightly less stereotyped array of characters. It is also very slightly longer, but not by much. Like "The Assassin and the Pirate Lord", it offers newcomers a reasonable opportunity to determine what the Celaena Sardothien books are all about and whether they hold anything of interest for little investment in either time or money. That said, a would-be reader would be well advised to come to this story via its forerunner(s), rather than starting here.Anyone who has already consumed all of the books of the main series published so far, only to find themselves hungry for more will, naturally, have to have this story too -- it does flesh out some of the events hinted at in the main series without spoiling any aspects of the main tale -- and would be well advised to buy the omnibus publication, rather than acquire each of the novellas separately.

"The Assassin and the Pirate Lord" is the first of five "prequel novellas" (or, more accurately, pre-release advertising teasers) for Sarah J. Maas' teen romance/fantasy novel, "Throne of Glass".The book is even more silly and cliched than the main novel it serves to advertise, featuring no originality whatsoever and with many utterly absurd notions that a publisher more interested in quality than in advertising copy would probably have worked harder to remove prior to publication. In addition, the story suffers from a distinct lack of polish in the plot department, with some quite needless and -- with never being explained -- entirely confusing twists at the beginning which are presumably designed to serve as intriguing hooks but which sadly are then abandoned altogether.Readers who already know and love Celaena Sardothien will, of course, not care a fig for these shortcoming, because even within this book's small compass (it contains only about an hour's worth of reading) it nevertheless manages to convey to perfection the character of the irritating head-strong teenage heroine of the Throne of Glass series. It also provides the very mix of kick-ass action and hesitant teen romance that pretty much defines "Throne of Glass".This book serves two functions ideally, then. Firstly it offers newcomers a good way to find out whether or not these books are for them, requiring little investment in either time or money. Secondly, it offers some more-of-the-same reading matter for anyone who has consumed all of the books of the main series published to date only to find themselves hungry for more.  It doesn't provide a great deal more, but existing fans should not be disappointed with the contents.When first published, the next novella in the prequel sequence was "The Assassin and the Desert". A new bound-edition print collection of the series, "The Assassin's Blade", features an additional story, "The Assassin and the Healer", between these two. This new addition to the sequence has not been released separately.

Isla Morley's latest novel, "Above", is ostensibly a teenage abduction thriller. Gradually, though, and almost imperceptibly, the book turns into something so much more, as it delves deeper into the value of hope and purpose, the dangers of obsession, the delicate balance between the two extremes. By the time it reaches its second half, the book is much more about humanity, about individuality and identity, and about freedom and just how illusory that can be in reality.The story is not an easy one to read -- at least psychologically -- but it is an almost impossible one to draw away from. Presented in the first person, the narrative is beautifully written using a unique voice that weaves the teenage and the naive with something ancient and wise in a way that constantly gives pause for thought whilst simultaneously maintaining credence and building empathy with the protagonist, Blythe, and her plight as an abductee held captive by a survivalist fanatic in an abandoned underground missile silo.  Each chapter is long, with sections that are discontinuous and are somehow disjointed and make the reader every bit as lost and disoriented temporarily as the protagonist. The narrative soon takes on an almost surreal floating timeless feel to it. It is also claustrophobic as well as tense and suspenseful.  Time and again, the tale twists in unexpected and unforeseen ways, causing the reader to surrender to the same emotional roller coaster ride as the protagonist.Ultimately, though, this is a book that makes it clear that the world is nothing like as black and white as we'd have ourselves believe it to be. It is a book that shows that the division between good actions and bad actions is nowhere near as clearcut as we think. It is a book that calls into question just what the word "freedom" means, and why it is important to us, as humans, and just how much we will pay, one way or another, to attain it. Above all, however, it is a book that explores what it is to be human and what it is that anchors us to that humanity when faced with ordeals and adversity.Highly recommended.

"The Visitors" is Rebecca Mascull's d√©but novel. And a real stunner it is, too. It should also come with a warning: it is 19 chapters long; I would advise you to have at least 3 tissues handy for each!Part tale of personal survival, part love story, part something so much more, the book presents as a period piece, set at the start of cusp of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. It is  told from the first person perspective of a young girl deaf and blind from an early age. It is emotionally charged and highly personal in its detail, with a prose style that is both sensitive and moving, yet epic in scope. The story speaks with a power that is simply overwhelming in its consistent and consistently up-lifting honesty, optimism and generosity. Once started, it is extremely hard to put down.Beyond that, I am not prepared to comment, simply because much of the beauty of this book lies in the surprises that the author manages to deliver on almost every new page -- surprises both large and small that are an utter delight when they occur and which repeatedly make the eyes water up and have you reaching for yet another tissue!In short, books as beautiful as this are few and far between. Buy it! You won't regret it.

It is easy for those wo didn't live through those times to look back over the war-torn first half of the twentieth century and to think that world peace was restored with the ending of the second of those World Wars. Victor Sebestyen's new book, "1946: The Making of the Modern World", quickly puts the lie to any such view, as well as any other cosy notion that global suffering and hardship at the hands of oppressive, invading regimes, somehow came to an end with the defeat of the Axis powers in the west, and the Japanese military machine in the east in 1945.  The book presents an overview, in more or less chronological order, of the key events of 1946, demonstrating how each of the decisions taken by the Second World War's "victors" in that year were to lead to the changes and events that have pretty much shaped the world ever since and which continue to impact on world peace and security to this day. Along the way, the book does a pretty good job of demonstrating the proof of Winston Churchill's famous words: "Those who can win a war well can rarely make a good peace and those who could make a good peace would never have won the war."The book necessarily has to review historical events and circumstances leading up to the year under review in order for readers to undestand and appreciate their context and background. In doing this, it reveals the various power balances that were in play, showing how the Second World War was largely responsible for shifting global economic power into the hands of the United States (as virtually the only country in the world to emerge from the war actually richer as a consequence of the war) and the necessary responses that other countries had to make to their altered global positions in that power struggle. Specifically, the book identifies 1946 as being the year in which many of the first steps were taken towards events which affected the world for most of the rest of the century and, indeed, continue to affect us today: the rise of the Eastern Bloc, foreshadowing the fall of the Iron Curtain and the ensuing East/West Cold War; the demilitarisation of Japan; the partitioning of India; the division of Palestine; civil war in Greece (and many other places); the threat of war with the USSR over Turkey; the ascendancy of Communism under Mao Zedong in China; the uneven and carefully orchestrated prosecution of war criminals. Above all, the book shows that the world in some ways was an even worse place in the immediate post-War years, with levels of human suffering and misery even higher than it had been throughout the war. Food shortages were worse; numbers of refugees and displaced persons at their highest ever and, with war reprisals all too rife, irrational and  mindless acts of barbarism between peoples quite possibly at their darkest.The author brings his full journalistic skills to the fore in presenting an extensive and exhaustive body of research into the events of the time, making the book an easy -- if highly depressing -- read for expert and lay reader alike. The author's sense of 'story' ensures that the book is never dense or plodding; indeed, at times, it reads almost as a thriller. Happily, though, the author manages to avoid overstating or over-dramatising matters and stays short of  sensationalising the facts. The book thus successfully navigates most of the pit-falls associated with popularising history texts.For the reader who wishes to dive deeper into the research, the author's sources are extensively referenced. Highly recommended.

Hornby have been making model railway sets in one guise or another since the appearance of Hornby Dublo in 1938; their "OO" gauge has pretty much been the de facto UK model railway standard ever since. The fact that the company is still very much in business is testimony to the quality and attention to detail of its products. And while some old-timers may tell you that its modern-day plastic moulded locomotives are not as sturdy not as pleasing in the hand as their earlier die-cast metal models, they are still very good reproductions of actual UK locos, with good attention to authenticity of detail.The "R1138 GWR Passenger Freight" electric train set is a nice little starter set, comprising a compact oval of track with a short length of siding, a GWR tank loco, with two goods wagons and a passenger coach, together with controller and printed cardboard mat on which the circuit can be laid out.  The set is small enough to be quickly assembled and put away again after use for occasional play and the components are robust enough to stand up to this too, provided they are not handled too roughly.The real enthusiast will, of course, prefer to install the set into a more permanent layout, most likely as nothing more than the kernel from which a much larger set-up will gradually (and never-endingly) grow!This set is an ideal way to find out how interested someone might be in playing with train sets generally without investing in a large layout. Be warned however that, like buying someone their first Lego set, this may end up by only being the start of a much larger undertaking!

The "NTF3000 No Touch Plus Forehead Digital Thermometer" from Braun is an excellent digital thermometer designed for measuring core body temperature in an entirely non-intrusive manner, making it ideal for use wherever there is a range of different potential patients -- such as in the family home.  It is as simple to use as it is safe and hygienic: simply place the device on or close to the patient's forehead and press a button. A clear and easily read LCD display then displays the temperature reading, helpfully colour coded to show whether the value is regarded as "normal", "elevated" or "high". The device can be configured to display either Celsius or Fahrenheit values by means of a slide switch tucked away in the battery compartment, which is handy for those who still prefer to think in old money when comes to some things. In normal operation, the thermometer will also beep to confirm its operation; this can conveniently be muted for those situations where this would be undesirable -- where you wouldn't want to wake a sleeping patient, for instance.There are a few simple guidelines that should be followed for best results -- ensure that the patient has been indoors long enough for any outdoor cooling effects to have been overcome; ensure that the forehead is not covered by hair or beaded with sweat; take care to use the area between the eyebrows; and so on. The device includes a proximity sensor which will prevent it from taking a reading if it is held too far from the subject. An error indicator shows when a reading suggests that the device has not been used properly -- if the reading is too low, for instance -- which reduces the potential for potentially dangerous (or frightening!) erroneous readings being taken. (Whilst a desirable feature for the device's intended use, this does, of course, limit its potential for wider non-medical temperature sensing jobs -- probably a good thing as it deters anyone from trying and ending up confused, or worse, by the results, as the device doesn't report the actual temperature it senses but rather computes a theoretical core body temperature from that value.)My only real criticism of the design concerns the dust cap that covers the sensor when not in use, which is a very tricky push fit, with a considerable reluctance to stay in place. I can see most people dispensing with or losing this item altogether very early on in the lifetime of the device. Hopefully, this won't matter too much.

Emergen-C's "Energy Release and Immunity Support" food supplement is a high dose (1000mg) Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) plus multi-vitamin and mineral product. It is supplied in boxes of single-dose sachets of powder which rapidly dissolves in water to produce an orange-flavoured daily health drink, designed to give you a daily energy and vitamin boost.The product offers a dose of vitamins well in excess of the recommended daily amounts (Vitamins: C - 1250%; B1 - 136%; B2 - 121%; B6 - 429%; B12 - 720%; D - 200%) as well as fair top-up of minerals Potassium, Calcium, Magnesium, Manganese, Chromium and Zinc (the Calcium and Zinc being particularly important as mineral accompaniments to Ascorbic acid). It is flavoured with natural orange and lemon extract and coloured with additional E162 (Betanin, aka Beetroot Red) natural food dye. So far, so good.Where the product falls down in the health-giving stakes is in its massive sugar content: it contains large amounts of fructose, cane sugar and maltodextrin as sweeteners -- which explains the product's "energy boosting" claims. It also contains bovine gelatine as an entirely superfluous ingredient which immediately renders it unsuitable for vegetarians or vegans.  Be aware too that some people suffer reactions to Ascorbic acid in the form of swelling to the face, water retention or digestive disorders; no warnings about these potential (but uncommon) side effects are given on the packaging of this product.For those wanting a short-term high dose blast of Vitamin C and a general immune system boost to face down an impending winter cold, these powders are probably OK. To avoid the sugar they contain, though, it is probably better to opt for "Redoxon Double Action" effervescent tablets instead, especially as these also offer a higher Zinc content (although these use Aspartame as the sweetener instead, which comes with its own problems). They do lack the additional vitamins, but it's probably also better to tailor vitamin and mineral supplementation to your diet and lifestyle than to take a single multi-mix. You might also wish to bear in mind that unless your immune system is taking a hit owing to an underlying health issue, it is generally regarded as undesirable to take regular large doses of Vitamin C over prolonged periods; they should be avoided altogether by anyone suffering from renal problems.

After a mediocre start to this series with "Throne of Glass", Sarah J. Maas has managed to build on the improvements delivered in "Crown of Midnight", with a very solid continuation of the tale in this third part of the saga, "Heir of Fire". The greater complexities to the storyline which were hinted at in the earlier volume are now much more fully exposed and developed, with the slowness of the earlier parts now fully revealed as but the beginning a long-form narrative piece that clearly still has some distance to run.Additionally, the writing and the drama have both tightened up considerably in this volume, the author having now very much matured in her story-telling skills, especially with regard to timing and tension. This latest volume has a more complex story line than either of the earlier books, with the author here splitting the action between some four or five story strands. The emphasis has also moved away from the teen romance elements of the earlier books, focusing instead much more on drama and action. Those who liked the romance aspect of the earlier volumes need not worry however, as it has not been dropped entirely.Sadly, the subject matter and the ideas remain every bit as derivative as the earlier books, with absolutely nothing new being brought to the fantasy canon here. That said, the author has at least developed a credible and consist synthesis of well established fantasy elements and lovers of the genre should be more than happy with the result -- there is nothing that leaps off the page as being wrong and much that is very right indeed. And what the book lacks in originality is partly made up for in sheer epic scale and scope of the vision behind it.Plot-wise, whilst many of the outcomes are predictable, especially with regard to the main Celaena thread, the routes to those outcomes often are not. Nor is at all obvious where many of the longer arcs of the narrative are heading. If the book has a real fault it is the continuing overly angst- and guilt-ridden nature of the heroine which is even more over-done in this volume than it was in the last one. The addition of a host of substantial new characters -- including a loveable baddy -- as well as some unexpected new elements to the story line does much to break up any "more of the same" feel that the book would otherwise have.In summary, then, "Heir of Fire" offers a rock-solid continuation of the "Throne of Glass" saga, albeit one which effectively serves notice on the reader that there is still a long way to go yet before this story completes. For most readers, I would expect that to be good news, not bad.  The ending will also leave you eager for the release of the next part of the tale.

"Sort Your Brain Out" by motivational speaker, Adrian Webster, and neuroscientist, Dr Jack Lewis, is not so much a self-help book as it is a lay person's guide to understanding the functioning of the brain, with hints and tips for keeping that organ healthy and properly operational. As such, the book falls somewhat between stools; being more instructive than instructional, the reader is very much left to their own devices to take away from the book whatever they can find there and so to work out (or not) ways in which to make use of that. For some, this approach will make a welcome change from the overly prescriptive self-help style of book which promises miraculous improvement to well-being simply by rigorously following a fully articulated (and mostly totally impractical) n-point plan. Rather than adopt that approach, the authors here present their readers with the neuroscience (in a simple and easily digested form) which underlies various key aspects of what the brain does and how, followed by some pointers as to how to keep each of those functions optimised.The danger of this approach is that it is all too easy to read the book and to end up feeling that all it does is to offer common sense, dressed up with a lot of technical detail that is of little or no import to anyone not studying for a neuroscience qualification. The book can also feel pretty thin on content with no obvious logic to its structure.Whether or not this book actually does help you to sort out your brain, you should find that it is, at least, an easy and fairly relaxed read, at the end of which you should be fully equipped to boost your performance, manage stress and generally achieve more in life.

Having pretty much closed off all scope for any further contemporary Erlendur stories with "Strange Shores" in 2010, it is interesting to see that Icelandic novelist, Arnaldur Indriason, has been unable to stay away from the characters he invented for his 'Reykjav√≠k Murder Mysteries' series for long. The first sign that there may indeed be more Erlendur stories in the offing appeared in 2011 with the release in Icelandic of a prequel story featuring the detective's former CID mentor Marion Briem, "Einv√≠gi√∞ (The Match)", set in Reykjavik during the World Chess Championship between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky in summer 1972. Then, in 2012, another prequel story, "Reykjav√≠kurn√¶tur (Reykjav√≠k Nights)", appeared, this time featuring Erlendur himself as a young rooky traffic cop working the night shifts in Reykjav√≠k (and playing sleuthe during his time off) in the summer of 1974, on the run up to the national festival at √ûingvellir to celebrate the 1100th anniversary of the settlement of Iceland.  Sadly, we are still waiting for a publisher to take up the English language option for the first of these two prequel stories, but the second is now available as "Reykjav√≠k Nights", in an excellent translation by Victoria Cribb.In many ways, "Reykjav√≠k Nights" is Arnaldur Indri√∞ason's best book yet: his minimalist prose are here at their leanest and his own unique style of brutalist realism honed to perfection. The 1974 setting provides the author with an opportunity to present an aspect of Reykjav√≠k that English readers will not have encountered in his books before. The author paints a fascinating and highly evocative picture of a Reykjav√≠k that is pretty much long gone but whose shadows still linger in the city today, and of a nation just starting to be influenced by increased access to foreign travel, TV, etc. As ever, Erlendur represents the traditionalist all at sea in the rising tide of modernism -- and, also as usual, the face of human caring in a world increasingly enslaved by capitalism and commercialism.  Like many of the other stories in the 'Reykjavik Murder Mysteries' series, this book also points up how fragile life can be and how narrow the divide between success and disaster; how little needs to occur for a life to go wrong.The story unfolds slowly at first but is cleverly constructed, its direction never obvious nor its outcomes certain. There are also some clever ties into earlier (or later, depending on how you reckon these things) Erlendur stories  (especially "Jar City"), for those able to spot them.For me, this book feels to be a rewarding outgrowth from the earlier books; it does not appear to have been written in any way as an afterthought but very much delivers new insight into Erlendur's character and behaviours in the events that occur later in his life.
