I would not recommend the book to those who have yet to read the main series, because I think much of the beauty and many of the delights of this book rely on the reader having knowledge of events that occur and characters that appear in later times. This volume also potentially gives away some of the surprises of the other books; essentially, the book reads best as the tenth in the sequence (for English-language readers), not as the first.For those who have read the other Erlendur stories, this provides an excellent addition to the canon. Let's just hope that somebody soon sees sense and adds "The Match" to the collection too.

As the sequel to "Throne of Glass" by Sarah J. Maas, "Crown of Midnight" continues the story of Celaena Sardothien, erstwhile Assassin of Adarlen and now newly appointed King's Champion. The action picks up straight from the earlier volume, with the author assuming pretty much throughout that her readers will be familiar with the story so far.This second volume is a great improvement on the earlier one, having plenty of exciting action, as well as packing in lots some unexpected plot twists along the way. In addition, the earlier book's sorry lack of character development has been rectified, with much more believable and well-rounded portrayals of the principles as well as additional supporting members of the cast.The book is not without its silly moments and stolen ideas (plus the author remains pretty inept at inventing credible character names) but these flaws can be easily overlooked, because by and large the plot development is kept tight and free flowing. At heart, the story remains as much a romance as it does a fantasy romp but the mix is much better balanced than in the earlier tale. The author delivers here an altogether more mature story-telling style but one which should nevertheless appeal to its primary audience of late-teenage/young adult readers every bit as much. Certainly anyone who enjoyed the first volume will love this.The book nicely sets up the third part of Celaena's story, "Heir of Fire".

"Throne of Glass" is the much vaunted d√©but novel by Sarah J. Maas. The publishers make much of the fact that the story has had a ten-year gestation period since the author shared its first draft with the world on FictionPress.com.  It is disappointing, then, that for all its honing, the book still reads as though it was written not only for teenagers but also by one. For while the author may have matured her writing style and narrative structures to the point where these cannot really be faulted, the book still retains one glaring feature of story-telling immaturity: a complete absence of understanding of her purported core subject matter. For all that this book purports to be an action fantasy novel about a teenage assassin with a "heart of ice and will of steel", the sad fact is that it is actually a plodding courtly romance, featuring an undisciplined, blushing teenager, with a great interest in eating candy, wearing posh frocks, attending parties and staying up all night reading romantic stories than in actually achieving the freedom she supposedly aspires to above all else.Throughout the book, the author fails to demonstrate that she has the slightest understanding of what would be involved in becoming the sort of character that her heroine is supposed to be. The author's desire to invent a character with whom her target audience can identify means that she portrays a teenage bookworm, concerned first and foremost with how she is perceived by the young men she encounters who -- naturally -- has some kick-ass abilities which they cannot immediately see. In short, the book presents some romantic sanitised Disney notion of "assassin", rather than any realistic portrayal of what the word means and entails.Characterisations are also generally poor throughout the book, everyone being both two-dimensional and unconvincing, with the author endlessly resorting to stereotypes. In addition, many of the fundamental premises upon which the story rests are both contrived and naive: the notion that an elimination competition to establish a King's Champion should be strictly non-lethal in both formulation and operation is hard to accept, at best; the idea that the Captain of the Royal Guard of a household as violent and blood-thirsty as that of the house of Adarlan should himself be a complete stranger to killing, is little short of ludicrous.In summary, this book is really nothing more than a soppy teen romance placed within a setting of action fantasy, almost all elements of which are highly derivative and lacking in originality. I would not expect the book's younger target audience to be disappointed at this and for many this will be exactly what they require. Anyone seeking a fantasy adventure story for preference, however, risks disappointment and would do well to avoid this book.A sequel, "Crown of Midnight", is also available.

"My Soul To Take" is the second volume in Yrsa Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir's series of 'Th√≥ra Gudmundsd√≥ttir murder mysteries'. The original was first published in Icelandic as "S√©r grefur gr√∂f (Digging their own grave)" in 2006; this English translation, begun by Bernard Scudder and completed by Anna Yates, following the former's untimely death, appeared in 2009.Stylistically, the book is more consistent than its predecessor, "Last Rituals", offering a fairly standard who-dunnit murder mystery, with a nice touch of dark supernatural undercurrents to counterpoint the book's fluffy chick-lit overtones. The action for this volume is entirely within Iceland's western peninsula of Sn√¶fellsnes, although an entirely fictional one of the author's own invention -- at least one hopes that the vague resemblance of the book's setting to B√∫√∞ir, with its modern hotel and striking black church, is entirely coincidental -- with some interesting historical references thrown in for good measure.  Thora's family situation manages to impose itself less on the story than it did in the previous volume, although still features to some extent, so that those interested in the on-going soap opera can be kept up to date with developments.As with the earlier book, readers looking for anything of the minimalist ultra-realism of Iceland's other notable crime writer, Arnaldur Indri√∞ason ("Jar City" etc) will undoubtedly find this story overly fanciful and unrealistic. Anyone simply looking for an engaging (but fundamentally formulaic) murder mystery set in an unfamiliar and unusual setting will undoubtedly love it.

Jim Taihuttu's film "Wolf" is a  strange animal. Mostly dressed in the clothes of its forerunners, it tries to be the Netherlands' answer to "Raging Bull" (even being shot in B&W) but instead ends up as a mish-mash of derivative elements from just about every immigrant misfit/gangster/boxer movie ever made. Whilst individual performances are strong, with Marwen Kenzari's lead character (Majid) very convincing indeed, the hackneyed unfolding of events and the very predictability of Majid's downward spiral of self-destructiveness ultimately rob the film of much of its merit.  Even the monochrome production feels like a mis-judgement, somehow smoothing over the very grit that I suspect it was intended to enhance.The film is in a mix of languages, but principally Dutch with English subtitles, from which I could not help but think that a lot has gone missing in translation.Overall, this film is hard to recommend unless you are really stuck for something to watch and you enjoy the sight of people out of control.

I do wish that when American authors set their novels in Victorian London that they would undertake at least some basic research beforehand into the nature of Victorian British society -- its class strata, its undercurrents and its real life events --  rather than just assembling a collection of quirky period objects placed in historical settings, populated with stock Hollywood caricatures dressed in music-hall costumes, acting out the same time-honoured but entirely fictitious American version of what might have been.  Alex Grecian's so-called murder mystery, "The Yard", featuring Scotland Yard's "murder squad" (the CID never get a mention) in the immediate aftermath of the Whitehall ("Jack the Ripper") Murders should serve a classic warning to all as to why this territory should be declared off-limits to American authors until they have learnt to study their subject a little deeper.Alex Grecian gives every impression of having tried. He imbues his story with countless little extra details that no doubt took many hours of research to unearth. Sadly, every single one is wasted, because they are invariably either wrong, or else placed in such an incongruous setting as to indicate all too plainly that the author has no basic understanding whatsoever of how different Britain is from America.  And for each detail that he includes, he omits or gets wrong at least ten far more important ones alongside it.Yes, Colonel Sir Edward Bradford was indeed Commissioner of Police, was universally admired by the men who served under him and did much to improve both the organisation and conditions of work within the Metropolitan Police. Unfortunately, he did not receive this Commission until June 1890, more than a year after the date in which the author so meticulously positions his story. Ironically, by the time Sir Edward was in office, the Metropolitan Police had all but removed from Four Whitehall Place (Great Scotland Yard)  -- the setting for "The Yard" -- and were operating from their "New" Scotland Yard premises on Victoria Embankment. And while Alex Grecian goes to some length to explain to his readers how Sir Edward came to lose an arm tiger-hunting in India, and is at pains to remind us of this deficiency whenever Sir Edward appears in the book, he himself seems never to realise that such a loss would, by its every nature, prevent this character from "steepling" or "interlocking" his fingers, as he frequently is described as doing during exchanges with his detectives.As the very epitome of the English gentleman, there is also absolutely no way Sir Edward would ever utter phrases so entirely American in nature as "use the room in back" or "different than" -- a fault that similarly applies to almost all dialogue throughout the book. Much of the book's dialogue attempts to sound period but fails owing to a lack of appreciation by the author that the very subject matter under discussion would be incomprehensible to the Victorian mind; many of the concepts ("closure" for instance) are entirely contemporary in nature.  The narrative too is splattered with words that have little or no meaning within an English context; wherever there is an American alternative for an English word, it is used instead, so that we have panhandlers, rather than beggars, shears instead of scissors, nightstick for truncheon, barkeeps where we should have landlords, beat cops in preference to Bobbies, and mention of the first floor as an incorrect (in British usage) and therefore confusing reference to the ground floor, and so on.  Whilst some of this could be put down to an over-zealous editor worried that too many truly English words and phrases would render the book too difficult for an American audience (I do think editors do their readership a disservice at times), blame for the book's other fault of transplanting American modes of thinking and preferences into the British characters' actions and behaviours can lie only with the author. In doing this, he renders almost every character in the book anachronistic in everything they say and do, from the small details of supplying office colleagues with a breakfast of tarts (that would be bacon butties, surely?) to the larger ones of Bobbies feeling able (or being allowed) to freely mingling with Inspectors at all.  On top of this there sits an over-riding impression of ignorance on the part of the author of many basic everyday details (all so well known to a British readership) -- that British Bobbies of the period wore helmets, not hats; that they carried their truncheons in a special side pocket of their trousers, not looped onto their belt; that detectives did not routinely carry firearms (and that if they did they would not be Colt revolvers); that the social classes did not intermingle in any way and that strict protocols were in force to keep it that way -- which completely undermines any authority the book might be attempting to bring to anything it says.All of which is a great shame, because Alex Grecian's story actually has the makings of a classic ripping yarn of the "Boys' Own" ilk, with (largely) likeable characters doing "the decent thing" whilst pitted against some of the very dregs of humanity.  As a comic book story, told in words rather than pictures, "The Yard" is really excellent and if judged on those terms works very well indeed -- each chapter presenting a classic comic book panel, painstakingly illustrated in graphic detail and punchy dialogue, kept to the point.  As an historical novel this book is a complete disaster but as a comic book romp (albeit a wordy one) it makes an excellent penny dreadful!

"Hypothernia" is the sixth of Arnaldur Indriason's series of 'Reykjavik Murder Mysteries' to be translated into English. The original Icelandic novel, "Har√∞skafi" (whose meaning is unclear, but which might be rendered as 'Slim Pickings')", was published in 2007 as the eight book in the series. (For various reasons, the first two volumes have never been -- and are unlikely ever to be -- made available in translation.) This 2010 English rendition is by Victoria Cribb, and provides a characteristically idiomatic translation of the author's original sparse, almost minimalist Icelandic prose.This volume in the series has Inspector Erlendur well and truly off piste, as he whittles away relentlessly at a number of seemingly unrelated mysteries, none of which give any indication of having a crime behind them, with not only the reader but his own colleagues at Police Headquarters wondering just what he is up to throughout much of the book.  With Sigurdur √ìli and El√≠nborg barely making an appearance in this book, this is very much a story about Erlendur more than anything or anyone else -- it is a story centred on obsession as well as depression and melancholia. As the book progresses, Erlendur increasingly seems to be cutting himself off from events of the present and dwelling increasingly in happenings of the past, while the story generally lingers far more around matters spiritual and supernatural that one normally expects in this series.Unusually for books in this series, this volume features a glimpse of Iceland beyond the streets of Reykjavik and takes in a number of locations on the tourist map; as a consequence, those readers who have visited Iceland may more easily relate to the settings of this book than to some others in the series. Also unusually, the more Erlendur digs, the more of his mystery pieces start dropping into place together, making this by far the most interconnected and intriguing of Arnaldur's stories so far. In keeping with the book's all-pervading feel of gloom, however, the ending -- whilst well-delivered and fitting -- has of it something of gently understated tragedy. It also hints that in at least one regard, not all of the outcomes have yet been revealed and something weighty may be being saved for a future volume.For all of its doom and gloom, this book is gripping and engaging throughout. It makes for a cracking read, once you are used to Arnaldur's sometimes idiosyncratic prose style, with his plot construction maturing very nicely indeed here.  Although the book has few dependencies on preceding volumes in series, it is very hard to recommend this volume in isolation, as it makes much more sense taken as part of the series in which it sits.

Right from the opening, you just know that Michael Lander's 2010 American psychological thriller, "Peacock" isn't going to end well. The only question really is just how badly awry things are going to go before the conclusion, for the film's main protagonist, John Skillpa -- a quiet 20-something bank clerk living alone in tiny Peacock, Nebraska, and a sufferer from Dissociative Identity Disorder.  A short way into this film, I started to wonder also if the writers hadn't actually overdone the while DID thing, as the story-line itself starts to exhibit similar symptoms, with the film not really sure what it is, or where it is going.  With more twists than a Mandelbrot set and enough tension to keep you wound up for weeks afterwards, the film is a gripping yet perplexing watch.  In the final analysis, though, I think that ultimately this film is a brave and audacious attempt at something different, which just fails, in the end, to pull it off.  It's certainly worth a watch and many may love it; equally, though, I suspect that many will end up disappointed or just plain puzzled.Performances from the principals -- Ellen Page, Susan Sarandon and Cillian Murphy -- are exemplary, especially Murphy as John/Emma. The atmosphere created through the sets, the filming and the dialogue is simultaneously dated and yet contemporary, having a feeling of isolation and separation from time itself -- more discomforting dissociation for the audience to deal with. The screenplay has scenes that are charming, moving and funny, interlaced with those that are excruciatingly poignant and painful -- or just plain nail-biting. Ultimately, though, I found the film let down in the end by a storyline that gradually loses all believability as it progresses and as people's dealings with John and Emma being increasingly unrealistic, unobservant and, in some case, just plain irrational.  And, as for the ending...

"Weetabix Oaty Bars" are pretty much standard industrial confection flaunted by the manufacturers as "high fibre" and "low calorie" and thereby managing to masquerade as a healthy food choice, whilst actually providing rather more air and packaging material than you think you're paying for. There are two main reasons that each of these bars contains few calories: the first is that about one third of its weight is supplied by oligofructose syrup, a cheap, manufactured sweetener derived mostly from acacia gum or chicory, which, by virtue of being indigestible to humans contains almost no calories. Being digestible by the bacteria of the large intestine, though, gives it the added benefit of promoting the activity of beneficial microflora of the gut, thereby allowing the manufacturers to wave the "healthy" flag over the product. The second reason the bars contain few calories is that they are actually tiny and contain very little substance: each bar takes up less than two thirds of their hermetically sealed, gas-filled wrappers and weighs in at a paltry 23g in total. Most of the volume of each bar is actually air, cunningly concealed in a light, gooey matrix of puffed rice. With a total of only 7g of cereal to a bar, though, they hardly count as "high fibre" in absolute terms.This is not to say that Weetabix are any more dishonest than any other manufacturer in their presentation of these snacks: they are not.In the mouth, the bars do have a good firm texture and are nicely chewy but like most of these snacks, anyone used to actual healthy cereal bars will find that taste-wise they don't really stack up. By and large, they are all far too sweet and have a strong artificial and chemical-tasting flavour that persists as an after-taste long after the bar has gone.  My wife declared these "Strawberry Crusher" flavoured ones inedible, which for her makes them worse that Alpen's Alpen Light Chocolate and Orange Cereal Bars, which she merely decreed "disgusting". Personally, I preferred these but I won't be rushing to replace them once they're gone.As a light snack to make you think you've eaten something and therefore shouldn't have anything else, these bars may work to reduce snacking of the less healthy variety, as long as you like the taste. Under no circumstances should they be mistaken for an energy bar, despite their sweetness; they essentially provide no nutritional value whatsoever.

With "The Road to Reckoning", Robert Lautner has delivered a remarkable d√©but novel. Set in America, in 1837, it tells the story of 12-year-old Thomas Walker and his widower father, a former spectacles salesman, who determines to leave New York in the grip of depression and disease and -- young son in tow -- strike out West in the hope of making his fortune by acting as a sales agent for Samuel Colt's Patent Arms Manufacturing Company. Equipped with little more than a wooden replica of Colt's revolutionary fire-arm, the Paterson -- the world's first practical revolver -- and a handful of "samples", the pair set off on what Thomas views as the grandest of all possible adventures. Thomas' father, however, knows little about guns and even less about their handling and, it turns out, altogether too little about the reality of life outside the bounds of city civility. It is not long at all before the boy's big adventure turns into a nightmare and he finds himself orphaned and alone in the depths of the Pennsylvanian badlands and desperate to find his way home.The story is narrated in the first person but recounted from the perspective of Thomas in later life, at a time long after he has himself laid his own two teenage sons in the ground, front-line casualties of the American Civil War. The blend of child's and man's thinking in the narrative is a real gem -- the sagacity of age mixed with the matter-of-fact simplicity of expression and clarity of uncluttered thought is breathtaking in its effectiveness. In part, the book offers a poignant commentary on the American love affair with firearms and the role that the cheap, factory-produced revolving chamber handgun had to play in this -- as the author says: "[Colt's] invention would change the world forever but perhaps not for the better; as the saying goes: 'The Lord made men, but Sam Colt made them equal.'" In the book, Thomas declares "I, to this day, hold to only one truth: if a man chooses to carry a gun he will get shot. My father agreed to carry twelve."The author paints an evocative portrait of the social landscape of pioneer back-woods America in the first half of the nineteenth century. The book is also about becoming a man and what it means to be a father. Its principal success, though, lies in the masterful characterisation of Thomas and the former Indiana ranger, Henry Stands, whom he inveigles into becoming his guide, helper and protector. During the course of his time in the wilds, Thomas learns much about the many forms that villainy can take and that it often lurks in the places you least expect to find it.While the events and plot-lines here are hardly original, the voice behind the telling is so charming and convincing that this matters not in the slightest. Once the tale really gets going, it becomes all but impossible to put the book down. All in all, I have only one complaint of this book -- it is over and done far too soon -- it is fairly short and also makes for fast reading. But also, one doesn't really want to part company from the charming and endearing protagonist.The most surprising thing about the book, perhaps, is that it is written by a Brit; I doubt that anyone is going to notice.  Highly recommended.

The "NUK Multi Dry" is a cross between an intriguing piece of kitchen Lego and a 3-dimensional jigsaw puzzle. It ships as a flat pack of assorted plastic components (all proudly labelled as BPA-free) which you have to work out how to assemble into a strange blossom-like sculpture, and for which you then need to find both a home and a use.  The manufacturers intend you to hang feeding bottles and other baby-nursing paraphernalia from its various plastic petals and stamens to dry. Personally I think a standard draining rack serves the purpose just as well and makes more efficient use of one's draining board -- the large circular nature of this gadget means it needs a lot of room for not very much utilisation; it has space for about six small bottles or so.The construction looks sturdy and it is stable in use, provided your bottles and other accessories are either small or themselves made of plastic. Being dishwasher safe, it is also easy to keep spotlessly clean. All the same, I can't help feeling though that this gadget is very much a solution looking for a problem.But it does look cute and I bet it makes a great toddler toy!

"Ready Brek" is one of those things that immediately transports me back almost fifty years to early memories of standing in a chilly kitchen in a pre-dawn half-light, heating milk on the hob to pour into a bowl of this fine oaty powder to make an instant, warming breakfast before dashing out to catch the bus to school.  Oddly, I haven't touched the stuff since those early school years and have subsequently come to file it away mentally as one of those childhood foodstuffs that I'd simply grown out of.  Coming back to it now, I am surprised to find that, first of all, it is exactly as I remember it and, secondly, it remains just as acceptable to my adult palate as it was to that of my childhood (although these days I'd prefer it to have a little more texture).It is good to see that "Ready Brek"'s formulation doesn't seem to have changed at all over the intervening years and is still primarily finely rolled oats and oat flour. It is particularly heartening that the manufacturers have still not seen fit to sweeten it at all -- something that is rare, these days. In these times of microwave ovens, it is even easier to make than it was in days of yore (although the old fashioned way still works best, I think) and it takes no time or effort at all to prepare.  Most kids (and some adults) will probably need to add a little sugar (or jam) just to pep up the taste a bit -- many may find it too bland otherwise.My wife somehow managed to avoid "Ready Brek" altogether as a child and so this sampling was a first for her. As a dyed in the wool Scots porridge aficionado (made with water and salt, not any of this milk and sugar nonsense) she was not expecting to enjoy the experience. We were both surprised therefore when she gave her first bowlful the thumbs up. While "Ready Brek" may not be as solid and satisfying as a good bowl of proper oatmeal porridge, it is certainly comforting and remains a good start to a busy cold winter's day.

Natalie Young's second novel, "Season to Taste (or How to Eat Your Husband)", is a very strange book indeed. The title tells you pretty much all you need to know about its subject matter and, yes, it is every bit as grim and gruesome as it sounds. It is, however, surprisingly hard to turn away from, as the author alternately and repeatedly disgusts and then endears the reader to the protagonist, Lizzie, and her rather bizarre choice of a method of disposing of the body of the husband she casually bumps off one day.The narrative is cleverly constructed, although ultimately I felt it was its very cleverness that is its own undoing, because the story seems to my mind to have just a twist or two too many for its own good, leaving me thinking I'd missed something by the end. Beneath its macabre outer trappings, the book is essentially a tale of disappointment, disillusionment and liberation from life's little tyrannies. It is well written, the prose sparse yet human. Its main merit (in addition to a certain originality, which gives the author plenty of scope for exploring ground that has hardly been touched in literature before) is its brevity; most readers should be able to consume it all within a single sitting -- provided they can stomach the subject.  I'm not at all convinced it will leave many satisfied in the end, however.

"Last Rituals" is the English language release of "√ûri√∞ja t√°kni√∞ (The Third Symbol)" by Icelandic novelist, Yrsa Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir. This book marked the author's  crime novel d√©but, in 2005, with this English translation (by the late Bernard Scudder) dating from 2007.The book itself is an odd mix. It opens as an unusually gory, gruesome and altogether bizarre murder mystery, involving macabre mutilations, student drug-taking, black magic cults and Mediaeval witch trials. From there, though, it quickly morphs into something that is much more a routine sample of romantic, investigative chick-lit. The book's central protagonist is a middle aged lawyer and divorcee with two children, Th√≥ra Gudmundsd√≥ttir, who is hired by the family of the murder victim -- a German postgraduate student at the University of Iceland -- to investigate the truth of his death.  Although not an investigative lawyer herself, Th√≥ra is lured by the outrageously large (or, as she phrases it, "interesting") fee and soon finds herself accompanying handsome German ex-policeman, Matthew Reich, into investigations into the darker deeds of Iceland's ancient as well as the immediate past.The author has quite clearly done her homework when it comes to background research for the book, with extensive historical detail adding depth and richness to the telling of the story. Unfortunately, the book's main characters are portrayed so stereotypically and are so predictable in their behaviours that they descend almost to the level of caricature. Additionally, the novel's plot is so outrageously silly, that it is hard to take the book at all seriously. This somehow makes the gory bits more funny than horrific, which -- while it does make the book less harrowing to some extent -- left me at least with a distinct feeling of unease.If this were a book by an American or even British novelist, I would probably have few problems with it, for this is very much a classic whodunnit (and a moderately good one too), which is Icelandic in character only in as much as that it where it is set. The book features many of the sites that most foreign tourists to that land will visit at some stage during a visit. Th√≥ra's office is even located right in the heart of Reykjavik's tourist area on Sk√≥lav√∂r√∞ust√≠gur and her home in the same suburb of the city as the author herself, Seltjarnarnes. All of this somehow lends the story something of a forced and artificial feel, when it comes to location and settings.Many readers will no doubt read this book and value it for what is. For those readers more used to the ultra-realism of Iceland's other notable crime writer, Arnaldur Indri√∞ason ("Jar City" etc), this book may well seem tacky and superficial -- rather like the endless mounds of fluffy stuffed puffins, seals and 'hidden folk' that line the shelves in the shops of Iceland's tourist centres. And, all in all, something of a disappointment.

"Alpen Light" cereal bars are standard industrial confection flaunting a "high fibre" and "low calorie" label to enable them to masquerade as a healthy food choice, while selling the customer as much air and packaging material as possible. There are two main reasons that each of these bars contains few calories: the first is that about one third of its weight is supplied by oligofructose syrup, a cheap, manufactured sweetener derived mostly from acacia gum or chicory, which, by virtue of being indigestible to humans contains almost no calories. Being digestible by the bacteria of the large intestine, though, gives it the added benefit of promoting the activity of beneficial microflora of the gut, thereby allowing the manufacturers to wave the "healthy" flag over the product. The second reason the bars contain few calories is that they are actually tiny and contain very little substance: each bar takes up less than two thirds of their hermetically sealed, gas-filled wrappers and weighs in at a paltry 19g in total. Most of the volume of each bar is actually air, cunningly concealed in a light, gooey matrix of puffed rice. With a total of only 7g of cereal to a bar, though, they hardly count as "high fibre" in absolute terms.In the mouth, the bars do have a good firm texture and are nicely chewy but taste-wise they don't really stack up, being far too sweet and with an artificial and chemical tasting flavour.  My wife declared them disgusting. I didn't find them that bad, but I won't be rushing to replace them once they're gone.As a light snack to make you think you've eaten something and therefore shouldn't have anything else, these bars may work to reduce snacking of the less healthy variety, as long as you like the taste. Under no circumstances should they be mistaken for an energy bar, despite their sweetness; they essentially provide no nutritional value whatsoever.

My neighbor, bless his soul, being in his mid 70's and once a great scratch amateur golfer, will see this kind of thing and think it might bring back the old glory.  He bought one of these, and away we went.What I like about it:It looks very cool at address, and seems very intimidating.That's it...What I don't like:-I'd say if there was an FDA limit on how much titanium they had to put in a golf club to say "titanium", this probably would fail.  This is an aluminum driver, and sounds like a cheap soda can when you hit the ball.-The shaft is extremely flexible, apparently to help with whip and hit it further.  What it does is help you hit is offline better.-The face is one of those bowed out faces, to help with rebound no doubt, and possibly help keep from caving in this huge head.-By my tempo and speed radar, I swing this SLOWER than I do my Cleveland, Calloway, or Taylormade.  So obviously, I hit the ball shorter.-He hit it for a few balls, then I hit it for a few balls, and he decided to send it back.  He had all original packaging and the box, including the receipt.  They would not take it back since we had hit balls with it.What did we do with it?  I put it on eBay and sold it at a great loss.  Oh, and the headcover that came with it was showing a totally different driver that I had never heard of.  Didn't even get a SoooLong headcover.  Sheesh...

Since I didn't plan on having to move mine, I decided to buy the one with three umbrellas, and no carrying case.  So far, I have been pretty happy with them save for one annoying issue.What I like:They do light up an area nicely, and the lights seem to be of the right wavelength to get proper color in pictures.The gold umbrella will install a strong yellowish light, and it must be used correctly to shade, fill or color.  The other two work great and are pretty predictable.The lights come up to speed fairly quickly, like a couple minutes.  I take a lot of pictures for eBay, so I am taking pictures off a white clothed table with a white backdrop, and these eliminate shadows, etc.What I don't like:They are not that powerful.  I find that the umbrella units have to be fairly close to shoot with the lighting I like.The gold umbrella seems to be more powerful and reflect more than the other two, so the yellowish light can invade more strongly.  I keep mine off to the side to it kind of cross catches the white light of the white umbrellas and mixes.  It works out fine.One of the sockets was bad, or so I thought.  I am pretty handy, so I took it apart and found a switch that was erratic.  I don't have any of the issues with the sockets as some have said - but I came up with a bad switch.  So far, I have not found a suitable replacement and may just straight wire it so it comes on when I turn on my power switch, which I use to turn on all three.  If I want to slow down the lighting a bit, I can just unscrew a light bulb a bit.Overall, for this price?  Silly good for the amateur photographer and eBayers like myself.  And having three umbrellas, bulbs, long cords?  Quite a deal, actually.UPDATE, Aug, 2015. After using this unit for months, I finally determined that I did NOT have a bad socket, but a bulb with a loose connection inside.  I had already changed the bulbs around initially to try and find it, and the bad bulb ended up in the socket I thought was bad. I changed out the bulb, and all is well.

I was into sand blasting years back, with a Central Pneumatic benchtop unit.  The gloves finally gave up, and it leaked like a sieve, so finally I gave up.I wanted to get back in, but pricing was an issue.  Here, I can get back in for less than $200.What I like about this unit:It is a good home unit as far as size, stability, and capability.The window is glass, with a plexi film on the top, and a stick-on plastic film on the bottom to protect the glass.  Mine came with five extra stick-on films, so I was happy about that.  I don't understand the other viewers comment about stick-on film.  Why wouldn't you want something to protect the glass?The gun is fine. The hoses I will address below.It leaks, but only seems to leak about the window frame.  A little foam during installation, like that inexpensive window foam will take care of this.  The rest of the cabinet seems fine.I like their move to a plastic door.  The old metal doors they used to use were thin, often got bent up going back and forth, so this is an improvement.Love the shelf.  Great place to store spare nozzle tips, and other small items you may be using or even blasting.  It is in there for stability, but quickly becomes a nice shelf.What I don't like:-The gloves are cheap.  I expect to be replacing them within a year or so.-The light is strange.  I first thought it was an LED stick light, but it seems to be a low voltage fluorescent.  I don't like the transformer at the end of the cheap cord, and I usually unplug it rather than use the switch on the side, which by the way installs upside down, so off is up.  The light also flutters after a while, I think maybe due to the static?  I don't know, but some advocate replacing it with LED pucks.  I hesitate due to the battery issues with these. So far, I am doing OK with the provided light, but am thinking of changing it out for a good stick LED unit.-This is an absolute BEAR to assemble.  Think propane gas grill, times two.  I am a pretty good mechanic, and general fix-it guy, the one guy in my neighborhood people come to for tools, advice and help.  This took me a full six hours to assemble, fine tune, and get right.-The hoses - ohhh, the hoses...They are TOO soft and kink.  They pop off their fittings even with stainless steel worm clamps.  And the fittings are too smooth.  Just bite the bullet, go to a big box store, and buy that stiffer clear hose in the same diameter in the plumbing department and a couple of decent barbed hose fittings.  It is the air supply hose that is the biggest problem with staying on, and the bigger pickup hose kinks almost automatically.  I replaced both and I am very happy I did.  Cost about $10.  Made all the difference in the world.  With the originals, you are so busy trying to see through the cloud and watch your article you are blasting you don't realize the original hoses will crimp almost all the time, eliminating your air or ability to pick up media.Finally, beware of the door on the bottom.  I knew it would leak a little - I put a bucket below.  What I didn't realize was the speed it will tear itself out of your hand with only 6-8 lbs of media in the unit, and knock over your bucket and drop all your media on the floor.  And I added a copper washer to the clamp rod that holds the door to make it seal tighter so it won't leak.

When I first bought these and took a sleeve to the course, I was in the middle of a swing change.  I was trying to eliminate coming over the top too much, and was putting more of a baseball swing.  So I pulled the ball a lot.  Not hook, pull.True to form, this ball went straight - straight with the pull and into the woods.  I could actually see it straightening itself out as it headed for the lumber.  Oh well, at the price I paid, back in the bag for a while...Then I played them again last week, determined to use them with irons, fairway woods, and also my swing was now pretty much corrected and I don't pull anymore.  Here are the results:I hit a slight draw now, and by golly, the doggone thing actually took a bit of an S curve in air, straightening out.  I could not believe I was seeing a golf ball do this!My irons, when I align the ball on the fairway, goes straight, but check up?  Forget about it.  If I let the ball lie where it is, almost always somewhere off the alignment of the shallow dimples, it checks up rather nicely if I am hitting into a green.  My Rocketballz irons have a tendency to hit them with a little more loft, so checking up is not too hard, but now they just stop dead and back up about 6 inches.  Aligned, they will bounce forward about a foot or two.  Interesting.Obviously, when I am playing with someone new, or in any kind of league, I don't use them.  This is a recreational ball only for fun and enjoyment.  That includes most of the golfers out there these days, I believe.  I am semi-retired, and my weekday play with friends allows me to play these since we don't bet, or have mini-tournaments.  I also am teaching one neighbor, so when he is struggling I often pull one out and don't tell him, and my constant straight hits drive him crazy, but make him concentrate harder and try to do better.  Maybe I'm being cruel, but it's better than trying to correct his swing on the course.Either way, these do work.  For fun, great ball.  Just don't get caught in that weekday choose-up using one of these.  You'll probably get thrown out of the grouping.

Kia downplays the fact that you don't get a spare tire with your new Soul.I wanted it included in the original purchase, but in between all the haggling, it got lost in the shuffle and I forgot to get it added.My Kia Dealership was over thirty dollars more than here, so this was a no-brainer.Coming from the Kia Parts depot, it has complete instructions, and is original factory stock.  It even comes with the sticker for the driver's door that will instruct any owner, (you and any others years down the road), that there is a spare and what poundage to inflate it to.In with the spare and jack, and the little compressor and jug of fix-a-flat out!Mine came inflated to only 40 lbs. It pays to check - the instructions and the tire side clearly say to inflate to 60 PSI, which I did before putting it in the tire well.

Found these on sale at D**k's, before they were available here.  For a 24 pack, my wife and I thought they would be possibly another poor golf ball.For me, up until they built the Gamer, I was not much of a Top Flite fan.  It seems like they have transferred that knowledge and added even more into this ball.  We found a lively ball, feels very soft off the club, good distance, and sticks like glue on short approaches.What I like:Does not seem to lose the yardage due to being so soft like the Callaway Supersofts.Price is just crazy good.Decent distance, good rebound off your putter, and sticks nicely.We read about these before we bought, but thought that they would probably be another overhyped soft compression ball.  Boy, were we wrong.  We like them a lot.If you are a long hitter, these may not be for you.  Too soft...

As usual, we get ants in our kitchen area every couple of years.  Living in the South, it is a bit of a problem.We tried this product and were disappointed.  It says, "Kills the queen, kills the colony".Not so...We find that the ants are certainly attracted to this bait.  Unfortunately, they eat it and make it maybe 2-3 feet back and start to die.  Some stagger around some, but it appears that none of them make it back to the nest to feed the others.  So no matter where you put these baits, you end up with a mess of ants roaming around the baits, some half dead, a few dead, some still trying to go for more.  And since the colony is not affected, all you really end up with is an ant attractant.  I put them behind the stove, my stove edges ended up with lots of ants roaming around.  Under the fridge, same thing.  My wife made the mistake of putting these baits in a cupboard and within about 24 hours the lower shelf was covered with dead and slow ants.  What a mess.Other brands of this type of bait allows them to make it back to the nest where they feed off and slowly die.  Usually takes about three-four days.  Not this stuff.Not recommended.

Found this book in a used book store.  As a 44 year master woodworker, I don't remember this style of woodworking ever taking off in any measure.  Still, it seems like fun and is comparatively easy, albeit time consuming.  I don't think his statement of a gallery paying $2000 for a large rocker and child's rocker would hold water today, since style and technique have developed so much people expect much more.The book itself is rather cheap newsprint, with low quality black and white pictures.  Some imagination is needed in some cases.  Also, he did not have the availability of modern day power grinding tools, such as the King Arthur series, which would make a lot of what he uses obsolete.  But, with all that being said, sometimes things come in style again after a couple of decades, so I might try one or two of these and see.  I have done laminated plywood bowls on the lathe, and they usually sell rather fast, although not anywhere at the levels he describes.Maybe the time has come again for a little laminated plywood carved furniture.

Bought this unit after my Hamilton Beach carafe-less unit finally starting leaking internally, which I knew it would.After looking over all the offerings in reasonable price ranges, decided on this unit from Wa*-M^%t.It looks sleek, easy controls, variable brews, and I like that the carafe sits well inside the unit, without the handle sticking out.What I like:1. The coffee maker itself has variable brew.  Nice touch, although you will have to experiment a bit to see how much your grind compares with the "Normal", "Strong", "Gourmet", and "Bold" settings.  I tend to stick with Normal, and adjust the amount of coffee I put into it, rather than have to set this thing every time I start it.  Normal makes great coffee.2. Although I am not fond of the grill-like cover that you are supposed to pour your water through to fill the reservoir, simply lifting the complete lid reveals a larger area to pour your water into, and it is fine.  It also comes with one of those ball shaped filter units that you push in, which is a step up from the old HB I had, which had no provision for any water filter.  It is also cheaper than the Mr. Coffee ring filters, which seem like an after market way to keep sucking money out of your wallet.3. The unit keeps coffee HOT.  This is good, since I drink from large mug, and often I have cold coffee at the end of the mug, unless it is hot to start with.4.  Some lower cost carafes have an open handle on the bottom, with sharp edges of the plastic handle.  If you are one of those people who put your pinkie under the handle when you hold it, like me, this carafe is much better since it has a closed handle all the way down, nice and smooth.What I don't like:1.  There has been much discussion here about the carafe.  I have had many carafes in my lifetime, and mine doesn't leak or pour all over the place.  Maybe I am just used to pouring more conservatively, or maybe they changed the design a little.  What I don't like is the fact I cannot get it all out of the carafe due to an internal lip at the top of the carafe.  Dumbest thing I've seen in a while.  Can't get all the coffee out, and cannot get all the rinse water out, or the fresh water into the reservoir.  Awkward and useless to put the carafe in the receiving position when you know there is already an ounce or two of plain water in the carafe.2.  You have to push a button to get it to keep coffee warm past two hours, but only after one hour of it already being warm.  Who remembers that after an hour of the coffee being made, you have to stop by and hit the Warm button again?  They give you the three hour feature, you should be able to set this before you start making the coffee, not at some period when you've made the coffee, consumed your first cup, and off to other things.  "Oh, got to go and push the button so I can get another hour of warm coffee"...NOT.3.  I am not a real fan of the micro-filter permanent type of filters.  You always get some micro grinds in your coffee, which muddies up the brew.  So I use the disposable paper filters.  Unfortunately they don't fit that well in the receiver where you put your grounds.  The wall is too high, and the steaming water can wash your paper filter off the wall, allowing not only clean water to get through, it can cause some of the grounds to actually make it down, at least micro grounds.  I finally learned how to make it so the paper filter kind of stays in place, by carefully pushing it against the wall of the grounds holder, before I make the coffee.  An annoyance, but you can get around it.Overall, this is a pretty good bargain for the money.  You get a coffee maker that does what it is supposed to do, give you a great cup of coffee and not do it with a lot of hassle.  But with the carafe issues, from people spilling coffee to my complaint on it keeping liquid inside due to the silly lip, I knocked off a star. Also don't care for the high wall of the grounds holder.Otherwise, this is a good maker.One last thing:  It makes a lot of noise when finishing.  And it does not have a beeper to let you know it is finished.  Some people like a beeper, some to not.  I like one beep.

Found these in a Du*&%m's on sale.  Bought the whole set.  Seems like I end up buying a new set of wedges every year or two.The color drew me in.  It is rather stunning, to say the least.  You will love the color, or hate it.  It looks like someone took a blowtorch to a steel finish, and the end result is a rainbow sort of "Trusty Rusty" type of finish.  They also make a black chrome finish in this same model, but I went for the "blowtorch" look.What I like about them:1. The grooves are prominent on the club.  You can actually feel them scratching at your finger when you wipe it across the face.  Most other wedges seemed much smoother and less likely to make a ball check up.  And check up it does, when you hit it on the face.2. The face is nice and large, with a larger top area to help the amateur make sure they make contact with the ball.3. In addition to the grooves being larger, the face is sand blasted and is also grippy.  This is usual for a lot of wedges, but with this finish, more prominent here, to a small degree.  Surprisingly, the black chrome finished ones I looked at seemed to even be slightly more sanded, but I didn't like the finish and the clubhead is identical.4.  No silly final wedges.  This is a standard 56', 60', and 64' set, without that crazy 68' or 72' that Pinemeadow and others sometimes offer in their sets, which usually ends up in your basement or in your garage sale.5.  No grind on the back edge of the sole.  For some, this means no "two clubs in one", and may be put off by the lack of this feature.  But for the amateur, having the club stable even when opening the face some is helpful.  It is a lot of practice and hard to get used to that second ground surface.  And there are actually four types of this grind.  Mostly on off the shelf clubs, you see what is called an arc grind, where the center section of the back of the sole is ground so you have a second flat to open the club up and rest on.  Problem is, it is small and hard to maintain flat on the ground during the swing, so a lot of amateurs are better off without it.  I fit that category.What I don't like so far:1.  They don't offer a 52'.  To some, this exclusion prevents this from being a complete set.  On the other hand, if you have a pitching wedge in your normal iron set, you probably have a 52' already in your bag, or at least a 48', which you can open a little.  So these are really a short distance club set, where you might carry only two of them at a time, depending on the course you decide to play and the size of you normal iron set.2.  Remember the big grooves and sanded face I mentioned?  Well, the drawback to this is you cannot really pitch and run with these since you will check a little, no matter how much you hood these when you swing.  The face is going to initiate backspin,  as long as you get the ball on the face, and you can depend on at least some checking.  I found this out immediately in the store in their little chipping area, even before I got them out to play.  But I wanted my wedges to check the ball.  That is a common problem for amateurs, lack of checking.  If I pitch and run, I often go old school and use my eight iron.  Others want a bit of a flop and then a strong release, and these have a harder time doing that.3.  Grips are terrible.  Not as bad as some I've seen, like the cheap Texans, but still they must be replaced.  I use an oversize grip, so when I first got the set home, off they came and my usual Lamkin Oversized grips went on.4.  Finish will scratch and not last.  It even started coming off in the store as I tried out the 60'.  I think we all know this with cheap wedges - that the fancy finishes will go bye-bye.  But the face has stayed pretty well intact over time, so the ball flight is rather dependable over time.Overall, getting a complete set of 56', 60', and 64' for less than $75 is a great bargain, and that is what you get here.  Recommended.

Bought this for a 12 string I am building.  Here are my findings:What I like:The 12 individual "saddles" are actually six normal saddles, and then six L shaped brackets that act as the second set of saddles, riding along with the ability to move on their own, within the movement of the main saddle it rides on.  So you adjust the main saddle, and then adjust the L shaped saddle mounted on the side.There is plenty of movement in the saddles, and the up/down movement is generous also.The screws and gold finish seem to be top notch.  Sometimes on cheap bridges when you move a saddle with a string under tension, the up/down screws can scratch the chrome finish.  Not here.What I don't like:Six of the strings are through-back, and six are through-body.  Not a real problem, but the six that go through the body are not drilled in a row.  Your ferrules on the backside of your guitar will not be allowed to be drilled in a straight line, if you want to meet up with the holes in the bridge.  Looks funky on the backside of the guitar with three "pairs" of ferrules that are not in a straight line.The L shaped secondary saddles are not really saddles, but little L shaped brackets with oblong holes in the long length, with a screw that mounts on the main saddle it rides with.  Also, it is a tiny bit lower than the main saddle, so you have to tip the height screws just a tiny bit to get the strings level.I had the high G string slip down between the L bracket and the main saddle.  There is just a tiny bit of notch in the L shaped saddle, and since it is  hooked to the main saddle body it rides on with only one screw, it can move away just a bit, and my string slipped down in the space between the main G saddle and the L bracket G.Overall, this is a great way to individually adjust 12 strings for proper intonation.  The old style six saddle units with twin grooves in each saddle don't cut it in the intonation department.  But the thru-body holes not being drilled in a straight line, and the L brackets seem to be a bit of a cheap bit of engineering that could have been much better.

OK, I've owned mine now for about six months, and finally started to run low on the starter cartridges.  We have a typical home setup, with two laptops, a DSL router, and this printer.  I have been wired to this printer with my computer while my wife ran out of ink on her old Kodak printer, and we finally made the switch to where we both use this printer in Wi-Fi mode.What we like:1.  It turned out surprisingly easy to install the wireless function.  I just followed the directions in the quick guide, installed the suite on my wife's computer since it was already on mine, selected the wireless functions on the printer as in the guide, let all three units, (two laptops and the printer), find each other, and we have been good to go.2.  I got more pages out of the starter cartridges than I thought I would.  I bought the off-brand replacement cartridges here on Amazon that rate 4.8 stars as replacements, and so far, so good.3.  Although the picture resolution is not what some people may like, for us it is just as good as our old Kodaks, and we're happy.  It is a little harder to find picture paper that is compatible with laser printers.  Most is for inkjets.4.  The copy function works well.5.  So far, two sided printing has worked flawlessly.  I printed out a complete manual for a Nikon D5000 camera, (152 pages), and double sided all of it.  Worked perfectly.What we do not like:1.  Since we took it to wireless, sometimes it just comes on for no reason.  It doesn't print anything, but goes through some kind of process.  Lasts about one minute.  You can be in another room and think it is printing something.  Odd.2.  The paper tray is almost dead against the desktop.  When you go to put paper in this thing, pulling the drawer out will entail removing everything you might have in front, even a few pieces of paper.  So leave some space in front of the printer to allow for this.3.  The warning lights and commands to change out the toner cartridges come on way too soon.  We read the first review here on how to reset that little problem, and so far, it is working well.  Milks a lot more pages out of the cartridges.  Still, I know they want to make money on the ink, but sheesh! I reset the black about 2 weeks ago, and I am still using the same original black cartridge.4.  HUGE footprint for a home.  Takes up almost half of my desk.Overall, we are totally happy we made the jump to laser in the home.  We had one years ago, a black and white unit, and have suffered the inkjet blues for years since.  No more.  Like this unit just fine for home use and occasional material I have to print for my woodworking business.

This is a good lacquer.  BUT, it comes out of the nozzle a little too fast, too much.  Hard to coat a vertical surface without runs.  I use it as a secondary brand when it is on sale.  Not my primary lacquer due to the rush it provides when coating.Drying times are normal.

I've been using whole house humidifiers for years.  This one has been in my house for almost seven years.  With a complete end-of-year cleaning, and faithfully using the humidifier anti-bacterial/fungus, we have had trouble free service.1.  You have to change the filters every year.  The best thing is when you know you will end its use for the season, take out the filters and toss them immediately.  Do not let then fester in the unit.2. Take the base and outside, rinse it out with a hose.  Put in a little bleach and rinse again.  Let it air dry outside.3.  Make sure you take off all the caps on the bottles for storage.  We usually take them off, let them dry for a couple hours, (the seals, mainly), and than put them in a sealed plastic bag and toss them into the bottom so we don't lose them.  The bottles can be rinsed and let to air dry in the unit after draining.4. Unplug it for the summer.On restarting:1. Put in new filters, available here on Amazon.2. Make sure you have a fresh bottle of anti-bacterial/fungus. (Don't buy the flavored stuff, some of it does not keep the bacteria and fungus away.)3. Fill the bottles and add the chemicals, let them fill the bottom of the tank, not you.4. Set it as you see fit, (we use either 45% or 50%, lowest speed)5. Let it run and enjoy.Ours has performed wonderfully over the years, but for a while it was hard to find the filters.  Also, the filters are square, and the place where they ride is slightly curved and they are a little hard to get in.Overall, a great humidifier.

Fit and finish is what these are all about, the this is a five-star score.  Allowed me to put a used huge 72MM fisheye onto my Nikon D5000 without messing up the distance and clarity of shot.This is the kind of little accessory that allows people to do things with odd lenses, filters, wide angles, etc. from other cameras.  Becomes a fun hobby to see what you can hang off the front end of a lens and the resulting effect.And, if you have the lone filter from another camera, or that fisheye you found in a pawn shop that didn't quite fit, this is your savior.Would buy again in a heartbeat.Only gripe, this is a LOT of rings to have in your camera bag.  I bought a ten pocket pouch to hold them all.

Does what they say it will.I bought mine to hold a couple filters, but mostly reduction and enlaragement rings.  You can put about two rings in each pocket.My biggest gripe was the price.  Seems more like a $4-5 dollar item, but I needed the extra capacity, so I pay.Otherwise, it fits well in my camera bag, and does the job.Clear windows on each pocket that allows you to see each filter or ring when you unfold it.

You would think that with three P90's this would be a screamer.  Not so.  It is more of a darker rockabilly, and even plays better blues and jazz.Fit and finish is excellent at this price point.The neck plays well, and is not too thick around the back like some others.It is a bit big bodied for me, so make sure you are looking for a full, deep-bodied guitar.Sustain is so-so, probably due to the thick paint coating on the body.Nicely appointed with the trapeze bridge.Overall, a pretty good offering from Dean.I keep mine strung with flatwounds, and play mostly blues riffs on it.  The slightly darker sounds are enhanced with the flatwounds, and it produces a unique sound for not too much money.

Our adopted Shitzu from a no kill shelter had a rough first year, and loves to play hard.  He especially loves play biting your hands, which gets very tiring.  My wife bought a bottle of this and sprayed her hands.It does make the dog go nuts, and he tries to wipe his face on the couch, pillow, anything.  But he thinks we are playing, and comes back for more and more until he is licking it off my wife's hands.Basically worthless for us...

Many of the earlier Danelectro units came with the infamous rosewood saddle bridge, which basically cannot be intonated.  It does better with a wound 3rd string, but for standard 10-46 strings, the rosewood saddle doesn't work very well.This bridge takes care of that problem, while still keeping that Danelectro mojo.I'm also glad this one comes with the mounting screws.It is also less money here than at other dealers, with free shipping.

I found one of those silly very long 500MM lens made by Opteka, Bower and others online for about $15.  It also had a 2X multiplier.  It came with a Minolta AF adapter.Minolta Maxxum series cameras will NOT work unless there is some way to send the aperture reading to the camera from the lens - so it would not work on any of my Minolta Maxxum AF cameras.But...I also own Minolta X-370 and Minolta X-1 cameras, so I bought this MD adapter, and boy-oh-boy, can I zoom like crazy now!  Manual focus, since there is not connection from the lens to the camera save this adapter, but it works like magic and lets me put on an otherwise worthless lens!

I was in my local Dicks, trying out new 3 and 5 woods.  Has been a constant struggle to find decent fairway woods.  I am older and my swing speed is now down in the high 80's, sometimes in the low 90's.I was trying out the Nike Convert adjustable 3 wood and the Callaway Razr X 3 wood.  Both were OK, but not much more than what I have been getting out of an older Adams Tight Lies.Then the guy at Dicks put this in my hands.  Although it was more money, I immediately hit it not only 12-15 yards more on the same simulator, I found myself hitting it straighter.I asked him why he thought I was hitting this further.He explained that the Taylor Made people put Senior Shafts on these, called M shafts.  He had been paying attention to my swing speed on the simulator, not my distance.  Callaway and Nike apparently do not put anything more flexible than Regular shafts on their fairway woods.  After my wife came up and looked things over, the price and the results on the simulator, we popped for both the 3 and 5, both in Senior shafts.  I had to special order the 5, Dicks does not carry a Senior M shaft 5 wood in the stores.My first round, I had my first chance to use this three wood after hitting a poor drive on a 350 yard par four.  I had 185 left, according to my Bushnell.  Out came this new 3 wood.  I tried to take my smoothest swing, and hit a screaming drive, very slight fade no more than green wide, and it bounced up onto the green, landing about four feet from the pin.  Never in my life...I birdied the hole, and this club and also my newly arrived 5 wood are now securely in my bag.Thanks to Taylor Made to recognize those folks who swing slower.  Like Cleveland with that 270 Classic Driver with the very flexible senior shaft, this club is made for hitters like me.

I wanted a Bushnell range with Jolt for quite a while.  Got into my local Golfsmith to just lay hands on one, and they also had this model.  I found this slightly bigger model with a larger reticle to not only be easier to use, the bright red lettering inside is MUCH easier to read. The price was also right, at a slim $329.  I also loved the horizontal arrangement rather then the vertical, like the V3. I popped right there.I bought the unit and came home to read reviews about recalls and failures which Golfsmith did not talk about.  I registered the product, and immediately contacted Bushnell Support at 1-800-423-3537 to see if I had just bought a lemon.I was told that these units did go through a recall about two years ago, but mine, although built about 24 months ago, should be fine and not in the problem area.  THIS IS WHAT THEY TOLD ME ON THE PHONE. We'll see...Other than that, I love the unit and cannot wait to get on the course with it.  Knocked off a star since it is a little larger, just a tiny bit too big to put into my pocket.  Other than that, it measured exact with two other Bushnell models in the store, measuring distance to signs and trees outside the store.  And the bright red readout, WAY better than the dark blue on the V3.UPDATE: MORE RESEARCH... Even though I was assured by Bushnell support on August 5th, 2014 that this unit will be fine, reading many Internet reports I have come to believe that this unit had a fatal processor error.  You may never see it, but if you buy one, it is best to buy it at a brick and mortar store, keep your receipt and box and all paperwork, and apparently at this time it is totally discontinued.  Bushnell is selling off old stock.  Looking closely at mine, it had a March 2012 manufacture date, and some very small scuffs like it was maybe used before.  I wonder if I simply got a repaired one?  No one knows of any official recall, just many, many repairs and replacements plus some speculation that the main processors may have had some bad lots that they just pushed through manufacture.  If yours does fail, Bushnell will replace it most likely with a V3 Jolt model, and a fair gift certificate to a major golf chain.  I plan on using mine a lot, and if it fails, I will simply call Bushnell and cash in. It seems that if they fail, 90% of the failures happen within a few months, well within the warranty period.  Glad I got the two year warranty, and mine is registered.  Great unit...hope it holds up.  One star removed.UPDATE #2:  First round confirmed what I like about this unit.  The horizontal orientation is way better than the vertical.  I could use two hands easily to zero in on flags.  For some reason, my local club uses different colored flags, some even dark blue.  This unit found them easily, even with a forest very close to the back of the green.  Bright red readout is exactly what I wanted. Fanny pack bag us useless.  I kept mine in the lined pocket reserved for keys and such in my bag.  So far, so good...

Love the glove, fits me well.  But I have a slightly larger than average hand.  Is this truly a "one-size fits all" glove?  Not on your life.  But, it does have a couple things going for it that I really liked:1.  It has a double layer around the fleshy part of your palm where a lot of gloves wear out first.  Love that.2.  It is made of a synthetic material that is obviously more durable than leather.  I know, purists will balk at the fact this is not leather and that deerskin feel, but this stuff is downright tacky and I like that.3. They come in cool, off-beat colors.  For some strange reason, I was attracted to the green.Couple of things that are gimmicks or just silly:1.  One size fits all is not a reality.  Bring me an NFL lineman and let's see if he can put on my Zero Friction glove...2. The first thing I removed is that silly tee in the tee holder.  There are some places you just don't put pointy tees, and the back of my hand is one of those places.3.  The color choices may turn off some traditional people who think all gloves should be white.  Personally, I like the choices and may go back for some other colors, just to change it up a little, round to round.UPDATE: 8/17/14 I have since gone back and purchased another green glove and one orange one.  They are really a nice glove, and work well.  I am also happy to see that somehow, these breath much better than my usual Footjoy or Callaway gloves, which almost always come off sweaty and wet here in the South.  Not these.

They are not the best ball I've ever played, nor are they the softest.  They do, however, produce a predictable distance.  In other words, once you dial them in, ball to ball they are pretty consistent and you know how far they will go.  Some of the slightly softer balls are a little more variable.I find them easy to putt.  They are great around the green, and stick well.  They reach a normal height in drives.  Very predictable, good for players who know how to hit and are in the mid handicap and below range.

My wife had me buy this, after we found it hard to find in local stores.  She swears by it. I know it is listed for men, but my wife loves it and although she has tried many other hair products to increase volume, this is the one.

This brace is NOT a cure-all.  What it does do is support your knee joints by latching onto your leg above and below the knee cap area.  I'm certainly no doctor, but I've been wearing this for a few days now, and from my perspective, it reduces stress and pain by about 60-70%.  The way my joints have deteriorated, I have very little cartilage left, based on a recent visit to my doctor and subsequent X-rays.  But still enough to not operate.  I am on Celebrex, which helped.  The problems were: Golf, which I love, and stores shopping, on flat concrete.  For some reason I would be in massive pain after about one hour on hard concrete.Not now.  This supports the knee and keeps the joint supported with less stress, hence less pain.Highly recommended, as long as you make certain to measure your size correctly.  This unit measures around the knee cap.

This club is sold as Affinity, Olimar, and Intech.  All the same club.  I found mine in a Dunham's on sale for $19.95. There was a big hole in the club rack where these sale clubs were, I bought the last one.At the range, I was pleasantly surprised to find, (maybe not so much, considering what I paid for my Callaway Razr X Black), that I hit this consistently about 10 yards further than my Callaway.  Every time.  I am older, and a 200-210 yard drive is OK for me.  This was consistently in the 220 yard range.It is also about 10 grams lighter than the Callaway, on my wife's digital food scale set to grams.  I believe that transfers into a slightly higher swing speed.The shaft is an EMC Uniflex/Low Torque/High Trajectory Kick Point.  That means that it should be better for beginners and seniors.  By the way, the EMC was the standard shaft used on the Callaway Diablo driver, now almost two years old but still available for about twice the price of this driver.As long as you can take the jokes and comments from your buddies on your "knock-off" driver, you can simply let the ball do the talking and this driver will deliver.  Quite a club for the money.  Lastly, the grip was not bad.  No need to change it out.

Is it a Shitzu?  Well, sort of...What you get is a really hairy dog cover that somewhat looks like a Shitzu.  Our Shitzu looks nothing like this.  I own other Daphne's headcovers, and have been pleased.  NOT so with this one.  We'll use it, but it took combing and a bit of a struggle just to find the eyes.  Dissapointed, considering the price.

Already had the Rocky The Squirrel headcover, which I bought on sale at Dicks.  This was the perfect match.  It did not disappoint.  Looks great, sturdy, and should last a long time.  Fits my oversized Cleveland Classic Driver well.  Glad I bought it.

These arrive in a USPS Priority Mail box, 10" X 7 3/8" X 5" prepaid box.  The box is stuffed full of tees, no other packaging.  Is there 1000?  I would assume they are tare weighted into a box.  A quick count by me of the first 100 leads me to believe there might be way more than 1000 in the box.  But who cares, this is a huge amount of tees.These tees seem to be better assembled, head to shaft than the Insignia Eco tees, which tend to lose their heads when you tee off.  The JP Lann tees seem to be glued on, and they stay on unless you snap the shaft.They come in a strong red head with natural shaft, or natural head with strong red colored shaft.  My wife and I both love them, and the 2 3/4" is fine for us, since I tee it just a little into the ground to handle my Cleveland Classic, and my wife tees it a little lower for her Affinity driver.This is a GREAT bargain, and I would definitely buy them again.  But I think I will have to be about 93 years old before I wear out all these..

They look nice, they are nicely made, but you WILL snap the head off one every time you tee up. The heads are simply pressed onto the stem.  You are left with the stem with a little wooden pin sticking out of it.Looks very cool with the two-tone color, but think on leaving it at the tee-box every time you tee one up.  On the other side, they might be stronger, since I've not cracked one stem.  Doesn't matter, the heads come off every time.

Here's how the compression ratings work:The USGA has determined that a ball can deflect from round no more then 2/10ths of one inch when struck by a consistent speed driver, that speed being standard to the USGA.  Then they divide that 2/10ths of an inch into 200, so the deflection is measured by high speed camera in the thousandths of an inch, and they get a 0 to 200 scale.To make it interesting, they reversed the numbers so, if it deflects the whole 2/10ths of an inch, the rating is zero, for zero compression which is actually full compression.  If it does not deflect at all, the rating is 200.  Just for the record, there are no 200 rated balls on the market.  That would be a rock.So when Wilson Staff says this is a zero compression ball, that only means it deflects a total 2/10ths of one inch when hit by the driver speed as dictated by the USGA.What does that mean for the average player?  Larger rebound, and a little more distance on slower swing speeds.  It also should stick better when it first strikes the ground on a long iron into a green.This is a win-win ball for amateurs, and the price is just outstanding to boot.  I use them, and I like them.

My father put a golf club into my hands at age 7. I was a scratch golfer much of my 20's and early 30's. At 63, I still play a fair game. I am also an industrial manufacturing engineer of 28 years. I believe this club to be almost everything a golf club SHOULD NOT be.1. When golf club head speeds began to climb with the invention of metal woods, the bottom was slightly rounded to ensure the club would hit minimum grass. This club is reversed, so the bottom is almost flat, exactly opposite of what it should be. Touch grass, slow down.2. When a golfer swings, the shaft flexes. It has to happen since the rebound of the flex is what generates much of the club head speed. The non-round shaft of this club will also flex, but I believe it will also twist, which is what shaft manufacturers hate. Twist is when the flexing shaft also twists off center, putting the club head at the wrong angle mid-swing. That is why virtually every shaft is round, so the twist can come back in time with the flex. (Cheaply made round shafts may not.) This shaft stands a greater chance of not doing that, since it is not round and will tend to follow the flattened pattern. End result? Club head has a greater chance to be at the wrong angle at impact.3. The sweet spot of this club is small, and centered. For a pro, that's OK. For an amatuer, that is not so good. Off center hits on 460CC traditional drivers can be fairly forgiving with a decent grip. Not so when there is no sweet spot at the toe or heel. Hit it in the middle or mis-hit. I own classic clubs made in the 50's with bigger sweet spots.4. As clubs developed, the larger drivers became more aerodynamic with trailing edges meant to allow the air to flow past easily, since the club face had grown. With this club, the air WILL swirl around the open back edges and cause a turbulance that will most likely slow down head speed, certainly cause minute strange flex and twist in the shaft, and increase the chance of a mis-hit.Overall, you have to ask yourself one simple question. Why is literally no professional on any tour carrying one, just one, in their bags? You would think this company could come up with at least one...even Scott Verplank carried club COMPONENTS for a while, clubs you made with club parts companies. I've never, ever seen a Hammer X on any tour, in any tournament, and I never expect to. I'm sure they have approached a few new, non-sponsored pros, and offered them free drivers. No takers? Wonder why? Because it is illegal, but not because it hits further.  It does not conform to the 460CC rule, and the shaft is not round.

I considered a number of parallel bibles, but this one stood out for me.First, to the phrase, when you turn a page, all versions keep up and there is no going backwards and forwards trying to study a single phrase in context with other versions.Secondly, it is not huge print, but slightly larger and easier to read font, which I like.It is not a red letter version, so you have to know when Jesus was quoted in the more modern versions here.Don't let the word Evangelical put you off - this is a great Bible, one that can really make a difference for you in a study class.For this price, it is a keepsake Bible.

Although these compete with a lot of wedges in this category, (Texas Classics, Wilson Harmonized, Pinemeadow, etc.), they hold their own, look good, decent grooves, and got just a hair of sole grind which is nice.  Slight heavy feel to help you get through the cabbage which I like.  Overall, a great traditional wedge with no gimmicks for the money.Only gripe, as usual they come with a dirt cheap grip.  Tore them off and put on my usual Oversized Lamkins.  Now, I got a set of nice wedges!

Bought this to try and find a decent sharpener for my drawing pencils, especially my softer charcoal pencils.What I like:The push-button fit and face pullback, which seems to hold the pencil well and stops moving once the pencil has a sharp edge.
