You put the pencil in gently, press on the button on the side while holding the sharpener face, and pull it open a bit to allow the spring mechanism to grab the pencil, then pull the pencil in while it is being sharpened and you turn the handle.Once everything is adjusted well, it gives you a nice, neat sharp point every time.What I don't like:The Blunt to Pointy adjustment on the back is a hit or miss operation until you get what you want.  Once you get a good tip on your pencil, don't move it.The clamp for the tabletop is not too hot.  Mine has come off a couple of times.  And there is no way to clamp it so the sharpener faces outward from the tabletop, only inward.Since it only faces inward to your desk top, you are forced also to take the shaving cup off onto your desk.Would I buy this again?  Probably not, mainly due to the clamp issue. For decades I was used to sticking a pencil into a sharpener that faced outward of my work surface.  It is a pain to have it facing inward. I like how it sharpens, but in the end it takes up valuable real estate since I have to keep the area in front of clear to make room for a pencil.The fact that it is all plastic, although the actual sharpening mechanism is metal.

I found this exact midsized set, (slightly oversized) at another dealer.  It comes with 13 grips and a putter grip, and tape.  The grips are very sticky, as you expect Tacki-Mac grips to be.  At less than $3.00 a grip, you would be very hard pressed to find as good a grip at this price level.  Tacki-Mac has been around for decades, they know how to make a grip.Is it a top-of-the-line grip?  No, but unless you are playing tournament golf, you probably will be super happy with these grips.  And if you are paying $8 to $10 a grip, you might just want to look into these.  They last just as long.  Very hard to beat this value.

Being a morning player at a local muni, I was interested in hitting these.  I had used the Noodle Ice balls with similar covers and lost one in the morning fairway with that "ice" cover looking just like dew.  I knew where it landed, just could not find it.Same thing with these.  Colors are not bright enough, and after losing two on the fairways after just four holes, I put them away and got out some Callaways.  Never lost another ball the entire round.They hit just OK.  I played Nitros years ago, but for the money, there are much better balls out there now, such as the Callaway Hex Warbird, usually the same money as these.

The Top Flite Gamer three piece ball plays to rave reviews for distance and softness.  This two-piece version has the exact same double dimple pattern as the Gamer, but having one core, not two, you have to sacrifice something.  In this case, the ball is not quite as long as the Gamer, but the feel is the same, especially with the double dimple pattern helping around the green.  And it is less money than the Gamer at most stores.  For slow speed swingers, this is a real find in a 15 ball pack.

This ball is a two-piece version of the Top Flite Gamer, which plays to rave reviews for distance, feel and soft compression.  This ball will not have the same length as the three piece since the center core, (the second piece), is trying to do both feel and distance.  With that, it has the identical double dimple pattern as the Gamer, which goes a long ways in the feel and straightness department.  I like the ball, it plays well, and although not quite as long as a Gamer, is a real bargain at some stores.

First saw these years ago for much more money.  We own two we bought at a local Home store on discount, and they make nice night lamps.  They put off a wonderful orange/pink glow.  As far as health benefits with the "negative ion" thingy?  About the same as golfers wearing copper bracelets. Total hogwash.  It is, however, a well made, beautiful decorative piece, just don't think you will be healthier.

Bought this as an IDENTICAL unit from Academy under a different name.  Also cheaper from Academy...Pros:This puts out a huge amount of heat, around 58,000BTU's at full power.The pan and basket are somewhat thin aluminum, but campstove OK, and the handles are not bad.The base is wide, and very stable.Cons:The cheap cast burner is hard to get adjusted so it is not putting out blackened smoke with yellow flame. Only at full blast, usually too much heat, does the flame get the proper color.As soon as you open the package, throw away the thermometer, just toss it in the trash. Go buy a good one. (You might want to save the handy basket clip). I almost set peanut oil on fire with this thing. It said 325', threw in the fries, and the shaking of the fries made it jump to the relatively accurate temp, which was a little over 400'. Obviously in about 90 seconds I had burnt fries which were still raw in the middle.The regulator has most of the adjustment in the first 1/8th or 1/4 turn of the red dial. Just be aware that this will go hot very quickly.At this price point, you might think igniter.  You would be wrong.  Don't hold a match close to the burner when turning it on unless you want your hand burned. Either use a handheld butane lighter, or throw a lit match on top of the burner and then turn on the gas.Overall, for what I paid at Academy, I got what I thought I might get, a low end fryer for occasional use.  I paid about half what is asked here.

I bought the visor clip and marker set only.The magnet is not strong enough to hold the marker safely on your visor.  I know I will lose this, it just falls off when you take your hat off.Visor clip unit NOT recommended

Found these locally and decided to try out a dozen since I've had fairly good results with other Noodles.  I am a 14-16 handicap on a local muni, 64 years old, lifelong golfer.Pros:  The nice red colored letters make your ball stand out among the others on the green.Cons:  These balls amplify your mishits so badly, I put them back into the bag after losing two in the woods and water on the first four holes of a recent round.  Lost no further balls, after going back to my Nikes.  I'm sure some guy at Taylor will say, "Hey, this is the same ball as other Noodles!"  Maybe it was the red painted letters, who knows.  All I know is I usually don't lose many balls at all.  These went everywhere but straight.What good is a long ball if it amplifies your mistakes?  As Harvey Penick once said, "The woods are full of long drivers".  They must be using these.

Qualifications:  I am a lifelong golfer who is now 64, arthritic, bad knees, and my hand strength is maybe 65-70% of what it once was.  Been using 1/16" oversized Tacki-Mac grips for years.  My distance has dropped from 250 yards ten years ago to maybe 210 on a decent day.  Needless to say, this puts a heavy pressure on my second shots, which have been my downfall.I found a set of Maltby Glider X irons in a used club shop with these grips on them.  Got the clubs for a dollar apiece.  No big deal, but the grips were the most comfortable I have ever used with this 1/8" over.  It felt like I could now really "hold the club like a live bird", as Harvey Penick used to say.I played the Maltbys on a recent round, and found that they were easier to hit with these grips, unlike other heavy cavity back irons I sometimes use.(Older Bridgestone Precept Power Packs)  I hit it straighter, longer, and for the first time in years, hit a 4 iron a few times almost 200 yards and never felt the ball leave the face.I will be putting these on my hybrid irons I recently got.  I feel that the slightly heavier weight of the grip, along with the slightly heavier hybrid head should help balance the club and allow me to hit a little longer, straighter, and have more enjoyable rounds.  I am currently about a 14-16 handicap on a smaller muni, (6000 yards).UPDATE:  Added these to my Powerbilt EX-200 hybrid set of irons.  Fabulous addition for seniors and those with large hands or weak grip pressure.  Now my hybrid set plays even better.  And I do NOT suffer that old adage that bigger grips will amplify left and right hits. Wonderful grip for the money.

I believe this heater is identical inside to the same brand unit sold by Lowes, a Dyna Glo 23,000 BTU unit.  The Lowe's unit is black, this is painted white, but the engine would be identical.I've run kerosene heaters since the early 80's, and there IS a difference in how they run, smell, efficienty, etc.This unit is about at the top of the list for all of the above.The reasons are basically twofold.  The distance between the wick lifting mechanism, and the center stack that holds the wick to the lifting mechanisn.  If there is more room than needed, the wick can flutter and gain more oxygen, causing an uneven burn and shorten the lifespan of the wick.  It also smells more.  When the space is more precise, just enough for the wick, it only burns on the top of the wick, and the burn is much more controlled and stable, clean burningThis problem can also be caused by a poor, thin wick.  Any system will run poorly with a thin, cheap wick.  They all wick up the kerosene, but the cheaper wicks also allow too much air to invade places below the burn line, a bad situation that often causes carbon buildup, poor burn, irregular burn, and a hard to control flame.  The Dyna-Glo people seem to have this down pat.You SHOULD get a fairly even flame all around the flame deflector, and it should extend no more than 1/2-5/8" above the flame deflector.So how do you know, going in when you've never bought one???You read reviews...If there are a lot of people satisfied with the flame, satisfied with the low smell level, satisfied with the run time, (poor spacing and poor wicks often burn faster than intended), you probably will be getting a good unit.This unit is in that class.I found mine in a pawn shop.  I had no intention on buying another.  I already have one very good one, and one of a dubious brand that I pulled out of a W--Mart that turned out to be not so good, but I use it in my woodshop, which has a lot of leaks to the outside air, like a really leaky garage door.  I bought this one as a third backup, and ended up using it as a primary in my house.  Clean, long burning, and I am totally satisfied as a person who has burnt kerosene for 30 years, on and off.It burns over 8 hours on a tank full, burns evenly, and the wick takes forever before it starts to get the carbon spots on top.  In other words, it is a great kerosene heater and I love it. Dyna-Glo is almost as good as the now defunct KeroSun heaters, (some old-timers in kerosene may remember), which were some of the best produced.I thought some others were OK, but Dyna-Glo is a much better, dependable heater you will not be sorry you bought.If you read the manual, pay attention to the 1-K kerosene you buy, (buy from a reputable source, not that no-name gas station down the street), you will be happy and warm.  Remember this is NOT a heater you should turn on and fall asleep for the night.  If you do intend to burn it overnight, be prepared to have one eye open all night.  Not that it is unsafe, but it is an open flame in your house.  I will burn mine overnight in really cold situations, (I have just a heatpump) but I don't get much sleep those nights as I keep getting up to check it.  It is always OK, but careful is how you stay out of the news.I also have forced air heat, and keep the circulation fan running to circulate the heat, and induce a little outside air, plus whatever the heatpump throws into the mix.  If I had heat that was stagnate, like radiators or baseboard, I would never run one of these without cracking at least one or two windows one inch.  You need to move some air.But as far as this type of heat is concerned, Dyna-Glo is a great product.

I recently had a snap cold spell in my home in the South.  I had not burned kerosene in my house for years, only using kerosene successfully in my woodshop.  A recent cold spell had me scurrying for another heater, and I found this one.What it does well:1.  It puts out a HUGE amount of heat.  Most people with 2000-2500 sq. ft. homes will be amazed at the amount of heat, and how it will move that heat around the house.2.  If you have forced air heat, this is a wonder.  By turning on just the air, you might be able to heat your house with only the fan.  In severe situations, (say below 30'), if you have a heatpump you will be able to let it run and this will make a wonderful addition that will cause the heatpump to cycle on and off with this on. (Avoiding the dreaded aux electric heaters and saving a lot of money)3.  Smell is minimal if you learn how to adjust the wick.  Mine came with the wick installed a bit high.  I could not get the needed 3/4" non-soot flame even at the minimal setting.  A simple take-apart and slight haircut of the wick, (about 1/8") was all I needed to get it so it would run in the proper zone as described in the manual.  You have to have a bit of understanding of these units, but the technology has not changed in over 25 years.  They just work...4.  It runs for hours and hours without running out of fuel.What is does poorly:1.  Mine triggers my up-to-date First Alert smoke alarm, even though I see no smoke, and detect no real smell. I can burn bacon to a crisp and cause a smoke cloud and my FA will not trigger - why my kerosene heater triggers it is beyond me.  It is not a CO2 alarm, so I just don't know.  I have a secondary CO2/Fire alarm by another company that does not go off, so I just disable the FA only.2.  It is rather hard to make it put out less than the whole 23,000BTU.  You will find this hard to run at say, 40'.  Better to let it set until you really need it, when your heatpump or other furnace is running hard.3.  It really likes CLEAN 1-K kerosene.  Make sure what you buy is good stuff.  I use a local supplier in my town, and only one.  Some others pawn off slightly cleaned diesel fuel as 1-K, not good.  If it looks like clear water going into your tank, you are probably OK. (Also not much smell on the raw fuel.)Overall, this is a pretty good heater.  Not as good as the old Kerosun heaters I used to have, but they are out of business.  You could do a lot worse.  For $130, this is a bargain in heat.

What is good:-Slow speed does not burn the beans.  You don't realize how much you burn them until you use one of these.-Consistent grind.  Unlike the faster blade and flat burr grinders, this does not make mush out of the beans, mixed in with your grind.  This produces a consistent grind.-Upper grinder removes so you can brush the remaining grind down the chute.  Not perfect, but close enough.-Unlike others, I did see just a tiny bit of static, but I keep my house at 45-50% humidity, and oddly, this problem seems to be somewhat bean specific.  Beans I buy out of a barrel at a local market with those wax coated paper bags seems to be MUCH worse than sealed bags of beans I buy.  Since there is so much good coffee out there, I simply stick to the sealed bag coffee.What is bad:-I almost immediately saw that the third finest grind on medium was a little too coarse for me.  When I turned it to the fourth setting, only one to the left, it got too fine.  Hmmm.  I try to leave it in the middle and it seems to work good, but this is definitely not an infinite setting machine.-The chute makes a 90' turn from the grinding area to the receiver.  If you do have static, this can somewhat clog and the little brush is not long enough to reach from the top to push them down into the receiver.  You have to take the receiver off and go in from the bottom, a messy affair.  I got a turkey baster brush which is about 5" long and reaches into the chute nicely. Just look for a marinade baster with a brush in it at any local grocery or sporting store that stocks smoking supplies for meat smokers and such.-Although it is easy to clean, you cannot dry a portion of the top holder.  You must wait till this air dries to use the machine again.Overall, this makes a wonderful grind and produces a fabulous cup of coffee.  It is under $100 and well worth the money.  Just be aware of the usual little static and grinder to receiver problems.  I also use an inexpensive airtight container that I bought at a TJ Maxx that holds my grounds, enough for about 6 days.

We were looking for a pump machine, after often running out of steam with our old tank unit.  We were not really ready to pay hundreds of dollars for a decent pump machine.  Walking through our Aldi's one day in the fall, (they sell the Crofton line of appliances in their grocery stores), we saw this for $39.99.  Thinking it could not be any good, we didn't buy it until we walked in about a week later and snagged one of the last two, marked down to $29.99.  They sold fast...All of the things said by other reviewers seem to be pretty correct, save our knob has not fallen off.  The pump steamer does take a couple of pumps to get rolling, but with a little patience, (15-20 seconds longer), it makes rich, deep foam with our usual 2% milk.  The bun warmer on top is a nice touch.  I thought the steamer stem was a little cheesy, but so far, it has held up well.  My wife makes the expresso and has no complaints save that cleaning is a little tough.We have a conical burr grinder, so we can grind our own expresso beans and this thing loves it.If you are lucky enough to have an Aldi's, you might want to consider waiting for them to stock this item again.

Some people have used Rustoleum for years, and it almost always is some sort of enamel.  Not this.  This is a rather thin, fast drying lacquer that dries gloss, but simply haybales out of the nozzle, hence the "2X" term.I find that although it is much less money than say, an equivalent Deft or Valspar lacquer product, it is somewhat thinner and prone to runs.  I only use it when I have a flat surface to work with.  Vertical surfaces, plan on doing some sanding and recoating.It does put up a nice shine, but WILL NOT spray over enamel.  It will simply crack and peel enamel.  Keep that in mind when trying to put a shine over previously applied Rustoleum enamel.

So far so good. Sturdy metal frame construction covered in plastic so the pool does not get scratched.  The net is thick and heavy duty, I'd call it medium-fine mesh.  Dust and really small particles will get through but anything that you can see standing at the edge of the pool is grabbed and held.I haven't decided which I like better- plastic construction or aluminum.  Plastic degrades in the sun, aluminum is slowly corroded by pool chemicals and pH.  This one is both.  If someone made one out of all stainless with use-replaceable nets, that would be the ultimate but probably pretty expensive as well.In the meanwhile, this is the best constructed of several of these that I've owed over several years.

I have another similar LED desk lamp. Same form factor, similar control, the difference is the LED light array is long and narrow, this if course is a larger diffuser panel.  I thought this would be basically the same, other than the light panel.  Wrong.  The other one is cool, but pretty light and flimsy, this one is rock solid.The control panel (4 soft touch buttons) control the temperature of the light, from very warm and orange to blue-ish and cool.  You can easily fine tune somewhere on the middle to get any type of light you want.  You could use this as a photo light for small objects in a studio.  The other two buttons control the brightness, with a lot of steps between dark and bright.  The light makes a faint buzzing sound when you've maxed out any control in any direction to let you know that is the limit.  Keep pushing the color temp button, when it is as cool or warm as it gets, it will buzz.  Same for brightness.You can turn the brightness down very low so it can be a faint reading or ambient light or you can blast it and light up a large desk area.The arm articulates on several axes, you can aim it where you need to at the angle that you want.The base is glossy piano black and heavy weight, the arm is black matte plastic.One small negative, is the power cord that plugs into the back does not seat securely, it has come loose and come out from just moving the lamp around- it lacks a firm snap in place, just kind of slides in there with a loose friction fit.I guess another is the color temperature buttons are backwards and counterintuitive.  Warmer light is always shown to the left on any illustration, cooler light to the right. That is how they fall on the color spectrum.  These buttons are backwards, the left one makes it cooler, the right one makes it warmer.  The cooler button has a little book icon, the warmer side has a cup of coffee icon. I guess that means, use bright light to read, use warm light to relax.Having two of these, one for each side of the desk would be the optimum set-up for someone who needs high quality diffused light that is completely controllable to do detail work, examine photographs or proofs under controlled light, etc.  2 of these plus a white backdrop would make a perfect desktop photo studio to photograph small parts, for product photography, selling things on eBay, etc.  The diffusion panel gives a perfect light for photography.
High quality, no issues.  These are a little wider than the manufacturer branded ones but fit fine in my machine.

Seems to be high quality stone, even and consistent.  Have used both sides for a variety of blades- woodworking chisels, wood planes, kitchen knives, all were sharpened and polished as I expected.  My fault for this, but I did not carefully check the width of this stone, it is too narrow to sharpen the entire width of my larger wood plane blades, so I have to use a back and forth motion to sharpen edge to edge, less than optimal and awkward.  Next time I'll be sure to buy the right width.  If this manufacturer makes it, I have no issue buying one of their products again.I like that a rubber foot is included.

Seems identical in every way to the OEM Canon battery.  Have not done an exhaustive test of capacity, but ti appears to last as long on a charge, maybe longer and performs the same.  Fit and finish (quality of the plastic. molding. shape, etc) is identical to OEM.  The camera's battery registration & tracking function recognizes it- sometimes aftermarket batteries can show up as "non genuine" in some devices and the internal software refuses to recognize it- I think the camera manufacturer does that to punish people for buying non-OEM accessories, but that is not the case here. It does contain the chip that has a serial number, so it plays well with Canon.

MOKO, are you reading this?  I do not know how to contact you, please PM me.  The sleep wake function does not work on my case.  There does not appear to be the magnet in the cover that enables this function.
Fits the 550EX snugly as advertised, diffuses the output, works as expected. No issues.

Great price for a good quality portable camera bag.  Offers excellent padding and protection and is made from high quality woven nylon and good velcro.  Soft interior will not scratch the camera. My small Canon point and shoot digital camera fits in it loosely.  This lives in my messenger bag, anytime I need to grab a good quality photo or video of something, it's always at hand and I know the camera is safe in my bag, inside of this case.I cut off the Samsonite logo because I don't like manufacturer spam on my belongings.Some other reviewer emphatically made the point that it is not waterproof.  Right, where does it say it is supposed to be?  It is also too small to fit an elephant inside and will not explode if held sideways.  Likewise, the listing does not claim that it has those abilities, so we're fine.  Any other non-sequitur comments to be made?

Works as expected, triggers the flash through the hot shoe connection and also through a PC cable connection.  The PC cable port is not threaded and does not screw in though, it just sits there & falls out pretty easily.  I'd have to use a non-threading PC cable or tape it in place.I use it with a Yonghuo 622c system to trigger my flash in a softbox remotely.  This optical trigger connects to the YN622c-TX, to trigger it in basic flash mode.  I shoot with a small point and shoot digital camera that does not have a hot shoe.  It has a built in flash that I set to it's lowest setting so it will not affect the exposure but will trigger this optical trigger, I place this optical trigger just outside of the frame next to the subject which triggers the YN622 wireless trigger, which triggers the speedflash in the softbox, I control the flash's output manually from the 622c-TX.  Of course I have a good DSLR that I use most of the time, but it is fun to use the small point and shoot camera to trigger the big studio lights and get professionally lit results with a light inexpensive camera.  I did this because I was bored on a weekend day, used Prime same day shipping to get it and had some fun that evening.  I now have the ability to use my small camera with an external flash, wirelessly.

I usually buy the double chocolate fudge Quest bars as low cal, low glycemic meal replacements.  The chocolate ones are delicious and it is incredible that you can get that much filling fiber and nutrition with so few net carbs.  These lemon ones on the other hand taste like lemon scented furniture polish.  I guess I get it- they can use real cocoa to make the chocolate ones which tastes real, but to get lemon flavor they have to use artificial lemon flavoring and that fails. I usually go through a box of the chocolate ones in 2 or 3 weeks, these lemon ones are mostly still sitting there and will probably hit trash when I get sick of looking at them.

Delicious product used to make the ultimate comfort or breakfast food, ochazuke.  I always had this stuff in my cupboard when I lived in Japan, it's a great way to reconstitute last night's leftover rice and warm up when it's raining or chilly.  Nice assortment, I like the salmon the best but the tart plums are always good as well on hot days, very refreshing.  Small crunchy balls (tenkasu?) stay crunchy to offer texture, salmon bits stay chewy.

Nice warm color of light, looks nice and works well.  3000k/ 35w equivalent as advertised seems about accurate.  Warmer than daylight but not yellow or orange.  Two of them are in my stove exhaust hood, pointed directly down on the stove top from about 24 inches above.  They cast a nice wide beam over the whole cook top and a foot or so to each side.  Perfect lighting to see what I'm cooking.  The LED bulbs that came stock in that hood were a harsh blue/ white light that was really ugly.Consider this an initial review, I just installed them and have no way of knowing their durability over time.

A rugged well made tool that works very well.  Same hi vis yellow plastic and black rubber grips as Dewalt Tools.I really like the adjustability of it.  At full sensitivity, I get it within a few feet of a circuit or fluorescent light and it starts buzzing.  All the way down and it does not detect anything, so the range of adjustment is fantastic. I can dial it in so precisely that I can hold it on one side of an insulated wire and it will not go off, but when I move it to the other side of the wire (where the hot conductor is) it goes off.  That's accuracy to a few millimeters.Best way to use it is to calibrate it ahead of time.  Stick it in the hot side of an outlet, on a wire or conduit, hover it over a wall switch or outlet that you know is hot and adjust the knob until it buzzes, now it's ready to test the unknown circuit.I live in a 60+ year old house with plaster and chicken wire lathe wall construction.  At a little more than 1/2 sensitivity it detects the wires inside the wall, inside of metal conduit.  By moving it back and forth and seeing where the buzzing starts and stops, I can trace exactly where that wire is in the wall between the studs.  Makes it easy to trace or detect wiring in the walls before I cut or drill through.If you will only use one of these to stick into outlets or against wires to see if they are hot then the adjustability feature may be overkill, but to get a lot of varied use, I'l glad I chose this one.

This has a fast set-up and dry time similar to Titebond red but it is waterproof like Titebond green.It has a thicker consistency than any of the Titebond glues because it has fine wood fibers mixed into it, much the same way you'd add chopped fiberglass or carbon fiber powder to epoxy resin to make it thicker and stronger and also fill gaps better.The thicker consistency helps minimize dripping.  Projects that I've used it on seem to be bonded very very strongly as you'd expect with any modern wood glue, "stronger than the wood it's bonding".Very fast set up time means that I only use it for small or simple projects, anything with a complex glue up or multiple parts, much better to use Titebond 2 or 3 for the increased open time.I see this as a good replacement for Titebond 1 (red) because it sets up just as fast, but I think that it's stronger (those wood fibers) and it's waterproof so you can use it for outside projects.

As others have noted, this is not really 2 on- and 2 off-levers.  Technically it is, but the green on-lever only works with the 100 series Intermatic timers and the silver on-lever works with the others, so depending on which timer you have, you will use either the green on-lever OR the silver on-lever, but not both.  Therefore in practical terms, it is ONE on-lever (that you can use) and two off-levers.  Not sure why they package it that way, if you only have one on-lever, you only need one off-lever, so the other one is extra and useless, unless you lose the first one and needed a spare.No doubt it is less expensive for Intermatic to package them that way.That small rant aside, they are OEM Intermatic levers and include the small thumb screws as pictured.

Not a thin, pressed aluminum ring, these are cut from thick shiny plated metal.  Won't bend easily.  Has a high quality look and feel. I bought the thin bottom ones, probably should have bought the thick bottom ones to cover up the bottom two (unused) bolt holes on my license plates, but not a big deal.

Very very addictive snack.  Super crispy, fairly salty (as they should be) they arrived perfectly fresh and crispy with that signature toasted sesame flavor and oat bran aroma.  Forget Lays potato chips- I dare you to eat just one handful of these and stop.  Perfect with cocktails.  Amazing with cold beer.  Awesome tossed in an Asian style salad.

Very heavy duty and heavy.  I have gotten good use out of it, used it to polish off rust and corrosion from several parts and tools, also dried adhesive from a large sanding disc.  Bristles have not deformed or even shown any signs of wear, none have flown off that I can tell.Bristles are fairly stiff- you can deform them if you lean into it but you'll need a powerful motor to not bog it down if you lean on it that hard.Great for general use.

Works as expected.  I have a used Intermatic timer mechanism (100 series) from an old pool pump, I wanted to re-purpose it as a garden light timer.  The original steel box was trashed, all I needed was a box to house the timer.This plastic one is OK, the timer mechanism snaps into proprietary clips inside the box, no screws needed to attach it.  Standard 1/2" and 3/4" punch outs to attach the conduit.  3 holes to screw it to the wall.  There is no gasket around the door as I'd expected but there is a lip and it is rated as water (rain) proof and I'm sure it is.The metal versions of these are pretty much bomb proof, this plastic one not so much.  The latch on the door will probably snap eventually when the plastic gets brittle from being out in the sun, etc.  I expect to get several good years out of it.

Dielectric grease as you'd expect. Similar appearance, feel and thickness as petroleum jelly.  I think some people think that you use dielectric grease to increase conductivity in circuits.  It has the opposite effect.  Dielectric means that it slows or stops the flow of electrons.  The purpose is to keep unsealed wires and connectors from getting corroded when exposed to the elements.  The dielectric keeps oxidation or galvanic corrosion from occurring.  That oxidation or corrosion could eventually case the circuit to fail, so dielectric grease has the effect of preserving electrical connections.It is also a waterproofer to keep the circuit dry and a lubricant to help fit connectors together (like sliding a tight spark plug wire over the spark plug).A little goes a long way.

A good, bright LED flood light at a good price, but despite what the description says, it is not a weatherproof outdoor light.  I used this in my garden to light up some trees, after the first rain the inside of the front plastic cover has condensation it and the sunlight has caused it to get a little cloudy.Fine product for inside, or outside where it will not get wet, but not an "outdoor" bulb.Color temp is a nice warm white, well under 3000k.

I use this a lot.  I have an older house with blown in cellulose insulation in the attic, might have glass fibers in it as well.  I made the mistake of going up in the attic without a filter mask once and spent a full day with irritated lungs and windpipe coughing that stuff up.  Now I wear this mask every time and never have any issues.  It's very hot in the attic, I never feel uncomfortable with this mask on.I also use it for yard work, it is dry and dusty where I live, so when I run the blower or mower a lot of dust is kicked up.  Finally, I'm a wood worker and run sawdust generating tools in the enclosed garage a lot.  I would never do that work without this on.It fits snugly and comfortably to my face, is easy to attach and take off with gloves on and the replacement filters are cheap.  Filters have huge surface area so I have not yet clogged a set and it is very easy to breathe in.

I'm a Chef, I use these in the kitchen.  Good slip resistance, comfortable, with the molded rubber sole that repels water and gunk.  Slip on/ slip off is a plus and they look cool.They came with a small pack of leather treatment/ waterproofer (NikWax) that seems pretty good.  After several months the leather still looks new and the sole is not worn at all.  I expect them to last for a long time.Besides all of that, nothing beats the look of Bludnstones with white socks and shorts.  So uncool, that it's totally cool.

4 stars because of the price.One of the big box hardware stores (the orange one) sells 2 versions of the same outdoor flood light- one LED, one halogen.  Both are the same, very rugged- cast metal, waterproof, with bare wires, you have to install in a weather proof junction box.  The LED version is expensive and also too bright for use in my garden.  Halogen bulbs suck a lot of electricity and have a short lifespan because of the heat they generate.I bought the halogen version of that light (very inexpensive) and replaced the bulb with this LED version.  Wound up much cheaper overall than the LED version, puts out just the right amount of light to illuminate my trees from below and uses very little electricity.  Time will tell the longevity.  With LEDs, you spend the money up front, then the electricity to run them is basically free so they pay for themselves over time.Now that I proved that it works well with one, I'll buy more to gently light up the back yard.These bulbs seem to put out the equivalent of a 25 watt incandescent.  I bought the warm white version and it looks identical to a halogen or incandescent. 2700k I'd guess.

Great price on this OEM Samsung cover.Best feature is that the phone snaps into this cover- you remove the existing rear battery cover from the phone and snap this on instead, it retains the waterproof quality of the phone. If the phone comes loose from the back cover at all, it senses it and you get a warning message telling you to be sure the phone is attached so it stays waterproof.  That's a cool feature.  The cover is made of a stiff material so it offers great protection.  The clear plastic window seems to be made of scratch resistant material because mine does not have a single scratch in it.  It does hold and show finger smudges though.The case also hangs over the edge of the phone a little, so that offers edge protection.  You could probably drop it on the corner and it would survive, but best practice is don't be a klutz and don't drop it.When you attach it to your phone, the phone knows this cover is attached, so a specific display shows thorough the window- you can set the background image and choose which information is shown.  You can access the camera and take smaller images with the same square view that you see through the cover- convenient for snapping an image to use as the background in the window.  You can also answer and speak on the phone with the cover closed.  I might be imagining things, but it seems that the phone's earpiece volume is louder when the cover is closed than open.One thing that I dislike about other cases that I've had is that they cover up the microphone hole to some degree so speaker phone functionality is diminished- I use speakerphone a lot.  This cover does not cover the mic at all, so the speaker phone works as if it had no cover.The S5 is a fantastic phone, this cover makes it that much better.

About as thick and heavy as a good bath towel, but woven from microfiber.  No complaints so far, they are more absorbent than a regular microfiber and do not put fine swirl scratches in the paint.  Awesome for doing a post wash buff with some spray on detail wax and for detailing the inside and dash of the car.  Best to hand wash them so you don't get any lint on them in the washing machine.

Replaced a well used, leaking larger Hayward in-line filter that came with my house when I bought it.  It leaked but I liked it, I was going to replace it with the same model but I saw this smaller one.The larger ones have a nylon net that traps smaller particles, this one has a molded basket with larger holes.  I was not keen on losing the ability to trap smaller particles in the basket pre-filter before they get to the DE filter.  Cleaning the DE filter is a PITA, I like to put that off as long as possible.Do a search here on Amazon for Hair Nets, select the one labeled as the #1 seller and see my review of using a nylon hairnet as a pool basket filter enhancer from 2013.  Since I left that review, several others have posted similar reviews so others must have taken my advice.  Great news is, those hair nets work in this Hayward filter as well- I stretch a hairnet over the molded filter basket and it catches fine stuff that the Kreepy Krauley sucks up, including dirt and sand that get blown in during storms.  Just had a few days of heavy rain and the bottom of the pool was covered in dead earth worms.  Would not want them to get into the DE filter because they would rot and foul the water, luckily the combination of Hayward in-line filter and basket with the inexpensive hair net trapped them fine so I could throw them in the trash.So, I've replaced the functionality of the larger filter with a smaller, less obtrusive and less expensive one that is every bit as durable.

Nice, relatively light weight tool with variable speed and plenty of power.  Has the "dead man" switch on it, when you release your grip, it shuts off.  This is probably better for intermittent work- if you were running the tool for long sessions you'd probably want the kind of switch that stays on until you turn it off to lessen fatigue, but that kind is considerably less safe.  I like tools that shut off when I release the grip.Super high quality Bosch tool.  Can not go wrong.

Some of these Dial soaps are so powerfully perfumed that I can not be in the same room with them for days after I open a new bar.  These have a nice natural fragrance that does not blast you out.  Kind of a green apple aroma.  Not sure about the lemon grass.  Cleans very well, does not leave a film on your body, does not dry like regular soap.  I've been using these for a few years, very happy.

Real OEM wheel locks.  High quality chrome plated. I never understood how these things offered security, I always assumed that the key was the same for all of them- if the crook had a lugnut key, they could steal any wheels with these locks.  That's not the case though, each set is custom laser cut with a unique key pattern.Here's another tidbit- these locks also fit the 2015 Santa Fe Sport, which is what I bought them for.  Those OEM wheels are expensive!!  I cross referenced the part number at another web site.  The seating surface that tightens against the wheel is the same as the stock lug nuts.  Amazon has the best price on these.

This is the standard workhorse light.  I had an old one in the pool when I bought the house, the bulb burned out so I took it apart to replace it.  It kept leaking water into the housing even though I used a new gasket.  Finally determined that the epoxy that seals the cord entrance and the rear of the light fixture had cracked and was letting water in.  Light was at least 10 years old, maybe more.The install of this one was easy in theory, though fishing the cord up to the switch at the pool pump proved very very difficult because it was very old and corroded and involved a jackhammer, concrete removal and an electrician to replace that rotted conduit buried in the pool deck.  Luckily I'm building a concrete block wall and had the concrete truck here that day anyway, so I just had the guy fill the trench in for free with the extra concrete he had on the truck.  Had it not been for that, it would have taken 30 minutes tops to install it.300 watt unit is fine for my 18,000 gallon pool though I'm researching dimmer options for it for those late night skinny dipping parties when I don't want to give my neighbors a show.The other option of course is LED, but there is a large price penalty.  You have to do the math to see how long the payback is for the savings in electricity. For me it was many years because I don't use it that much so the incandescent unit (costs about $.05 her hour in electricity to run) was the better option.

Always some problem with these freaking lithium batteries.  Most of the time they are counterfeit and have well below the published capacity, or they are listed as having overcharge/ undercharge protection and don't, or that kind of nonsense.  I've opened up 18650 batteries to find a tiny cell inside surrounded by a lot of air, with a fraction of the capacity that was stated. Of about a dozen of these kinds of batteries that I've bought, only 2 of them were legit.When these batteries arrived I had hoped to have a trouble free experience.  They are very heavy and solid which leads me to believe that they are filled with lithium and not air.  They had the little holographic seal in them, though what does that really mean?  If you have the technology to counterfeit a high tech battery, then you can produce some holographic stickers pretty easily.  Those holographic stickers are meaningless.Anyway, these batteries showed good promise, I connected them to the smart charger and charged them one at a time so I could check the capacity.  Charged at 1 amp for a nice slow, full charge.  First battery arrived with voltage of 3.6 and took 1200mAh of charge.  Second was 3.8 and took 2500mAh.  When I put the third one on, I got a low voltage warning from the charger and it would not charge it.  I set the charger at the LiFe setting which charges at 3.3v and it took it.  I do this with cells that are under voltage to "fool" the charger into charging them.  After a minute, I changed the charger's setting to Li-Ion at 3.7v and it took the charge starting at 3.5 v.Looking closer at the 3 batteries that came in this package, two of them have a button top, one has a flat top and is about 1mm thicker.Jeez, C'mon!!!  What is it with these freaking batteries?  They are never what you order, they are odd sizes, they are inconsistent, some are under charged, 3 batteries in the same package from the same supplier have different specs and configuration.Once all 3 are charged, I'll edit this review to see how they work in the big flashlight, also once they're depleted, I'll do a full discharge/ recharge cycle with the smart charger to see what their real capacity is.  Fingers crossed.

This is a pretty case, well made, fits the phone like a glove and I really like the look of it;  Let's face it, it is designed to make your S5 look more like a big iPhone.  Similar metal like case around the outside.Another BIG plus, is that the main on/off sleep/ wake button on the right edge of the phone, built into the case works perfectly.  Adds very little resistance to the pressing action which is great because I use that button a lot.  Molded TPU cases with that button molded into the side of the case add a LOT of resistance so you really have to push the button much harder to get it to work, with those cases on.What I'm not psyched about, is that it makes an already big phone, even bigger.  Of course any case adds to the size of the phone, but this really does.  I had this cover on for a week or two when I first got the phone, got used to it, then took it off and was amazed at how thin, light and svelte this phone is without that case.  Second, because it is in two parts, it is kind of a production to get it on and off, so if I need to change the battery or plug it in to my large car charger and need to remove the case, it adds time to the process.  The outer plastic ring has to fit into a channel in the black silicone part of the case perfectly so you have to spend extra time working it into the groove with your fingers. By comparison, I bought a Tech 21 impact mesh TPU case that, like any molded TPU case, pops on and off in a couple of seconds and offers excellent protection for the phone and adds less bulk than the Spigen case.Without a doubt though, this Spigen case looks fantastic, very classy and is perfectly made.  I use the TPU case for everyday, going to work use where I need solid, basic protection for the phone and the ability to pop the cover on and off.  On the weekend, out socializing etc where I want my phone to look great, I use the Spigen case.

Works as it is supposed to.  Apparently the Jandy tanks have a non-standard proprietary thread and thread size so if you want to add a valve or drain lines, you have to buy this adaptor to screw into the drain valve at the bottom of the tank.I have a Jandy DEL48 filter, I re-plumbed the pump and filter assembly and am building a new shed to house it.  That puts the drain valve at the rear where it would be hard to reach.  I use this connector to plumb in a valve on the side so I can reach it to drain the tank.Does not say it above, but the slip end of this fits 1 1/2 inch, standard schedule 40 PVC pipe.It is a very well built piece, very heavy duty, no complaints but I knocked a star off because of the price.  I buy quality PVC fittings for between $.99 each and $2.00 (if they have threads, etc).  Even the 1 1/2" valve that I used for this system, which is a far more engineered, complicated, materials intensive piece cost $9.99 at the plumbing supply.  Why on earth should this simple fitting with a silicone o-ring cost this much (with a list price of $30.00?!!!!!!)  Because Jandy chose to use a non-standard thread, so you have to buy this one, so they can charge you this much for a fitting that would otherwise cost about $2.00.  I'm not a fan of companies that do business like that (ahem, Apple computer).  Standard plumbing fittings should be standard.

I'm coming from a galaxy Nexus mounted on a Samsung dash mount to an S5 mounted with this. Nexus is a smaller phone, and the Samsung mount is VERY strong.  The result, is that my Nexus did not move or jiggle one bit when in the mount in the car.  Rock solid, did not move.  With this mount, it's like jelly.  Obviously a smaller, thinner mount with a heavier phone, but it is very distracting.  I live in a big city, all paved roads, no bumpy dirt roads etc but it almost gets to the point that I can't see the GPS screen.So, you get what you pay for, now as always.  The samsung big $$ mount was rock solid and completely stable, this one jiggles and wiggles to the point that sometimes you can barely see the screen.  I drive a lot for work, use the GPS and phone constantly for hours a day, I need a mount that holds the phone still.  This is not it.Otherwise, the spring grip part works well, you need two hands to spread it and fit the phone in.  The suction cup seems solid.  I can confirm that a Galaxy S5 with a large case (Spigen Neo) will fit in there, but barely.

This is a tiny light, I did not realize how small.  Maybe 2" square or less.  Packs in 36 LED emitters.  It is a heck of a deal though- consider this:  It comes with lithium ion battery and charger, the battery included is not some off-brand junk, it is a Fuji Film branded NP-45.  These batteries sell for about $14 by themselves here on Amazon, a little less if you buy a no-name.I was just shopping here to buy a second battery for it and when I realized the cost of the battery, a light went on (pardon the pun)- just buy an entire new light kit, with battery and charger for $14.95.  You'd pay that for the battery alone, so it's like getting a second light and charger for free!  Having that second light off on an angle helps to remove shadows cast by one light alone.I use this and similar lights for food photography.  The tiny size and ability to mount on a tripod or hot shoe (or double sided tape on the wall, hand held, etc) allows me to stick it anywhere for a little fill light, though it is certainly bright enough to be the main light source.If it lasts, it'll be a huge score.  I even envision using it as a portable flood light- working on the car in a dark spot, etc.

Small in size, fairly light, works well for smaller surfaces and projects.  Has enough power that you can use coarse belts and bear down pretty hard removing a lot of material quickly and it won't bog too badly.  Belt changes are very easy and it has a knob on the side that you can screw in or out to change belt alignment on the fly.Downsides are, first, that it runs pretty hot.  After a few short minutes of working it hard, it gets almost too hot to hold.  I'm not a wimp, I have a high tolerance for heat, but it gets hot.  Also, it is fairly flexible so when you bear down the rollers flex which changes the belt angle, causing it to move to one side or the other.  You can counteract that by turning the knob, but as soon as you stop bearing down, the belt goes in the other direction.  Best way to use it is not to bear down, just let it skim the surface.Finally, dust extraction is poor.  I connect it to my dust extraction hose which draws well, but the space between the dust outlet and the rear of the belt is very narrow so air flow is very low, so it is hard for the dust to get sucked out.Overall I would not consider it a high grade professional woodworking tool, more like a light job or hobbyist tool.  I've done some big projects with it and worked it pretty hard, it shows no signs of wearing out or slowing down.  I received mine as a "freebie" add-on when I bought the big Triton router.  The Triton router is a very well made, heavy duty well engineered brute, different in that regard from the palm sander.Takes 2 1/2 x 16" belts, available here on Amazon in varying qualities.

These seem to perform every bit as well as the more expensive Eneloops (and there are those who feel that they are re-branded Eneloops).  I used to live in Japan and bought the Eneloops there when they were first released, then I usually buy another pack when I go back to visit.  These are every bit as good, which saves on air fare...  ;-)I have these in remotes that I put in there just out of the package that have been in there for months and months, still going strong without any additional charge.  999 more charge cycles to go!~This is the future of consumer type batteries.  Invest in a high quality charger to take care of them.Recommended.

I had ordered these before, I like them a lot.  I'm on the phone in my car all the time, conference calls etc and the plug in earbud/ mic combo that comes stock with all phones is just way better than anything bluetooth for you hearing them but most importantly them hearing you.  Bluetooth sucks, no matter how much you spend.Anyway, I re-ordered these, T-400s and they are a little shorter than the T-500s that I bought before.  They do not go into my ear canal as far.These scrunch down and go into your ear, then expand- aka memory foam. Not so firm that they hurt your ears, just enough to isolate and keep them in.  Highly recommended to use these instead of the silicone ones that you see more often.These have the small plastic tube in them to attach firmly to the driver in your earbud and keep them from collapsing, but do not have the anti-earwax screens which seem pretty useless to me.  Just clean your ears from time to time.

I was talked into getting a jug of this at my local brick-and-mortar chain pool supply just after I bought a house with a pool.  The salesperson assured me that it would solve and prevent most common pool chemistry related problems I'd encounter.  I somehow felt that the salesperson was selling me snake oil and I was skeptical.  Former owners of the house left me the pool with a bad algae infection and troubled water chemistry so I wanted to try it.This did not kill the algae and clear it up- using algaecide and shocking it a few times did, but this has kept it from coming back in over a year.  I rarely have to adjust pH (I've used less than 2 gallons of acid in a year in 17,000 gallons), I add a few large tabs of chlorine to the floater every few weeks (maintain under 5ppm) and that's it.  Chemistry is stable and when I get the water tested, the phosphate levels are barely detectable, despite a lot of trees around the pool constantly dropping vegetation in there.  Clear water, clean pool, no algae, reduced chemical use compared to what friends with pools use.  As well, I do detect that the water has a "silky soft" feel that is hard to describe until you feel it.I add it to the skimmer ever other week with the pump running on high speed to mix it up, that seems to work well for me.

Mankind started out as hunter gatherer and nomads. Moving place to place with tier animals it would take a god many a years before they settled down into sedentary farmers. With the establishment of civilizations along such rivers as the Nile, Indus River, Mesopotamia and others mankind was getting exposed to more and more pathogens. This was cause by lower amounts of protein in the diet an higher carbs for one. But also with people being so close together and the fact that people knew very little about hygiene it would come as no surprise that diseases could wipe out entire populations. Also the close proximity to animals and their manure also brought about the increase of sickness.Since man has been plagued by sickness and disease, man has tried to find cures for what was ailing him. Many thought that the gods were upset and so they sent a sickness to punish the man or society. Gradually their healing techniques would become more scientific based and less mystical. At first healing techniques were thought to come from the spirit world and shamans would go into a trance to find out cures for all that ailed the tribe. Most healing relied upon herbs and natural remedies but the ancients did in fact employ surgery.  Paleopatholigist, people who study ancient diseases and their treatment have been able to determine how people died and what treatments were used. Trephiniation or making the hole in the skull was one such example.Bodies that have been preserved in bogs and mummies have presented the best specimens for archaeologists to examine. The first group of people discussed was the Egyptians.  They did not know much about the body but they did know about herbs.and how they could be used to heal people. Surgery was not done regularly and the dead body was never allowed to be dissected for medical reason or autopsies. They could submerge a body in the river and as the water eroded away the skin the doctors could see what was going one. The most qualified doctors  were taught in the temple‚Äôs medical school.The next group discussed were the Chinese. They believed that the body was composed of five main elements. Fire, Water, wood, earth and metal. They has to be in a balance in for  their to be health. The main emphasis was on the holistic balance between the yin and the yang. The whole body has to be strong.The Ancient Indians were also discussed, They  believe in moderation and right living. They would use herbs to help the body. They used yoga to regulate and nourish the mind and the body. Ayuvedic medicine was based on restoring a balance. The Indians believed in prana or energy. Much like the Chinese belief in qui. The Greeks held belief in good diet and exercise plus the balancing out of humors in the body. The Romans were to emphasis bathing and hospitals. From the era Hippocrates and Galen were best known. Nifty little book.

This is definitely a tribute to the dark ones. definitely not a fluffy safe version of the craft and this is definitely not Wicca. THe author is a student of many traditions and he pulls from such sources as Traditional British Witchcraft , Voudou, Hoodoo, Goetia, Santeria and perhaps several others that I may have missed . The rending is poetic and inspirational , a reading that will definitely transport you to the Emerald Castle in the North. I should be as poetic.In the early days mankind was close to nature and it's spirit aligned with that of the forest. Taboos against sex were not yet instituted by the all powerful Christian Church , which enclosed the continent of Europe in a bloody grip fog terror in order to force upon it the ways of the cardinal and church fathers. After Christianity became established anything that was wild and free was considered dangerous and evil. Instead of everything being thought of as one it was not a dichotomy of good and evil something which they defined. THe witch saw everything as interconnected and the more connecting a goal to a thing the more likely it was about to manifest. The gods of old were equated with the devil or other demons. Such inspiration for the devil came from HErmes, Baal and Mithras. But really who is the devil? Are Satan and Lucifer the same entity.? Some would say yes and others would say no. Satan means opposer while Lucifer was a light bringer. Light bringers such as Prometheus often brought knowledge to mankind, often at great cost to †themselves. THe author covers this much in depth.Discussions go into the nature of the dark goddess and her many faces. Lilith, Hecate, Circe are all discussed as well as wondering in the night ffor it is from darkness that hidden knowledge is revealed and our unmanifest desires become manifest. Fairies, Jinn and other spiritual creatures are discussed as is their interaction with mankind. What is the3 nature of these beings? Read and find out. As the question as to what makes ¬†a witch is discussed there is talk of faerie blood and human spirit interaction in the creation of witch blood. THe book has some recipes and several rituals.FOr those wishing toi pursue the old traditional craft this is one good book to have in your collections. I would advise reading some of Michael Howards materials along with Paul Husson to get a complete picture and develop your practice.

Wicca was introduced to the world by Gerald Gardner since then it has grown and new traditions have sprung up around it. This has given some rise to debate. The debate stems over new practices versus old practices. Traditional Wiccans don‚Äôt change much and look askance at some of the new practices. Check out some of the book and websites the debate is raging. This book covers the debate and does a thorough job to boot. Some of the ground is covered in other such books as Drawing Down the Moon and Triumph of the Moon.While Traditional Wiccans may keep to the way Gardner has done it, the Innovative Witches are putting together their own tradition and practice. This has some unique causes and consequences. Let us look at causes. Most innovative will study books and pull their practice form those books. They may also pull from different strains of witchcraft and other religions to put their practice together . Innovative ¬†may also just come up with stuff from Unverified personal Gnosis. Let us not forget that public lectures, workshops and rituals are now becoming the norm as opposed to traditional covens. Take a look at witchvox and the number o books available. Some Tradtional Wiccans have crossed the line and become Innovative Witches.Finding covens is rather hard, so if you cannot join a coven you have to learn this stuff and practice this stuff on your own. That means if a witch or wannabe wants to practice the craft they will not have access to the coven initiation. Some options they may pursue are self dedication, or self initiation. ¬†How valid these self initiations are remains a hot burning controversy.The increase in Innovative Witches has led to some profound changes in the craft. One of several differences revolves around the Wiccan Rede which states harm ye none. Not all the Innovative buy into this. Many feel that if someone harms you or means you harm then it is ok to use magic against them that may harm them. Another difference is in the tools. Innovative which are more flexible in which tools they use an do not use. One controversial tool is the scourge. While it has been used in the past, many are denouncing it‚Äôs use because the tool could be abusive. This attitude is permeating the Traditional Wiccans as well. The Five Fold Kiss an the great right are not so up their either. It is too explicit especially for ¬†public rituals.There are similarities though. Both groups are challenging the feminist view of history that has been taught, especially with the exaggerated accounts of the Burning Times which put the death toll at 9 million when the number was really much smaller and many of those killed were not even witches. Another historic item that is challenged is the view that humans were once matriarchal and worshipped one Goddess. The lack of solid proof and academic enquiry has lead less to believe in this.Thanks to ¬†innovations witchcraft has become more accepting of gays, same sex coven and the craft has politicized around issues of human rights and the environment.. Remember that Witch craft and magick are practices an what you believe its not as important.

What's in a face you say? Perhaps plenty. Looking at the features of someones face could tell you lots about them. Are they nice?kind? mean? dependent? or Independent? THe Chinese used to look at the face the way gypsies used to look at your hand in order to tell what your futre and fortune would be like. Jean Haner, Feng Shui specialist, married into a chinese family and learned this stuff. Obviously she cleaned it up to make it more in tune with the times and more realistic. In other words a lot of the superstitions were thrown out.THis book was basically written so you could look at your face and tell exactly who you are. You can also look at the face of other people and tell what they are like. A bit of modern wisdom is thrown in where in the author tells people to compare faces to the same racial types to get an accurate reading. She also tells us that we are all different and approach things rather differently,that is cool seeing that all of us are different. ¬†We must be true to ourselves and allow others to be true to themselves.Now I cannot go to deeply into details but I can cover a few basics and if this seems like a book you would like then by all means check it out from the library or buy it. First off Chinese philosophy or medicine is based on 5 elements. Those elements are water, wood,fire, earth and metal. We all have a bit of each in us at least. Some of us are strong in a few and weak in others. Most of us will fit into a certain type though.Water personalities tend to be more dreamy and enjoy their sleep . Water hangs around in the caverns below Earth and it flows in the seas and river. It is a soft hidden power. People like this often like to sleep late and enjoy theirr dreams and tend to be rather creative. To read water features you would look at the Ears, hairline, forehead, under eye area, philtum and chin.Wood personalities are the doer. They get up on time and are always actice on some project or other. They tend to be rather industrious. To read someone's wood features you would look at the eyebrows, browbone, temples,jaw and stature.FIre people are those who lie to be in the limelight and have very showy personalities. They tend to be rather excitable and even bubbly in terms of personality. To read someones fire features you would look at their eyes, types of hair and tips of features.¬†Your Earth folks tend to be very nurturing and friendly. They are ¬†quick with hugs and if you visit their house they will have some milk and cookies for you. They tend to be very helpful and tend to want to do good. To read someones earth features you would look at their mouth, upper eyelids, bridge of nose, area above the upper lip, lower cheeks near the mouth.Metal folks tennd to be the ones who refine things. They also like to stay to themselves and need their personal space and boundaries. To read someones metal you would look at their nose, cheeks, Fa Lin ines, eyelids and upper brow plus any moles.THE face be divided into two or three different zones. THe right zone is where we place or public persona, the left side our hidden parts. If you do the three zones then recall that the top part is our analytical zone, the middle zone is our practical zone and the bottom is our emotive zone.I found the book to be quite entertaining and author quite knowledgeable. I found out a bit about myself and will find such information useful in dealing with other peoople. Because if you want to help or work with others yu have to be able to read them.

The term Martial Arts normally conjures up visions of Bruce Lee, Chuck Norris or some other practitioner of Asian Martial Arts. The terms is usually applied to Karate, Judo, Kung Fu etc. Martial means war and it comes from ¬†the Roman God of War Mars. Now If I were to say Nigel Pennick you would most likely think of witchcraft and magic. Well now you have an occultist writing books on European Martial Arts.¬†This book provides real enjoyable read that is both informative and exhilarating. I read through the book rather quickly and learned several things I might not have known and ti top it ¬†off it was written in a way that is easy to comprehend and ¬†easy to retain the information.¬†The first part of the book covers the metaphysical underpinning of the European Martial Arts. Man was considered a microcosm of the universe. His body was supposedly consisted of four humors and when these humors got out of balance wee then that is when we got sick. Face reading was also covered . This was based primarily on Greek philosophical knowledge.¬†The author takes us to the age of a hunter gatherer where men hunted sometimes more than they needed. Heroes or super hunters would slay wild animals or pack of wild animals that were guilty of making things difficult for mankind. ¬†From this evolved the hero warrior. Also hunting cults developed from this as well.¬†Cults dedicated to Odin would live out in the wilderness and hunt or harass enemies in packs. These people were your ulfredrs or wolf hunters. By donning the wolf skin they could take on the characteristics of the wolf. Wolves operated in packs. Berserkers were bear warriors who operated alone. There were also boar warriors and dog warriors. Oft times the skin was believed to be magically warded against swords.¬†As the fighters became Christianized they lost their connection to nature and adopted the code of chivalry. The code of chivalry obligated the night to behave in a courteous manner, be kin to women and stick up for the weak. The book discussed ¬†the process of a young nombe boy becoming ¬†knight.¬†There was also a preview of the different shields, swords and other weapons the knights used to use. There is some discussion on how they trained. After the intervention of gunpowder and the end of the use of bow and arrow the interst I warrior arts waned. After all any fool could pull a bloody trigger.¬†Over all if you are interested in the history of European martial arts or learning the techniques of such this book may at best be a primer or a good place to begin. I am not sure any bone pagan groups used all the things he describes. After all the heathen Norse mst likely did not know too much about Greek medicine.

Don Webb is a magus of the Left Hand Path, an official in the Temple of Set. I have read some of his earlier works and was quite impressed with his erudition. The meat of this current work is the examination of Crowleys great revelation "THE Book of Law" . Now many ¬†Thelemites have told me that Crowley would not discuss the book of law because it was written for each and every single one of us and it is a revelation meant fort each invidual that reads it. Don Webb has written his own commentary on and has published Michael Aquino's commentary on it as well. At first I found the work somewhat questionablee because I am not so sure how much either of these authors spent in either the Golden Dawn, Order of Thelema or Ordo Templis Orientalis.I know Anton Lavey did not nor did Michael Aquino. No less Aleister Crowley influence the entire generation. No Crowley no sixties quite literally. Crowley's influence went well beyond the occult world. ¬†There has been question has to whether Crowley was a right hand path person or a left hand path person. Crowley wanted one with diety, yet he said he did not want followers or slave but he wanted an army of strong individuals to spread the word he also told people not to blindly rely on him but to come up with their own revelation.Find their own revelations many people did. Gerald Gardner the father of the Witchcraft revival was a member of OTO and worked a lot with Crowley. But Crowley also influenced Anton Lavey, Timothy LEary, L Ron Hubbard, Jack Parsons, Kenneth Grant, and slew of writer and other great thinker. His students did blaze their own trail and thanks to Crowley's inspiration a whole new Aeon was ushered.The Aeons of Isis and Osiris are over with and it is now the aeon of Horus.traveling thorough Egypt in 1904 Crowley and his wife Rose held a ritual where in Crowley came into contact with Aiwass and wote down his revelation. Finding a steelae he named the main god and goddess Nuit and Hadit, next to them was Hrous.THE Aepon of Horus is likened to the age of Aquarious where man is free from societal restraint to pursue his will and live in accordance with the desires of his soul. Recall that every man and woman is a star meant to live out its destiny while at the same time being respectful of the other stars out there in the sky.In addition to commentaries Webb informs the reader of the influences of Crowley. His father was a member of the austere "Plymouth Bretheren" they had a strong work ethic and were strict. Crowley's mother called him the great beast and he went on to live up to that title. Crowley was also influenced by far eastern religions such as Buddhism, Hinduism, Tantra and Nietze. remember Nietze believed in thee will to power and Crowley was about will. ¬†After the commentaries the author discuses several philosophical under pinning of Crowley's philosophy.Be honest I liked most of the book with the exception of the commentaries . I felt that they did not increase my understanding all that much. The first part of the book and the last part were features of the book that saved it or redeemed it. ¬†Whether you are an occultist or not you may have something to learn from Crowley.

For countless centuries the Middle East has been home to a variety of religions that do not fall into the mainstream. People will find it hard to believe that non Muslim minorities could survive so long in the Middle East. Fact of the matter is that the Muslim Middle East was more tolerant than Christian Europe . That does not mean that life was easy for non Muslims in the Middle East, as these minorities have undergone persecution. ¬†Islam bespeaks tolerance and protection for people of the book ie Christians, Jews and sometimes Zoroastrians and Samaritans. Many of these minorioities survived by hiding out in hard to reach places like high mountains or marshlands. These minorities have also been tenacious.Now things are changing. In ancient times the Muslim governments did not wish to route out followers of other faiths, after all Muslims profited from the extra jizya tax. THe Muslim governments did not have the power to get at people in those hard to reach places. Now they do. While life in the past was relatively stable, modern times has proven lots more precarious.In Iraq you have the Mandaeans and Yazidis. ¬†THe author Gerard Russel is a British Diplomat who decided to travel and visit these people who are holding out and clinging to their traditions. In the south he visited the Mandaeans. THe Mandaean liv e in the sourthern marshland of Iraq and Iran. Thanks to blind fanaticism and the fact the that the marshlands are no longer a safe haven, many of the Iraqi Mandaeans have let their native Iraq. The faith of the Mandaeans is a gnostic faith. This means that the material world was created by an evil deity meant to imprison souls. THe Mandaeans hold that they are descended from Seth , Adam's third son. John the baptist is the Messiah and Jesus was a rebel against the order. They are most known for having baptisms for every occasion and their sign is a cross dressed in a white sheet. ¬†The white sheet stands for purity and the cross symbolized four directions. THe evil Goddess Rouha created the world to trap souls. Mandaean thought had an impact on Manicheism.¬†THE second group in Iraq live in the Northern part of the country. Many live in Sinjar, while others live in Qunitra. In the past the Yzidi have been much left alone. Now things have changed with the onslaught of ISIS. Many have fled to Lalish the place ¬†where a founding member is buried. Many do not know the fundamentals of ¬†their faith. There is a learned group and an unlearned group. Most Yezidis fall into the unlearned group. Yezidis have been thought of as devil worshipper. Of course, nothing could be further from the truth. Much like earlier legends, Satan or Melek Taus, was God's head angel. The head angel loved god but refused to bow down to man. For that he was flung into Hell.But while in Hell he repented. His tears quelled the fires from Hell. He tasted redemmpfion and he rules the the world. AS GODS¬† lieutenant he is revered along with the sun and the moon. It is believed that there were 7 peacock made only two survive.¬†THe third group takes us to Iran, coincidentally enough to the Iranian city of Yazid. This is the central place ¬†of their faith. Their number are in decline because of increased persecution. Zoroastrianism was the official¬†Iranian religion prior to accepting Islam. ¬†Islam had a debate as to ¬†whether Zoroastrians were people of the book. While maintaining a belief in monotheism they do believe in a dualistic world. Ahura Mazda is the god of life and light while Angra Mainyu was the evil god always going against him. It should worthy of note that all thrtee faiths discussed thus far read the stars and allow their dead to be eaten ¬†by birds before being buried.The next two groups have a presence in Israel. They are the Druze and the Samaritans. ¬†The Druze live in three countries and they are Lebanon, Syria and Israel. On principal they fight for the county they live in. Druze get a lot of their ideas from Pthagoras. They believe in the Universal mind which gave rise to the Universal Soul and Intelligence. THey also believe in reincarnation and that all Druze will bve born into the body of another Druze. Sometimes they have souls that go to ¬†China. Much like the Yazidi ¬†they have two groups of people, the learned and the unlearned. The Druze religion is not a very demanding religion.The Samaritans live in Colon, Israel and in the Palestinian city of Nablus upon the hill of mount Gerizim. THe Samaritan are very similiar to Jews. In fact they claim to be remnants of the Lost Tribes of Israel left over from the Assyrian conquest. THe Jews in the past have thought that they were descended from settlers transferred to Northern Israel by the Assyrians. THe two groups have not always gotten along and in New Testament times they were at each others throats. ¬†THe Talmud says contradictory things about the Samaritans. Now relation are improving and the Samaritans might be a bridge between the Palestinians and the Israeli Jews. But Samaritan number are dwindling. IN terms of history it is only recently that they ¬†have allowed wives from outside the community to convert into ¬†the Samaritan society. Every year at Passover tourists flock to ¬†the Samaritan celebration.Lately ¬†the Samaritans have opened up even more. Now they are putting out literature for those who want to live the Samaritan way. This may help bolster their decreasing numbers. I ¬†think they should allow men to convert into their community for marriage just like they do for the women.THe final two groups that the author visited are the Copts and the Kalasha. The Copts are located in Egypt and were introduced to Christianity via the apostle MArk. For centuries they were tolerated but recent history has shown that things are turning against them. unbar Pasha increased many of their opportunities and allowed for ¬†them to have positions in the government. This pretty much happened under King Farouk. With the over throw of Farouk the era f Sadat was ushered in .Under his leadership the Muslims brotherhood got increased power. This was bad for ¬†the copts. Increased fanatical presence on university campus has led to aN ISLAMIFICATION of curriculum. Christianity is not taught at all. Also it has been harder since Sadat to build neddw churches or repair ¬†the older ones. under Mubarak things went on like before with few improvement . Mubark still worked ¬†with the Brotherhood. Since things have gotten bad many Copts ¬†have choses to get closer to the church . It must not be forgotten that Muslims and CHristians ¬† helped overthrow Mubarak and that Muslims and Christians formed human chains to prevent the destruction of CHurches. in the ¬†south the fanatics are a lot more ruthless. Then again the Copts are more numerous in the South and have the ability to fight back.The Kalasha live in the Hindu Kush mountain bordering in Afghanistan, Pakistan and India. They worship old gods from Pagan times. they have solsticee celebrations for Spring and and Winter as do ¬†the Zoroastrians. The author arrived in the winter. The Kalasha have their pantheon o0f gods and they get on with their Muslim ¬†neighbors. Like many Middle Eastern groups women during their ¬†menstruation have stay separated .There are also laws that demand ritual ¬†purity that only they can do.THe book finished in Detroit where in discussion venters on how emigres ¬†from the Middle East are coping.
