Maybe my inner child is just dead, but this was boring.

My damn studio has recently branched out to doing life events, and you never know what sort of equipment venue has. It was sort of a blessing to have this microphone come into our lives when it did, because I frequently have to emcee such life events. Thus far, the range is pretty good, with no  problems involved in it cutting out or anything else like that. It's very comfortable to hold, and doesn't pick up much background noise, but rather focuses on the voice directly in front of it.  The sound quality is good, though it was a little hard to tell in the last few venues because of extraneous audience noise, or in the case of the gym, strange acoustics, but from what I could tell, it was crisp and clear, true to the voice of the user.

The main downside is that the capacity for liquid is limited compared to the size you need to cover in a space. For larger spaces, you need to refill the cleaner a few times. At the same time, if it were much larger, it would add weight and bulk, and as it currently is designed, this is a pretty good balance between capacity and portability: it is kind of bulky and heavy, but not bad for what it can do.As for how well it cleans, it does a great job! We have two cats, and this thing really extracts a lot from the carpet, from little tiny particles to bigger things like hair. We chose the deep cleaning, which meant we needed 3 hours for the rug to dry. This is not bad; after a professional cleaning, they recommend 6+ hours dry time. We have someone clean the house every other week and the carpets in the bedroom were professionally cleaned 6 months ago, and considering the cats are generally not allowed there, the fact the water came out Very dirty was surprising. There are two settings: deep cleaning and light cleaning. We did the deep cleaning, and it really worked. This thing is great!The assembly and setup was easy, though to clean it up after use, it is a bit of a pain when it comes to dealing with carpet beater. The water? No problem. Same with the thing that holds the dirty stuff.Excellent vacuum, and cheaper than having professionals come and do it. Comparing the costs, this is well worth the expense.

This is a great little thing to have in the crib. It has soft music and not-too-bright lights that activate when you touch the mat. It is a great way to teach babies to self-soothe and get back to sleep on their own. The design is very pretty and cute, totally gender-neutral, and it works well for the first couple of years or so.

I think this is one of those things kids like more than adults, because it was way too sweet for me. Then again, when I VERY rarely drink soda, I have half plain soda water and half actual soda, and that's enough sweetness for me...Having said that, the ingredients are better than what you find in a lot of similar products, featuring organic and gmo-free milk and fruit. It has a nice amount of protein and fiber, but check the sodium and sugar content, and bear in mind that those numbers are pretty high (180mg sodium, 15g sugars).This is good...in Moderation.

This is the Best idea for a gift! Not only does it nurture creativity and a love of books, but children can actually create a Real book of their own! It even has an "about the author" section! You can inspire your child to become a writer or research something they love, or to make beautiful artwork and see it made into something "real" and official.I recently reviewed another book that was similar: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00TLFTTB6?redirect=true&ref_=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_0This one is about $14 less for the same number of pages, BUT it is slightly smaller in size and is a soft-cover book, whereas this one is a hard-cover one. That makes a pretty big difference, but of course, it is something to consider. This one has a lot of helpful tools for ideas, as well, which is great to inspire kids.This is one of those gifts that is as fun for kids as adults!

These things are a little addictive. Between the online integration of games and points, and the fact that these things can interconnect and stack, kids can turn into hoarders pretty quickly. There are lots of ways to customize these, and setting it up is a big part of the fun. While this isn't the best one of all the "littlest pet shop" sets, and it doesn't have as many options and do-dads, it still is pretty fun. Nice toy!

We have plenty of lighting here in Florida, so something like this sure comes in handy. Between the warranty and the surge protection, this is great for using with entertainment systems and expensive technology like computers and high end laptops. Nice product!

This cream has good ingredients, goes on smoothly, doesn't leave residue, and absorbs nicely. Also, the price is very reasonable! The problem is the scent. It has a strong granny smell. The scent is pretty unpleasant, and I had to use some essential oils to mask it, but that only did so much. It would have 5 stars if it smelled better.

This product is the worst. We sprayed it on, as directed, and it was white. It looked like white hair. Then there are the fumes. We were choking with the junk in the air, which remained for some time. To remove this white finish, we had to wet her hair and kind of scrub it with our fingers.The only positive comment I have is the nice citrus scent (which you later choke on from the dusty spray stuff that lingers in the air). Nope.Side note: we kept a decent distance (again, as instructed), and it still had the results you see. I tried again on my hair, which was ingido and royal blue at the time (yep, you heard me!), and the color was REALLY dulled by the spray. *maybe* if you have Super pale blonde or white hair, this product is fine.

This has lots of cool features and some deliberate break-away parts to recreate a bit of destruction and mayhem, and between that and the Huge size, kids will get a kick out of this stage. It looks a lot like the real thing, is more or less to scale with the action figures, and has a few (underwhelming) lights for the stage. As a theater person, the lights really need work. They're just red and not very powerful. As for the giant screen, you will find in the other reviews that this is just an iPad or tablet holder. There's an app that works with the stage to introduce the players, which is pretty cool, actually, but also assumes you're willing to let your kid use your expensive iPad as an overpriced toy accessory. Nice idea, but my iPad is Not getting volunteered for that.As for the price, it's pretty high, so I would not personally spend money on a toy that takes up this much space and requires the use of my iPad, but that's just me.

These are perfect for curious little hands--big enough to not be dangerous (these things can look like candy for little ones, and they love putting stuff in their mouths), and the bright colors and different shapes are very appealing and help with hand eye coordination.I always loved building blocks growing up. They help with spatial reality, are gender neutral, and are lots of fun!

Thinner than I expected. Nice selection of sizes. Spouse learned never to use a serrated knife on them, he deeply scored the smallest one cutting meat. Now it's still useable, but, harder to clean. With my regular blades they have stood up well and cleaned up well. I took one star expecting the surface to be harder, and for them to be thicker. I will update the review after I have had them a few more months.This trio was the same price as just one board about the size of the largest one, part of the reason I purchased, along with the niceness of getting the different sizes. I will say the smallest one was a very handy size...

Wife guessed, it is the size I used to be (having lost 30#) but I'm still a big guy. It is comfortable, and a GREAT bathrobe. It is a little longer than I wanted but she insisted for the colder days ahead that it should be like that. Color is good, dark, and as she says 'hides when I feed my lap while eating' better. The fabric isn't flimsy, and I like having two different belt loop 'heights' to choose from. Felt a little 'rough' when I tried it on, after it was washed, feels great.

This style of glasses is light on the face, close to the eyes. If nothing else they are good eye protection and give a moist 'microclime' that is important especially if you have dry eyes, wear contacts, or have had eye surgery. I buy these in clear for general shop and hobby work; a light grey tint for outside general work and day driving glasses, as they take down just enough glare, and the very dark greys when I need glare reduction. Bonus is they are rated Z87 safety glasses and will protect from UV. I started buying the light grey 'carded' on hangpeg at a place that sold serious lawn maintenance equipment, and have worn those for about 5 years (replacing every season). It is good to find them for a lot less here. They can get scratched up doing yard and garden so glad to be able to replace them especially for driving glasses. Totally have been worth their money

Not using it exactly as expected. I have a special diet and have to cook most of my own foods. I use this for some sauces and spice blends when I need them to warm and meld for awhile (start a gluten free pizza crust, and mix the red sauce with the herbs & spices and leave it to warm and flavors blend together while I go through the crust prep cycle) It is a very good size for what I need. It will not 'cook' food but if I need it warmed without scorching it does the job well. For my needs, good investment.

To be fair, I bought ScratchNdent. They were well packaged, four came in bubblepack and one came in original box. No instructions. I was at least clued in and bought the power supply at the same time... they do not come with a power supply.It took a bit to get the body separated from the clipon holding ring. No mounting screws but two mounting holes in the holding ring. There is very little clearance. 6-40's didn't fit, 4-40's almost did. I had to carefully use a cone shape grinding bit in my dremel to gently bevel things and get enough screw clearance (drill from side that faces/touches the main puck body).The pucks are metal cased and metal holding/mounting clip, they are very well made. No warping here from a bit of heat. The wires are red and black, have a bit of heat shrink to go between mounting surface and out the half moon on the holding clip, and are joined flat, wires. You can split them from each other as needed You must fasten them to the mounting area or hide them somehow, and fasten them into part 1 of the power supply. There are two rows of holes to accept the wires, total number of pucks it will support, 6. That part has a joined double wire that goes to a plug with clip, that will clip onto a second clip (the mate to the first one, on the 2 prong wall socket type plug in). It has wart-itis, it will take up space. Both of those wires have some yardage, you can wire the top of an installed bookcase flanking an entertainment center and run wiring all the way down and behind to where the other electronics plug in, easily.Quality of materials, I'd give it a 5. No instructions on the website for the manufacturer either (I expected no documentation as it was a scratchNdent repack) so I took a star for that.  Above the average plugNplay install, part of the reason for that missing star. There was some surface scratching to one of the pucks but it didn't matter because of where I installed them, that was not an issue for me. Over all they are very nice looking and classy, much better than the plastic xenon and LED pucks I've installed before.I installed these undercabinent, so cut a piece of plywood to fit on the bottom shelf on top the bottom shelf proper, this gave me plenty to screw into from the bottom and no points sticking through, then I covered it with shelf paper and that part of the install isn't visible.  They have no on-off, I plugged them into a switched outlet. Warm white is okay, it's over a cooking counter surface, they do make daylight white, and that would have been my first choice. Price was very good, I was able to handle the extra work being a veteran of installing puck lights into/onto various things.

This is the dark grey version of the lightly grey tinted ones I'm addicted to as driving glasses. These will do the job, if you want dark sunglasses. If you have had eye laser surgery or your eyes dilated by the eye doctor, these are a good choice for wearing afterwards. They curve around to fit fairly closely, yet give you a good range of vision, they are lightweight so they sit well on the face, and they are also Z87 rated safety glasses. If you are working in the yard or something like that, they can protect your eyes. They are fairly inexpensive here on Amazon, I usually put a few pairs on an order just so I have some on hand. Well worth the money and I highly recommend them...

Lightweight, curve around so a closer fit, and a very light even grey tinting. This are excellent driving glasses as they will cut the glare but allow you to see clearly on whatever you're doing, whether it is driving or working outside. If you have had eye laser surgery and need to wear sunglasses afterwards this is a choice... they do keep the moisture near your eyes and protect them as well. They can scratch up but they are so inexpensive through Amazon, that you can easily buy a few pairs and keep the best ones for driving. I have been wearing this style for years and swear by them. There are also darker grey ones if you need true sunglare cutting, and totally clear ones. I prefer the light even grey tint of these, as said, they are excellent glare cutters. They are also Z87 Safety Glasses, which is great! when you're doing yardwork. I tend to put a few pair on as addons to an order during the year so I always have some around.

My better half is changing sizes and dimensions, (going down) and the weave allows him to 'make a hole' where he needs it. It has been holding up except the buckle loop and tongue sort of pulled out, he gently bent it back into shape with a pliers. Since that (right at the start) the belt has been holding up ... I will recommend it for the ability to pick where you need the 'hole' for the tongue, making an exact fit (and if you ate a little too much for supper you can make it looser without having to punch a new hole)

The bowl of the spoon is very small, but. The handle is very sturdy and it is a solid feeling spoon. It has cleaned up very well and reaches to the bottom of the smoothie glasses my better half uses, which was the main issue with most other spoons. It is holding up well. It works well on my iced tea also to get to the bottom and corners of the glass to get the sweetner mixed in. It should last for many years, I recommend it as it is not at all flimsy, well worth the price.

It is copper, it is very well made. I purchased it for the shape it makes-1930s and 40s vintage small farm tractor. The price is why I gave four stars instead of five, but. I do hope it will last. It cleaned up well after I used it, and works for biscuits, rolled sugar cookies and cutting lunchmeat/cheese type sandwiches.

Not John Deere Green. Not an extinct green that I have no idea what the original name was. The swatch shown on my monitor is not close to the color but it's not a light green and it's not a dark green. It has a little different twist and appearance than Super Saver. I purchased this to match part of a very old skein of Super Saver that doesn't have the band and this isn't it.Overall though Red Heart Yarn is the one I've used for most of my projects of the last 40 odd years. It has rebounded from that fiasco of the one supplier folding doors and the replacement and some of the icky dye feelings. Classic though seems to be a little thinner and a different twist than Super Saver. I still gave it five stars because it's a good yarn and I will use it for a project. Not their fault it didn't get close to a yarn made in probably the 70's or 80's.

I liked that the outlet plug and the socket to plug in your light are in line so easier to put your light in without certain issues when trying to assemble some setups. You can plug this in to the top outlet of a two outlet wall unit and still be able to use the bottom one if you don't have a fat plug for the second one. This one rode through a power out with no issues other than I had to reset the present time on it afterwards. It is fairly quiet so far, I will update if it changes. If you are using a power strip, this can stick out on the sides and you may lose a plug to plug it in as the top will cover one outlet, but. I can use pressure once IT is plugged in to plug in my cord, without rocking the prongs of the timer OUT of the socket. Also this one is a straight out cord not a from the side cord angle, if that is what you prefer in the situation this one is perfect.

Was glad to find these, they are perfect for adding to broth or soup to give it a little more body. It cooks very fast (4 min) so you can enjoy them very quickly. If you are needing Gluten Free and/or salt free, these can help you replicate the 'soup mix in a packet' stuff without much hassle, and also be able then to control spices and salt. Five boxes will pour into a half gallon sealable container. Six boxes will last for far longer than you think. They are a great product, and I was glad to find these on Amazon.

Gluten allergy--gluten free <check>Vegan--animal free, dairy free, egg free <check>Good Tasting <check>Easy to use <check>GMO free <check>No nuts <check>I switched from Bob Mill's TVP because that is processed with hexanes. This isn't. It has a wee bit of 'fat' that the other doesn't but it doesn't seem to be affecting my cholesterol numbers or weight...I do think it tastes better, gets 'tender' faster (reconstitutes easier) and is a little less off feeling in the mouth (texture) than the TVP. I measure it with a 1/8 cup stainless coffee scoop, and consider 2 heaping scoops a daily serving of protein. Heat 1/4 cup of water to boiling, add a teaspoon of your boullion if you want to flavor it (1/2 to 1 teaspoon) then after that dissolves put in the TSP and let soak for a few minutes. Or add right into your soup or stew at the end of cooking. These are about twice the price of TVP but I think they are much better for me, and a 4 pack runs about two months at that size serving for one. The individual bags are a bit bigger than a similar bag of TVP as well. One will fit nicely poured into a 1/2 gallon sealed container.  Subscribe and it is cheaper, I like that. The hard part is to figure out how much and how often to set up your subscription for.They have also made good pizza toppings and taco and burrito filler. For pizza I will reconstitute and sprinkle across the pizza right after the sauce and before other toppings, so it's in there being a 'meat' layer. I have not found a binder that will keep it in burger or meatball form that I can eat (the binder) so I treat this as a loose ground meat fake. It will be a very light colored loose ground meat fake, is a drawback if you are really trying to fake 'meat'. As a 'protein source' instead, it's wonderful.

Bought two, a few months apart, as we ended up with two phones in the family. The design changed slightly from the one bought late November 2014 to the one bought mid January 2015. When your order arrives Tech Armor sends you an email link to a youtube video on how to install their product, as they want you to be totally happy and do the install right. (our phones were delayed in arrival so had product before phones) I took the protectors in and during setup, installed them--before anyone touched the screens. The phones come with a cling wrap that totally goes around it, I peeled this after a hand washing and followed the directions, using the wipe and the little cloth then floating the glass from the top down as it showed. It literally melted on. The November one after the X made with finger literally melted into place, no funny spots or bubbles. The January one took a little more convincing but my thumbs easily shoved the slight bubbleation totally off. Afterwards they looked factory installed or the phones came that way. There are two versions offered, a PET plastic and a Ballistic Glass, I always prefer hardened glass, and saying that, they look great. There is an edge there that can catch glurp so be very careful if you have to clean along there. I have a feeling the protector will last for the life of the contract without any problems. No issues with tactile transfer either, it 'listens and obeys' when I touch the screen. If you do a search the cheaper one is the PET plastic, the more expensive is the glass. Go glass.It comes with a small microfiber cloth, a squeegee plastic tool, a packet with a sealed cleaning towelette that's premoistened, a pamphlet with how to do this, and the protector in a sleeve with a peeltab for you to get the adhesive covering plastic off. And Tech Armor sent me the email with the video link twice, once each purchase (got email through Amazon) so that you can view the install video. Totally happy.

Excellent. Hardened tip that grips. I got stuck using this in a space on a #2 as this was the only thing I had that fit. Serious transfer of torque from your hand through the handle, it powered right through. Wish I had a #2 that performs in this way... I am going to look into other Klein drivers.Worth the money, and worth adding to your toolbox.

Was referred to as an alternate for a Defender Ottercase, as the latter has an issue with the screen protector window sitting above the screen surface. This one does require you to add a screen protector, I paired it with the Tech Armor HD ballistic glass. It is NOT waterproof. It CAN stand being dumped a few times in a row onto the paved parking lot just fine. It is good to grip, I have long fingers so the 6 plus is not too hard to hold, and this case is easy to hang onto. It feels solid, it is lightweight for what it is. I feel like I have a comfortable secure grip hanging onto it. It is not difficult to remove either (so I can use my backplate-attach tele/micro lens set) for dedicated camera work. Only drawback is the little easel leg, but just making sure it is in the right place when installing the phone and it sits and folds/unfolds correctly. Enough to mention, not enough to drop a star for. The combo of protector and this case came to about half of the Ottercase as well, so I am very happy with the purchase. I only wish there was an option for a safety orange or bright lime green or hot pink color, as I like high visibility cases. The blue is sleek though, and nice enough finish off for more elegant settings. I did get a waterproof bag type protector for if I think I'm going to be in wetness, to slide this into, it fits well in that. It is not a belt holster type case... but it does have the included easel standup leg for setting on tabletop or desk. Controls and ports are get-to-able, even the home button. A definite recommend.Update, we recently got another phone in family, and purchased the Spigen 110xx case for that one, this is the 109xx... the last two digits are a color. This one has more angular contours, the 110 is more rounded. The small handed person likes the angles on the 109 better, it gives more to grip. The 110 for the person with the large hands feels more comfortable, they have plenty of grip as well. Both make the phones feel more substantial and sturdy without being HEAVY. Both cases went on similarly and both were very easy to put on. Do follow the instructions, peel the black rubbery part out, put that on the phone first, then make sure the easel leg is in place then snap the hard part on, side to side. With the Space Grey, the black front with the black rubbery edge looks sleek. With the Silver or Gold, the black rubbery edge puts the white face trim into high contrast. Either looks good.

Well made and grips the slots well. I am happy I added this to my toolbox.  I can also get some good torque going, the handle though slim is surprisingly good to grip. Well made tool. The tip didn't immediately tear up either, a cheaply made screwdriver will do that; this one looks like it is durable and will last.

Thank you for delivering me. I am gluten intolerant and massively miss BREAD. I've already tried one of these recipes and I love how the master recipes can be adapted for other ways of cooking/baking and quantity also. I will be dedicating much time in the near future to exploring this!Gluten free tends to go stale quickly, but the fact I can bake up a small amount and be able to consume it in a meal or two is wonderful.Thank you, I was a bread-aholic and that has been one of the worst bits about the diet change. If you are in the same circumstances, get this book. I'm not regretting my buying it after just one day/recipe.  I will update as I work on the recipes in here.*edit* I see I'm getting dinged as this isn't helpful?????C'mon. Bread and pasta withdrawal when I hit having to go gluten-free has been no fun at all.Others say the pictures are B&W? So, at least there's pictures. Some of my mother's and grandmother's cookbooks had NO pictures. And some of the older ones I collect, they don't even tell you precisely how to make something. They EXPECT you to be well versed then just follow a few sentences or a paragraph of description and make it turn out (my best hollandaise recipe came from a reprint 1904 Gold Medal Flour cookbook and after a few trials and errors; I now can make that (and now it's for others)superbly) This book doesn't expect you to have to do that; they tell you how.I like rather than having to buy expensive mixes in a box; I can mix up some DIY mix, then dip into that and make it into bread when I want to. Yes you have to do the prep of mixing up your own mix; and store that. After that, this is the great way to make bread again. I've had many doughy fake-o gritty as if the litterbox got dumped in there fiasco hockeypuck bricks that yield coasters instead of real slices of b-r-e-a-d. This has been allowing me to get something that actually looks like bread, smells like bread, tastes like bread, and has texture I expect. I can even feed it to my spouse without complaints, who can have gluten.This has been a wonderful addition to my growing shelf of cookbooks as I deal with no gluten, no salt, no cholesterol and diabetic. This DOES mean I have to actually go back to say the era when I learned to cook and actually COOK every day. At least this cookbook is allowing me to once more have bread. Without having to be a chef level cook. Without having to have cooked for a good 40 years already.This has been worth my money. It's still 5 stars plus.

I developed gluten allergy, and it is amazing how little it takes to cause a reaction. Trust me this is no fun. I WAS buying my TVP from a health food store that had on the bags a warning about non-dedicated facility, so they couldn't guarantee no cross contamination. Batches/bags from them was a crapshoot and you'd run across a 'cursed' batch more often than not. This brand is made in a dedicated facility, no chance of cross contamination. If you are gluten-intolerant this is VERY IMPORTANT.These are store retail bags, packaged in their shelf/display box; one box holds 4 bags. I liked the extra security the box gave the product during shipment.The quality is very good, it readily rehydrates, good texture and mouth feel; and even better, no tossing the proverbial coin about being 'cursed' after eating. It is very much worth buying my protein this way; I count on TVP to make my gluten free foods better; and add the protein I need. TVP rehydrated with boullion, will take on that flavor (go 2x amount of boullion) and makes a wonderful pizza topping!  I also find it good to add a few spoonfuls to soup to thicken the broth and replace the need for crackers; and again, add the protein. This has about three times the protein of lean meat, and no cholesterol. You do have to count it as a carb though.TVP is like mushrooms, it will very readily pick up a flavor. This can work to your advantage in many ways.If you have to turn to TVP as part of your diet, this is a good product to depend on and a good way to buy it in bulk. Further handiness is the display box is a good way to store the bags in your pantry.

I got this through Amazon Warehouse scratchNdent so it is not a true reflection on the regular seller, who is downunder-us.Another friend purchased two of these spring of 2013 and uses them in a 7x11' greenhouse attached to his garage to make his orchids bloom. It does give off mostly red light, which encourages plants to bloom; and uses it in the hour after sunrise and hour before sunset to supplement the natural light. I will say it works well for him. I am building a walipini greenhouse, screen growing house (frame with shadecloth) and a rearing area so I can do intermittent mist and various other ways of starting and bringing my plants from seed, cutting, or graft into a full marketsized plant...for my own use (two acres means I need a lot of plants year round!) I will update this review as I work with this light in my setup.The unit is about the size of a Frisbee but the depth of a pet food dish, and weighs a few solid pounds. The casing is powdercoat metal, a nice solid feel to it. Attached to the back by clips is a trio of coated woven fiber (thin, reminds me of picture framing stuff) attached to a hang hook, it drops about a foot. Attached to that is a moderate length (about 6') black rubberized round cord with 3 prong plug.  The unit has 'plugged in-it's on' to 'unplug-it's off'. It would be easy to plug it into a timer to be switched on and off. There are three small fans and three outlet grilles in the top. LED's can run very warm, so it doesn't surprise me about the venting. It will be very important to keep direct drip/condensation drip off this unit, out of afternoon sun if in use; and keep the top and sides of unit clear to allow good air circulation. I would not suggest hanging from the top part of a greenhouse shell where the heat gathers.I have a light meter coming any time now, I want to test light output. Friend says he has it at 3-4' above the top of his orchids, and two cover his 7x11' space with enough useable output for the plants. The lumens will drop off some over time but being LED should last several years still putting out at least 70% by the end. Most of the LED's are putting out reds, threre are a few blues, which are 'growth' spectrum. Red encouraged blooming. If you are starting and growing seedlings you want blue end (cool white at minimum; or a majority blue-LED light, not a mostly red-LED like this)The condition of the item was accurately described; it had a scratch across the LED protective lens and the metal case; in the back it had a dent into one of the vent fan areas on the grille. It was wrapped well in bubble wrap, no other packaging. The scratching in front is cosmetic; the back I was able to use a thin flat bladed screw driver and bend the grill out to a satisfactory 'flat' to allow the fan behind it to run properly. It does come on when plugged in; and not something you a person wants to look at for long times. I will suggest using UV blocking sunglasses or safety glasses if you have to work around it while on.I am sure that the retailer does provide quality product, this WAS through Amazon Warehouse Deals and was an 'as is' item that was damaged so it was discounted. I have bought many things through Amazon Warehouse Deals and this was about the 'worst' I have encountered so far; but the condition was pretty accurately described so I bought informed.

I got this used at a steep discount, so in that sense I got what I paid for (and why I gave it three stars, had I paid full price it would have been two). Not enough detail, not enough information. The cover art is somewhat misleading. My advice is to keep looking, this book is not going to be an asset to your wood and metal working library.

Had one beat up and rusted cap on one of my B&S, this was a perfect fit and replacement. It's not painted but the chrome color still goes well with the engine colors. I like resurrecting/repairing old small motors then finding a use for them; it was good to be able to get a replacement that fit. This is somewhat of a universal stock size, that will fit several different engines. Cost is good, shipping is reasonable and merchant is great, also.

A friend got the ebook then showed it to me and asked my advice.I told them to go see if they can get refunded NOW.I don't know who the happy camper is with a 5 star review, they must be one ... naÔve person.It's sort of pseudo hydroponics and not very good instructions.Buy Square Foot Gardening, or anything else other than this one.  I have nearly 50 years gardening experience, you will get much better information and results with SFG.The dings mean I'm revisiting this one.The poorly written phamphlet ebook is about 'set up some hydroponics' to achieve this grow lots in small amount of space. However the instructions are not very clear, very comprehensive and in general are not worth spending ANYTHING on. Seeing five star reviews I think they are huckstering this to try to get people to buy it; and you should go elsewhere. Just do an online search for hydroponics DIY and you will find a lot of FREE information.Another editThe person who bought this and showed it to me, was given a link to download their product... and had a good 90 minutes of other huckster hardsell commercials to go through before they finally were given the link to download what they'd ordered. For other publications, and other merchandise that this person was selling. Then they get 22 pages of poorly written and a few bad illustrations... for their money.Some of the 5 stars look like friend and family glowing reviews added to try to push the rating of this UP so people will buy it. Do NOT.As I have said and in comments below; do a free search on 'hydroponics DIY' in any search engine and you will get a lot of better and free information to do the same thing. I wish that Amazon would allow zero-star ratings.

I miss my trackwheel.This mouse is LARGE. My hands are small with long fingers and it does fit my hand fairly well. You do NOT have to move the mouse, it sits still on the desktop, you use the ball and the buttons to move stuff about to do what you need to.The red ball stays in if you turn the mouse upside down. No missing ball.It is very responsive, and very precise. If you are scrolling up and down through pages of text, you have to do it by rolling the ball and trackwheel is much faster. If you are doing graphics editing, it is very nimble to roll about (this is what I got it for).I have hand and finger nerve damage, this did help spread some of the stress on my fingers, thumb, and wrist around, which is another plus. I gave it four stars only because I was a trackwheel addict; and at times I can lose the cursor on screen and have to do some frantic roll-back-and-forth to see where the cursor got to again.I do like that I no longer need the full mousepad space, just getting it situated though where it can stay put can be more difficult sometimes. I can also push it into the edge of my laptop sometimes by accident and depress a side key which can cause problems.I consider it a specialized mouse, for graphics crunching, editing and some gaming it may be perfect. I am happy with it and it is mostly doing everything it should and what I need. Your first finger still moves a lot but it's no longer doing the clicking (I use first and second fingers to roll the ball), the thumb does most of the clicking, ring finger or little finger usually gets to do the rightclick...it does take the stressing mostly off your wrist.I thought the secondary buttons would be more of a problem but I rarely have that issue. They are programmable for mostly gaming purposes....I have not tried that.

I had to go gluten-free. I also have other dietary constraints and having that one heaped on top really made it horrid... no COMFORT FOOD.  Going through several brands of non-wheat pasta, including rice only, quinoa and/or amaranth based, and a couple of corn and rice based; Barilla does it right.Product LOOKS right. It has a fair shade of yellow that does look like durum-wheat based pasta.Cooking... it doesn't want to stick to the bottom of the pot right away and keep sticking; it doesn't toss up a sort of sticky film in the middle of the pot on the water; and the water doesn't turn into a sort of gelatinous glue. When you drain this you drain 'water' off. It also cooks in about the same amount of time as the Barilla wheat-pasta.Texture. It feels like, yes it chews like, wheat-pasta.Only downside is do NOT overcook, drain it right away. It does sometimes give you a hint of a taste of 'canned corn' but it is not bad at all. The rice-only stuff is very pale, sticks onto the pot while cooking and doesn't chew right. Quinoa and/or amaranth is the really gluey stuff (often has corn in it too) and chews 'gritty' (leftover in fridge for a few hours does get a little less gritty feeling).Out of all the 'fake food' I have had to learn to like; this is a very good substitute. It is made in dedicated gluten free space with dedicated machinery, aka no cross-contamination. I can at least have my pasta, my comfort food; just have to watch the carbs. My spouse who doesn't have the diet restrictions tried this and gave it five tines up too, this one tastes good.

I was glad to find this, especially in a smaller quantity... a tube, not a can.  A little goes a long ways; and for working on small engines, this is close to a lifetime supply if you're just keeping a few lawn mowers going. It works very well, an excellent product.

I had this same set under a different brand name, for a few decades, and they have been lost or died. I got these as a replacement. To be fair, I needed one with smaller tips.Recently when I needed to change the wheel drive on a self propelled mower the tips were too weak to remove the snap ring. They are hard to use where a good quality tool makes the job easy. I will rate them as okay for light duty, but I am once again shopping for a better quality set.

This was originally a proprietary private press book sold with a dog training system and franchising. In 2000 we adopted a puppy and the neighbor across the street had set up to give training lessons with this system... we liked it because it is all positive feedback and our dog turned into a well mannered all around good doggie citizen. (Keeshond, can be a little stubborn... :) )We lost the papers the trainer had given us; and it was wonderful we were able to find this book off the secondary market. Franchises originally sold for $15,000 I'm told; so this is indeed a deal to get off the used market. The method takes some patience, and investment in time with your dog, but it most certainly WORKS.As the other reviewers have commented, the 'silly little rectangle' was indeed very silly, but. It Works.We had a good dog, that sat at doorways, didn't immediately bolt for freedom the split second she seen an open gate or door. Some breeds are more likely to want to do that; bolt at any chance; but. I can't say enough good things. It is like any training method though; you have to be consistent, follow through, and dedicate some time to turning your dog into a good doggie citizen.

I have not used it yet so I gave it 4 stars because I was forced to give it some number of stars. It seems to be good well made material...The dimensions given in the description are incorrect.According to other sources on the web the correct dimensions are 12" x 28" x 1/16"

This is one of the smaller colocasias, and it is lovely, but. It is a little more delicate and gorgeous, well worth the effort.I killed my first one so I went back and got three more; and gave each one a little different environment trying to get something to survive.It is a 'wet toes'. I put it in a deep 8" recycled nursery pot, and it sits in a catchpan about 3" deep and a few inches larger in diameter, and I keep about 1" of water in the bottom of the catchpan. It can mostly then have roots out of the soggy zone but it has all the water it wants then.This is a temperature loving colo, in that it really hates seeing night temperatures near or below 50f. 70 or so is more to it's liking. It likes lots of filtered sun, I had put it under 60% shadecloth outside when the weather permitted and it grew well.The leaves, mine topped out at about 8" long, and the plant in pot is about 3-4.5' tall, closer to 3'. When perfectly happy I had 7-8 leaves, most of the time it's around 5-6, and the life expectancy of a leaf isn't as much as some other colos.  The one I grew in the house did fairly well, kept leaves more at 4-5" and a few feet tall in a 6" pot. I would suggest an 8". I also found it likes to 'eat' and suggest a mild kelp based fertilizer, a few cups properly mixed weekly. It is a beautiful plant; well worth it, but. It seemed to like low 70s for the night and no more than mid 90's for the day, and lots of light but filtered and it needs wind protection. It did okay as a houseplant. If your night temps are dipping towards 50, it needs to come in, if you get anything below 50f, it will not like it.If you want a big showy colocasia look at a Thai Giant. This is not a BIG plant. It is beautiful, to me, worth the bit of extra effort. If you want one make sure that you order during the season you are not having freezing temperatures; if it gets too cold in shipping it will die. When you get it unpack it and repot into a larger pot immediately, good soilless mix, put in a warm place with bright but not direct light for several hours a day and bottom water it. As long as the growing shoot is not badly damaged (the leaves form along the last leaf's stalk then separate and unfurl) it should come around.Update 2/5/14, adding a picture taken about a week ago, of a mojito leaf in my greenhouse. From tip of finger to wrist bend wrinkle my hand is 7" long, for comparison. The pot is sitting in about 1.5" of water with 3.5" out. Plant in pot is about 3' high.

Long story about the Ariens RM1332 riding mower I acquired; then coaxed into working. The key broke off in the slot, adding to my woes, and it was nice to find this and it fit perfectly, for about half the price of one from Ariens, plus I have two that fit for half the price of the Ariens branded one.

That was my biggest surprise, US made. It is a heavy and well made tool, it made extracting the valves from one of the B&S (older 3 hp) engines I'm working on a breeze. Well worth the price and the wait to get it. Sometimes it is well worth getting the right tool and this was just the thing. It came in a black box marked Zim (registered) specialty tools, valve spring compressor #131 and a little sticker that says Stens and #750-174; it is the item as otherwise described.

Roses lack a particular color gene period, they can not produce blue. I am a 'bit busting pixel jockey' aka my job is to fix digital photography into looking good. This picture has been obviously retinted, probably a white to begin with.Most 'blues' are a lavender rose... they geneticially inserted a blue producing gene and did some other stuff to a rose type and got another lavender they are touting as 'blue' , the "Applause". They could not succeed in totally turning off a red producing gene and there is a compatibility issue with the blue (pansy) gene they inserted so it is still a lavender rose. The florist supplied 'blues' are either food dye tinted (white buds put in strongly blue dyed water) or airbrushed or spraypainted to give a blue tipped blush.Roses are very hard to grow from seed, and unless the pollination was totally controlled (bagged blooms and hand pollenating) you have no idea what the genes are in the seed proper. IF you know what you're doing, and it is a long process of cold dormancy and scarification then some pretty precise germination conditions; you can get maybe 20% germ. Maybe. One in five chance. Maybe.  And that is if the seed was handled properly from harvest onwards. Expect especially with 5 seeds you're going to get a zero return.Save your money and your headache. Roses are best propagated as cane divisions, budding to rootstock, or air layered to produce own root based plants.  Something this rarified would probably have to be put to rootstock and probably have a high failure rate... then like Sterling Silver, a real careful 3-5 years to get it established enough to survive. A Sterling Silver is about 40% likely to make the first three years... save your money, keep going.

After a shocking incident many years ago, I insist on 'solid' taps if I have to use a splitter.  With my ponding, watergardening, aquarium work, greenhouse, and plant work it seemed that it took a minimum of two 3way ganged together to get enough taps for that set of lights, water and air pumps, etc. And they always wanted to come apart, in the middle.This is a little overkill but... it doesn't come apart between. You can lock the incoming cord in (I can lock a 12/3 in easy) and if you need to you can lock ONE outgoing cord. Else it gives you five taps and there's no issue of 2 3's deciding to part enough to be a hazard in the middle. It's overall more water resistant than a power strip, and with the extension feeding this on a GFCI circuit, I can be safe in my work. It is a bit heavy, even before you plug things into it, but I am very happy with this purchase.I do NOT recommend running several power tools off this at once; anything with a serious amp draw should have it's own adequately rated single line. If you are running several fluorescent light fixtures, or similar, it is great.

This originally started as dog training franchises and were on the order of $15,000.... this is the self published book that outlined the method of no punishment/no harm dog training. A neighbor had gotten into a franchise and we had gotten a keeshond; they can be a bit on the bratty and stubborn side. We liked the lesson system as it didn't make the dog fearful; but an obedient and well mannered doggyperson who was a good dog and part of our family. We lost the lesson material we were given as part of the training several years ago; the dog has passed on, and we wanted to get another dog... and train the new one the same way. Trust me, getting this book off the used market was a great find!Having a dog that would sit on command even when there was someone at the door, didn't bolt through an open door or gate at any opportunity, and was boundary trained; was well worth it. I will say though that with any dog training method, sometimes the owner and family also need to be trained... and have to stay consistent!  Still this is the best training method I've found and the results were well worth the hunt to get a copy of this book. (I don't think you'll ever get a keeshond to HEEL but you can get them to walk without pulling you along or jerking you all over)

It said pocketed, there weren't any. I had to add some. If I hadn't gotten them on a sale price it would have been very disappointing. Because of the size one can't always be choosy. I gave them four because they are generally holding up and haven't pilled out after four passes through wear/wash... but I was surprised about no pockets.

This is a good priced basic hobby set. I use and abuse exacto knives and have trashed my share of handles. Some of the different blade shapes are nice, good sampler assortment. Decent value for the price.

If you need cleaning brushes this size, this is a good set to invest in. I like the ring to keep the set together, harder to lose one brush that way, and easier to hang up to prevent them from being mangled.
This fits my holder with the tap and die set I have. 5-40 is not a common size and pitch combo, usually stuff is 4-40 or 6-32. I was glad to find this as I needed this size, and it works well.

This fits the handle of the set of tap and dies I have... it is well made and easy enough to use. The 5 and 40pitch is not a common size either, a lot of things are either 4-40 or 6-32. I was glad to find this at a reasonable price.

These are a tropical plant. Colocasia like 'wet toes' and are 'voracious eaters'.  The picture with the fellow standing in it is possible, but I will say mine is potted and is more like 2-3' plus long leaves, held vertically, a few splay over.  I have seen ones that big with lots of compost and in a gulf/tropical climate (over about a 10a).The blooms as shown are about 4" long, don't really smell much, and last a few days then flop and take about a week to being ready to harvest.  The one I got I started from a softball sized corm; it is currently in a 16" pot and stands about 7' high. It keeps 4-5 leaves at all times and the leaves last for some months. It has put on a side shoot that's about 2' tall and I need to divide it. It also bloomed and I harvested the berries after the bloom fell over; squished to pip out 1-2 seeds each and immediately planted them into moist soilless mix then covered them for humidity. They sprouted, I got 13 of 17... and are currently in 6" pots and 8-12" high. (the pulp and that are somewhat toxic, make sure pets and kids can't get into either)Colos like it wet usually, though I found the established plant doesn't want to stand in water. I water by putting 2" in the catch saucer every 3 days or so and a cup or so dumped on top the soil, it then sucks up the water happily. I fertilize every third time with two cups of humic soluable fertilizer mix, mixed up and shook before measuring.  I have seen pictures of leaves fully 6 1/2' long and 5' wide, they planted it directly in a finished compost pile. Mine spent the summer in a shade cloth growing house outside with night getting down to 50-65 and day going 85-100 under 60% shade, and loved it. It got some wind but it was mostly sheltered and the screen house helped diffuse the wind as well. It is now in greenhouse space for the winter-spouse is allergic-no houseplants allowed any more.These plants will briefly and infrequently tolerate upper 40's but by then I moved it inside.  Can get these little black aphidy looking things about flyspeck size, easily cleaned by hand (yes, mush with your fingers or take a damp paper towel and wipe the stems off). Holes or breaks/damage to the leaves can draw mealybugs right at the damage spot!  Because of the temperature, I wouldn't order this until you are seeing your night-times in the upper 40's to low 50's pretty reliably and when you start seeing cold spiking into 40s at night in the fall, again don't order.I consider this a very fair weather plant; instead of letting it go dormant I am keeping it as a year round plant; and it does have an issue of SIZE. Other than that I have had much fussier houseplants. After one year I now have them coming out of my... and the coming year definitely plan to add them to my landscape in shady wind protected places (we have issues with heat, low humidity, brutal sun, and lots of wind) and will continue to grow them as a cool plant. The leaves are BIG, distinctive, held mostly upright and make a great statement. Compared to my other Taro, this has the biggest flattest leaves, and the sturdiest stalks.When you get one of these, they should be immediately potted up into a 6" or 8" pot and held in bright light and at least 70f if you can manage it (at night too) for a few weeks (no direct sun unless within 3 hours of sundown), don't let it get over about 85f; and let it recover from shipping. Bottom water every few days; if you get tips of the oldest leaves going brown/dead/crispy it's too dry!  Aim for nicely moist without soggy.  Then if you're putting it outside start hardening it off for a few weeks. Suggest a shady spot with wind protection and good drainage. As it gets bigger each new leaf will get larger than the last, and it quickly goes to looking like the picture!I love Thai Giant, it looks so tropical and lovely, it's worth the bit of extra work to me.2/5/14 adding a slightly blurred but good picture of relative size of my winter leaves. Plant is in 14" pot and stands over my head in pot; always has 4-5 leaves flat and out; and it has a baby about 2' tall that needs to be divided off. The seeds, I got 13/17 to germ and lost a few along the way, all the babies are in 6" pots and some are making a foot tall now and biggest leaf is about 3-4' long (8 made it to quarter size leaves and strongly 4" tall), in 5 months. By May they should be in 8-10" pots and tall enough to be adopted out, by fall they should be nearing adult size.

It is extremely well made, sturdy, and with a little care will be a lifetime tool. Just that when I ordered it I thought was longer.  I don't regret what I spent; but for outside on-maneuvers I bought a 2' plastic $10 one to take the really rough stuff. This is an 'indoor shop tool'.  I'm told this one is sold under a different  brand name for a good deal more.... It is worth what I paid for it, definitely.

Nicely powdercoated, cuts into turf well, if....We have literally adobe topped with Bermuda grass; to use this we have to water well, and sometimes when the point hits 'hard', back off, pour water into the hole, mark it... come back a time or two, refill... then redrill. and may have to repeat a few times.This is not a heavy duty hack it all drill point for feeding the tree roots... if you do not have hardpack heavy clay or caliche, this is a great tool. In a corded drill it will walk down into a few feet of dirt that's not dry dry or the heavy hard stuff.Do be warned that it is indeed not a professional level hard hitting tool; it is a good homeowner/weekend warrior level; well made for what it is; and I like the powdercoating as dirt and such doesn't stick to it as easily; making for an easier bore.For the price it has been worth it, for most gardeners and homeowners it will be just fine. Cordless rechargables won't have the oomph needed though, run a cord from a GFI and use a corded drill on this.

Rarely does a woodworker need or go through a gallon of wood glue with a project or two. It may seem cheap to buy a gallon but if you don't use it before it goes south; it's a waste.This may be a little small for some projects but it is a good sized bottle. And I have when planning to go on a major binge of work; bought a gallon and refilled this size container as needed.It will get 'crusted over' with time and need replacing now and  again, but I can easily pour three gallons through one of these before I decide on 'replace the squeezy bottle'.That being said, Titebond II is a glue I turn to for a lot of things. I have used it for craft as well as wood; especially in making padded upholstered display panels. (smear onto plywood, lay 1/2 to 1" closed cell foam over it, put another piece of luan and a few carefully spaced concrete blocks to dry overnight...) It will adhere the foam to the backer board, to then be covered. I have also glued upholstery fabrics to the top of said foam with it, leave about 4" unglued of the foam around the edge, then tuck fabric into place, glue, recover and reweight for the night; and it will turn out well. Test bleed, it can bleed through and make stiff.I go though a lot of Titebond II, the other is the polyurethane 'foaming' glues that are water activated. This is a good size unless you are after a large project, in which case buy a larger jug and use one of this size as a handleable 'field squeeze' bottle.  This is a definite go-to glue for me, and in the ways I do wood and other projects, a glue I reach for. Do keep it from freezing!

Doing a shop space remodel and had some restrictions about the thickness of the fixture and how far it stuck down from the surface it was mounted on. This was a rather slim 'mount on surface' versus cutting holes and doing a full recess.  The plastic cover is not the easiest to get on or off; it ages (yellows), it collects bugs.  It sort of looks like an oversized cheap pullbehind camper interior light.  That said, it does fit where we needed to give some light for passing through that area. I would not put this into a major renovation.  For the price, it is doing what it needs to. I am satisfied with what I paid for this unit and it is doing the job expected. It IS fluorescent, and I have the rest of my house and shop where possible using fluorescent or CFL, and this does give an adequate amount of bright, I wouldn't call it 150 watt but it is 90-100 watt incandescent.

Had a five year old machine with only two USB ports and needed a few more. This was easy to install and has been working well to add the extra ports I needed in-machine versus a small stick out front dongle type one that never seemed to connect well (like an extension cord splitter, it had three at the end of it, plug into one slot and it was supposed to give you a few more). This in-system one has been more reliable.

I did an upgrade of a friend's much older system, and this was exactly what I needed to graft a new harddrive onto the older system. It came as a reverseable configuration, so it could be an older style drive to a newer system as well. A year later when the older system gave it up, I recycled this part to put the older drive into a newer system  (I could move the newer drive directly).  The demand for something like this and the supply of this sort of adapter may be going down; so if you ever think you might need one, get one before they're gone. This adapter worked well, was easy enough to install, and did the job. The instructions/youtube also were more for grafting an older drive onto newer system, but you can do the reverse as well.

The blank roll allows you to make your own custom sized bags/pouches. With a little foresight you can make 'longer neck' pouches that can be cleaned and resterilized, and used a few times before the trim-to-open makes them too small to be useable.  They fit the food saver we have just fine, and brought the cost per pouch way down, to where it is affordable (not exactly cheap but) to use the unit.  They will work with a few other units as well.

Spouse insisted and insisted on getting one.  The few times we've used it it has been reliable, quiet, and worked. It's not dead silent, it makes some noises, but compared to a few other brands that sort of make noises, don't do a good suction, and the heating element doesn't do it's job; this one is great. It's not for commercial style packaging; it's very tedious to portion up and freeze individual servings of stuff... but with the laminator you can make any size pouch you want. And it's easy to make a 'long neck' pouch so you can wash, sterilize, and reuse the pouch a few times before the trim-to-open makes it too small and unuseable.  For the price paid it is a good unit.

These are great, and they've gone in and out of availability and it looks like, they went into 'no longer made'. Else why does a box cost $20-25?  My spouse swears by these and we got caught with suddenly, the price went through the ceiling, no searches indicate if they are still being manufactured or not, but. Bring Back Our Chooz!!!!!!!!!  (I even contacted a manufacturer of 'specialty gums' that claimed they made and brand-packaged an antacid gum, to get a bulkpack of similar, say 10k bagged/boxed, and they admitted they didn't make an antacid gum despite what their site said) I really hate it when manufacturers discontinue a product especially one we've known, counted on, and purchased for over twenty years.  If you have reflux, this gum really helped after an 'explosion' that even the prescription meds couldn't keep a lid on... in soothing the afters.

I work on small engines a lot, and refurbishing carbs drove me to get one of these. Been well worth the investment. I have run ammonia, CLR and other baths, and you do have to stay with it and watch your etch-out, but. This has been a dream in getting the gunk off and rehabilitating some of these units. It is a bit of a problem at times to wait for it to warm up the bath enough but, I will fill it, plug it in, go make my lunch and enjoy it, then come out to run the parts through. I work on lawn mowers, larger water pumps (1-3 hp) and similar, and this has been worth the investment for the half dozen or so I've run through the cycle so far; if I don't do anything more with it I have gotten my money out of it. Don't leave your parts unattended; if you have it in unheated areas make sure you empty it if there is a chance something will freeze.  Doesn't take up much shop bench space. The basket is a little funky but a set of cheap metal tongs they make for serving buffet food work well, just rinse them off good after dipping.

It covers where others have successfully grown this sort of stuff, and what you have to do to replicate their success. This is one of the few where the 'look inside' feature gave me enough to make me comfortable in ordering this book.  If you are in grow zones 4-7, you can grow some stuff that is normally say 8 or warmer... not guaranteeing your results, but if you are truly looking to push a few boundaries and grow what you always wanted to, this may indeed help (I grew up in 2a, it's now up to 3a there; and moved southwards and gained altitude the last few moves. We were recently classified as 6b, up a half... and I am within 2 hours drive of full grown palm trees and magnolias, grown with an eye to sheltering and microclime...if they can, *I* can). The idea of growing a palm or palms is definitely something I wish to do; I am currently into Taro (Elephant Ears, Alocasia and Colocasia)... and learned the hard way that a Gunneria will NOT grow here, temperatures go too high in our summer and our sun and wind are just too brutal...(such a cool looking plant too, and they will not survive the winters) ... This is a very good book for pushing your warmer climate plants and making them happy out of their 'normal zone'. I do rate this as not for the totally inexperienced beginner gardener; you should be comfortable with being able to do some garden construction (cold frames, windbreaks, shade cloth), mulching, pest control, compost, and investing some TIME and EFFORT to get what you want. I am a competition grower in a microclime pocket/niche zone; so this book fits right in with what I'm already familiar with... I do heartily recommend this book for the $, if this is what interests you.

We had a past dead sliding screen panel for our patio door.... and with sleuthing it was figured out that the door itself was an Anderson. From them this part (2 in package) was like $40!!!!!  It arrived very promptly, was installed within an hour, and bliss! The door works excellently once again. This seems to be a perfect replacement, it looked identical to the old ones.  No more being locked in or out of house because the old assembly had locked up and the only option was to unship the whole screen from the track to get in or out then replace it. Strongly considering getting another package for the eventuality this one wears out, but. So glad it fits and works.

I went to buying these off the net because most of my craft suppliers tend to be out of them, especially around sales times.  They are working good for cutting lighter craft paper, and vinyls.  If you need to cut heavier things go to the 'deep cut' blades.

I bought off the net because these can be so expensive and at times very hard to find. They work great for cutting thin cardboard stock for making gift boxes and the fancy paper airplane models.  (I have aftermarket software to allow my cricut to cut things that are not in a standard cartridge).  I'd recommend if you need to cut 90-130# cardstock.

It was recommended to me a few years ago by a serious website on various bog and carnivorous plants. I asked them for a good book as I had had fair to poor luck over years (including setting up peat bog terrariums that were watered with distilled water....) and managed to keep something alive for about 8 months.  I finally bought the book and it was well worth it. If you truly want to keep pitchers, sundews and trap plants; this is a good reference. I don't like wasting $ on print reference so if I give it 5 stars it was worth my money.  Hopefully in the spring I will be set up to adopt some specimens and be able to keep them healthy and happy this time.

It's written more for showing you some pictures... reminds me of the 70's era Sunset Books, but. I did get it used and was happy with my purchase of this book.  I rated it according to it's more of a show book than a reference book.  I would not have bought this as a reference/working book...
As the title says, I have a 1970's era Dremel and the chuck was kind of beat up, this was a good replacement. I'm happy with the replacement.

It doesn't like anything in the water to speak of, and the float is...unresponsive. I hook/hang the float in a vertical position when I want to pump water with it.  I got it for moving water when doing pond maintenance (not muck pumping either) and if I had a friend that had one to tell me what they're like I would not have bought this one. I am not buying another one.  I rate it as 'okay' because it does run and water does flow. I don't think I'd count on it in a critical situation (such as a sump)(update 3-30-2014)It is still working; if the water is close to freezing the float cable tends to be stiff and stays that way, it doesn't bend.  I installed it in a 1000 gallon 'water seasoning' tub that is about 4.5' deep when full; in my backyard... and use it to fill/top ponds and tubs as needed. I had to dig through my tote tub of fittings and came up with one for adapting to garden hose. It 'hangs' on the top lip of the tub until needed, then I drop it to the bottom of the tub, plug it in, and the float has a catch cord I added that I can clip to the top lip to keep it 'up'. I also know almost to the minute how long it takes to pump the tank to certain points and will set a timer to remind me to go check it before it hits 'bottom' so I don't run the pump dry.It has lasted far longer than I expected. It pushes water fairly well, I have only asked it to deal with 4-5' of head and it does well with that. I only use it with the 'clean' water, it does not like ANYTHING in it's water; it is no where near a dirty water pump. I've cleaned out the bottom intake and impeller stuff twice, not as much wear as I expected.

We've been talking about buying a safe ever since we moved into our home in 2008.  Everyone needs a place to store important documents (tax forms, social security cards, mortgage information, passports, birth certificates) where they're safe in case of emergencies.  Unfortunately, that was six years ago and like many people, we still hadn't bought a safe.  Enter the SentrySafe SFW205CWB Water Proof Combination Safe, 2X-Large.  Here are my thoughts;Pros+ Ample amount of storage room.  2 cubic feet per the description.+ Provides you with peace of mind knowing that your documents and valuables are secure.+ Varying degrees of internal temperature protection depending on the contents.+ Sturdy construction.+ Can be bolted to the floor.+ Water resistant.Cons- Heavy (that's a good thing) but this makes moving it a 2 person job.- No emergency key lock in case you lose or forget the combination.- Desiccants and periodic airing out of safe is required.- Items can still melt (photos and such) inside if the temperature gets too high.- Dial lock is plastic and feels cheap.We were happy to welcome the SentrySafe SFW205CWB Water Proof Combination Safe, 2X-Large into our home, especially since we had no safe prior.  It has provided us with a secure place to store our valuable documents and belongings as well as setting your mind at ease against threats such as burglars, fire and storm damage.  That being said, the safe isn't exactly perfect.  I don't like not having a back up way of opening the safe in case you misplace or forget the combinations (remedied if you register the safe with SentrySafe).  The safe also won't be able to protect all of your valuables from heat damage.  Finally, like other reviewers have stated, the dial combination is plastic and I'm concerned that it wouldn't survive a fire.  All in all I feel the SentrySafe SFW205CWB Water Proof Combination Safe, 2X-Large  would be a solid investment for those looking to protect their personal valuables from unfortunate circumstances.  I know our home is happy with it.

We spend a lot of time in the kitchen around our house trying different recipes and foods, so we tend to use a lot of different cooking gadgets.  When you find a good one it becomes invaluable.  As we've gotten older eating and drinking healthier has definitely become more of a concern.  Enter the "Big Boss 9358 Multi-Speed Stainless Steel Power Juicer, 800-watt."  Here are my thoughts;Pros+ Rubber grip feet at the bottom help keep the unit stable while juicing.+ Easy way to produce juices and other healthy foods.+ Powerful 800 watt motor makes processing even the toughest foods nearly effortless.+ Instruction manual, although basic is helpful for beginners.+ Effectively removes seeds and other non-edibles.+ Pitcher makes collecting and pouring the juice simple.+ Stainless steel casing.+ 3 year limited warranty.Cons- Plastic parts (all accessories and knob) feel rather flimsy.  I worry about their durability and longevity.- Removable pieces are technically not dishwasher safe and are rather time consuming to clean by hand. The blades/screen may take a bit longer to remove any lodged fibers.- Small pieces of food can still fly out of the pulp bin even when it's properly attached.- Cost of fresh fruit and vegetables for juicing tends to get expensive.- Lackluster instruction booklet.At the end of the day the Big Boss 9358 Multi-Speed Stainless Steel Power Juicer, 800-watt is an effective juicer for the money.  We had no difficulties juicing any of the fruits and vegetables we tried, even the more fibrous ones.  We primarily use it for apple and orange juice often with a bit of cucumber.  If the food costs weren't so expensive we'd probably use it more often.  Clean up is another reason it doesn't get more regular use around our household.  We just find the multiple parts a pain to rinse and clean.  The price of this unit also seems to fluctuate quite a bit.  I've seen it anywhere from $99 (a great deal) to its full list price of $199 (a bit too much).  This is one of those items I'm sure many would love to receive it as a gift and would gladly put it on a wedding registry.  If you're looking to eat/drink more healthy the Big Boss 9358 Multi-Speed Stainless Steel Power Juicer, 800-watt is a nice place to start as it definitely does what it's supposed to.  It was a welcome addition to our household and we'll get many years of use out of it.

My dog is a 65lb English Bulldog/German Shepherd mix that repeatedly suffers from allergies, especially from food. He can also be a bit of a picky eater so finding the right mix can often be difficult. While he loves just about any treat, but I always have reservations about trying new food. Unfortunately, a large majority of popular dog foods today are filled with terrible ingredients not to mention carrying a high price tag. I'm always willing to try a new food so here are my thoughts on Nutrience Natural Healthy Adult Dog Food, 18-Pounds, Seven Fish Medley;Pros+ A nice healthy variety of fish, vegetables, fruit and supplements.+ All ingredients are made in North America (U.S.A. and Canada) which gives me a bit more piece of mind than foods containing ingredients from China.+ Easy to open re-sealable bag with a Velcro strip at the top to help keep food fresh longer.+ Dog loved it and gobbled it up quickly with no fuss.+ No corn, wheat, soy, artificial colors, flavors or preservatives.+ A plethora of healthy and helpful ingredients such as Omega 3 & 6, antioxidants, vitamin C & E, glucosamine and chondroitin.+ My dog had no digestive issues after eating this.Cons- Kibble may be a bit too large for smaller or older dogs.- Velcro reseal on the bag isn't air-tight but it's obviously better than no seal at all.- Limited availability in brick and mortar stores.  As far as I can tell it's sold in Canada and online only at the moment.- Expensive for an 18-pound bag.  If you have larger or multiple dogs the price will get a bit hefty.- Strong fish smell, good for the enticing the dog but not so pleasant wherever you're storing the food.- Not Grain Free.My dog really enjoyed Nutrience Natural Healthy Adult Dog Food, 18-Pounds, Seven Fish Medley.  He was of course extremely excited when I approached with the bag (as he is with every new food) and quickly at the half cup I mixed into his bowl.  His current food is Diamond Naturals Dry Food for Adult Dogs, Large Breed 60+ Chicken Formula, 40 Pound Bag which he enjoys, but after introducing him to Nutrience he seems to prefer it over the Diamond brand.  Currently I'm still mixing the two foods until both are gone at which point I'll most likely switch completely to Nutrience Grain Free Dog Food, 18-Pound, Ocean Fish.  Although the price is a bit high to purchase on a regular basis, I feel the savings will outweigh the cost of unnecessary veterinary visits due to allergies and infections caused by questionable ingredients in other foods.  If you're willing to pay a little extra for your dog's food in hopes of keeping them happy and healthy, then you may want to give Nutrience Natural Healthy Adult Dog Food, 18-Pounds, Seven Fish Medley.

As a DJ and avid gamer I'm always in the market for new and decent quality headphones. I've owned and used many headsets over the years (three Turtle Beach) and there always seems to be something new for PC, gaming consoles, mobile devices and DJing.  As I always enjoy testing out new headphones here are my thoughts on the Turtle Beach Titanfall Ear Force Atlas Official Xbox One Xbox 360 PC Gaming Headset;Pros+ Simple to plug on the X1 (adapter was immediately identified and was asked to update the controller, very simple process, took less than 2 minutes to update the controller).+ Nice sound, crisp treble, solid bass with nothing being too overwhelming.+ Includes Xbox One Audio Adapter ($25 individually).+ Multi-platform use (X1, Xbox 360 and other mobile devices.  They even work with my PS4 and PS Vita).+ Microfiber ear cups are comfortably padded, even for those of us who wear glasses.+ Sleek looking Titanfall decal design.+ Separate game and chat audio control options.+ Fantastic noise isolation.+ Lengthy main USB cord.+ Detachable mic.+ Officially licensed.+ Lightweight.Cons- Sounds better on the PC than on the X1.  I've noticed it doesn't seem to get as loud on the X1.- Headband tends to be a bit too tight after a while which is odd considering I have a smaller head than most.  It was not very comfortable to wear for extended periods of time.  This would be problematic for someone with a larger head.- Crackling sound and sometimes microphone pop noise on the X1. (UPDATE - most recent X1 Update fixed these issues).- Control remote on the cable is a bit larger than it needs to be.  It's always falling off of my computer tower at the slightest pull even.- Amplifier not compatible with the X1.- Can be hard to plug the cable into the amplifier because of the rubber casing, had to make sure it was properly inserted, since it sounded like s*** before I rechecked the connection. It makes it hard if you want to switch on the fly between the PC and X1, since removing the cable from the amplifier that's connected to the PC.- Build quality of plastic and synthetic is a bit disappointing considering the price tag.- Steep list price of $150 which I feel is too much for what you're getting.- Ear cups only swivel 90 degrees one way and 45 degrees the other way.- Not wireless.At the $150 range, the Turtle Beach Titanfall Ear Force Atlas Official Xbox One Xbox 360 PC Gaming Headset unfortunately falls a bit short to justify the initial asking price.  On the plus side, the noise isolation is decent and the audio quality is quite good for both games and music.  The inclusion of the X1 adapter allows you to personalize your gaming audio to maximize your playstyle.  The majority of games I've played so far have had crisp and clear highs, mids and lows without ever sounding dull, distant or hollow.  I've been playing multiple games (Thief, Payday 2, Titanfall and Dark Souls II) with all resulting in quality sound.  However, I feel that the list price is too high for what you're getting in the end.  I feel that this headset would be a more worthy investment around the $100-$130 range.  Personally, I feel there are better headset choices on the market for the current asking price.  However, if you're a Titanfall fan and want to complete your collection then the Turtle Beach Titanfall Ear Force Atlas Official Xbox One Xbox 360 PC Gaming Headset might be for you.

My dog is a 65lb English Bulldog/German Shepherd mix that repeatedly suffers from allergies, especially from food. He can also be a bit of a picky eater so finding the right mix can often be difficult. While he loves just about any treat, but I always have reservations about trying new food. Unfortunately, a large majority of popular dog foods today are filled with terrible ingredients not to mention carrying a high price tag. I'm always willing to try a new food so here are my thoughts on Hill's Ideal Balance Large Breed Natural Chicken & Brown Rice Recipe Mature Adult Dry Dog Food, 15-Pound;Pros+ Perfect kibble size makes the food suitable for both large and small dogs.+ A plethora of healthy and helpful ingredients such as flaxseed, Omega 3 & 6, antioxidants, vitamin C & E, glucosamine and chondroitin.+ No corn, wheat, soy, artificial colors, flavors or preservatives.+ Ingredients made in the U.S.A. and Europe, not China.+ My dog had no digestive issues after eating this.+ Photo of food in "actual size" on the back of the bag.Cons- Dog wasn't exactly excited to eat it.- Expensive for a 15-pound bag.- No way to reseal the bag after it's opened.My dog was pretty indifferent to Hill's Ideal Balance Large Breed Natural Chicken & Brown Rice Recipe Mature Adult Dry Dog Food, 15-Pound.  He was of course extremely excited when I approached with the bag (as he is with every new food) but that quickly changed after I dumped a little in his bowl.  Initially, he sniffed it and looked up at me as if to say "What's this?"  He then took a small bite and promptly spit it out on the floor and walked away.  At this point I pretty much assumed he wasn't going to eat it unless he had nothing else.  Since I don't like to waste food I began to slowly mix it into his current food.  Every time he ate he would take a mouthful of the mixed food, spit it out on the floor and then eat only his current food Diamond Naturals Dry Food for Adult Dogs, Large Breed 60+ Chicken Formula, 40 Pound Bag and leave the Hill's Ideal laying about.  Thankfully he's slowly become accepting of eating this food but only mixed with his current food.  Although my dog wasn't crazy about this food I really liked the ingredients.  However, the cost is a bit too high for me to purchase this on a regular basis.  I've seen law enforcement buying this food for their K-9 partners at our nearby Petsmart which makes me feel good that our four-legged friends who protect and serve are being quality food.
