If you're willing to pay a little extra for your food then you may want to give Hill's Ideal Balance Large Breed Natural Chicken & Brown Rice Recipe Mature Adult Dry Dog Food, 15-Pound a try.

We've really only ever had two types of knives around our home, kitchen knives for cooking and utility knives for opening boxes.  Therefore we've been on the lookout for a knife to help with heavier jobs other than cutting plastic straps and packing tape on boxes.  Enter the Coast FX352 Frame Lock Folding Knife 3.5-Inch Blade.  Here are my thoughts;Pros+ Contoured grip gives the knife a comfortable fit in your hand and prevents accidental slipping.+ Easy to open for both righties and lefties.+ Durable construction with a Stainless Steel blade and frame.+ Sleek look and design.+ Handy belt clip.+ Lifetime warranty.Cons- Requires a bit of additional sharpening if you want a finer edge.- May be a little heavy as a pocket knife for some.We couldn't be happier with the Coast FX352 Frame Lock Folding Knife 3.5-Inch Blade.  It's extremely durable, well-designed and feels great in your hand.  It‚Äôs been able to handle all our heavier duty household jobs from cutting cable to slicing out sections of our ceiling after a water leak.  If you're looking for a dependable and sturdy pocket knife for work or home then the Coast FX352 Frame Lock Folding Knife 3.5-Inch Blade fits the bill nicely.

Recently I purchased a Motorola Moto X -  16GB, Unlocked Phone - US Warranty - White which unfortunately like many Android phones today doesn't come with a micro USB slot.  Being able to instantly expand a phone's memory by an additional 32GB is extremely useful.  We've often purchased Corsair RAM for our PC's because of its dependability and quality.  That being said, I had no reservations about testing another Corsair product with my portable devices and PC. Here are my thoughts on the Corsair Flash Voyager GO 32GB USB3.0 micro USB OTG Flash Drive for Android devices CMFVG-32GB-NA;Pros+ Compatible with Windows and Mac as well as Linux.+ Plug and play on select devices.+ Quickly transfer data between mobile devices and your PC/Mac without a cable.+ Small size (37mm long) and attaches to your keychain for easy portability.+ 5 year warranty.+ Affordable.Cons- Small size makes it very easy to misplace unless you have it a keychain.  It almost went to the wash a few times before I attached it to my keychain.- May have compatibility issues with many Android devices.  Currently the list of phones and tablets supported is terribly short without the use of a ES File Explorer App.- Transfer speeds may vary depending on the device or computer.- Female USB end doesn't have a cap which can easily collect dirt and dust.- Male USB end was an extremely tight fit on all of my devices.  So much so that I thought I was insert it incorrectly or that I might damage something.The Corsair Flash Voyager GO 32GB USB3.0 micro USB OTG Flash Drive for Android devices CMFVG-32GB-NA is a really great idea but a bit flawed in a few areas. While it's small, reliable and extremely efficient it has its share of issues with the main being lack of compatibility without using a ES File Explorer App.  I've used it with my Sony Xperia Z SGP311U1/B 10.1-Inch 16GB Tablet (no App needed), my Motorola Moto X -  16GB, Unlocked Phone - US Warranty - White (App needed) and multiple PC's (no App needed) with no problems whatsoever.  For its function it's also quite affordable compared to other flash drives on the market.  In my opinion the drives versatility alone makes it worth the purchase price if you want the ability to swap date between all of your devices. Despites my list of Cons, the Corsair Flash Voyager GO 32GB USB3.0 micro USB OTG Flash Drive for Android devices CMFVG-32GB-NA was a welcome addition to my family of ever-changing devices from a manufacturer I've come to trust.

We spend a lot of time in the kitchen around our house trying different recipes and foods, so we tend to try a lot of different cooking gadgets.  When you find a good one it becomes invaluable.  As we've gotten older eating healthier has definitely become more of a concern.  Enter the "Philips HD9230/26 Digital AirFryer with Rapid Air Technology, Black." Here are my thoughts;Pros+ Straight forward digital controls and extremely easy to use.+ Cooks extremely quickly and effectively.  The bottom rack takes a bit longer to cook more thoroughly depending on the food item.+ Use little to no oil to cook which makes for healthier eating.+ Food stays warms for quite some time after cooking is done when left in the tray.+ Additional attachments (sold separately) also allow you to bake and grill/roast as well.+ Very well packaged to prevent damage during transit.+ Auto shut-off once timer ends.+ Sleek look and simple design.Cons- Drawer and components are bothersome to hand wash after each use.  The bottom grill traps a lot of food drippings and even with a lot of soaking it can be difficult to get out and shreds sponges pretty quickly.- Components are not really dishwasher safe as advertised.  The basket and grilling rack quickly began to rust after only a few cycles.  Everything is now hand wash only to prevent further rusting.- Takes up a bit of counter space with its oval shape.  It's slightly larger than our KRUPS EA8250001 Espresseria Full Automatic Espresso Machine with Built-in Conical Burr Grinder, Black.- Additional Fry/Grill Pan and Non-Stick Baking Dish should really have come included.  They're another $40-50 each.- Basket size feels a bit small compared to other fryers on the market.  You can fit a regular bag of frozen French fries or four medium sized chicken breasts as an example.- Tray doesn't lock into the unit.  I found this rather surprising considering the amount of heat the units puts out to cook your food.  It felt a little dangerous to me as a curious child could easily pull this out and off the counter.- Quite expensive listing of $349 at the time of writing this review.- Digital interface can be a little sluggish and unresponsive.- Determining proper cook times takes some experimenting.- Poor instructions and lackluster cookbook.We were very impressed by the effectiveness of the Philips HD9230/26 Digital AirFryer with Rapid Air Technology, Black.  The fast cook time and tastiness of the finished food was quite surprising.  So far we've made chicken (all types of cuts), fish (swai and tilapia), bacon (very messy and you can't make a lot), burgers (also a greasy and messy clean up), various vegetables and of course French fries (perfect!).  It's important to note that the capacity of this fryer is rather small and better suited for one or two people.  I'd highly recommend this to those people who have a small space in which to cook or cook small meals.  Other than the small basket size I would say the overall cost is the biggest drawback to those looking to purchase this unit.  However, I'm sure many would love to receive it as a gift and would gladly put it on a wedding registry.  For the price of this machine it should definitely be considered an investment and some may consider it difficult to justify.  However, if you can afford the purchase price it definitely does what it's supposed to. I can absolutely say we've been more than satisfied with the Philips HD9230/26 Digital AirFryer with Rapid Air Technology, Black and I know our household will get many years of use out of it.

Let me start off by saying we currently don't have any children although they're in the future.  That being said, we do have limited counter space to dry our dishes.  Leaving out a regular-sized drying rack is not really an option so we've been looking for something compact and easy to store to help dry our plastic dishes.  Enter the Philips AVENT Drying Rack.  Here are my thoughts;Pros+ Easy to assemble, disassemble and store. Fits easily in a drawer.+ Bottom tray drains water away easily.+ Sturdy construction.Cons- Flexible design is a bit misleading as the drying arms are stiff plastic and can only be inserted one way into the tray.- Only safe to dry lightweight or plastic items on the rack.- Some items may be easily knocked off.- Unsure if the item is BPA free.The Philips AVENT Drying Rack is pretty standard.  There's really nothing terribly special about it and it does its drying job as well as expected.  Combined with our Envision Home Microfiber Dish Drying Mat, 16 by 18-Inch, Black we're able to dry the majority of our plastic and glass dishes with ease while taking up very little counter space.  The best part is when your items are finished drying both items are easily stored in a kitchen drawer.  When children enter our household the Philips AVENT Drying Rack will obviously get a lot more use drying all those plastic baby bottles and nipples.

Like many people I've struggled with oily skin my entire life.  The oil traps dirt, clogs your pores and ultimately gives you acne.  Fun stuff.  As a teenager I suffered the worst of it.  Now, as an adult it's manageable but still an annoyance.  That being said I'm always on the lookout for different morning facial washes to use in the shower.  I've tried many Nivea products for men and have enjoyed the majority of them.  Therefore, I was more than happy to give Nivea for Men Sensitive Face Wash for Men, 5 Ounce a try.  Here are my thoughts;Pros+ Applies gently to your face.+ Sensitive formula doesn't irritate skin.+ No drying alcohol.+ Chamomile and Vitamin E ingredients.Cons- Tube design collects and retains water around the cap if kept in the shower.- Although the product is advertised as a perfume free formula there's a lingering perfume smell that stays with you long after you've rinsed the product from your face.- After 1-2 hours my face was oily again.  No different than any other facial cleanser I've used.Nivea for Men Sensitive Face Wash for Men, 5 Ounce just didn't cut it for me.  I didn't really see any noticeable change in my complexion after using it daily (sometimes twice) for a month, but I can say that about most facial cleansers.  Would I use it again?  Probably not.  The "fragrance free formula" was definitely not as advertised.  To be honest, my face smelled like Grandma's perfume for the majority of the day after use.  Not a scent I was particularly fond of and enjoy smelling.  However, since I like Nivea products I'm glad I gave it a try.

Schwartz fits a lot of goodness into a small package with Demon Hunter. Despite the unprepossessing cover, the book inside compares favorably to Ilona Andrews (especially her new Sweep series), with intriguing world-building and top-notch characters. My only complaint is that quite a few pages are devoted to explicit sex, which waters down the story a bit. Still, I'd snap up book two in a heartbeat should it become available.Speaking of the sequel --- I was a bit leery to begin book one without knowing if book two is slated for release anytime soon. So I was very glad to learn that this book ends with a solid resolution and can be considered a standalone easily. However, the characters are so good I'd still love to read book two!

Ellen O'Connell is currently tied with Laura Florand as my favorite romance author. Their books are entirely different, but both share an astonishing ability to combine a page-turning, character-driven story with a setting so vivid you feel like you've gone on vacation in a different country or, in the case of O'Connell, in a different time.Fascinating historical tidbits aside, Into the Light is my favorite of O'Connell's books because of the love story. How could you not enjoy two wounded souls drawn together when they meet on city benches in the dark? Neither knows the other's identity, with both predictable and unpredictable results.My only complaint? I've only got two O'Connell books left. What will I do when I run out?!

I'll start with the potentially bad. My Tomorrow is very solidly a New Adult book, so it's not surprising that there's a strong thread of moral ambiguity running through the plot. In the end, I felt like that element made the book more real and deep, but if you want a simple romance with no cheating, this story might not be for you.Okay, with that out of the way, I can definitely say that this is Isbell's best book to date. As soon as you meet Drew, you'll fall in love with him and will be unable to put the book down. Drew is a handsome, wealthy, self-made architect who is, first and foremost, the perfect gentleman. So what's he to do when attracted to his assistant who's ensconced in a four-year-relationship with her live-in boyfriend?My other warning --- you'll be incapable of turning the last page without yearning for book two. Isbell can't write fast enough for me! I hope the sequel comes out very soon.

So, Susan's Grant's world reminds me an awful lot of the Star Wars universe...which is great! Especially since she adds in strong female characters and believable romances to make that knockoff universe sing.I enjoyed the first book in this series enough to try The Star Prince, but I'll admit that Grant's first effort had flawed pacing. This sequel, though, is 1,000% better, with the same tantalizing feel but in a much more cohesive package. I'm looking forward to book 3, and can tell I'll be sad to see this fast, light series end.

I've read three of Ellen O'Connell's books, and this is my favorite so far. She's definitely hitting her stride, including the fascinating historical setting, the wounded characters, and the tantalizing romance in a more cohesive package as she grows as a writer. I can hardly wait for the next book!

So many romance novels seem to be written for teenagers. There's lots of in-depth description of sex, but no real depth to the emotional bond being built between the two characters.Eyes of Silver, Eyes of Gold is the exact opposite. The slow growth of love between the two protagonists is beautiful and their struggle to overcome their era's racism fascinating and thought-provoking.I have two true markers of an A++ book --- first it keeps me up too late reading, and second I cry at the end. This novel hits both markers solidly and I'm looking forward to reading everything else Ellen O'Connell has written. The only question is --- which one to read first?

I adore post-apocalyptic novels, but sometimes the violence and bad choices of characters faced with a new disaster is just too depressing. Ice Diaries was such a delightful change, keeping the best parts of the genre while deleting most of the violence and unsavoriness.The book begins a year after a pandemic wipes out of most of the world's population, followed by an abrupt climate shift that buries London under 60 feet of snow. We open in a little community of posh Londoners who are getting by quite happily raiding supermarkets for their supplies, gathering together for ceilidhs, and looking out for one another. Our heroine is kind and spunky, but is still mourning her lost boyfriend, whom she assumes is now dead.Enter a semi-thug dying of a knife-wound and hypothermia while lying in the snow outside her flat, and the story is off! I won't tell you about the middle because most things I say would be spoilers, but the end is fully satisfying while also leaving me yearning for a sequel. Please tell me book two is in the works?

Twice Born is intriguingly different from your run-of-the-mill shifter book. It's solidly urban fantasy instead of paranormal romance, with plenty of world-building (set in Australia, which makes it doubly different!). The story starts with a bang, following a character who's lost her memory of the last few hours but who just vaguely remembers blood dripping from her hands. How could you put that down?I don't want to tell you much more, because this book's twistiness is one of its best points. There are mysteries within mysteries, and it's intriguing watching our heroine figure out what's going on. Unfortunately, I feel like that twistiness went a bit too far --- thus four stars instead of five. A bit of foreshadowing of one element that shows up near the end would have made me more emotionally invested in the book and brought me through a middle that otherwise felt too long. Or perhaps the author should have just cut out a hundred pages or so. (I do like my books short and sweet.)But the end more than made up for that slight flaw, and I'm looking forward to book two. On for more twists and turns and dragon shifters!

I put off picking up this book because I have no inclination to sell any of my food, even though I devote quite a lot of time to producing all the vegetables my husband and I eat in a year. I shouldn't have delayed. Because Fortier's beautifully illustrated and easy to read book fills in gaps in my production campaign, giving me ideas for streamlining production so my crops will be more bountiful with less work. His focus on hand tools and on high-density production makes this a book that will suit backyard gardeners just as much as, or maybe even more than, market gardeners. No matter your goal, if you like to grow things and want to do so in a sustainable fashion, The Market Gardener is a good book to have under your belt and I can't recommend it highly enough.

This is an intriguing, multimedia glimpse into various modern paths toward wisdom. The art is intriguing, and although I didn't watch any of the videos (I'm just not a video person), I suspect they also added depth to the text. Finally, there are the hands-on exercises that bring what you've learned into the truly personal sphere.The really powerful part, though, was the several different points of view, one of which will likely present a perspective that speaks to you. There's an Indian-Kenyan-English searcher for truth, a Rabbi who has lived on three continents, and an anthropologist intrigued by the human life cycle. And that's just in the first "pillar" (chapter) of seven!Overall, this is a resonant text that is best savored slowly. Settle in, relax, and enjoy the ride.

Nothing like a book set in a world you're not familiar with (horse racing in this case) with characters you enjoy and the promise of a happy ending to turn a normal weekend day into a relaxing interlude away from the real world.The bad news is that this marks the last of the author's horse books that I hadn't read. Please write more fast!

This excellent novel reminds me of Zelazney's Amber series, with its elaborate world-building (perfectly set off by just the right amount of unique vocabulary) and similar setup. But I prefer Bartol because of her heroine (you had me at a girl running from the foster care system) and just right amount of romance to keep me turning pages without rolling my eyes.I could write more, but I'm instead going to head over and download the next book in the series ASAP. I can hardly wait to see where the story goes and I'm usually not a fan of series!

I think this might be my favorite read of the month. I can't really explain why, except to say that the story really worked. The heroine dealt with so many physical and emotional problems with such grace, "bad" guys mostly had redeeming qualities, and the romance was right up my alley (a long internet courtship and no on-screen sex). I've liked but not loved other books by this author, but this one didn't let me go until the very end. I'm definitely going to have to try more Kelly Oram.

These are such beautiful postcards! I suspect I may pore over them for hours before finally writing on the first one...My only minor complaint is that sometimes the descriptions on the back don't name every single variety pictured, instead simply saying something like "Pears from [source book]". So, if you're a serious plant geek like I am, you may be tantalized but not educated. Yes, I know these are meant to just be eye candy not educational aids, but still....On the other hand, the box they come in is so beautiful, I know I'll have to find a use for it once empty. So there's a bonus!

At a recent grafting workshop, I had dozens of apple varieties to choose from and only 10 rootstock. Which should I pick? Luckily, the hosts had copies of several books, including this one, on hand as selection aids. While other books had pretty pictures and nice formatting, Fruit, Berry, and Nut Inventory came through with more descriptions than anyone else and I immediately ordered a copy of my own when I got home.Keep in mind that this is a dry, list-type book. If you're obsessed with rare fruit varieties, you'll spend hours poring over the descriptions. But if you're looking for pretty pictures (or *any* pictures), look elsewhere.

If you liked the first two books in the series, The Assassin's Salvation is just as good or better. Personally, I liked the main characters in this installment the best of the options so far (what's not to love about an ethical assassin?) and it was nice to see appearances by characters from previous books as well. I'm reading book four now and am already mourning the fact that I've almost reached the end of this engaging series.

I have to admit that the only thing I remember about the first book in this series is the apple tree, but that didn't really matter. I was sucked in from the first paragraph, the rich wording and emotions lulling me into a book coma it took me hours to come out of. This is what literary fiction *should* be, in my opinion --- stellar prose and thought-provoking passages all wrapped up in a character-driven story that keeps me reading far too late. If you enjoyed Chocolat, the magical realism in this book will be right up your alley as well.
A charming space-opera romp with a truly geeky hero (who reminded me a bit of Spock...but more socially awkward). I could write more...but would rather download book three!

Mercenary Instinct reminded me a lot of Elizabeth Moon's space operas, or perhaps of Star Wars if you're more of a movie person. Which is to say, if you suspend your disbelief, there was lots of pure, swashbuckling fun involved. And it looks like the sequels are available for borrowing, so I'm off to download the next one now!

I've been burned so many times by Kindle First books that I now look at them a bit askance. But Boundary Crossed proved me wrong. Olson's tale is full of unique worldbuilding, follows a flawed by lovable heroine, and left me wanting more (without ending on a cliffhanger). Boundary Crossed is right up there with the paranormal fantasy pros like Patricia Briggs and Ilona Andrews, in my opinion, and I can't wait to see where this series goes next!

I'm always intrigued by comic-book-style stories, but usually end up disappointed. I like the alternative worlds where people with superpowers keep the common guy safe, but the two-dimensionality of the characters generally turns me off.Luckily, Vigilant has all of the pluses of a comic-book story with none of the minuses. Our heroine is particularly enticing, a great blend of power and vulnerability. As I later learned in the author's note, Lawson spent years working with troubled kids as a social worker, and that part of the story rang particularly true. I also enjoyed the mystery --- are the men in her life normal joes, superheroes, or supervillians? The ending isn't a cliffhanger, but does leave you wanting more, and I'm looking forward to checking out book two when it becomes available.

I've been lucky enough to hear Tradd speak in person a few times, and his lectures are always visually appealing, intellectually revealing, and completely inspiring. His book is more of the same --- which is to say awesome!I've been particularly wanting more information on rafts, totems, and propagating mushrooms on cardboard, and this book form of the lectures I'd attended didn't disappoint. In addition to providing step-by-step directions (with great diagrams and photos) on those topics, the text provided additional home-scale experiments that I'm itching to try, including propagating shiitakes using stacked rounds, raising oyster mushrooms on old clothes and coffee grounds, and producing homegrown morel spawn/microbe slurry for outside inoculation. (If you have no idea what I'm talking about, don't worry --- the beginning of the book has great information to bring beginners up to speed.)The last third of the book consists of species-by-species cultivation accounts, and I'll save that for more intensive reading later. For now, this book is one of the few titles --- about three to five per year --- that contains such a breadth and depth of information that it merits a permanent place on my bookshelf.For those of you new to mushrooms, this is probably the book I'd recommend reading first. It's like a combination of the inspiring accounts of Mycelium Running with the hands-on information of Stamets' older text, but with a more homestead-scale appeal. But I should warn you that you'll need to commit serious time to reading Tradd's chapters slowly and in order since my initial skim was a bit disappointing --- raising more questions than it answered. Only after I read every word did the true wonder of the book gel together into a beautiful whole. So even if you're an intermediate mushroom growing, start with chapter one and prepare to be inspired!

I almost never pick up a fiction book by a man nowadays because they generally lack the heart I'm looking for. The Neon Lawyer is a notable exception to that rule.Victor Methos does a superb job taking a Grisham-like story down to the common man by following a new lawyer who has been working as a janitor in the book's opening scenes. You'll enjoy all of the characters, from the seedy mob-related lawyer who eventually hires our hero to the woman our hero is employed to defend. The story is fast-paced, just the right length, and will keep its claws firmly rooted in your stomach after you turn the last page. Here's hoping more legal thrillers are in Methos' future!

Not Quite Forever starts off as a run-of-the-mill romance novel. But after a while, the story deepens as characters grow into their extra dimensions.For me, the true test of a good book is if it makes me cry. I only hit the tearjerkers every month or two, but Not Quite Forever definitely made the cut. If a book makes me cry at a happily ever after, you know the author is worth her salt!

Sometimes I wonder why an excellent book like this is out of print and barely read while similar books are still going strong decades later. Sure, Stille's book is slightly rough around the edges, with a few more typos than I'd like to see. And some goat keepers may disagree with some of her advice (but isn't that always the case?).On the other hand, The Goat Care Handbook is the perfect example of a book written from firsthand experience. Stille has been keeping goats for decades, and her attentiveness to their behavior shows through.In fact, I stumbled across her book while googling about trimming hooves on pregnant does --- my gut said that I shouldn't wrestle with Mama Goat in her nearly-due state, but I couldn't seem to find any evidence to back up that impression. Luckily, Stille agreed with me. "Don't trim the hooves of a pregnant doe after the third month of gestation," she warns, "unless she is very docile because her struggles may harm her and the unborn kids." She also offered excellent advice in preparing for kidding (trimming the hair on her back legs and udders, etc.) and when and how to help during birth.In the end, I still recommend Storey's Guide to Dairy Goats as the first goat book to read, but this or Raising Goats Naturally would make a good second opinion. Or, better yet, read all three....

The run-of-the-mill cover hides the fact that this is an exceptionally good book. It has all of the elements I love --- unique world-building (urban fantasy with daemons and half daemons), a great heroine, and an intriguing love interest (who's almost a dragon). If I had to make complaints, my minor nitpicks would be the presence of infodumps (although all of the information dumped is very useful for the plot later) and slightly rough ebook formatting. But that wasn't enough to keep me from reading up late and then picking up book two immediately.On the other hand, if you hate cliffhangers, you may or may not have a gripe with this book. I didn't really consider the ending a cliffhanger since the plot was resolved...although the author does then introduce a new problem to keep you on the edge of your seat. Chances are that, like me, you'll *need* to know what happens next, but if you want to quit after book one, you can.
Just the right blend of suspense, romance, and mystery made this book into a real pageturner. I could write more...but I'm busy picking out her next book to read.

With her third novel, Meara is really starting to hit her stride and find her own unique voice. I enjoyed the way A Boy Named Rabbit felt different from most mainstream offerings, more like a Gene Stratton-Porter book, perhaps mixed in with a bit of A Little Princess.Once again, the Appalachian setting provided the perfect foil for a well-turned story. With some wilderness survival, a healthy dose of suspense, gentle at-home scenes, and a tinge of paranormal activity, A Boy Named Rabbit has something for everyone. And, although the story wraps up well, the teaser for the next book in the series is well done and will leave you wanting more.

I enjoyed Intimate Enemies more than many romantic-suspense novels because the author balanced the romance and the suspense very well. Never did I feel like the suspense portions of the plot were simply tossed in to ice a pre-made romance novel, and the romance actually worked within the storyline as well. A great, fast read that kept me up way too late at night.

This is one of the most enticing and original young-adult offerings I've read in a while. It could possibly be called steampunk (although it's not). There's some artificial intelligence, plenty of moral ambiguity, a great heroine and hero, and two completely unique worlds, both of which I want to learn more about. Honestly, I can't understand the so-so reviews since this book hit the spot in every respect!
Nice kit with all of the tools you need.
They're fine. Not great construction, but they get the job done.
Solid construction and it really produces the power.  It even comes with double-sided mounting tape and velcro so you can stick it where ever you like!
Reasonable quality and construction.  The wireless works well enough from your license plate to your mirror, but it is prone to occasional interference.
Great price on this little unit.  It really works well and installation was a breeze!

A fine little charger to use in a pinch to charge your ChromeBook, but as others have mentioned, the power supply charges the Samsung ChromeBooks just fine, but if you operate the trackpad while it is plugged in, the tracking is erratic.  I use it as my backup charger in case I run low on juice on the road.

Do not trust your sanity or your life to these units.  Our house built in 2010 has 8 of these units and now 4 of them have failed.  I've had false CO alarms that left our family standing outside in the cold at 3am as the fire department was called out.  The incessant chirping will drive you insane.  Sometimes an alarm will start chirping for low battery even though fresh batteries were installed only weeks ago.  (Pulling the battery and unplugging from the hardwire for a few minutes will fix it sometimes).  Unidentified and mysterious chirping happens too.  The units will occasionally start triple-chirping which is some other issue, not the battery.  Search the manual all you want, there is no reason for the triple-chirp.Oh, and that 7 year warranty?  Good luck with that.  Even though our appliances, carpet, and fixtures came with manufacturer warranty with our brand new house, BRK won't honor their warranty.  Since we didn't buy the units directly, our builder's subcontractor did, they won't honor the warranty.Stay away, these units are horrible.
Really good price on the genuine product.  Very satisfied.
Good quality, good price, exactly as described.

Yes, it's Cards Against Humanity! The toy sensation that's sweeping the nation! Only $14.95 at participating stores! Get one today!Warning: Pregnant women, the elderly, and children under 10 should avoid prolonged exposure to Cards Against Humanity.Caution: Cards Against Humanity may suddenly accelerate to dangerous speeds.Cards Against Humanity contains a liquid core, which, if exposed due to rupture, should not be touched, inhaled, or looked at.Do not use Cards Against Humanity on concrete.Discontinue use of Cards Against Humanity if any of the following occurs:itchingvertigodizzinesstingling in extremitiesloss of balance or coordinationslurred speechtemporary blindnessprofuse sweatingor heart palpitations.If Cards Against Humanity begins to smoke, get away immediately. Seek shelter and cover head.Cards Against Humanity may stick to certain types of skin.When not in use, Cards Against Humanity should be returned to its special container and kept under refrigeration. Failure to do so relieves the makers of Cards Against Humanity, Wacky Products Incorporated, and its parent company, Global Chemical Unlimited, of any and all liability.Ingredients of Cards Against Humanity include an unknown glowing green substance which fell to Earth, presumably from outer space.Cards Against Humanity has been shipped to our troops in Saudi Arabia and is being dropped by our warplanes on Iraq.Do not taunt Cards Against Humanity.Cards Against Humanity comes with a lifetime warranty.Cards Against Humanity! Accept no substitutes!:)All fun aside, Cards Against Humanity is awesome and the Fifth Expansion is no exception.

Yes, it's plenty big for your Keurig and even more important it handles the weight of a full Keurig in solid fashion.I bought this for my folks who have low-hung cabinets in their kitchen.  They were constantly dragging their Keurig in and out so they had enough room to refill the water reservoir.  This handy little device appeared to be just the solution, so for ten bucks I figured what the heck.  When it arrived, we were concerned with the all plastic construction and the fact that the item is very light weight.  The performance is quite spectacular.  The Keurig machine is actually quite heavy and the Handy Caddy lets it glide like it's on air.  After daily use for the last 6 months, it really looks like this is a great device that will hold up for quite some time.

This Emergency Release Lock Kit is the "standard" configuration for every type of lock like this.  It will fit in the hole that is pre-stamped in steel doors and the bolt holes will line up correctly.  As others have noted, this is NOT a Genie part, but it works.  If you are really worried about high security on this lock, maybe you shouldn't install it at all because popping open a garage door is pretty darn easy with or without one of these release locks.  This device just makes it so you don't do damage to the door to release the garage door opener in case of power outage or malfunction.Also note that this is a unit with the shorter cable, about 24 inches.  Remember, shorter doesn't mean worse, it just means shorter.  If the cable is too long for your needs you will have to shorten it or you risk a problem with it hanging down when the door is up and a larger possibility of it getting tangled up when you need to use it.  It's really easier to extend a cable that is too short rather than shorten one that is too long...just add a piece of nylon cord.  If you already have one installed and need a new one, measure the current cable.  If you are installing it for the first time, take a piece of string from the intended installation position to find out what length cable you need.I agree with other reviewers, the seller should be required to disclose the actual brand.

This is the genuine Kohler set that will also fit their other line brands Sterling, Wellworth, Highline, Northline, and Barrington.  Basically, if you look into the top of the tank and you see 3 screw heads in a triangular pattern, this will be the kit you need 99% of the time.Don't make the mistake of replacing only the triangular gasket, the leak is commonly from a hairline crack in the valve tube and you'll save yourself lots of time by just replacing all of it at once.  Read the instructions and follow them carefully as the nut on the bottom is often over tightened and this will result in continued leakage or cracking of the valve tube assembly.Be aware that this kit does NOT include the screws.  You need to replace the screws as I'll guarantee your originals are corroded.Why only 4 star?  The kit is original manufacturer parts and they're as good as they get, but the reality is it is very expensive for what it is and at this price they should include the screws that you have to have.  It's a horrible design that is destined to give you issues with leakage into the bowl and always causes more work when doing repairs.  The cost for the seal between the tank and commode for most other toilets is less than $2.  In my experience as a property manager, standard toilet seals almost never fail and I've had to replace way too many of these Kohler gems.

If you're looking for the Dorian style in brushed or satin nickel, this is the one to order.  The handles have a lacquer finish so they are smooth and will wear well.  Solid construction and a good feel in the hand.  I purchased two to replaced damaged ones in an older rental and they were perfect matches.Full kit includes all of the hardware (including latch and strike plate) and the screws needed to install.  You'll get it quicker and cheaper on amazon than ordering it from the local big-box store.

My wife and I love popcorn and the NordicWare popper is just the perfect solution.  This popper works great whether you want to get out the good old popper oil or go healthy and don't use any oil at all.  A 1/3 cup of fresh popcorn dumped in the bottom and thrown in the microwave for 3 minutes is the perfect solution for us.  (Your microwave will be different, just listen the first few times you pop with it and open the door when the popping slows to 1 pop a second or less.)  We get very few unpopped kernels and the batch is always big and fluffy.  The bowl itself gets quite hot, but we just grab it with a kitchen towel and it helps keep the treat warm while we eat it.Give this popper a try for less than the cost of a box of microwave popcorn bags and you'll never go back!

The Max Burton 6000 is well constructed and works just as advertised.  The unit is large and can handle your biggest boiling pots on the plate while still being able to access and read the controls.  Operation couldn't be simpler for the novice or more flexible for the true chef.  The unit combines easy to use power levels and temperature control with a timer (great for when you use it as a warmer and want to make sure you don't forget to turn it off).
This is a vinyl bag with a brittle plastic closure.  One of the closure clips broke off on the first use and the bag tore on the second.  Keep moving, don't waste your money.

We own rental units and now place Schlage Keypad Deadbolts on all of them.  They are very easy to install and use.  These keypad deadbolts work differently than a lot of the competitor's keypad deadbolts.  The Schlage does not move the bolt automatically, it just engages the handle when an authorized code is entered and you do the work to move the bolt.Is that better?  In a word, yes.  We have used other brands that move the bolt automatically and there are disadvantages to these units.  They are slow and on a very cold night you may find weak batteries will leave YOU out in the cold.  We installed our first unit in our home over 3 years ago and used the included 9-volt battery (not expecting it to last too long) and it is still going strong.  Since it only uses the battery to read codes and engage the handle, the little 9-volt will last a very long time.

For a non-name brand, this lever is made very solidly.  Good feel in the hand and positive action.  The only negative comments are that there are zero instructions (not that installing a door handle is too hard) and that you may be searching for the screws.  They come screwed fully into the handle.  Have a power screw driver handy...they're long.

This kit is a true Moen kit with ALL of the parts including the Posi-Temp stops (those tough to find plastic parts) and the screws commonly missing from other kits.  Truly the only things that you need to bring to the party is the valve, cartridge, and a tube of caulk to seal it all up."This is the right kit with everything included"

Good quality car vent mount!  I bought two.  One for my wife's car.  The clamps for the iPhone are very secure, the ball joint can be secured tightly after setting the phones position, and the tines that connect the mount to the car vent are very long and tight enough to grip the vent securely.  Very well built and the price is right.  Highly recommend!

I picked up this case looking for a something that would be simple to put on and take off and something that would be thin, but provide ample protection from falls.  When I received this case, it met these criteria, but it also impressed me in other ways.  For one, its hard to see in the photos, but the case is molded with indented areas on the back which aid in gripping your phone.  When I picked the phone up, my thumb easily found the iPhone button placements on the left, while my remaining four fingers seemed to automatically utilize this indented area for gripping while pushing the buttons.  So from a grip and drop standpoint, I like the case a lot.  Secondly, the camera holes on the back are perfectly designed so that they don't interfere with either the lens or the flash.  This may seem a no-brainer, but I can't tell you how many times I've purchased low priced cases that simply prove to be worthless, because they interfere with photo taking.  Speaker, earphone and lightning adapter cutouts are also perfect.  And lastly, as far as esthetics, I really liked the transparency which allowed my iPhones design to shine through, and the "toughness" of the plastic material which is a bit stiffer than plastic or silicon cases I've purchased in the past.  In terms of protection, I feel that case provides ample protection from most drops, although luckily, I've yet to experience any drops as of yet.  The corner protection seems good, the back protection of course is excellent since its totally covered, and in terms of the face protection, the case should protect the phone from flat surface drops but like most other cases of this type, if it drops just right on a pebble or something, your screen will probably crack or be scratched.  It's just the nature of the beast.  If you want full protection, you simply need to buy more of an armored case.  So given that the case meets protection standards that I feel are acceptable for the type of design, I cannot fault the case in any way in terms of protection.  For the money and features, I highly recommend this case.

Just received my Etekcity digital postal/luggage scale and I love it.  Why?  Well, first it's small enough to not add significant bulk to your luggage.  After all, what good is a luggage scale if it adds enough weight where you have to remove something in order to meet your airlines luggage restrictions?  Second, it has a "zeroing" function which could come in handy for a number of reasons.  Lets say you want to weigh an anchor, but in order to hang the anchor on the scale, you need to include a short piece of chain which you don't want to weigh?  Well, with the zeroing function, you'd first hang the chain on the scale and let it record its weight.  Then you'd hit the zero button to tell the scale that the weight of the hanging chain is zero pounds.  You'd then connect the anchor to the chain and reweigh.  Now the scale would reflect the weight of just the anchor because you effectively negated the weight of the chain with the "zeroing" function.Another nice feature of this small scale is that it has the ability to record weight in kilograms or pounds, and records pounds to the nearest 10th of a pound or kilograms to the nearest 1/100th of a kilogram.  The scale also measures ambient air temperature in either centigrade or fahrenheit scales.  Both can be measured to the nearest 10th of a degree centigrade or fahrenheit.  Why one would want to measure temperature with a luggage scale however, is beyond me, but it does appear to be fairly accurate, as the scale compared well next to a thermometer I bought several years ago, which was designed for the specific purpose of recording outdoor temperatures.Some other points I like about the scale is that it comes with a battery and since it's a coin battery, having to buy one would have been a bummer because I sure don't have spare coin batteries lying around.  I also like its ergonomics....in other words, how it was designed for its intended purpose.  It was designed to be held in a human hand and figuring that there would be a heavy bag hanging from the end of it, it allows the bag to be hung close to the scale itself.  Why is this important?  Because there's nothing worse than having to live the bag 12 inches in the air before the scale can even begin to record the weight.  The Etekcity scale comes with a hanging strap that can be adjusted to different handle configurations to insure it doesn't have to hang to far away from the scale itself.I highly recommend this scale if you travel a lot.  And if you're simply looking for a digital scale but not interested in using it to weigh luggage?  Well, it should do this just fine as long as what you have to weigh can be hung, or place onto or into something that can be hung.

Nice sleeve.  Protects phone well all around including corners.  Also fits snugly so that if I drop the case with the phone in it, it's unlikely to fall out.  Tab makes it easy to remove phone however, when desired.

This kit worked like a charm!  The blue box like part allows you to center the watch strap in a way where you can place the pin you want to remove, over one of the many holes in the box.  Then you simple take one of the 3 supplie "punches" and lightly hammer the pin out.  When I triedbit on my watch, the pins came out very easy.  Made me feel like I was a jeweler.  I feel it was a great purchase for the price.  Highly recommend!

Love this charger!  I was hoping something like this came along....  a multiport sub charger with more than two ports....  with intelligence built into each port so I don't have to worry about which port I plug a given device into.....and portable & light so I can take it with me on travel....  ad best of all, built well.  Highly recommend this charger!

The build quality on this massage table is "kit glove" tight....the seams are well designed and manufactured.  Much like the experience you have when you view the leather in a well built car seat....tight tolerances and tight fits.

Good build quality...i say this because it is replacing a wheel where the black rubber separated from the white inner hub.  And so far, this wheel has held it's own on the same lawn.  I think the original OEM wheel actually may have been defective....no matters....this one is holding up well.
Shipment was prompt....no dead on arrival batteries in the bunch.

Works great!  I had another brand and it would actually cut out at some points which made listening to anything a horrible experience.  This receiver's transmission is solid and consistent!  Highly recommend to others....

I love this case....  thick rubber and a safe gap between tablet face and the ground.  Feels like I could drop this from several feet without any problem.....sorry, not going to actually do this for the purposes of this review!  :-)  Also, if you're wondering, the buttons work great!  I was wondering whether this would be the case but somehow, the contacts of the rubber buttons are positioned well to make button pushing a worry free experience.  Lastly, the sound vents focus the sound and make listening easier...an added plus!

If you're reading this review, please note that I'm referring to the $49 UT-61A model....not the $9.99 model....  which is the problem with a lot of the reviews you'll read related to this listing, and that is that 99% of the reviewers fail to denote which model they're referring to.  That's right, all the reviews for all three models under this one listing, are grouped together.  It's comical how some reviewers start off by saying "I'm not sure how other reviewers gave this item a 5 star"....  Which item?  You won't know unless the reviewer tells you which item.  Oh you might get hints because they'll describe the item and then and only then, would you realize that they're probably not talking about the same product.Anyways, as I mentioned, this review is about the $49 UT-61A model.  I mentioned in the title that it's built like a tank?  Well, I've owned several multimeters over the years, and most were the size of one of those kiddie orange juice cartons that you put their lunch pails.  This multimeter?  Well, when the Amazon box game, I was surprised to get a delivery that weighed so much and was so large.  I didn't order anything from Amazon that large or heavy, but when I opened up the box, I realized it was actually the Etekcity Multimeter.  And when I took it out of its own box, I was flabbergasted to see how large and heavy it was.  Not that I cared about this, but I was expecting some small, lightweight multimeter.  But this....this seemed to be the multimeter of multimeters!I used to work in Aerospace and the company used to have a saying that if it looks good, it will fly good.  Well, I believe in that axiom because in order to make something look good and feel good in your hands, it usually is an indicator that equal thought went into it's design because the company spent extra time and effort on the build quality.... so why would they scrimp on the build quality on the inside?  I realize this isn't always true, but in the case of this multimeter, it's my opinion that it's built well and built to last.First off, it's encased in this extremely thick rubber housing.  The tolerances on how it fits to the inner multimeter housing and face is visibly tight.  No loose housing on this baby.  Weight?  The multimeter weighs in at just under a pound!  The plastic screen is void of any visible defects and is clear as glass...(maybe it is glass?)  And it's size was unexpected....About 7 inches tall, 3-1/4 inches wide and just under 2 inches thick, it's no kiddy orange juice pack in size....no, this baby is about the size of a brick.  Now this didn't bother me, but if you're looking for something small that you can put in your pocket, you better have baggy pants!  I'm happy because this thing is built to last and I wasn't necessarily looking for something too mobile.  Still, it's easy to carry and doesn't weigh anything close to a brick.As far as functions, I won't go into that because in looking at the item's general description, I think it covers what overall functions this multimeter provides.  But I thought I'd go over a few functions I like that you may make you consider this more expensive version of Etekcity's like of multimeters.  First of, this has auto ranging.  What is that you ask?  Well, you may be able to make out on the pictures of the UT-61A model, that it has no range selections on the dial like a normal multimeter.  This is because usually, you manually have to select the range you think the item your measuring for capacitance, resistance or voltage, might have.  Auto ranging allows the multimeter to determine this for you.  This means that you won't have to guess and better yet, it's less wear and tear on the dial mechanism because you only set the dial once to what you're trying to measure, and the multimeter will will automatically determine the proper range to set.  (About the dial...this is another indicator of build quality.  No cheapie feel to the movement of this thing.  It's movement from selection to selection is solid and the dial doesn't feel loose.  And the connection point of the test leads is also solid in feel.)The other features I like are the auto shut down feature.  After 30 seconds, it will perform a self shutoff, which should save battery life.  Lastly, I like the readout....extremely clear LCD display with large characters (over a 1/2 inch in size) make the display pleasingly visible.  There's also a controllable backlight in case you're working in a dark environment....  which is often the case if you're using you're multimeter to figure out why the lamp light went out and you're in the dark!Overall, I highly recommend this multimeter!  It works like a charm and I see no reason to rate it other than with 5 stars!

Received this quickly with Amazon Prime and set up was just as quick.  Just plug the receiver units in an electrical outlet and double-stick the transmitter in the location of your choice and that's it.  Instant doorbell chime in two rooms!  Great product!

I give this scale 5 Stars.  It's simple to use, straight forward operation is all one needs in a device meant simply to weigh one's weight.  After you put the two provided AAA batteries in the battery well underneath the scale, you simply have to turn it over, place it on a flat surface, stand evenly on the scale and wallah!....  Your weight is provided on the digital display.  Yet, as simple to use as this scale is, it does provide some key features one might look for, even in a scale as simple as this one.  First, the display is bright and easy to read in this regard.  To enhance readability further, the numerals are large and easily readable.  Second, the scale automatically turns on when weight is applied on it, and it conserves battery life automatically, by turning itself off after a few seconds.  Lastly, the design of the scale is very stylish with its sharp lines, low profile and glassy surface.  finally, the scale seems accurate.  While I wasn't able to determine how accurate it is in relation to a certified scale, I can vouch for its accuracy in the sense that it returned the same reading time and time again after weighing myself within a two minute period.  And after all....For a device whose intent usually will be to show fairly accurate weight in order to allow the user to judge the progress of diets and/or exercise, accuracy in terms of consistency is more important than how accurate the scale is in relation to a extremely accurate certified scale costing hundreds of dollars.  As such, I highly recommend this scale to others.

Here's my thoughts upon my recent purchase of the Etekcity 4 Port High Speed HDMI Switcher.  The switch was shipped promptly by Eteckcity and arrived in perfect condition.  While the packing of the product isn't important to many, I often take notice of how a products package is designed and how well the item is packed and presented.  I say this because more often than not, how a product is presented is often indicative of the company's due diligence by it's original manufacturer, towards the design of the product itself.  In the case of this HDMI switch, the switch came in a well designed box, with compartments to safely ship the individual components.  The switch's shiny plastic surface was protected from scratches by a thin sheet of film, and the remote control was wrapped in plastic for protection as well  The 3rd and last component (other than the instruction guide) was the AC adapter, whose cord was wound and bound for safe transport.  All in all, it seems some level of thought was placed into the packaging of the switch.  One other thing about the packaging.  The remote control uses a battery which was already installed in the remote, but the again, the manufacturer took time to design its packaging in such a fashion that the battery is prevented from being active from the time it was inserted, by the insertion of a thin plastic strip that sat between the battery and its contacts.  Once I removed the strip, the remote was ready to function.In terms of use, the HDMI switch is easy to use.  It's function is to receive inputs through multiple HDMI cables providing input signals from high definition sources such as TV's, gaming consoles, etc..... then allow that signal to be distributed to one HDMI output port on the switch.  Hence the 4 ports as described in the products description.  1 output port and 3 input ports.So why would someone need a switch like this?  In my case, I had an issue which the switch helped solve.  I have a flat screen TV which only has 3 input HDMI ports on it.  But as you might have guessed, i have way more devices that I often connect to the TV (Xbox, Playstation 3, overhead projector, gaming recorder, laptop, etc).  Two of the HDMI ports on my TV are on the back and because they're a pain to get to, I never touched the cables connected to those ports.  Instead, I was constantly pulling out and inserting HDMI cables into the third HDMI port on the side of the TV, and I realized that at some point, the connection to this third port would eventually wear out.  What I needed was a switch where I could connect the HDMI cables from the devices I wanted to use, then just select the one I wanted and have that signal sent to the TV through a cable I could leave connected at all times.  The Eteckcity switch was the answer and solved this problem flawlessly.Once I connected the HDMI cables from my 3 source devices and connected the single HDMI cable to my TV, I was ready to put the switch through its paces.  Once I turned on the source device i wanted to watch (in this case, my Xbox on port 2), I then switched my TV to the appropriate input.  When I turned on the TV, nothing was being displayed yet, but as soon as I took the remote control to swich to port 2, I was able to see my Xbox.  The picture was perfect with no visible distortions apparent from having to be sent through the switch.  How simple was that?  The Eteckcity switch worked as described.I should state at this point, that while the swich came with an instruction manual, but i didn't need to use it.  It seemed intuitive to me that I needed to connect the right cables coming in, connect the output cable to my TV, then simply turn everything on and switch the the right port on the switch.  However, the manual does describe some other functions that I don't plan on using.  One function would have been the ability of the switch to select between various output options such as 2 channel audio, 5.1 surround sound and 7.1 surround sound.  I say would have because this audio selectability feature is not supported on this switch.  I wouldn't have been able to test this for anyone anyway, since my set up only uses 2 channel sound.  But for those attempting to switch between 2 channel and surround channel sources over this switch, may want to contact the manufacturer to see if surround sound would be sent through the switch even if it was not selectable.  The manual did not say.  Why the remote shows this function is probably because the manufacturer wanted to make a remote that could be supported by several of it's products, including a product more advanced than this model.  I am not aware as to whether Etekcity sells a more advanced switch that uses this remote.  Again, you should contact them directly to find out, if you're interested in using this switch with a home set up that must use something other than (or in a addition to) 2 channel audio.The other feature that the manual describes on the remote, apparently is supported. It's the ability of the switch to support between multiple pictures displayed in a "picture in picture" signal.  Unfortunately, I was not able to test this for other prospective customers since none of my devices is currently leveraging picture in picture (PIP) functionality.  But I'm assuming that it provides the ability to connect a device with two or ore pictures being displayed on the one signal, and then be able to select through the remote, which of the pictures on the single single you want displayed.  Again, this is just my guess as to what this function supports.  The manual doesn't describe it's function in any detail, so you'll need to contact the manufacturer if you need that capability.In summary on the remote, there are many more buttons than you'll need (or be able to) use.  The manual describes which are functional with this switch and which are not.In summary on the switch, it's easy to set up, easy to use and functions well.  It's a simple switch, whose remote offers a nice touch (you don't have to get up in order to switch between input sources.  Just push a button).  And, I liked the price.  For me, it was just what the doctor ordered.

Today, I received my Etekcity, T3 Bluetooth Wireless speaker and I have to say that while I was looking for a small bluetooth, wireless speaker to listen to podcasts, I didn't expect the quality and performance I received in such a small device.Packaging:  First, the packaging.  The packaging was pretty impressive.  Sort of what you'd expect from a company like Apple.  But this product is from Etekcity and they didn't disappoint.  In my view, the package design often reflects the build quality of the product itself and as I'll explain later in my review, the design, quality and performance of the T3 speaker is fantastic.  So when I opened the shipping box to find such an impressive looking (albeit small) box, I immediately was excited and hopeful that the speaker would follow suit.  Opening the T3's outer box "shell" yielded further evidence of design carefully engineered to protect, separate and display the speaker and it's supporting contents.Box Contents:  Inside the beautifully designed packaging was the T3 wireless speaker, a USB charging cable, an instruction manual, and a surprise in the form of a cloth case to carry he speaker in when traveling.  NOTE:  the charging cable isn't very long so if you do not have other "mini" USB cables handy (not the newer "micro" USB cable often used with newer devices), jus keep his in mind.  Also, a charger is not supplied, so keep this mind also.  You can charge the T3 with a standard 1 amp or 2.1 amp charger provided with many of today's cell phones or simply charge the T3 by connecting it to a USB port on your PC or Mac.Start Up:  Getting the device connected was a snap.  I simply powered the T3 on, went to my iPhone's bluetooth setup and within about a minute, my iPhone "discovered" the T3, enabling me to hit the connect option on my iPhone.  Within seconds, my iPhone was "paired" with the T3 and I was ready for a sound test.  When attempting to pair devices such as the T3 to a computer, tablet or cell phone over Bluetooth, the device often has to placed into a "pairing" mode before it can be "discovered". In the case of hue T3, no such pairing mode was required.  The T3 connected flawlessly and in addition, it has continued to do so automatically after being turned off, or my iPhone Bluetooth was turned back on from an "off" state.Performance:  how do I describe performance?  Well, a Bose Bluetooth speaker it is not.  But neither is it as big as one either.  Holding the T3 in my hand, I'd describe it as being around the size of a tennis ball.  Bit it's cylindrical, so maybe a better description on its size would be like a jar of jelly that's 1/2 the height.  Despite its size, it took my podcast and made me forget that the sound I was hearing was originating from my iPhone.  The sound was deep, loud, with no audible distortion.  Not bad for a half of pint of jelly!Design:  besides the T3's size, the design of the T3 features an on/off button, a volume up button, volume down button, a button for pausing or playing audio content, a port to connect the mini USB cable, a headphone jack for listening to the sound streamed to the T3 silently over a headphone, and a tiny light hat flashes to indicate charging/charged conditions as well as pairing status.  On the bottom of the speaker, the T3 was designed such that when it is placed on a table, vibrations would be dampened.  In my tests, turning the sound all the way to max, did not yield any vibrating noises from the speaker.  The bottom of the speaker is also designed with tiny holes, which probably are used to increase the T3's bass response.  Finally, the design of the speaker is made so that the sound is projected from the very top.  Sound is not projected from the sides.  In fact the sides are surrounded with rubber for a nice tactile feel when handling the T3.Conclusion:  the Etekcity T3 Bluetooth Wireless speaker is a well assembled, well designed product that should give you years of quality use.  When expectations are paired correctly with proper use scenarios, it will meet your every expectation.  Similarly, purchase the T3 thinking you're going to shake the house down with the latest House and Techno music hits and you'll have unfairly set performance requirements never meant to be met with a speaker of this size.  With all this said, I highly recommend the T3 to anyone searching for a wireless, bluetooth speaker to extend/amplify the sound of tablets and cell phones.

I think having bought 3 of these recommend Water Right hoses over time probably convinces you, but if not, let me explain why I recommend this hose.First off, take my word for it when I say that you've probably never seen a hose like this at a hardware store, Target, Walmart, etc.  it may be its polyurethane composition or simply how it's made, but the minute you take it out of the box, you know it's made differently.  it's hard to describe why, but it just feels and looks better designed and made.  This has translated into great "coiling" characteristics.  It uncoils straight when needed, but when you're ready to put it away, it seems to coil however tight you want to have your coil for storage.  When it does get pinched, it immediately springs back with no visible creases nor any feeling as if the pinch is a reflection of the hoses wall weakness.  Instead, it's construction makes you feel confident that this hose will handle pinches forever.Other great features of this hose is the high quality connection hardware and safety.  The connectors look and feel high quality and the hose is guaranteed to be drinking water safe.The last thing I'll pass on to you is it's diameter.  This is a half inch hose so if you're used to the higher water delivery of more standard hoses you seem at your local hardware store, you might want to buy Water Rights "high delivery" rate model.  I don't believe that Amazon offers this version yet, but for myself, my opinion is that this "slim" version is adequate enough for any home use.  In fact, I believe before Water Right began selling their high delivery version, they provided test results for water delivery rates between their slim design hose and standard garden hoses and the differences were negligible ...  But if you feel you need a higher water rate for some special applications, look at their website to get info on the high delivery model.

I guess if you're reading this review, you may have been like me ...  In that you have a nice lawn being invaded by clovers or that dreaded Oxalis weed.  And you're probably wondering the same two things....  First, does it work and second, will it kill my grass.  Well, from my observations, the answer to the first question is yes, but for Oxalis, it may take a couple treatments.  I noticed that it has definitely affected the Oxalis, but because it's such an evasive, strong weed, it's leaves turned brown but the roots seem like they're still unaffected.  I'm hoping its early yet and the leaves are an early sign that it will eventually die.  But for sure, this particular variant of Scott's Weed-B-Gone has been formulated to systemically affect Oxalis.  I'll try to remember to update this review at a layer point in time, but even though my Oxalis doesn't appear to be "dead-dead", I'm satisfied that I found something that addresses it.As for the regular grass...  Well....  Good news!  So far at least, my regular grass seems unaffected.  And it remains so after a good drenching of Weed-B-Gone with a garden hose attachable sprayer.  So this made me even more pleased.The product seems to work as advertised, and even if it takes awhile to kill the Oxalis (or simply halts it's advancement) I'm happy.  Because at least I have something in my arsenal that affects Oxalis specifically and will not kill my Marathon Lawn...!  :-)

If your looking for a deal on an inexpensive case offering good protection, this Eco-Fused product should be what you're looking for.  Comes with the extras as indicated.  There are 4 cases, but my wife has chosen to use only the pink one so far, since that's her favorite color.  Fit like a glove.  We also put the screen protector on that came with the set, and it laid down nicely on the screen with no bubbles.  The supplied cleaning cloth was a nice touch, as we used it to remove any dust on the screen first.  Great deal.  Came in two days which is standard for Prime members.  Highly recommend!

Today I received my Etekcity Wireless-N Wifi Repeater.  Here's my thoughts on the product.BOX AND CONTENTS - Upon opening the box, I found some fairly decent instructions along with an ethernet cable and the repeater device itself.DOCUMENTATION - On a scale from 1 to 10 with 10 being best, for the documentation I'd say it rates an 8.  I've definitely seen better but I've also seen way more that were worse.  I docked the instruction manual 2 points because there were points in the documentation where it became obvious that a translation probably occurred into English, from it's original language.  None-the-less, even with a few translation issues, the documentation was easy to read and understand.  And for Windows users, the diagrams/images pretty much matched what I encountered when navigating the various steps towards getting my repeater up and running.  For Mac users (I actually have both Mac and Windows devices), the diagrams did not match what I saw through my Mac setup interface, but the the Repeater is so simple to set up, the minor differences really didn't hamper me from configuring it a second time through a Mac.SETUP - There are two basic modes for setup.  There's whats called a "Wireless Repeater" setup, where the repeater basically is set up to take your routers wireless signal and repeat it wirelessly, using the same Service Set ID (SSID) and password as the router, or there's a "Wireless AP Mode" setup, where the repeater is hardwired to the router via an ethernet cable, and a wireless signal is repeated from the location where the ethernet cable terminates into the repeater.  Quite frankly, i'm not sure why anyone would want to use the Wireless AP Mode.  One usually buys a repeater to get a better signal in a remote part of ones house or property and doing so by wiring the repeater to the router seems to defeat the purpose of the repeater.  But I'm sure there must be some situations where this would prove useful and/or the better option.  For myself, I chose the Wireless Repeater option.  So I navigated to the portion of the documentation that referenced this setup and in seven simple steps, the Repeater was configured.PERFORMANCE - I didn't apply any scientific tests to test performance of the Repeater.  But in my view, the real test is whether the Repeater solved the problem I expected it to, and in my case, the issue I had was a need to get a better signal out to my garage, so that my treadmill could receive a better wireless signal to allow me to play videos from the internet while exercising.  Did it meet my expectations?  With flying colors.  I had configured the Repeater in the house by plugging it into a socket next to my PC and Mac.  But after I configured the Repeater, I carried it out to the garage and placed it in sort of a "middle ground" location.  As soon as I booted up my treadmill, I was able to see that I had a solid Wifi signal and immediately, I was able to start playing around with the built-in web browser!!!OTHER - As with most other repeaters and wireless extenders, the Etekcity Wireless N Wifi Repeater comes with built-in software that allows you to configure and manage the device.  You initially log into the repeater with a default username and pass, but you can change the default within the software.  Also, when initially setting up the Repeater, you log into the repeater by connecting to it wirelessly as you would any other network.  It comes set up with a default SSID, which I was easily able to locate with my network card, and you shouldn't have to change this, but the software does allow you to change this default SSID (and associated password and security settings).  I did try playing with this feature, but I wasn't able to determine how this would be used, simply because the whole purpose of configuring the Repeater is so that it can REPEAT your router's SSID, pass and security settings at the remote location.  Once this is set up, the repeater reboots itself and at that point, as far as I was able to tell, even if you had changed the repeaters own default SSID, pass and security settings, you can't connect to the repeater through these settings once its rebooted.  Once it's configured and rebooted, the only SSID i was able to view was my router's repeated SSID.There are some other advanced settings in the Repeater that are available for modification from the software's interface, however I because I didn't have a need to modify any of these settings (at least not yet), I won't be able to comment on these option at this time.I highly recommend the Etekcity repeater because of its ease of setup/use and performance.

This is what I describe as an "I-want-to-live-inside-it" book. It's unhurried (but not slow), almost like the author is giving you a teaspoon to eat a dessert that they know youre going to want to savor.And I did. I LOVED this book.One reader online (I think there's a total of two short blurbs in all of cyberspace) suggested that this book was only for seasoned Warwick Deeping fans. But I would disagree. It IS wordy, but most readers who enjoy old fashioned storytelling won't have a problem with this. Of course, if you are a WD fan (as I am) it's just pure heaven.Basically, a wild young man of ease has one too many drunken sprees and ends up spending a year or two in prison. On release, he has one night of "the good ol days" and wakes up with self hate and remorse. Lacking purpose, he travels the continent and eventually finds a measure of peace connecting with nature in a forest, where he builds a cabin with his own hands.His nearest neighbors are a farming family, a deaf man of all trades, and a struggling author, his tubercular wife and a capable daughter who eventually becomes a love interest.But this isn't simply a love story, sub plots are money grabbing land owners, Roman ruins, treasure, sabotage, suicide etc.A wonderful story and a new favorite for my pile.CONTENT:PROFANITY: D'sVIOLENCE: A few fist fightsMY RATING: G

I'm being generous with two stars. This is a miserable, hopeless story.If you are considering this book because you are interested in pearl fishers, I would recommend Henry Dr Vere Stacpoole"s " The Pearl Fishers" instead.If you're reading this for some hidden literary merit because "It's STEINBECK, for goodness sake", then I can't help you. Read it and weep.

Pinocchio? Really? You're reading Pinocchio? Ok, I can explain this.A week or two ago, my mum and I were talking books, and my dad, feeling a little left out, announced that he also bought a novel at Barnes and Noble while my mum was purchasing a Victor Hugo... I was a little surprised because he doesn't really read anything except medical books or non-fiction."What did you buy?""Pinocchio.""Ha ha, funny. No really, what did you buy?""I bought Pinocchio."Silence."Yeah, the lady at the checkout was pretty surprised too.""You really bought Pinocchio?""Yeah, what's wrong with that?""Uh, nothing. Nothing, I...guess...."Lo and behold a box arrives in the mail the other day...Yup. Pinocchio.So I had to read it.And surprisingly, it's pretty good.It's a little dark, but some parts are very funny in a black humor sort of way. I'm not sure that all kids would appreciate this, it can be rather morbid at times and might give some bad dreams since Pinocchio does not get rescued from every calamity ( cos how would he learn his lesson, right? And how would kids know what happens when they're lazy, disobedient and dishonest?) but for the right child, it's awesome.By the way, did you know that Pinocchio's nose does not grow from lying, but rather anxiety? It just so happens lying causes anxiety but other things do, too. Lesson? A guilty conscience is always visible...Fun read for the proper audience. I'm not sure who that is, but if you enjoyed Struwwelpeter, then you're good to go. :)

3.5 StarsThere's nothing like conflicting reviews to make me want to read a book. Up until a half hour ago I never heard of this short story. I read the blurb and thought, oooh psychological thriller, yes please.Basically it's about a woman's decent into madness while staying in an attic room covered with ugly yellow wallpaper. We've all seen paper like this. The kind of pattern that twists and turns and makes phantom pictures when you're trying to sleep.Little by little, the woman starts to "figure out" the pattern and with it her escape...So ok, it's a little creepy. Nothing really upsetting though. It makes you think and feel for those mentally ill, and makes you really glad if you are sound in that way.Overall, a clever story.CONTENT: G (Mild PG if you're very sensitive)

Pleasant who-dunnit about a NYPD detective who, on probing the murder of a young woman, falls in love with her. And then one night while sitting in her old apartment musing the case, a woman in rain soaked clothes enters. .. is Laura really dead, after all? Who wants her dead and will he/she strike again?So this was good, I enjoyed it, but I enjoyed Vera Caspary's book "Bedelia" much more. "Bedelia" was highly atmospheric and you experienced the story at the same time as the characters, whereas in "Laura" we have a police investigation after the fact. It's a matter of taste.Also I guessed the villain/weapon/method far too early on which spoiled things a bit. But give it a go, it's a pleasant enough way to spend a few hours.CONTENT: Mild PGPROFANITY: D,B
