As the modern day Levites found out, it is not easy to live out Leviticus in the 21st Century. The results were pretty predictable. There was a lot of failure and frustration. The participants provided a lot of great insight and were honest about their struggles along the way. There were several times when I laughed out loud as I read.Pastor Harrell rightly states that obedience is a key part of the Christian life. We will never be able to be completely holy in this life. But that doesn't mean we should chuck the whole idea out the window. The fact that we are under grace through Christ does not mean that we are exempt from obedience and holiness. But it is only through Christ that we have any hope at all of being holy. We cannot do it on our own. I found it odd that Pastor Harrell and the participants focused only on the Old Testament. Especially since the New Testament has so much to say on the subject. I also find it odd that the book of Hebrews was never even mentioned. Especially since this New Testament book clearly shows how the Law was fulfilled by Christ.I don't doubt that everyone who took part in this experiment did so with good intentions. But I also believe that the experiment itself is fatally flawed. I understand what they were trying to do, but they were going about it in the wrong way.The New Testament  explicitly explains the purpose of the Law and why it was given. The book of Galatians compares and contrasts living under law and living under grace. Romans 3 also talks about the Law. Romans 5:14 tells us that the things that were written in the past (ie the Old Testament) were written for our instruction. It was written so we could learn from their mistakes. It was never intended as something for us to emulate. I think a lot of the time, we as Americans aren't willing to learn the lessons God wants us to learns. We write off the Israelites as ignorant. We think we would respond differently in the same situation. But human nature is human nature. It hasn't changed all that much. We are no better than the ancient Israelites, regardless of what we believe. I admit that I have often been guilty of this. For example, when reading about Adam and Eve and the Fall. I find myself thinking things like "Seriously? They had complete freedom to eat from any tree in the garden. Except that one. Why didn't they just walk away? Why did Eve listen to the lies of the serpent? Just because Eve chose to eat the fruit, doesn't mean that Adam had to. He could have made the right choice." I would like to think that if I had been in that garden, I would have made a different choice. But honestly, I'm not so sure. I am guilty of the exact same thing that Adam and Eve did. I blame God and other people for my sinful choices. I try to rationalize and justify my sin. There are times when I read a command or teaching in Scripture and tell myself that obedience is optional. We all do it. There are many lessons to be learned from the Old Testament. If we are willing to pay attention.To illustrate this, I am going to list a bunch of Bible verses from the book of Galatians. Unless otherwise noted, all verses are taken from the New Living Translation (NLT) My comments are in parenthesis at the end of each verse.Galatians 2:19 For when I tried to keep the law, it condemned me. So I died to the law-I stopped trying to meet all its requirements-so that I might live for God.Galatians 3:10 But those who depend on the Law to make them right with God are under His curse. For the Scriptures say  "Cursed is everyone who does not observe and obey all the commands that are written in God's Law.Galatians 3:19 Why then was the law given? It was given alongside the promise to show people their sins.Galatians 3:23 Before the way of faith in Christ was available to us, we were placed under guard by the law. We were kept in protective custody, so to speak, until the way of faith was revealed (The law was only intended to be temporary. Once Christ paid the penalty for sin on the cross and rose from the dead. The law was no longer needed. Christ Himself stated that He didn't come to abolish the law, but to fulfill it.)Galatians 5:1 So Christ has truly set us free. Now make sure that you stay free and don't get tied up again in slavery to the Law. (Salvation in Christ was first offered to the Jews and then to the Gentiles. Paul makes it crystal clear that Gentile believers were not required to keep the law, and Jewish believers were set from its requirements as well. This verse compares trying to please God by keeping the law slavery.  I simply don't get it. Why would anyone who has experienced the grace, mercy, forgiveness, and freedom that only Christ can give, want to go back to the old system of bondage?)Galatians 5:4 For if you are trying to make yourselves right with God by obeying the law, then you have been cut off from Christ. (This warning is never even mentioned in the book. But readers of the book would do well to heed it, if they ever feel the desire to attempt a similar experiment)Romans 3:19-20 Obviously, the law applies to those to whom it was given. For its purpose is to keep people from having excuses and to show that the entire world is guilty before God. For no one can ever be made right with God by doing what the law commands. The law simply shows us how sinful we are.The book of James also gives a clear picture of the futility of trying to keep the law to earn God's favor.James 2:10 (NIV)For whoever keeps the whole of the law and yet stumbles at just one point is guilty of breaking all of it. This verse reminds me of a project in my 8th grade Tech Ed Class. We made bottle lamps out of champagne bottles. In fact, I still have mine and can see it as type this. One by one, the teacher asked each student to plug their lamp into the socket. If it lit, you got an A. If it didn't, you got an F. Those were the only two possible grades. It was pass or fail. This verse from James tells us the same is true in regards to the law. There is no grading on the curve. If you keep the law perfectly, down to the smallest detail, then you are declared innocent. If not, you are found guilty. But you aren't just guilty in the area where you fell short. If you break God's law in one area, you are guilty of breaking His law in every area.  Even if it was just a minor infraction, it doesn't matter. You are still guilty. That is what makes grace so incredible and amazing. Jesus did for us what we could never do for ourselves. He set us free from the penalty of sin and the law.)God give us a choice. But there are really only two options. We can either try to live a righteous life on our own by keeping the law(and fall miserably short) or we can accept the grace, mercy, forgiveness, and freedom that Christ paid such a heavy price to secure for us. But we need to understand, that the stakes are incredibly high and the consequences are serious and eternal. We can't have it both ways.One of the best resources that I've found on the Old Testament is a book called "The Message of the Old Testament."  by Mark Devers. In this book, Pastor Devers goes through each book of the Old Testament. First he gives some background information for each book. Then he lists and discusses in detail the main themes and teachings of each book. Lastly, he shows how the Old Testament and New Testament are linked. A friend sent me this book a couple of years ago. It has greatly helped my understanding and appreciation of the Old Testament. Pastor Devers also has a similar book on the New Testament.

I have been using Lancome Teint Miracle for the past couple of months. I found to be an average foundation. It's not awful, but it's not amazing either. I didn't like that it turned into a greasy mess on my nose, and the staying power wasn't the greatest either, even with primer. I bought Skin Balancing foundation from the Body Shop (it was on sale for $5 and is usually $22) and also got a sample of Laura Mercier Oil Free Supreme Makeup. Neither one really worked for me. One foundation that I wanted to try was Makeup Forever HD Invisible Cover Foundation. I stumbled across a blog online that said Revlon Photoready Liquid Makeup is a dupe for MUFE HD Invisible Cover.There is a grocery store about 2 blocks from my house that has a small cosmetics section. They carry Revlon and Cover Girl cosmetics. I know a lot of people on this site really like Revlon Colorstay. They have a formula for oily skin. It took me a while to decide between that foundation and the Photo Ready Liquid Foundation. In the end, I decided to try the Photoready foundation.I have to be honest, I'm generally not a big fan of drugstore foundations. Either I'm allergic to something in it, it looks great at first and fades away to nothing after about 3-4 hours, or looks cakey, heavy, and thick. I've tried a couple of drugstore foundations that never even made it out of the house they looked so awful. (L'oreal Infallable, the Body Shop foundation I mentioned earlier, and Maybelline Fit Me all fit into this catagory) Also, finding the right shade in drugstore foundations is both challenging and frustrating because there are no testers. The store lights make it hard to choose the correct shade. It can look one way in the bottle and totally different when you put it all. I've noticed that drugstore foundations also have a tendancy  to oxidize more than high end foundations.I intially purchased the Photoready in shade 06 Medium Beige. It looked like a perfect match when I first applied it, but it did oxidize a little. I didn't look like an oompa loompa or anything, but it was definitely a little too orange. It wasn't enough to be embarassing, but it was noticeable. So I went back to the store and did an even exchange for the next shade down, which is natural beige. This seemed to be a much better match for my skin.Here is how I apply it: First, I apply a tiny amount of my Aveeno Baby Daily Moisturizing Lotion and rub it in completely. Then I apply the foundation, and finish it off with a light dusting of loose powder.This stuff is amazing! It doesn't transfer, it looks natural, and the staying power is great. I've had it on almost 9 hours and it still looks great. It has only worn off the tiniest bit on my nose. The coverage is amazing too. It does a good job of covering up the redness and smoothing out the tiny bumps on my face. It dries quickly, but not too quickly. It is easy to blend and is buidable. I usually apply two thin layers and it never looks cakey or heavy. I paid $14.99 for this foundation, but I found it at Target for $10.99 I absolutely love this foundation and hope that it is never discontinued. There are a lot of reviews out there that say this foundation doesn't work very well on oily skin. But it's worked great for me. My search for my HG foundation is over!I've never actually tried the MUFE HD Invisible Cover, so I can't really say if it's similar to that or not. I NEVER thought I would fall in love with a drugstore foundation. Never in a million years. But I have. The MUFE HD costs $45 for 1 oz of product. The Revlon Photoready is $10.99 for 1 oz. I don't mind paying $45 for a foundation, but why should I when there is a drugstore version that costs about 1/3 the price? It's a no brainer for me.

Ever since college, I've struggled with my weight. I was never obese as a child or a teenager. But once I hit my 20s and 30s, I started gaining weight. At my heaviest, I weighted 260 pounds. I'm tall (about 5'11) so I didn't look awful, but I definitely feel as good. I also was diagnosed with both high blood pressure and high cholesterol. I finally realized it was time to make a change. I eventually decided to a modified version of Weight Watchers. I followed the eating plan, but didn't go to meetings. I was successful, I ended up losing 60 pounds.  But eventually, I got frustrated and fell of the wagon. I ended up regaining about 20 pounds. It wasn't enough that I had to go back on my meds and none my clothes fit, but it was still disappointing. There were several things about the Weight Watchers plan that I found frustrating and hard to stick with. First, it was hard to stick to the plan during special events like holidays and parties. I enjoy going out to eat with friends on occasion. When I was following Weight Watchers, I was often confronted with a choice: Do I eat what I want, feel guilty, and blow my diet? or do I order something I don't really want just to stay true to my diet? I have to be honest, there were times when I ate and ordered things I really didn't want, just for the sake of staying true to my diet. When I first started Weight Watchers, the Points Plus system didn't bother me. But after a while, I got really tired of having to look up the point value for every single thing I put on my mouth. When I cook, I make a lot of casseroles. I do try to prepare healthy meals. But it got really tedious having to look up the point values for each ingredient in the casserole.I have read countless diet books and haven't found one that really provided what I was looking for. Either they were too restrictive, too complicated, or didn't give me enough guidance about how and what to eat. I wanted to find a diet that didn't require any measuring, counting, or complicated formulas. I wanted a weight loss technique that gave me freedom to make my own choice, made nothing off limits, and could be easily incorporated into my lifestyle. I recently purchased a copy of Women's Day Magazine. In there, there was an article that mentioned this book and eating plan. To be honest, I was skeptical. I have found that if something sounds too good to be true, it usually is. But I was intrigued by the idea of 1:1:1 so I ordered a sample on my Kindle. I figured if I hated the book, I hadn't lost anything. I was so impressed by what I read in the sample that I immediately ordered the full book.The premise of this book is incredibly simple. You simply eat one carb, one protein, and one fat with each meal and snack. That is it! There is no counting of anything (fat, carbs, points, calories) and no hardline restrictions or foods that are off limits. the doctor also gives you a huge selection of possible meal ideas and recipes using normal, every day, easily available foods. But the possibilities for meals are really endless. I disagree with a previous reviewer who said that you have to eat 2 or 3 items with every meal and snack. I disagree. For example, today for lunch I had a tuna sandwich. This fits the 1:1:1 framework. The tuna was the protein, the two slices of bread was the carb, and the mayo was the fat. Everything all in one neat easy package. This is not a diet, it is a lifestyle change. If you want to have chocolate, ice cream, dessert, or a baked good, you can with this plan. You can eat whatever you want without feeling guilty. the author is a nutritionist, so of course, she does encourage you to make healthy choices as much as possible, but she also gives you permission and freedom to indulge is some so-called unhealthy choices from time to time. You are allowed a generous portion of food on this plan. You get 3 meals and two snacks. She breaks it down in a way that is easy to apply and understand. She also gives you suggestions as to what to eat. But she also makes a point of saying that these are simply ideas, they are NOT a set meal plan.I read this book in one sitting. As soon as I read the last page, I thought to myself "Now, this I can do." I can't wait to give it a try. If you are sick and tired of complicated, restrictive, or fad diets, do yourself a favor and purchase this book. You won't be sorry.

I had been using Burt's Bees Sensitive Facial Cleanser with Cotton Extract. I liked it, but it comes in a 5oz tube that was lasting me about a month. It was also $9.99. I was wondering around Target and saw this product. It's $8.99 for a 12 oz tube. I also like that has a pump rather than a squeeze tube. It makes it much easier to control how much comes out. My skin is very oily and very allergy-prone. I've had allergic reactions to products that claim to be for sensitive skin before. So I'm a little apprehensive about trying new things in my face. I never really know how my skin is going to react.I can't really comment on how this cleanser works for removing makeup, because I don't use it for that. I use it to cleanse my face in the shower. This cleanser claims to be Ultra Gentle and it definitely is. It didn't irritate my skin or cause any type of allergic reaction. It rinses off in a snap and doesn't leave any kind of a film behind. It foams nicely and leaves my skin feeling clean and fresh after I use it. I also like that you get 12 oz of product rather than 5 or 6 oz like other facial cleansers. I have no complaints whatsoever about this product and will continue to buy and use it.

I purchased this because I was having trouble finding the correct shade of Lancome Teint Idole Ultra. The shade I purchased was WAY too dark and make me look like an oompa loompa. But I lost my receipt and wasn't able to exchange it until I got my new state id. So I needed something for a few days. I saw a lot of positive reviews for this, so I decided to give it a try. I also had heard that it was a drugstore dupe for Makeup Forever Mat Velvet.I feel like the foundation was nothing but a huge waste of money. I honestly don't understand why this product has so many positive reviews. It's not the worst foundation I've ever used, but it's the third worst foundation I've ever used.I read all the previous reviews on this site, and saw that there are several reviews that state this is a full-coverage makeup. I disagree. In my opinion, it's sheer to light coverage. It's a long way from medium coverage, much less full coverage. I have a lot of bumps and redness on my face, especially on my chin, nose, and cheeks. I applied it using a brush. It literally did NOTHING to cover up the redness. Even after blending, you could still clearly see the redness through the makeup. It also settled into very bump on my face and made them stand out even more. It didn't do anything to blur or cover them.As far as being buildable, forget about it. When I tried to build it up in areas where I need a bit more coverage (especially on my cheeks) it looked (and felt) heavy and cakey. I've also tried Makeup Forever Mat Velvet, which is much more buildable, and looks a lot more natural. In my opinion, that makeup has nothing in common with this one. I do like the Mat Velvet, but it turned into a greasy, slimy mess in the areas where I'm most oily. So I quit using it.I can't really comment on the staying power of this foundation because I only had it on for about 10 minutes. I wouldn't feel comfortable wearing this out in public. If you have flawless skin and only need sheer to light coverage, you will probably love this makeup. But if you have any type of bump, scar, or flaws on your face, I would suggest avoiding this makeup. This has happened to me so many times with drugstore foundations. That is why I will stick with my Lancome Teint Idole Ultra. Yes, it's a lot more expensive, but it gives me the coverage, finish, and staying power I want. So to me, it's worth the extra money. I went to Sephora and got color matched in the Teint Idole Ultra and was FINALLY able to figure out the correct shade. So I will be sticking with that foundation. I would not repurchase this foundation and wouldn't use it even as a backup.

Several months ago, I severely damaged my hair by using Not Your Mother's Clean Freak Dry Shampoo. My hair became very dry, brittle, and started falling out. Not enough to really freak me out, but definitely more than normal. I've tried numerous product since then to restore and repair my hair.  I've tried several different products, but haven't found one that really made a major difference.First, I tried Aussie 3 Minute Miracle Deeeep Conditioner, which worked great for awhile, but then quit working. Next, I tried Garnier Hydra Recharge Deep Conditoner. It made my hair soft, but didn't do much to repair the damage. I also tried Neutrogenia Triple Moisture Daily Deep Conditioner. Even though this made my hair silky and shiny, once again, it didn't do much of anything in terms of repairing the damage.Yesterday, I was at Sally's Beauty. I'd done some research on deep conditioners from there, and wanted to try one out. I was looking around when I stumbled across their Generic Value Products Collection. This collection includes a variety of hair care products including shampoo, conditioner, gel, hairspray, and a couple different deep conditioners. This line are basically generic versions of high end salon products like Redkin, Paul Mitchell, and Matrix. I purchased a 6 oz tube for about $4.50. It lists the ingredients for the Paul Mitchell version and the Generic version right on the tube. The ingredients are identical.I used it for the first time this morning, and I noticed a major improvement in my hair after just one use. My hair looks and feels more healthy. You only need a very small amount. This is a very thick conditioner. I thought it might be really hard to rinse out, but it wasn't at all. I was also afraid it would weigh down my hair and make it look gross and greasy. But it didn't at all. I would NEVER pay for the Paul Mitchell version, but with this gem, I don't need to. You get basically the same product for a fraction of the price. I highly recommend this conditioner to anyone who has dry, damaged hair. It truly is amazing!

First off, let me say that I am not at all acne prone. I can count on one hand the number of pimples I've had in my life.  But a couple months ago, I developed some pretty big whiteheads. I think it may have been from a crappy foundation. At the time they developed, I was trying various different drugstore foundations. So it could have been any one of them. I'm not sure which one. But I had quite a few whiteheads. I had one on my right cheek, a cluster of four on my forehead, and another cluster of 4 on the very top of my forehead, just under my hairline. I tried several different products to try to get rid of the whiteheads, but nothing really worked. I tried Clean and Clear Acne Spot Treatment (salicylic acid) a tea tree oil cream, and Neutrogena On the Spot Acne Treatment (Benzoyl Peroxide) I used them all 2-3 times a day, for over a month, but there was no change in my whiteheads. I was getting frustrated and discouraged.I work as a cashier. I recently had a customer come through my line and buy this Zit Zapper. She asked me if I'd ever tried it, and told me a friend of hers swears by it. I told her I'd never tried it. I know we sell quite a bit of it though. I had some time to kill after work, and my curiosity got the better of me. I decided to buy some. I had very low expectations. My skin is extremely sensitive and very allergy-prone. I figured I'd use it once, have an allergic reaction, and end up tossing it in the trash. But then I realized, I didn't have anything to lose. After all, it only costs $1. So if it ended up in the trash, it's not like I'd be out a lot of money.Here is how I apply it. First, I completely remove my makeup. Then I roll the product on to my fingertip and spread a thin layer on the whiteheads. I let it dry, (which takes only a few seconds) and then apply a second layer. I apply it just before I go to bed, so it has a chance to soak in and do it's thing.I've been using this for about 3 days now. It is AMAZING! The cluster of whiteheads just below my hairline is almost completely gone. The cluster on my forehead and the one on my cheek, have also shrunk significantly. I think it will take only one or two more treatments before they are gone completely. I see and feel improvement every time I use it. I've also used this after cleansing my face after my shower. I use it under my primer and foundation. It dries clear, so no one even knows I have it on.My skin tolerates this product really well. I haven't had ANY problems at all as far as irritation or allergic reactions. In addition to being sensitive and allergy prone, my skin is also extremely oily. The Clean and Clear Acne Spot Treatment caused a slight burning sensation. It didn't do much to shrink my whiteheads, but it definitely caused the surrounding skin to become very dry and flaky. But I didn't have either of those issues with this Zit Zapper.I've read a lot of reviews where the smell seems to be an issue for a lot of people. People have commented that it smells terrible, but it's not an issue for me. In fact, I rather like the smell. This product doesn't have a lot of complicated ingredients. It contains salicylic acid, witch hazel, and tea tree oil. That's it.As I mentioned earlier, I only rarely get pimples, so I can't really comment on how it works for that. But it has worked wonders on my whiteheads/clogged pores. I hope I don't get any more whiteheads, but if I do, I will definitely use this product again. I have already purchased a second tube, and will continue to repurchase.This is the first E.L.F. product I've ever used. I have to say, I'm very impressed. This product works great and it works quickly. Best of all, it only costs $1! This works better than products that cost more than double the price. Give a try, if you don't like it or it doesn't work for you, you're only out a dollar.I recommend this product for all skin types. It can be used on even the most sensitive skin. Great product.

There are a couple of topics I absolutely HATE hearing sermons on. One is marriage (primarily because I'm single and intend to stay that way) and the other is money.I've heard many sermons on the topic of stewardship, and most of the time, I cringe inwardly the entire time. I've even read a few books on stewardship. I've found that most Christian pastors and authors approach stewardship in one of two ways.First, there is the Prosperity Gospel camp. These folks typically say that God wants all His children to be rich and that financial blessings are the primary way God blesses faithfulness. In my opinion, this teaching doesn't square with the whole of Scripture, especially the teachings of Jesus Himself. It reduces God to a genie. If you send in a large enough donation, pray the right prayer, or claim the right verse, then God has no choice but to bless you financially. If you are poor, it's your own fault because your faith is too weak and you aren't trusting God to provide. Proponents of the Prosperity Gospel also frequently twist Scripture and quote it out of context.On the opposite end of the spectrum are those who try to use guilt and intimidation in regards to stewardship. People of this persuation usally put a lot of emphasis on tithing (giving God the top 10%) and frequently quote Malachi 3:8. It is implied (and sometimes directly stated) that believers who don't tithe are robbing God. If you are bold enough to question, why you should tithe, you will probably not get a straight answer. You will probably just be told the Bible commands it and that's it. But in my opinion, it's not quite that simple. I believe that it is possible for someone to tithe regularly out of less than pure motives. It can lead to legalism. Just because a person tithes doesn't necessarily mean a person has a right attitude and heart towards money. There are many non-believers who are far more generous with their money than a lot of Christians. It's sad, but true.This book manages to avoid both of these pitfalls. Andy Stanley is definitely NOT a prosperity preacher. But he also doesn't restore to guilt-trips to motivate people to give. Instead, he focuses on an issue that is almost completely neglected when it comes to finances. Fear. Andy Stanley asserts (and I completely agree) that the main reason many (if not most) Christians don't give generously isn't pride or selfishness, but fear. In this current econonmy, many people are struggling to afford essentials like food, rent, and gas. They are just barely able to make ends meet as it is. It seems impossible and unfair to be expected to give when you can barely afford the true necessities. I can't speak for anyone else, but I know this is very true in my case. I often feel torn. I want to be generous and give, but I feel like I can't because I can't afford my own apartment, groceries, or a car, gas and insurance. I am living paycheck to paycheck, with very little left over.But rather than emphasizing the importance of the tithe, the basis for Andy Stanley's teaching is found in another portion of Scripture all together. It is found in 2nd Corinthians 9:7 (NIV) Each of you should give what you have decided in your heart to give, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver.The Lord has definitely been stretching me in the area of giving and stewardship. He has been challenging me to step out of my comfort zone. He has also challenged me to change my attitude and thinking in regards to money and how I spend it. This is an area where I really struggle. But I know I am not alone. I think there are many Christians who struggle in the area of finances. But they are afraid to speak up.Guilt will only motivate people to give for so long. Eventually, they will get fed up and just say forget it. A person who truly wants to be generous must allow God to truly change their heart and attitude towars money. It won't happen overnight, but it will happen if they allow God to truly transform their heart and mind.I highly recommend this book to anyone who is new to the subject to stewardship or to anyone who is fed up with the two extremes I mentioned above. I also recommend any of the other books by Andy Stanley. He writes in a way that is convicting and thought-provoking, yet practical and easy to understand.

Yesterday, I had some time before work and went into Sephora to repurchase my Makeup Forever Mat Velvet, because I didn't want to run out. The SA who checked me out, asked if she could get me a sample of anything. I asked for a sample of this.  According to my Color IQ number (1Y07) I was matched to shade 2.2, so that's the one I requested a sample of.To be honest, there isn't a whole lot I liked about this foundation.COLOR: The color was good in terms of not being too light or too dark. But I think this foundation is definitely geared towards people with yellowish undertones. My skin is light-medium with cool undertones. As a result, this foundation looked very yellow on me.COVERAGE: Other reviewers have stated this is a medium to full coverage foundation. I don't agree. In my opinion, this gives light to barely medium coverage. Definitely not as good as my Makeup Forever Mat Velvet. I also found this foundation extremely difficult to blend. I like fast drying foundations, but this one dries crazy fast. I mean, it touches your skin and it's dry.  No matter how hard I tried to blend it, it just wouldn't cooperate. It never really absorbed into my skin. It just kind of sat on the surface. It also didn't do much of anything in terms of covering up the redness. Even worse, it settled into and emphasized every bump on my face and made them even more noticeable. Definitely NOT what I was going for. BUILDABLE: I don't think this foundation is buildable AT ALL. One layer doesn't cover much of anything, but applying more than one layer is a recipe for disaster. Trying to build this up even a little bit results in it looking thick, heavy, cakey and VERY unnatural.DURABILITY-I can't really say if this foundation stays on 15 hours or not. I only had it on about 10 minutes tops. It took me 3x as long to apply my makeup, and I absolutely hated the results when I was done. It looked like a mask. Definitely not the look I was going for. In fact, I would have been embarassed to wear this foundation in public. There was no way I was going to work looking like that. So I removed this foundation and reapplied the Mat Velvet.BOTTOM LINE: I'm glad I gave this foundation a try. But I'm also VERY glad I got a sample as opposed to splurging on a full-sized bottle right off the bat. In my opinion, this foundation is just not worth the extra money. I will not be purchasing a full-size bottle of this. I am very happy with the results I get from the Mat Velvet and intend to stick with that.I would recommend this foundation for people with yellowish skin tones and flawless skin. But if you have cool (reddish) undertones and any type of scar, bump, or fine lines, I would not recommend this foundation. I highly recommend the Mat Velvet, however.

My skin is extremely oily and extremely allergy prone. As the result of a genetic disease, I have a lot of redness and small bumps on my face. Both of which make me extremely self-conscious. I've tried so many different liquid foundations, and have been disappointed with them all. Either they faded away into oblivion after about 4 hours, (even with primer)didn't give me the coverage I was looking for (medium to full) or looked heavy, cakey, and unnatural.A couple months ago, I decided to try the Color IQ system at Sephora. They use a really tiny camera to take pictures of your face, neck, and cheeks. Then it is entered into a computer and you are given a 4 digit number. Mine is Y107. You can then use this number to find your shade in any foundation Sephora carries. I was skeptical, but the foundations I've tried based on my number have been perfect matches.For trying the Color IQ, you also recieve two free foundation samples. The two I were given was Hourglass Immaculate Liquid Powder foundation and this one. The Hourglass was good as far as shade, but I really didn't like it.I was also given a sample of this foundaiton. I'd been wanting to try this foundation for awhile, but didn't want to commit to a full-sized bottle before I knew if I liked it. According to my Color IQ number, my shade is 35 Vanilla. When I first saw it in the sample cup, I was concerned it would be too light. But once I applied it, it was a perfect match. In fact, I don't think I've ever used another foundation that matched as well as this one does. I love everything about this foundation. It is easy to apply (I apply it with my fingers) a little goes a long way, it lasts all day, does a good job of controlling oil, and gives me a natural, flawless finish. It gives me that "my skin only better" look I was after. It is very buildable. I never have to worry about it looking cakey or too heavy. It also covers everything I want covered. I finish with a light dusting of loose powder, and I'm good to go.I did end up returning this foundation because I thought I was allergic to it. Shortly after I purchased a full-sized bottle, I started itching. So I returned the foundation. But the itching didn't stop, in fact, it got progressively worse. I finally realized it wasn't this foundation I was allergic to, and immediately repurchased it. It turn out I was actually allergic to the L'oreal Damage Erasing Balm I was using on my hair. I stopped using it and the itching went away.There are a few things I don't like about this foundation, two of them I can live with, but the third is a deal breaker. First, I don't like the bottle it comes in. First, it's very small. I wish you got a little more product for the price, but it's the standard 1 oz. You only need a little, so the bottle lasts a long time. I've been using it daily for over two months, and I'm still on my first bottle. I also don't like that the bottle isn't see through. It makes it a bit challenging to see how much is left in the bottle. If these were the only issues, I would repurchase this foundation in a heartbeat.But my biggest complaint with this foundation is that it turns into a slimy, greasy mess on the areas where I'm most oily (my nose, area around my nose, and my chin) after about 5 hours. I even tried using it with an oil absorbing primer to see if that would make a difference. It didn't. Which is a shame, because this foundation looks amazing all day on my forehead and cheeks (where I'm somewhat less oily) But it looks and feels awful on the areas where I'm most oily. I did purchase a second bottle of this, but I think I'm going to return it. If you are only moderately oily, you will probably love this foundation. But if you are super oily, then you will want to avoid this foundation.

I cannot  think of a more ironically named foundation that this. This foundation is definitely NOT infallable in my opinion. In fact, I would say this is THE WORST foundation I have ever used.  I am trying to find a drugstore foundation that will get me through the next week or so until I can purchase the MAC Matchmaster, which is currently out of stock in my shade. After a major disaster with Maybelline Fit Me Foundation, I decided to give this foundation a try. I'd read online that it was good for people with oily skin. I also had a coupon for Ulta for $3.50 off a $10 purchase. So I used (or should I say wasted) it on this foundation. I purchased this in Shade 613 True Beige. I usually need more of a natural beige, but this foundation seems to run light. I could tell just by looking at it that the Natural Beige was going to be way too light. The lady at Ulta suggested the True Beige and I agreed. With my coupon, I paid 9.96 for this foundation. I tried it for the first time this morning.I like the pump. That's pretty much the only thing I liked about this foundation.This foundation is very thick. The first time I tried to squirt some out, the only thing that came out was some light brown water. So I shook it and tried it again. Still really runny and watery. I shook it again and it finally came out decent.This definitely is NOT a lightweight foundation. If you are looking for a liquid foundation that will give you a natural look, this is definitely not it. It is  thick and heavy even when it is wet, even more so when it dries. This is not a makeup that you apply and forget its on. You can definitely feel it on your face. If you have any flaws at all, this makeup will do nothing except magnify them. I remember wearing clown makeup as a kid for Halloween one year. That is pretty much what this makeup feels like on your face. It is also very cakey. It is  difficult to spread and blend. It is also not at all buildable.  This is a case of you cannot win no matter what you do. If you apply a thin layer, the coverage is very sheer. If you try to build it up, it looks cakey, unnatural, and pretty much  awful.At first, I thought I had  a good color match. When the foundation was wet, it seemed fine.  But once it dried and was on awhile, it turned very orange. I cannot really comment on the staying power of this makeup, because I could only stand to have it on my face for a little over an hour. I could not wait to take it off. I really had to scrub to get it off. After I completely removed this foundation, my face felt sticky. I tried using water to get rid of it, but that didn't work. I ended up using my Clinique Foaming Face wash before applying different makeup. The bottom line is this: Don't waste your time or money on this foundation.For drugstore foundations, I recommend Boots No 7 Beautifully Matte. For high end, I recommend MAC Matchmaster or Makeup Forever Mat Velvet.

This is the second worst foundation I have ever used. I purchased this because MAC is currently sold out of my shade of the Matchmaster. My sample was running out, and I needed something to hold me over until my next payday.  have no idea  where to start regarding the things I hate  about this foundation. I bought this because it was relatively cheap, and I wanted to give it a try. Finding the right shade was really tricky. There is a little paper shade chart, but it is pretty much useless. It does not at all resemble the actual shade of the makeup.First, it comes in a glass bottle without a pump. The glass bottle does not  bother me, but the lack of a pump kind of does. Even though I shook it before I applied it, it still came out very watery and runny. You waste a lot of product.I also did not like the way this foundation felt on my face. Even though it comes out of the bottle very watery and runny, it looks and feels very thick and heavy on your face. This foundation also does not  dry very quickly. It never really absorbed into my skin either. It just kind of sat on the surface, making me look and feel like I was wearing a mask. Even after it dries, this foundation looks slimy and wet. Definitely not attractive.Third, this foundation provides almost no coverage. It is very sheer. If you need only very light coverage and have flawless skin (which I definitely do not) this foundation might work for you. But it did nothing to cover the redness on my face at all. It made the small bumps on my face really stand out. Definitely not what I was going for.Fourth, this foundation is not buildable at all. When I tried to build it up just a little, it looked terrible. It looked thick, heavy, gloppy, and not at all natural. It pretty much screamed "Look, I'm wearing makeup."When I purchased this foundation, I brought along my sample of the Matchmaster foundation to try to get a good match. I thought I had succeeded. I purchased this in Shade 230 Natural Buff. When I got it home, I applied a small amount to my chest and compared it to the skin on my neck. It looked like a perfect match. But within a few minutes of applying it to my face, it darkened and turned REALLY yellow. In the bottle, it looked like exactly the same color as my Matchmaster foundation.This foundation is NOT for gals with oily skin. I only had this on for about an hour and a half this morning, and I could already see and feel my face getting greasy. Even with MOM underneath, I do not think I would have even gotten 3 hours of decent wear out of this foundation. But I did not  leave it on my face long enough to find out. There was no way I was going to go to work with this stuff on my face. Fortunately, I was able to get one more use out my Matchmaster foundation. I have already purchased a different drugstore foundation to get me through until I can repurchase the Matchmaster. After I took this off, the bottle went where it belongs. Straight into the garbage. I will not be wearing or purchasing this foundation again.

I bought this on a whim after finding it in the clearance bin at Target. I paid $1.04 for it. I have to say, I wasn't really all that impressed.This is a thick, rich creamy conditioner. On the plus side, it didn't give me an allergic reaction, I like the smell, and it didn't weigh my hair down.In my opinion, this is not really a deep conditioner. If you are looking for just a regular conditioner, you will probably really like this product. If, however, you are looking for something to repair dry, damaged hair, this isn't it.If you want  a deep conditioner that really works, I highly recommend Neutrogena Triple Moisture Daily Deep Conditioner. My hair was extremely damaged after I used a dry shampoo for several days in a row, back in March. My hair was dry, brittle, and falling out. Every morning after my shower, I was having to pull hair out of the catch in the drain. But not anymore. The Neutrogena Triple Moisture Daily Deep Conditioner pretty much saved my hair. It leaves my hair shiny, soft, and healthy. I love running my fingers through my hair after using it. I can see and feel a major difference in my hair after using this product. The longer I use it, the better my hair gets.In my opinion, this John Frieda Conditioner simply can't compare to the Neutrogena Triple Moisture Daily Conditioner. I got much better results from that, and intend to keep using it. All things considered, I'm glad I only purchased a travel size. I will not be purchasing a full-sized tube of the John Frieda Full Repair Full Body Conditioner.

I work retail, so occassionally, I am scheduled to work at 8:00 a.m. When that happens, I usually take my shower the night before.  My hair is normally pretty oily, so it looks greasy and limp if I don't shampoo it every day. I bought this dry shampoo on a whim. It's relatively cheap, and a fairly big bottle.When I first started using it, I loved the results. It did a good job of controlling the oil and you couldn't even tell I'd washed my hair the night before. I also liked that you got the desired effect using very little product.But then in March, I was scheduled for 8:00 a.m. shifts 5 days in a row. I washed my hair the night before, and then used this dry shampoo before work in the morning. The following week, I noticed a major change in my hair. It became very dry, brittle, and started falling out. When I blow dry my hair, I run my fingers through it as I'm drying it, just to fluff it out a little more. When I would do this, I would find numerous strands between my fingers.  I also started noticing more hair falling out in the shower. Not enough to really freak me out,  but definitely more than normal. My hair started looking like straw, which has NEVER been a problem for me before. I realized it had to be from this dry shampoo. So I stopped using it and threw it in the trash. But the damage was already done to my hair.I tried several deep conditioners, but couldn't find one that repaired the damage and made my hair healthy again.  But then I found Neutrogenia Triple Moisture Daily Deep Conditoner. I had to use about a palmful of product and leave it on for 5 minutes (as opposed to the 1 minute it says on the tube) but the Neutrogenia Deep Conditioner has done a good job of repairing the damage. My hair is soft and looks more healthy than it has in months. It's not 100% restored, but it is very close. I suspect that it will only be a few more days before my hair is back to normal.One final note: A couple days ago, I was on the Ulta website and saw this product there. There is a link where you can view the ingredients. When I saw the ingredients for this dry shampoo, I was absolutely floored. The first 3 ingredients are isobutane, propane, and alcohol. No wonder it fried my hair! Needless to say, I don't recommend this product to anyone, and will definintely NOT repurchase. If you are looking for a GOOD dry shampoo, I suggest the one by Suave Professionals. It comes in a silver bottle with a yellow cap. It's affordable, it works great, and it's gentle. It won't wreck your hair the way this one does.

Back in March, my hair got majorly fried after using Not Your Mother's Clean Freak Dry Shampoo for about 5 days in a row. Ever since then, I've been trying to find a deep condtioner to repair and restore my hair. My hair is normally very oily, but after using the dry shampoo, it became like straw, very dry, brittle, and was falling out. It wasn't falling out enough to really freak me out, but definitely more than normal. I tried Aussie 3 Minute Miracle Deeep Conditioner, which work great for about two weeks, then quit working. I also tried Infusium 23, which pretty much did nothing. Then I tried Garnier Hydro Recharge, which made my hair very soft, but didn't do much in terms of repairing the damage. I then tried a sample of Matrix Exquisite Oil, which made my scalp burn. Next, I tried Nioxin Scalp Therapy, which burned even worse than the Matrix. In fact, my scalp hurt for the rest of the day after using the Nioxin Conditioner.I was starting to get really discouraged and frustrated. I picked up this product on a whim. I don't remember what I paid, but I think it was around $6.99 for an 8.5 oz tube.  This is a very rich and cream conditioner, but it doesn't weigh down your hair at all. It's very light. I used this daily for about two weeks. Even though it says on the tube you only needed it leave it in for 1 minute, I left it on my hair for 2-3 minutes and then washed it out. It's easy to rinse out and rinses clean. There is no build-up left on your hair. It left my hair very soft,  but it didn't really do much in terms of fixing the damage. Even after using this daily for over 2 weeks, my hair was still damaged, brittle, dry, and falling out. About 3 days ago, I was about to give up and try something else, I decided to give this conditioner one more chance. I did a couple of things different. First, I started using about double the amount of product (about a palmful.) I also decided to try leaving it on my hair just a few minutes longer. I left it on about 5 minutes total. I was afraid that doubling the amount of product might cause my hair to feel weighed down and look greasy. But it didn't. Once I made these two changes, I noticed a major difference in the condition of my hair. It felt very soft and became less dry, brittle and more healthy in general. You could see and feel the difference. This morning was the first time in months, that I haven't had to remove any hair from the drain catch in the shower. My hair is still a tiny bit dry, but no where near what it was. I think within a few days,  my hair will be completely restored and back to normal.EDIT: Even though this has made my hair soft and silky, it hasn't done much of anything in terms of repairing the damage. If I stop using it for even one day, my hair gets dry, brittle, and starts falling out again. I would definitely recommend this as a regular conditioner, but definitely not as a deep conditioner.

I have been searching for a cheaper alternative to my Pop Beauty Face Magnet primer. I did a Google search and found several websites that mentioned using this as a face primer. I have SUPER allergy-prone skin, and have had really good luck with Aveeno Lotions in the past. I absolutely LOVE the adult version of the Daily Moisturizing Lotion. My hands get very dry and cracked (especially on winter) and the adult version of this lotion heals it within just a couple of days.This lotion is hypoallergic and formulated for sensitive skin, so I thought it was worth a shot. I felt a little silly buying baby lotion because I'm lacking a key component for buying baby lotion (ie a baby) But I got over it and paid less than $6 for an 8.0 oz tube. This lotion fragrance free, hypoallergic, non comedegenic, and oil free. and specially formulated for sensitive/allergy prone skin. I also like that it has a moisturizer already in it.To be completely honest, I was skeptical about using this as a face primer. I really didn't expect it to work. I thought it might make my foundation look heavy and cakey. But incredibly, it didn't. You only need a TINY amount. If you apply too much, it will cause liquid foundation to pill and slide around. It did take a little trial and error to figure out the right amount to use. But here is how I apply it. I squirt a tiny amount into my palm (I used a dot about the size of pencil eraser. That is more than enough for my entire face)then I dip my finger into the lotion and rub it into my skin.  Since you only need such a tiny amount, it absorbs and dries almost instantly. In addition to be extremely allergy-prone, my skin is almost extremely oily. Which let me tell you, is not a good combination. Without primer (and sometimes even WITH a primer) my makeup generally lasts about 4 hours before it starts breaking up and disappearing. By the 5 hour mark, there are large patches of redness and bare skin showing through. By the 6 hour mark, it's pretty much completely gone. I've tried MANY different primers (both drugstore and high end) and have had varying degrees of success. Even primers that work generally only give me about 7  hours of decent wear. Which is better than 4 hours, but it's still not great. I've been hoping to find a primer that will give me at LEAST 10 hours of decent wear from my makeup. I think I have finally found it. I applied my makeup around 9:00 a.m. this morning. It is now a little after 6:30 p.m. My makeup still looks amazing. I am the most oily around my nose and on my cheeks around my nose. Even in the areas where I am super oily, my makeup has only worn away the tiniest bit. I am not one to touch up my makeup. Since you only use such a tiny amount, this tube will last a really long time, which makes it a great value.I feel this lotion has done a great job in terms of controlling oil, keeping me matte, and helping my makeup stay on longer. I'm not sure how it work for someone with dry or combination skin, but for oily skin, it is truly a miracle. I have tried a couple of other cheap alternatives to face primer. Milk of Magnesia and Monistat Anti-Chaffing Gel. The Milk of Magnesia does work and doesn't irritate my skin, but was hesitant about using it long-term. The Monistat Gel didn't do much of anything for me in terms of controlling oil or keeping my makeup on longer. In addition, it also made me itch. I  have tried so many different primers both drugstore and high-end. I haven't found another primer that works as well as this does. It has given me everything I was looking for in a primer. I am suprised how well this actually works as a face primer. If I hadn't read about it online, I would have NEVER thought this could work as a face primer. But it does. If you are looking for a cheaper alternative to face primer, I highly recommend this product. I especially recommend it to people who have very sensitive/allergy prone skin. You can't beat the price and you get a lot of product for the price. I will purchase this again and again. This is now my HG primer, and will never use anything else. Give it a try, you won't be sorry.

I've been hunting for a good affordable primer that will help control oil and keep my makeup in place longer. I do really like the Pop Beauty Face Magnet Primer. But it costs $26. Since my foundation is $35, I wanted to find a slightly cheaper primer. I tried a couple, but didn't really like them. Then I saw this at Ulta. I've read positive reviews about this product before, and read that it worked really well for oily skin. It was $16 at Ulta. The packaging has changed. Rather than a squat plastic container, it now comes in a tube with a pump. They also increased the size from 1 oz to 1.4 oz. I know that the Iman line is intended for women of color (which I am not) so I was a little concerned about this caramel color of this primer. But I used a tester on the back of my hand before purchasing it. It dried super fast and dried clear. It is so lightweight and feels wonderful. This tube should last a long time, because you only need a tiny bit of this primer. I used about a dime-sized amount for my entire face. This primer dries almost instantly. My skin is super oily and very allergy prone. But this primer didn't irritate my sensitive skin, and I feel it did a very good job of controlling the oil. Without primer, (and sometimes even with primer) my makeup looks decent for about 4-5 hours before it starts breaking down and disappearing. With this primer, I had only minor breakthrough at the 8 hour mark. I think I have finally found my HG primer. This is a wonderful primer for $16 dollars. Very few primers that I've tried actually work with my skin. Either they don't control the oil very well, or they give me an allergic reaction. This primer one of the best I've ever used, and I will definitely repurchase.

I am just about out of my Pop Beauty Face Magnet primer. I love it, but since I splurge my foundation, I wanted to try to find a cheaper primer that will work. Over the last few weeks, I've tried a few different ones, but didn't really like any of them. I orginally went to Sally's to purchase the Claudia Stevens Facial Prep Foundation Base (the one in the white tube) but they were out of stock. At first, I was just going to forget it. But then I went back and decided to give this one a try. This product comes in a green tube. It cost me $5.79. To be honest, I didn't really have high hopes for this primer. I was also skeptical about the anti-redness claim. But I figured it was worth a shot. If I hated it, I was only out about $6.I have to admit that when I first saw the color of this primer, it freaked me out a little. It is a VERY dark green color. But it's a light, gel-like consistancy. It does feel a little weird when you first apply it, but it dries really fast and turns clear. It is very easy to apply, and a little goes a long way. I have quite a bit of redness on my face, and this primer definitely did tone it down quite a bit. It also made my Makeup Forever Mat Velvet foundation glide on. It feels so lightweight, you can't even tell you have anything on. It blurred the imperfections on my face and made it look flawless. My skin is extremely oily and extremely allergy prone. I really expected it to disappear after about 4 or 5 hours. But it didn't. I applied my makeup around 8:30 this morning. As I write this, it is now a little after 7 in the evening. My foundation has started to wear away very slightly on my nose, but no where near what I've had with other primers. It also doesn't irritate my extremely sensitive skin. This primer did a great job of controlling the oilness and kept my face matte all day. That is HUGE for me!My only complaint is that its a very small tube of product. But at less than $6 a pop, I can live with that.EDIT: 10/12/13This is yet another example of the old adage "You get what you pay for." I really this primer the first couple of times I used it. But then I started to notice it was changing the consistency of my foundation. Makeup Forever Mat Velvet is not a thick foundation. At least it wasn't until I started wearing it over this primer. My liquid foundation became thicker and became more like a cream foundation. I usually have no problems whatsover getting my Mat Velvet to absorb into my skin. But when I used it over this primer, my foundation started slipping and sliding around. It also never really absorbed into my skin. It just kind of sat on the surface. In addition, my foundation would ball up. Once my foundation set completely (which takes about an hour) it looked even worse. Normally, the Mat Velvet looks very natural and flawless on my face. You can't even hardly tell I'm wearing makeup. But this primer made my foundation look thick, heavy, and cakey. I applied the same amount I always have. It basically made my $35, high-end foundation look like a cheap drugstore foundation. This primer obviously does not play well AT ALL with liquid foundation. Maybe it would work better with a powder or mineral foundation. I'm not really sure. I have been really happy with the Mat Velvet up to this point, and see no reason to switch. More than likely, this primer is going to end up in the garbage. I recently started using the Iman Undercover Agent Oil Free Primer, and like that much better. I wouldn't recommend this primer to anyone who wears liquid foundation. I will not repurchase.

I have been searching for a long-lasting, full coverage, lightweight foundation for a long time. I tried Amazonian Clay. It lasted all day and provided great, flawless coverage, but it was much too cakey and powdery for my liking. After returning the Amazonian Clay, I decided to swing by Macy's. I had a card for a free consultation and a 10 day supply of any foundation. So I felt like I had nothing to lose, so I took advantage of that. The girl who did the consultation told me my shade is Dusk (3C1) After applying this foundation, she asked me what I thought. I wasn't exactly sure how to respond. The girl did a great job applying it, I just wasn't crazy about how it looked on my face. Shortly after my consultation at Estee Lauder, I bought a bottle of Boots No 7 Double Wear Beautifully Matte. I've been using that for a little less than a week now, and I absolutely love it. I decided today to try the free sample of Double Wear.This makeup just isn't for me. Even though the girl who applied this for me told me it was full-coverage, I don't agree. I think the coverage is closer to medium than full. It also didn't give me a very flawless finish. It did an okay job of covering up the redness, but you can still clearly see the bumpiness underneith this makeup. I also don't like the way this makeup looks on my face. It doesn't look very natural in my opinion. You can definitely tell I am wearing makeup. I also have some very fine lines. So fine you can't even see them with the naked eye. But after applying this makeup you can see them clear as day. I'm also not sure this is the right shade for me. You can clearly see where the makeup has been applied to my skin. My skin is light/medium with cool undertones. My skin isn't fair, but it definitely on the light side. I think a shade or two lighter might have worked out better. I also agree with a previous reviewer who said this is like applying paint to your face. That is pretty much what it looks like when its dry.This foundation is too matte for my liking as well. It looks cakey and thick on your face.  But I also think that I'm allergic to something in this product. Ever since I applied it this morning, my face has been itching. It's enough to be distracting. I also found this makeup very difficult to remove. It took a lot of scrubbing.When I compare the two, there is simply no comparison between this and the Boots No 7 Beautifully Matte.  The Beautifully Matte foundation provides full, yet natural looking coverage, contains sunscreen, is oil free and hypoallergenic. It lasts until I take it off at night. It also gives my face a smooth, flawless finish. It covers both the bumps and the redness very well. Even better, the Beautifully Matte is much more affordable. It sells for $13.99 as opposed to a rather pricey $36.99 for the Double Wear. Who would have thought that I'd prefer a drugstore foundation over a high-end one? Certainly not me. But in my opinion, the Beautifully Matte is superior to the Double Wear. I will not be purchasing a full-sized bottle of the Double Wear. I'm glad I tried it out, but no thanks. I'll stick with my Boots No 7 Beautifully Matte foundation.

I have been trying for a long time to find a foundation that will do what I want to. I tried the Amazonian Clay Full Cover 12 hour foundation. It felt light on my face and covered great, but it was much too cakey for my liking. Needless to say I was disappointed. I got a free sample of Estee Lauder Double Wear foundation. The shade matched perfectly and I loved the way it looked and felt on my face. What I wasn't so crazy about was the price. $36 for a foundation is definitely a splurge for me. I would have spent it if I had to, but I wanted to see if I could find something a little more affordable that would have the same staying power and look. After getting the free sample from Macy's, I suddenly remembered that Boots No 7 was available at Target. So on a whim, I decided to see if I could find it. I wasn't exactly sure what shade I needed, but I thought that the Cool Beige looked about right for my skintone. I have light/medium skin.  I have a lot of imperfections on my face that I want to cover up (bumps, redness, and huge pores) To be honest, I really didn't expect much at all from this foundation. I've tried countless other drug store foundations in the same price range. They either didn't give me the level of coverage I wanted or faded away after just a few hours. Even though this foundation claimed to last 14 hours, I was more than a little skeptical. I've tried foundations that claimed to last 16 or 24 hours before and found they didn't even come close to lasting that long on my face. Most of the time, I was lucky if I could give 5 hours of decent wear.  But for 13.50, I decided to give this a chance. I also bought some of the Boots "Expert Anti-Redness serum) for 7.99 (also from Target) What drew me to this foundation was that it claimed to be full coverage, long-lasting, and hypoallergenic. It is also oil free. I have extremely sensitive skin as well. I was pleasantly surprised to discover that this product has a pump. I know some people don't like the pump, but I love it. In my opinion, the pump  makes it so much easier to get the amount you need without getting it all over the place. I apply it first with a sponge and then just a tiny bit with a brush. It looks amazing. A little bit of this goes a long way, I know this bottle will last at least 3 months.The following day, after cleansing my face in the shower, applying the redness serum and a moisturizer, I applied this make-up. It is super easy to apply. It doesn't feel heavy on your face at all. The coverage is wonderful. It doesn't feel cakey or overly powdery at all. It looks very natural. The Cool Beige is a perfect match for my skin. It looked great all day. It doesn't rub off and it stayed on until I removed it before bed.Today, I got stuck in a minor rainstorm. I went for a short walk. When I left, it was just lightly sprinkling. But it started raining a little harder as I walked. I had my hood up, but I could still feel the rain hitting my face. I expected my foundation to look awful by the time I got to the store. I went to the bathroom and found it still looked amazing. A short time later, back at home, I realized that I was overheating from wearing too warm of a shirt.  I started to sweat like crazy. I had beads of sweat on my forehead and running down my face. I took a paper towel and blotted my face. I expected to see a ton of foundation on the paper towel as well. But there was NOTHING! Not even a little bit of it came off. I was surprised and delighted. All for 13.50. This foundation has given me everything I was looking for. I will probably try the Double Wear, but I won't be buying it. This is my new go-to foundation. If you are looking for a lightweight, full-coverage, long-lasting liquid foundation, I highly recommend this product. If you purchase this product, I promise you won't be sorry.  I will definitely buy this again. I also highly recommend the Expert Anti-Redness serum. It feels great on your skin and I have noticed a decrease in the redness on my forehead and nose since I've started using it. I can't say enough good things about this foundation. Thanks Boots!

Amazonian Clay Full Coverage 12 hour foundationI have a lot of issues when it comes to my face. I have a lot of redness and bumpiness on my cheeks and chin. Even though the bumpiness isn't an issue on my nose and forehead, redness definitely is. I very seldom get acne, but I would describe my skin as oily, especially on my nose and cheeks. In addition, I also have very sensitive skin. I have to be really careful about what chemicals I put on my face. I have had used a couple of products that made my face feel like it was on fire. I've had many more that caused me to itch like crazy. Even though I always purchase products that are hypoallergenic or made specifically for sensitive skin, a lot of them still make me itch.I have tried many different types of foundation. I have tried some very cheap ones (NYC and Hard Candy) I have also tried most of the mid-priced store brands (Loreal, Maybelline, Merle Norman, Avon, and Mary Kay. I've even used a Clinique foundation. But regardless of how much I pay or where I purchase it, the result is always the same. It looks great when I first apply it, but after a short time, (generally 4 hours or less) the shine and redness start peeking through again. I had almost given up hope. I started to think that maybe my expectations for a foundation were unrealistic. Obviously, things like oil-free and suitable for sensitive skin are important, but for me, the three things I was most looking for were1. Lightweight2. Full, yet natural coverage3 Long lastingThe amount I've been spending on foundation has slowly been creeping up, so I decided maybe it was time to consider a high-end foundation. I spent about 3 days researching different foundations and reading reviews. Finally, I narrowed it down to 4 I was interested in trying. This product was the most expensive of the 4. This foundation is somewhat pricey,  so I didn't want to invest in a foundation I wasn't even sure I was going to like. I read a lot of positive reviews of this foundation online,  but honestly, I was skeptical. It just seemed too good to be true. Rather than shelling out the money for a full tube right away, I decided to see if I could somehow get a free sample. I felt a little silly. But I went to Sephora and asked if they did free samples of foundation. I expected the lady to laugh at me, but she was very nice. She said "That's not a crazy question at all. We are actually really big on samples. You can sample any product in the store."  I also explained that I wasn't exactly sure what shade I needed. She said she would help me with that as well. I thought I needed either needed Medium or Light Medium. It turns out that the Light Medium was a perfect match to my skin. I was given a very generous free sample and couldn't wait to try it. But I was also nervous. I'd felt disappointed with so many other cosmetics, that I didn't really expect anything else from this product. Online reviews recommended applying it with a brush, so I purchased a cheap make-up brush and applied it that way.After applying this product for the first time, I was blown away when I looked in the mirror. It covered the bumps and redness completely, given me a flawless, natural look.  It also feels incredibly light on my face. It feels like my natural skin, not cakey or like I'm wearing a mask. But I knew the real test was still to come: How long would it last? Some previous reviewers did state that this foundation didn't last 12 hours, so I was a little worried. But I figured even if it lasted 8 hours it was an improvement over other products. I applied this product the first day at about 7 am. It still looked great when I removed it at around 10:30 that night. It hadn't faded or worn off at all. I was little concerned that this product might be difficult to remove. But a make-up remover wipe removed it with no problem whatsoever.Update 4-4-13When I first got the sample of this product and started using it, I loved it. I thought I had found my go-to foundation. So I purchased a full-sized tube. But the longer I used it, the less I liked it. This foundation doesn't feel heavy on your face, but it does get very cakey and powdery when it dries. I also found it difficult to apply evenly. In some places, I would get it too thin and in others too thick. It also wore off where I am most oily (my cheeks and especially my nose.) I also started to notice that this foundation rubs off very easily. One day I was trying on shirts. I was wearing a turtleneck and a tee-shirt. When I pulled my turtleneck up over my head, I immediately noticed that I had a good amount of foundation on the inside of my turtleneck. I felt less and less confident in this foundation as time went on. I also wasn't crazy sbout the texture of this foundation. It's kind of weird. It's somewhere between a liquid and a cream. I realized that I prefer a liquid foundation. I also want something that will cover well yet will blend into my skin. Previous reviews have mentioned they didn't think the coverage of this makeup wasn't matte enough. In my opinion, the coverage of this makeup is much too matte for my liking.I would recommend getting a free sample of this product, and trying it at least a week before buying a full-sized tube. I would also recommend getting matched at a place like Sephora or Ulta so you are sure to get the right shade. I can definitely understand why there are so many positive reviews for this product. It lives up to its promises and offers great coverage. But I realized I had been hasty in purchasing a full-sized tube. I ultimately ended up returning the full-sized tube. This just wasn't the right foundation for me.In my opinion, a much better alternative to this product is Boots No 7 Beautifully Matte. It is available at Target and online for around $14.00 It is hypoallergenic, oil free, contains sunscreen, stays on all day, and is very lightweight. It provides full coverage, yet looks very sheer. It doesn't look heavy or artificial at all. It is also sweatproof. I started sweating like crazy recently while wearing this makeup. I blotted my face with a papertowel. I expected to see a ton of my foundation on the paper towel as well. But there was NOTHING! It still looked great! It has given me everything I was looking for at a fraction of the price of Amazonian Clay and Estee Lauder Double Wear. When choosing a shade, realize they they come in pairs. There are two choices each for light, medium and deep. The first shade in the pair is for warm tones and the second is for cool tones. Warm skintones tend to have yellow undertones. Cool skintones tend to have pinkish undertones. In my opinion, the best way to determine your skin tone is to look at the veins in your wrist. If they appear greenish, then you have a warm skin tone. If they look bluish, then you have a cool skintone. If you can't tell, then you have neutral skin tones. Most people tend to have warm skintones. But I discovered that I have cool skintones. So I chose to purchase the shade "Cool Beige" It was a perfect match for my skin. Give the Boots No 7 Beautifully Matte a try. I promise you won't be disappointed. A great product for a great price.

I have been struggling for a long time for a foundation that will do what I want to do. I have a genetic disease that has left me with a red, bumpy rash on my face. I am very self-conscious about it, and I would like to find a foundation that will cover it yet still look natural. But I've tried countless different foundations. Either they don't provide enough coverage or fade after only a few hours. I also have very sensitive skin. So I want something that offers good coverage and yet is light. I don't want to feel like I'm wearing a mask.After reading glowing reviews of this product, I went over to Wal-Mart and bought some for $6. I'm glad I didn't pay more for this product. I was excited to try it and tried applying it as soon as I got it home. It was HORRIBLE! The texture is very thick. It looked and felt like mud. I even tried thinning it out by rubbing it with my fingers. Even that didn't help.  Once I put it on my face, it felt greasy and sticky. Worst of all, it settled into the bumps on my face. Rather than camoflaging them, it made them stand out even more. Definitely NOT what I was I looking for. I had to wash my hands with soap and water 3 times before I got this stuff off my fingers. But even that didn't get rid of it completely. When I got up the next morning, I noticed I still had traces of this make-up on my fingertips. Yuck. Needless to say, this foundation went where it belongs: in the garbage. There is no way I would wear this make-up out in public. I guess this is a perfect example of the truth of the old saying "You get what you pay for." In my opinion, this product is nothing but a huge waste of money. Don't waste your precious time or money on this product.If you are willing to pay for a higher end foundation, I would recommend Amazonian Clay 12 hour full-coverage foundation. It feels very light on your face, gives you great, long-lasting, full coverage, and looks totally natural. Yes it is a bit pricey, but it is worth every penny in my opinion.

When I saw this cookbook available on Amazon Vine, I was very excited to receive it. I am following Weight Watchers and am always on the lookout for light, easy, and satisfying recipes. I am able to adapt regular recipes with no problem, but it is always nice to find recipes that don't need to be adapted as well. When I paged through this book, I was excited. There were quite a few recipes that I was anxious to try. However, when I got out my points calculator, I was significantly less enthusiastic. I think the title of this book is very misleading. Most of the recipes in this book can hardly be called light. Even the lightened versions have pretty high stats for fat. (Most of the recipes have between 10-20 grams of fat per serving). But even more shocking is the carb stats. Weight Watchers is not a low-carb diet, but carbs can definitely negatively affect the point value for a meal or food. Generally, the higher the carbs, the higher the point value. There were recipes in this book (and not just a few) that had carbs in the 50's, 60s, 70s, and 80s. One recipe for a Chocolate milkshake had a whopping 98g of carbs! That is just crazy.In my opinion, a much better cookbook would be "Hungry Girl to the Max". It features many of the same recipes with much more reasonable stats and larger serving sizes. Here is a brief comparison of very simliar recipes from both cookbooks.Chicken MarsalaAmerica's Test Kitchen-WW PointsPlus Value of 9Hungry Girl to the Max-WW PointsPlus Value of 5 for half of the recipeOven Baked ChickenAmerica's Test Kitchen-(serving size 2 pieces) WW PointsPlus Value of 11Hungry Girl to the Max-(serving size 8 pieces)with a WW PointsPlus Value of 7Chocolate MilkshakeAmerica's Test Kitchen-WW PointsPlus Value of 13 (!)Hungry Girl to the Max-WW PointsPlus Value of 5Warm Chocolate Fudge CakesAmerica's Test Kitchen-(serving size 1 cake) WW PointsPlus Value of 11Hungry Girl to the Max-Chocolate Lava Cake WW PointsPlus Value of 5 (per cake)I really wanted to give this book a glowing recommendation, but I can't. I do, however, highly recommend Hungry Girl to the Max or any of the other Hungry Girl cookbooks.
I wasn't quite sure what to expectwhen I ordered this necklace. But it is veryunusual and pretty. It's not like any othernecklace I own. I will wear it often

In 2006, I got a degree in Medical Transcription. I loved it and couldn't wait to find a job. But it never panned out. Just a few short months after graduating, voice recognition software arrived on a the scene basically elimating the need for transcriptionists. I also found it frustrating that it is next to impossible to get an entry-level transcription job. The few jobs out there require 3-5 years experience. How the heck are you supposed to get experience if no one will hire you and give you the opportunity to prove yourself? But I love the medical field and have wanted to pursue another avenue in the medical field. I just can't imagine myself in a career like nursing, medical assistant, dental assitant or a CNA. It's just not for me. I had a job once in a hospital in insurance verification and absolutely loved it.  Lately, I've been thinking more seriously about going back to school. I have been thinking about getting into coding for several years now. But a program director from a nearby technical college told me that coding is heading in the same direction as Medical Transcription. The last thing I want is to obtain another degree that will soon be rendered obsolete. So I have hesitated about pursuing my interest in medical coding.I recently did a search in the Kindle store and stumbled across this book. I was very impressed by the sample chapters, and decided it was worth the $3.99. I'm so glad I did. This book is written in a conversational, easy to read format. It's is not full or jargon or hard to understand lingo. It is very thorough. It enables the reader to hear from people who are actually in the field. It talks about the importance of certification, the future of coding, job prospects, and how to get educated. It talks about what personality types are suited for a career in coding. For someone like me, who had little to no real understanding about what medical coding is and what the job actually entails, this book is invaluable. After reading this book, I feel much more confident about pursuing a career in coding. It put a lot of my fears and hesitations to rest. I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants to get a indepth overview of what it really is like to work in the field of medical coding.
