The Roman civil wars and pressures from "barbarians" occured while St. Jerome (346-420)edited and translated the Vulgate Bible, and St. Augustine (354-430) wrote his classics such as THE CITY OF GOD. The Popes did what they could to maintain Catholcism in spite of barbarian invasions and fickle poltical leaders. The reputation of the Papacy and the early Catholic Church was enhanced when Pope Leo I (440-461)successfully negotiated an agreement with Atilla the Hun (400-453)not to sack Rome which later resulted in Hun defeats and the collapse of the Hun threat.The Catholic Church also benefited from barbarian realms which were created out of the Roman Empire. From c. 500-750,barbarian leaders needed literate people to administer new found kingdoms. Since the only literate men were Catholic clergy, monks, and nuns, these Catholics were valued for their literacy. Clovis (c.480-520) gave the Benedictines land and recognition due to their learning and ability. St. Benedict (480-544)created this order whose monks created the library at Monte Casino. Pope Gregory I (590-604)encouraged learning and is credited for creating Gregorian Chant. Crocker explained that the Catholic authorities were enhanced by Charles Martel's (718-774)victory over supposedly invincible Moslems in 732. His later successor Charlemagne (768-814)was crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Leo III (795-816)to benefit of both Charlegmange's Franks and the Catholic Church.Unfortunately, after Charlemagnes'death, the Europeans were invaded by Saracens (Noth African Moslems)Magyars (Hungarians), and especially the Scandanavians. The Papacy suffered creditibility due to simony, bribes, and nepotism. Crocker "did not shy away" from the Church scandals and carefully explained these problems. Secular rulers tried to take control of the Catholic Church, and the scandals gave cause for secular "reform." The installation of Pope Gregory VII (1073-1085)brought reform and what some historians call The Papal Revolution. Gregory's reforms led to conflict with the German ruler Henry IV (1056-1106) which led to excommunication, reconciliation, and war. While Henry's were forced to leave Italy by the Normans, the Normans looted Rome when they were not paid. Gregory did not live long enough to realize his Papal Revolution whereby the Pope and the Curia gradually wrested control of the Catholic ChurchAnother crisis emerged re the Crusades. When Pope Urban (1088-1099)called for the Crusades in 1095, European History changed radically. The initial success of the Crusaders was marred by later political and economic power struggles. In 1204, the Crusaders looted Constantinople in revenge for Byzantine savage attacks on Catholics previously. The Crusades were ultimately a military failure, but they helped Europeans learn from their enemies. The crudading spirit also affected Western Europe. In 1208, French Catholics defeated a much large army of Algigensians who threatened the social order and stability in Europe. The Albigensian threat was based on their fanaticism and casual toleration of murder.To meet the threat of the Albigensians, St. Dominic (1170-1221) started a new order called The Order of Preachers or Dominicans who were a studious order who used reason and effective preaching to combat heresy. Crocker gave credit to St. Dominic,St. Albertus Magnus (1193-1280), and especially St. Thomas Aquinas (1225-1274)who re-emphasized Aristotle's work on logic to make the Catholic Faith reasonable to counter "blind faith," supersitition, and fanaticism. Crocker's coverage of St. Thomas Aquinas & co. was short but surprisingly well done.In spite of the progress of the "High Middle Ages" (c.1050-1350),the Catholic Church had further divisions and almost complete disaster. Crocker wrote a good account of the Catholic Church's Schism (1377-1414)wherby a dispute between Phillip IV (1285-1314)and Pope Boniface VIII (1294-1303) led to rival claims to Papacy, persecution, and finally reconciliation at the Council of Constance (1414-1417). However these conflicts weakened the Church and assited the "Reformation." Beginning with the political support of Luther (1483-1546)and the division of Europe, Europe was convulsed in violent religious hatred, terrible religious wars including the terrible Thirty Years War (1618-1648), and attacks on science. As some historians noted, the Europeans entered a new age of barbarism.Yet, the Catholic Counter Reformation was spectacular. The Catholics regained areas of Poland from the Protestants. New effective Catholic orders were created, and the Society of Jesus, the Jesuits, were the most notable. St. Ignatius of Loyala (1491-1556)started the Jesuits, and their fame of learning became well know. As St. Ignatius once wrote,"Virtue unlearned is virtue  unarmed." Catholics regained self confidence, and the expansion became permanent.Crocker devoted a section to refute false claims about Catholics denying science. Father Copernicus (1473-1573)developed a heliocentric solar system which Catholic authorities promoted. The false canard that Galleo was jailed and tortured was refuted by Crocker. Galileo was never imprisosned and never tortured. His biggest fault was that he was an ungrateful guest. In 1610, Pope Paul V (1605-1621)had a large reception honoring Galileo. Later in 1624 Pope Urban VIII (1622-1644)who "persecuted" Galileo, honored Galileo with another huge reception. Galileo insulted his hosts and made claims which could not be proven at the time. Galileo was given a house arrest in 1633 which was a moot point since he was legally blind. While under arrest, Galileo resides in luxurious living quarters with his own chef and wine taster. While he was told not to write, he did, and his daughter a devout nun, did his written expression. Some of Galileo's best work re physics was done in his later life.Crocker spent considerable time writing about the convulsions started by the French Revolution. Crocker gave "chapter and verse" details about the convulsions of the French Reign of Terror, wars of the French Revolution, the Napoleonic Wars, and the persecution of Catholics plus Catholic martyrs. With the aftermath of French Revolution and the rise of Nationalism, the Papacy lost control of the Papal States. Yet, Catholic influence did not die with the loss of the Papal States. A Catholic started renewal of Thomism and successful response to Modernism enhanced the Catholic Church both socially and intellectually.Catholics were again challenged by the convulsions of the 20th. century. Crocker, among others, refuted the false claims that somehow Pope Pius XII was "Hitler's Pope." Crocker again cited "chapter and verse" with numerous sources as others have done. The Catholic authorities made intelligent responses to crises during and after the Cold War. Crocker summarized recent Catholic History very well.Crocker's book is well written and informative. While this writer disagrees with Crocker's political views, the undersigned cannot deny that Crocker wrote a good book that should be attractive to readers of whatever political persuasion. The book is a good start for those interested in Catholic history.January 11, 2015James E. Egolf

Mabel Walker's book titled THE FENIAN MOVEMENT is a well researched book that is both tragic and "a comedy of errors." The background of the book was the Civil War and Reconstruction Era which explained the Fenians' hope of establishing an indenpednt Irish State in either Ireland or Canada. Walker gave detalied explanations of the eventual failure of the Fenian movement some of which were amusing.As noted, the background of the Fenian movement was the Civil War. As readers may know, the Northerners recruited many Irish to fill the ranks of the armies. While a Fenian spokesman claimed the number of Irish who were recruited was about 150,000 men, the actual number was ;probably just over 50,000 men which was still a considerable number. As an aside, both Confederate an Northern commanders gave these men credit for being brave and good soliders.Irish Catholics, and in fact most Catholics, faced hostility and attempts at persecution before and after the Civil War. As a result, the Irish formed socieites for cultural unity and defense against such bigotry. Among those who were hostile to Catholics were members of "The Know Nothing Party." In response to anti-Catholic bias in parts of North American and Great Britian, the Irish were imbued with Irish Nationalism. Since so many Irish were trained military personel, the Fenians thought these men could be organized into Irish brigades and create an Independent Irish Republic in Canada or Ireland which were both under British control.The Fenians were bitterly divided over leadership and the use of funds. Walker descripbed in great detail the accusations and counter accusations of theft of funds, betrayal, and leadership incompetence. Another issue was the question of creation of an Irish Republic in Canada or Ireland. Some of the Irish wanted a constutional, peaceful approach while the Fenians wanted an Irish armed revolution. These issues and accusations pre-occupied the Fenians during the 1860s until 1870. As Walker noted, the Fenians were devout Catholics. Pope Pius IX (1846-1878) condemned "secret societies," and the Fenians were accused of being a secret society. The moral dilemma for the Fenians was to either remain a secret society or operate openly. The latter option left the Fenians open to exposure and victims of spies and informers.Another issue was the diplomatic problem between US and British authorities. The neutrality laws between US and British authorites caused tensions. The British accused US leaders of violations because of some limited support for the Fenians. US leaders accused the British leaders of violations re British de facto support for the Confederates during the Civil War and the release of Confederate naval raiders such as THE ALABAMA. The Fenians hoped that such tensions would lead to war and give the Fenians a chance to claim an Irish republic in the midst of such tensions. Unfortunately for the Fenians, "cooler heads prevailed." Walker carefully explained the problems that the US Secretary of War Stanton and Secretary of State Sewerd had in handling such delicate diplomacy. At times, the Irish vote in the US influenced decisions or least "lip service" in support of the Fenians. Walker did an excellent job explaining these problems.Due to informers and tepid US support plus Fenian distrust of the leaders, the Fenian movement was doomed to failure. A Fenian expedition into Canada in 1870 met with disaster. Rebellions in Ireland were "stillborn" because of British spies, and the Fenian movement lost support. Lack of effective unity and diplomatic issues doomed Fenian efforts both in Canada and the US. The British Prime Minister, Gladstone, made concessions to the Irish (in Ireland) by a land bill which gave the Irish hope for a constituional solution for indendence which armed force could not achieve.G.K. Chesterton (1874-1936) commented that some Catholic bashers said the Irish were priest driven. After 1923, the Irish disgourged themselves of British landlords and were no longer landlord driven. An Irish joke which may give insight to failure of the Fenians is an alleged remark by an Irish Catholic priest. He told the men in his congregation that they drank far too much which was why they beat their wives. He then said the strong drink incited them to shoot at British landlords and that strong drink was the reason they missed.Mabel Walker did a good job of informing readers of a neglected topic re history. Her reseach is meticulous, and her written expression is clear. Her research is a good case study of careful historical investigation to support her conclusions. Those interested in Irish History will enjoy this book.James E. EgolfJanuary 7,2015

Wendy Towle wrote a children's book that is informative and "inspiring." The book give a short precise of the life and achievements of Elijah McCoy (1844-1929)) who was a son of escaped slaves. Elijah's father, George McCoy distingushed himself via the Canadian  1837 Rebel War and was awarded a large amount of land for his service. Even though the Mccoys were escaped slaves they knew the value of learining and serious study.Elijah McCoy went to school in Colchester, Ontario where he studied hard and mastered literacy. McCoy's avid interest in mechnaics was enhanced when he was sent to Scotland to study physics and engineering when Elijah was only 16 years old. Elijah McCoy earned advanced degrees in engineering but could only get a "menial" job as a fireman/oilman for the Michigan Central Railroad Co. in Michigan.This job served Elijah McCoy well. He had to monitor the firebox and the water boiler which was dangerous. As Wendy Towle reported, Elijah McCoy lubricated wheel axles which was tedious work. He developed an advanced oil cup which automratically did the work.His invention was so good that other products were simply inferiour. Historians argue that the phrase "The Real McCoy" was due to MeCoy's surperior oil cup. He also invented the ironing board and better shoe soles.Wendy Towle reported  Elijah created other inventions which earned 55 patents.McCoy's second wife Mary McCoy was a dedicated wife and active in civid work and charities. In spite of the "race issue," the McCoys were well respected. Elijah McCoy's genius was widely recogized.Wendy Towle mentioned that Elijah McCoy tried to encourage young people to study and focus on what is important. His example and advice are important especially when readers consider that he was the son of escaped slaves.Wendy Towle introduced readers to an inspiring story of someone who was not supposed to succeed. However, Wendy Towle showed readers that good parental encouragement and dedication to study and learn can lead to great achievement. Those who demean people of difference races and ancestry should not read this book due to mental apoplexyDecember 26, 2014James E. Egolf

Henrik Tikkanen's (1924-1984) anti-war novel titled THE THIRTY YEARS' WAR is a short but poignant portrayal of the stupdidty, hyprocricy, and tragedy of false patriotism and lack of reason when "war is in the air." Tikkanen was multilingual and was branded as a "leftist"  whatever that means. He was knowledgeable and well informed. He also had a delightful sense  of humor which is demonstrated in this novel.The first page of the book is funny. Tikkanen teasingly contrasted Finnish sainsts as war heroes with Italian saints who were deeply religious. Since the Italian soldiers did not do well in modern war, the Italians relied on God while the Finns relied on their military commanders. Tikkanen probably knew that Italian troops were brave, but modern Italians were not industrialized enough for modern war.Tikkanen proceded to explain the illogic of military officers. One of the characters named Hurmalainen was a brick layer who made the rank of sergeant. However, because, through no fault of his own, the sergeant was demoted to a private with loss of benefits. Since Hurmalainen was a brick layer, he figured with the destruction caused by war (The Finnish-Soviet War which started in late 1939 or 1940)that as brick layer he could find employment once the war stopped.Some of the people in Finland were alternatively under the control of either the Soviets or the Finns. These people were told that each side was fighting for these folks' "freedom," but those who wished to left alone did not understand nor want either sides' "freedom." As an aside, does this sound familiar?The main character was named Viktor Kappara who was a private in the Finnish army who took abeying orders to extreme. Not realizing that W.W.II was over in 1945,he remained at his post for 30 years thinking that anyone who entered his "combat" zone were  either Soviet troops, Communist sympathizers, or Communist infiltrators. He NEVER got any orders to return home, and Viktor would not ever disobey "official orders." The thirty years he stayed at his post were amuisng and tragic. He murdered an unarmed man and woman who were innocent of any wrong doing. He murdered this couple in "cold blood" even though the woman was nude and taking a both. Viktor figured these folks who apparently had no business living in a remote area had to be Communist infiltrators. When Viktor learned that the West was engaged in the Korean War, he thought the Finns had overrun the Soviet Union and were fighting in Asia.Later when a sheriff's investigation into the murder of the above unarmed civilians, the scene turned almost comic. The sheriff was just a paranoic as Vikto, and many of the professionl anti-communists in the US. The sheriff realized that Viktor probably committed the murders and thought the Finnish soldier had killed this couple "defending the homeland." The sheriff spied on Viktor, and Tikkanen compared both men's ignorance and paranoia.Later the novel was more comical and tragic. When different Finnish bureaucrats realized the situation, they sent "experts" to Viktor's post to make a hero out of him for being so loyal defending Finland for so long. Each blundered, and some were killed. One of the favorite paraphrases was the Finns and Germans had to die so Finland and Germany could live. Or to use a stupid phrase during the Vietnam War, a village had to be destroyed so it could be saved.Toward the of the novel, Viktor could not understand the Orwellian view that former bitter enemies became allies and vice versa. Finnish arms manufacturers as well as those in the West were arming both "allies" and "enemies" who "changed shirts and uniforms" instantly.The last part of this novel, was dsiturbing yet humorous. Those who were sent to rescue Viktor were either shot or forced to retreat. Finally ovewhelming force had to be used to eliminate Viktor and to prevent major embarrassment in the name of "national security." Tikkanen made remarks to update this novel. When Lt. Calley was responsible for the My Lai Massacre, he had to be the scapegoat even though he obeyed orders. The pictures of dead childen clinging to their dead mothers could not be ignored. The Lt. obeyed orders, but no higher ranking officers were held responsible. A jornalist got paid $100,000 for writing about the Lt. Yet, no one would have been paid ten dolloars for writing about nameless victims of the massacre. Jouranlists nailed Nixon for his indescrtions, but very little is even mentioned about the mass murder state of Lenin and Stalin.This novel is well worth reading with memorable quotes. When men are drunk, they know exactly what to do. Yet, when these men get sober, they realize sensible solutions will never occur. The notes and the Afterward are good introductions to Finnish History especially during the Communist Revolution and W.W. II.December 21, 2014James E. Egolf

Father Ciszek, S.J., (1904-1984) wrote WITH GOD IN RUSSIA which is book of memoirs while incarcerated in the Soviet Union for fifteen years. Ciscek's book is full of surprises, Father Ciscek writing is  very graphic, descriptive, and detailed. His writing is suspenseful and leaves the reader with the view of "what happens next."Father Ciszek wrote about his younger years of which he was not proud. He was a tough kid and a bully. Without an explanation or an epiphany, Father Ciszek suddenly decided to study for the priesthood. Later, in spite of his father's objections, Ciscek made another sudden decision to join the Society of Jesus (the Jesuits). As an aside, the Jesuits can be very obedient and/or very defiant. Father Ciscek fit both descriptions. He was athletic and did exhaustive exercies. Ciscek was also impulsive and once committed to "a cause," he was not to be denied. Ciszek volunteered for the Vatican's Russicum which was a missionary school to send Catholic priests to the Soviet Unionto celebrate Mass and the Sacraments. The undersigned viewed this effort as suicide missions given the vigorus police state under Stalin. Father Ciszek went to Poland and then volunteered to go to the USSR under the guise of a worker in the Urals where he worked hard. An interesing anecdote is that of a Polish Jewish fellow who was fooled by the promises of "The Workers' Paradise." This young man was shocked by the harsh realities of Soviet society.While working in the Urals as a logger, Father Ciscek was discovered as a Catholic Jesuit priest and was charged as a spy for the Vatican. He was held in the infamous Lubyanka prison for about five years under very harsh conditions. When W.W.II started, Ciszek hoped the Germans would bomb the prison and the prison trains to either escape or get killed and be out of their misery. After physical abuse and torture, Ciszek was sentence to a concentration camp in Norilsk which over four degrees nother of the Arctic Circle or about over 70 miles north of the Arctic Circle. Ciszek worked loading coal which was a dangerous job. Ciszek mentioned working in dark areas avoiding flying coal the size of a skull. Some inmates were seriously injured or killed.Ciszek also described conflicts between political prisoners and violent offenders. Violent non-poltical prisoners would try to intimidate political prisoners. Such conflcits erupted into violence which guards worked to suppress. Ciszek was clever. He described an incident whereby some thug tried to steal from him. Ciscek reminded the thug that all the prisoners "were in the same boat," and the thug could make a bad situation worse. Ciszek graphically described the murder and violence of prisoner-on-prisoner violence. One man was attacked by an inmate who hit him with sledge hammer. Ciscek mentioned that as Catholic priest, Ciscek had heard the victim's confession and gave the poor soul absolution prior to the victim's death.On the other hand, some of the more violent offenders were cordial and even protective of Father Ciszek. Ciszek's reputation of honesty and respect attracted other violent prisoners. A Mongolian and an inmate called the Turk or the Ottoman became Ciszek's close friends. Some of the inmates who worked in the medical facilities helped Ciszek to get light work, and Ciszek learned pharmacy, medical techniques, and care. Ciszek also learned to be a mechanic and construction trades. During Ciscek's incarceration, he courageously celebrated Mass and repeatedly administered the Sacraments which was dangerous to say the least.The concentration camp experience became more dangerous in 1953 when Stalin died. The inmates in "The Gulag Archigelago" rebelled in violent classes with guards. These rebellions erupted in many Soviet concentration camps, and only when disciplined Soviet troops were called to crush the rebellions did "law and order" resume. Ciszek wrote the concentration camp conditions significantly improved, and those who survived the rebellions had better living concitions.Finally in 1955, Ciscek was released and lived as "A free man restricted." He resumed his priestly duties and was able to establish a parish or sorts in spite of threats. Ciszek was threatened with arrest under Soviet "law" which forbade clergy from getting paid for religious work. Ciszek defended himself by proving he got no pay. He was beloved by Ukrainians, Russian Orthodox Christians, and other Eastern Europeans and Asians. Ciszek so infuriated the authorities that was sent to another town where he worked hard as mechanic and was given several awards for his hard work and skillYet, Ciszek wanted to return to the US. In 1955. he managed to get a letter to his sister. In spite burearcratic delays, Ciszek was transferred to European Russia in 1963. He was treated very well by the USSR authorities in Moscow and was "wined and dined." In 1963, Father Ciszek, S.J. flew to the US. While in Moscow, Ciszek visited Lenin's tomb and prayed for Lenin with the remark re Lenin"...he may need more prayers than he is getting here. Ciscek remarked that when he met with US officials, these officials were among the first to refer to him as Father Ciscek.Father Ciszek's book is full of suspense. To use an overused expression, his book is "a page turner." This reviewer believes that Father Ciszek was either reckless, masochistic, or divinely inspired. A good companion book is Alexander Solzhenitsyn GULAG ARCHIPELAGO. Readers should that Father Ciszek's experience was rare given the massive deaths in Soviet concentation camps. So many died, that Siberian construction workers had to stop work because of mass graves. The book is both depressing and "uplifitng."James E. EgolfDecember 14, 2014

Eugene C. Black edited an informative collection of essays re European Liberalism from 1815-1870. This collection of essays dealt with the political sympathies and antagonisms between "Classical Liberals" and working class Europeans. Some of the essays examined living standards, effects of disease, diplomatic successses and failures, and reinterpretation of the some of well known European historical figures.The first essay examined the rising living living standards in England between 1800-1815. R. Max Hartwell's essay made a good case that England's working classes actually had increased living standards. Industry, technology, and railroad construction lowered prices and provided employment. While wages did not rise much, prices of basic goods and services dropped increasing living standards. Reform legislation improved sanitation and limits on child labor. While contemporay Americans would not tolerate working and living conditions in England between 1800-1815, these living standards were much better for the English classes in the 19th. century than previous centuries. This reviewer found this essay convincing. Too many conventional historians try to "read back" from current times which is always a bad mistake.Asa Briggs wrote an essay re the effects of cholera and politics in Western Euroepan, especially Great Britian and France. The epidemiologists learned to be humble, and no one could explain the contagion. Some political leaders argued that the illness was confined to poor working class areas. Yet, some working class neighborhoods had practically no incidents of cholera while other working class neighborhoods had epidemics. Even more mysterious was the fact that in some working class nighborhoods one side of a street was spared the disease while other sides of the same street had epidemics. The unusual phenomenum invited political opportunism, but political complaints could not explain the disparities. As an aside, interested readers should read the book titled RATS, LICE, AND HISTORY.Robert Kann's essay re Prince von Metternich (1773-1859) was written as a re-evalution of Metternich. Metternich was often considered "The Evil Genius of Reaction." Metternich justly feared the rise of Nationalism. The Hapsburg Empire had an oleo of national minorities, and Metternich knew the potential for national rebellions which would have disintergrated the multinational empire. What Metternich also knew was the fact that these minorities would turn on each other in fits of violence inviting the Russians to intervene. Kann compared Metternich with Pres. Wilson. The big difference re Metternich & co. is that they were well informed re European History and politics. Metternich's policies were designed to promote peace and to "keep the lid" on national hatreds and war. Wilson & co. actively intervened in W.W. I and knew nothing about European History. Metternich's policies promoted peace. Wilson's policies led to the bloodiest century in history.Douglas Johnson's essay re the French politician, Guizot (1787-1874), showed the tensions even within the French "liberal ranks." The June Days of 1848 rebellions frightened "Classical Liberals." While the liberals opposed monarchy, they saw "democracy" as possible mobocracy. As a political figure, Guizot had to reconcile, or try to reconcile, these poltical tensions. He did the best anyone could do at the time, and his critics fail to take into account the difficult poltical confrontations he had to face.Irene Collins' essay re 19th. century "Classical Liberalism" was informative to say the least. The essay explored the original defiintions of liberalism, and some were critical and some were favorable. One of the issues that European Liberalism faced was the problem of social reform. Classical Liberals wanted limited state action, but social reform re the working classes and their increasing numbers forced factory reform and state imposed sanitation which were practical reforms. In other words, political reality and desparate health conditions led to practical solutions which ran against idealistic "Classical Liberalism."Lewis Namier's essay re Nationality and Liberty was similiar to above essay re Metternich.Namier's thesis was that liberty and nationality are mutually exclusive. Liberty means, among other things, freedom of press, speech, religion, and legal due process. Yet, many leaders of nationalism refuted these concepts. Nationalism often included bitter religious hatred, suppression of cultural and political dissent, and violence against those who were "different." As Namier noted, the contraditions are obvious. The horrible results of W.W. I, W.W. II, the rise of "Fascism," and Big Communism confirmed Namier's thesis.Another diplomatic essay was written by A. J. P. Taylor. Taylor's essay re the Crimean War is "different" and well done. This was, as in most cases, an unnecessary war. The squabble between Russian Orthodox clergy and Roman Catholic clergy should NEVER have led to war. As Taylor described the war, it was a "war that would not boil. The British were the primary beneficiaries in that they again kept the Russians out of the Mediterrean Sea. Napolean III and the French only got glory. The Russians had their incompetence exposd without any attempt at later reform. The Turks disappointed their "allies" by refusing to make necessary reforms.Raymond Grew made some interesting commentary re the Italian Risorgimento. Grew critisized Cavour whose alleged "Classical Liberalism" was more cynicism than liberalism Cavour was "more concerend with moderation," but Garibaldi was more concerned about Italy. When Garibaldi conceded to Cavour, Garibaldi unknowingly betrayed his Red Shirts and Italian freedom. The following reforms after Cavour restricted the franchise and reform rather than expand these policies which Garibaldi wanted.A.J.P. Taylor wrote another essay in this anthology re Bismarck's policy. For better or worse, Bismark was a clever manipulator. As Taylor noted Bismarck manipulated different political parties against each and in favor of Bismarck. Bismarck's sponsored social legislation such as Workmen's Compensation, "socialized medicine," and Social Security benefits finally muted the fast growing German Socialist party. Bismarck's hasty retreat from his anti-Catholic laws kept the Center parties in line since many members of the Center parties were Catholic. After the unification of the Germans in 1871, Bismarck used effective diplomacy to keep the Russians, the Hapsburgs, the Italians, and the French tied to his policies and maintained peace.John Gallagher and Ronald Robinson contributed an interesing essay comparing Imperialism and "Free Trade." The expansion of the Europeans' empires, especially the British empire, had little to do with free trade. The European expansion into Africa beginning c. 1870 was described as "scrapping of the bottom of the barrel." The fact that "free trade" included force and resticted access to markets and resources. The reality betrayed the ideal.These essays give readers and historians reasons to think and reinterpret long established mythis and realities of European Classical Liberalism. The essays are not dated in spite of the fact the book was first publsihed in 1967. This book is much preferred to badly written textbooks and media nonsense. The undersigned enjoyed the book and learned from the contents.James E. EgolfNovember 23, 2014

Father Baron is a productive Catholic priest whose books are readable, subtle, thought provoking, and perhaps too optimistic. Baron's book titled BRIDGING THE GREAT DIVIDE should appeal to readers with "residual common sense." Some of the essays in this book were written for more "advanced" readers especially those dealing with St. Thomas Aquinas, St. Augustine, and Father Merton. Other essays appeal to those who are not well read re history, philosophy, and theology. The essays have connections and should be read patiently.The first essay focused on the Cardinal Roncalli's,the future Pope John XXIII, remark re Vatican II reforms. As Father Baron commented, the Pope John XXIII and the Vatican II attendees wanted to build a bridge between what should be conserved and what can be "reconfigured." As Baron noted, the Catholic Church should be an active force for good rather than "a museum piece." An "Orthodox" Catholic made the statement that those Catholics who did not agree with her visions of Catholicism to leave the Catholic Church. As an aside, she did have any plan to force them to leave. On the other hand, other Catholics want to dilute Catholicism to the point of meaninglessness.  Baron included a litany of saints who had different views, and yet remained within the Catholic Church.Father Baron cited Dorothy Day and Peter Maurin as examples of Catholics who "bridged the gap." Dorothy Day was a Communist, a Socialist, and finally a devout convert to Catholcism. Her Catholic Worker Movement was a valiant effort to help destitute people. She was considered a "leftist" and a "radical." Anyone who now shows compassion and kindness is now considered a radical. One should note that the early Catholic martyrs were considered "radicals." On the other hand, Dorothy Day attended Mass every day, prayed the Rosary, kept the Office of the Hours, and was as devout as any devout monk or nun.What is Catholicism? An obvious answer is that Catholicism is a major religion. Father Baron defines Catholcism as "The Way." The Way is not only to be studied and defended. The Way is to be lived as though Catholicism is relevant and vital. While participating in the Sacraments is important, the Sacraments are of little use if Catholics do not walk The Way and adhere to what are known as "The Cardinal Virtues." Father Baron used a remark made by the late Bishop Sheen. Sheen said that the Three Wise Men left the Infant Christ and returned home another way. No one who encounters Christ can return the same way. In other words, men and woman who are serious about Catholicism must live a different way (The Way). The world should not change the Catholic Liturgy. The Catholic Liturgy should change the world for the better.As mentioned above, Father Baron used St. Thomas's work to enhance these essays. Baron made some philosophical comments about St. Thomas Aquinas and the late Blessed Pope John Paul II. St. Thomas Aquinas and John Paul II argued that God and people are in a human and divine order that brings people closer to each other and  to the Divine. Reason and study of Creation give examples of the finite world which can lead to the Divine and the Sacred. The philosophical and theological reasoning can help those not familiar with these studies. Father Baron wrote that true freedom is authenic truth and not trivia. Father Baron viewed the Cosmos as an example of God as an artist. This requires men and woman to recognize good vs. evil and beauty vs. the ugly. To appreciate what is good and what is beauty, people must be able to contrast such concepts with what is evil and ugly. The ability to use reason and understanding to know the difference is what makes us truly human and truly humane.In re evil, Father Baron had an interesing interpretation of the Fall. The Adam/Eve story is NOT  negative narrative of people as depraved. Father Baron argued that the Adam/Eve expulson from Eden was a transition for child-like innocence to adult awareness of good vs evil and responsiblity. This is not to say that defiance of the command of forbidden fruit was right. The lesson is that innocent children become adults and question what may be arbitrary authority. Not all authority is justified or right, and people learn this lesson for better or worse. Again, the knowledge of good and evil should be necessary for the Human Condition. The Incarnation may have been an effort to help people to recognize false piety, hypocricy, and insensitive authority.Father Baron wrote that true authenticity requires patience and no "quick answers." Baron's essay re such patience used the Advent Season as a background for this essay. What does Advent actually mean? Father Baron used a comment from Father Diekmann about the key concept of people. Father Diekmann used the term "Diefication" meaning that people are diefied by God, and men and women have the responsibility to live according to such a status. For Father Baron this meant that people must show compassion, mercy, kindness, bona fide love, and forgiveness. One must wonder how far the current culture has betrayed these concepts.One section of the book that did not provide good answers was Father Baron's treatment of the problem of evil. He used sections from the book of Job which are unsatisfactory. Father Baron's remark that natural and human disasters may lead to a better future is of NO consolation to those who suffer. Father Baron made a valiant attempt to reconcile the problem, but his arguements go begging. However, his explanation is better than most this reviewer has read. The book titled JOB AND THE EXCESS OF EVIL is another good attempt to explain the problem of evil.Theologcally the Cosmos was made by God and was "made good." Father Baron focused on Father Thomas Merton's efforts to establish peace. The thesis here is that violent competition and neglect of the concepts in the above paragraphy are a divorce of the Way (Christ's Way). As Father Baron explained, if some aggressive over-bearing person is confronted by another over-bearing person, conflict is inevitable. However if each is met by kindness and avoiding violence, what can the aggressive person do? Gandhi is a good example of this non-violent resistence. Blessed Mother Teresa either ignored fools and continued her work, or she refuted critics with searing response.The last sections of the book dealt with the status of Catholic clergy. Too often the Holy Office of the priesthood is either marginalized or reduced to irrelevancy. Catholic parishoners too often do not know that Catholic priests "do not grow on trees," and a shortage of priests exists. Catholics should be in a position to help Catholic clergy rather than express complaints and lack of concern or help. Catholics should not take Catholic priests for granted. As Father Baron noted, the indifference toward Catholic priests is cause for concern.Father Baron's book takes time and focus. His writing is clear, and the philosophical topics require attention to understand. If some readers claim the topics are above their heads, then they should stretch their necks. While some of the topics are philosophical and intellectual, Father Baron is certainly no snob. This reviewer's only criticism is that Father Baron is too optimistic. In an age of trivial concerns and praise of unbridled violence, Father Baron may despair. However, this book is well worth reading.James E. EgolfNovember 16, 2014

J.L. Witterick's book titled MY MOTHER'S SECRET is a tale of rare courage, compassion, mercy, forgiveness, and bona fide love. Some of the statements are thoughtful and a reminder of whom we should be rather than who we are in times of oppression and tyranny.Wittterick's book began with a husband and wife (Franciszka)debating the rise of Hitler & co. Franciszka had insight to know what could happen and had bitter arguements with her husband who prasied the rise of Hitler and Hitler's supporters. This debate led to a separation when Franciszka left her husband moved to Poland.Events quickly forced Franciszka and her daughter Helena to make decisions about "doing the right thing" is spite of deadly risks involved. Helena got a job with a company headed by Casmir who had connections in Germany. When W.W. II erupted in 1939, Franciszka sheltered Jewish people and German deserter. Witternick commented that Franciszka told Helena, the daughter, that doing the right thing becomes a reflex if one has the character to do so.The book related that when W.W. II began, Franciszka and her family were on the Russian side  because the Germans and Soviets agreed via secret protocol to invade and divide Poland. However, when the Germans and Soviets turned on each other, the Franciszka family were under German occupation which was especially lethal to Jewish people. Franciszka and Helena had a balancing act of harboring two Jewish families and a German solider. This was at a time when many neighbors were rewarded for being informers, and the mother and daughter had to be careful that they did not reveal their refugees which would have meant death to all concerned.Bascially Helena wanted to be with her employer Casmir whom she loved. However, Helena had to stay with her mother to help protect the refugees. Helena faced the issue of what is right vs. what I want. The tense situation was made worse when Franciszka learned that her son Damian died helping partisans against the Germans. Yet, Franciszka and Helena remained undaunted.The book then describes the views of the refugees. The German deserter Vilheim gave anecdotes of his dangerous situation. He was not meant to be a soldier and did not want to kill or be killed. His status as a refugee was tenuous because Frnaciszka was also harboring Jewish people, and she did not want the German soldier to know of the Jewish refugees. This was a delicate balancing act to say the least.A tragic bit of treachery occured when workers were recruited to work for brick factory only to be shot when they arrived. The Jewish workers thught they had a chance to get income for their families to survive only to lose their lives. A pharmacist betrayed Jewish people by informing on them. When the pharmacist discovered that the Wolenski family who were Jewish were being sheltered, the father, Dr. Wolenski, offered medical care to avoid being reported to the German authorities. The ploy worked.Dr. Wolenski and family were typical Jewish people. In spite of living in cramped, dangerous condtions, they did the best they could to insure that the children had books and learning. Dr. Wolenski was grateful to Frnaciszka and after W.W. II, showed his gratitude without being asked to do so. Righteous Gentiles and Jewish people shared the concepts of compassion, kindness, mercy, etc.What did this book teach? The book taught that fear is normal, but one should show courage in spite of fear. The book also taught readers something about shared kindness and gratitude. The characters in the book survived the war and extended their gratitude long after W.W. II was over. What else did this book teach? The book further taught that "The standard defines the exception" and the potential actually to be great.J. L. Winnerick's book is a good antidote to the willful stupidity that exists. At a time, when too many hate mongers want to demonize people because of ethnic origins, language, religion, etc., this book is a reminder of what can be done. This writer went though "dark times," but he met people who reminded him of the characters in this book who helped escape such dark times. This book reminded the undersigned that the concept of "Original Sin" is not that we are depraved. Orginal Sin means that people are not as good as they can be. An adage states that it is easy to be right when everyone else is right. However, it is difficult or even dangeous to be right when everyone else is wrong. This writer enjoyed the book and enjoyed the other well written reviews. The only regret this writer has is that he did not read the book sooner. This book is HIGHLY recommended.James E. EgolfMarch 26, 2013

James Burham (1905-1987)once wrote that hypocrisy was England's greatest export. William Cobbett (1763-1835) could have written that hypocrisy was England's greatest gross domestic product. Cobbett's book titled A HISTORY OF THE PROTESTANT REFORMATION IN ENGLAND AND IRELAND made this point very well. Readers must remember that Cobbett was PROTESTANT, but he had a passion for truth. He was bascially self-taught, and he did a credible job in exposing the terrible consequences of the English Reformation(s). Readers should note that Francis Cardinal Gasquet, D.D., OSB (1846-1919)edited the book by citing references and making minor corrections which provided a  bona fide list of sources to easily support Cobbett's book.Cobbett started this book by underming some of the erroneous claims made against the Catholic Church. One false claim that Cobbett refuted was that Medieval monks/nuns were the carriers of "monkish" ignorance and superstition. During the so-called Dark Ages (c. 500-c. 750), the Catholic monks and nuns were almost exclusively the only learned people. They assisted the poor, opened schools to as many people as possible, hand copied books and created libraries when many people were illiterate. Cobbett chided Blackstone (1723-1780), a well known English jurist when Blackstone wrote about Catholic ignorance. Blackstone knew very well that abbeys, monastaries, etc. were built by Catholics who taught students including law where Blackstone was housed. The Magna Carta and concepts of due process and legal "fair play" were part of English Catholic Constitutional History.Cobbett also stressed the fact that much of England was pagan prior to 597 when St. Augustine, d. 601, and not to be confused with the other St. Augustine (354-430),brought Catholicism to England in 597. Pope Adrian IV (1155-1159)was an Englishman. Monks and nuns helped the English acquire learning and were a valuable asset to the poor via hospices, legal protections re property, etc. Yet, the English "Reformation" begun by Henry VIII (1491-1547) ended these achievements. The monastaries, convents, other Catholic property were unlawfully confiscated by Henry's henchmen especially Thomas Cromwell (1485-1540). Marriages were unlawfully disolved. Henry VIII had his daughters Mary and Elizabeth declared illegitimate and had Anne Bolyn unlawfully executed. The "divorce" between Henry and Catherine of Aragon was also unlawful which caused Henry to start the English "Reformation."Cobbett had more criticism re the English "Reformations(s)." The English complaint that they had to pay Peter's Pence to support the Catholic Church was shallow. The English paid more in one year for foreign mercenaries than they paid in four centuries re Peter's Pence. Henry VIII did not think he separated from Catholcism, but the splinter groups caused problems. The situation was so bad that men and women were tortured and executed for believing in the Real Presence and then for not believeing it. Queen Elizabeth I (1558-1603)exceeded Henry VIII's cruelty in arresting and torturing Catholics and dissident Protestants. One of Eliabeth's first official acts was to order the execution of four Anabaptists by burning at the stake. When some refer to Elizabeth's predecessor, Mary, as "Bloody Mary," they omit the fact that  Elizabeth's mass executions of Catholics and dissent Protestants  made Mary's executions look tame by comparison. When the "powers-that-be" could not find enough Catholics to murder, they turned on each other because of lethal greed and power lust. Cobbett mentioned that family loyalty was so diminished that James I appointed advisors who had James' mother put to death via an illegal trial. Cobbett made numerous references of the valuable services of Catholic priests, nuns, monks, etc. prior to the Reformation. Records, docuements were trusted to these Catholics who were known for their learning and honesty.As Cobbett repeatedly wrote, 900 years of English Catholic History were prosperous by comparison. Learning was encouraged, and, again, the "lower classes" has a reasonable living compared to the Reformation and thereafter. The middle class and poor were so dispossed by the Reformation that the English had Poor Laws for the destitute which were unknown in England prior to the Reformation. John Locke (1632-1704)chided the wretched poor for being lazy and shiftless. What he omitted in this "official" report is that the poor folks' ancestors were driven from their land. He failed to note that many of the poor were denied entry into the job market. These poor souls were punished for begging. Their "wages" if they had any were kept below subsistence levels. Locke forgot that restrictions and other "legal" impediments kept men and women from gainful employment. The English were so paranoid that a monument was erected blaming Catholics for the 1666 London Fire. No evidence exists whatsoever to support such an outrageous claim.Not only did the English "Reformation" cause terrible problems in England, but the Reformation seriously hurt English foreign policy. Queen Elizabeth betrayed so many different factions in France, that she HAD to withdraw troops from different intrigues. When William and Mary were illegally installed as King/Queen of England in 1688, they ventured on foreign adventures in Europe which required the English to establish a national debt to be paid by the middle class and poor to the financial interests. In other words, the English exhausted their options for bleeding the middle classes and poor which required future debt.When the English tried to impose their "system" on the American colonists who benefitted from years of  legal neglect, the imposition of such measures that had worked in England were successfully resisted, and the English had to face the reality that their system had "seen better days." Cobbett then directed his attention to the French Revolution which struck fear in England. Perhaps out of fear and desparation, the English began relaxing their lethal laws against Catholics to gain political unity. The English expressed shock at the French Revolution and the revolutionary persecution of French Catholics. The French had learned very well that plunder and massacres of Catholics had worked before in England. These events were in effect "a blessing in disguise" for English and Irish Catholics who could say, "I told you so."Cobbetts' book and Cardinal Gasquet's editing make this a well researched book that undermines bias and dishonest history. The book is "an eye opener" for those who have been exposed to bias and dishonest history. Careful readers should read the notes and comments to grasp the importance and accuracy of the book.James E. EgolfMarch 15, 2013

Father Jaki, OSB (1924-2009), was a devout Catholic and a brilliant physicist, mathematician, and astronomer. He was also a historian and a profound thinker. His book titled MIRACLES AND PHYSICS is a combative rebuttal re those who scoff at the concept of miracles. Fr. Jake "took no prisoners" in writing this book. Fr. Jaki also showed a sense of humor in an otherwise very serious book.Fr. Jaki cited Hippolyte Taine(1828-1893)who stated that if the Catholic Church officials and scholars survived Darwinism, they would survive anything. Now, Darwin's (1809-1882)theory has been seriously challenged if not rebutted. Readers should know that Fr. Jaki was not a literalist or fundamentalist. He knew too much about physics and astronomy to accept the literal biblical account of Creation. He also saw the Bible in an allegorical sense but not nonsense. Fr. Jaki let readers know that the Catholic Church has EASILY survived the challenge of Darwinism. Fr. Jaki had harsh words for those who try to be "trendy" and "modern" when they try to dabble and use arcane philosophy in their writing which is so much "academic bafflegab." He cited a quote from THE SCOTSMAN (December 16, 1988: p. 12) which is as follows:Jesus said to them, "Who do you say that I am?" They replied, "You are the eschatological manifestation of the gorund of our being, the kerygma of which we find the ultimate meaning in our interpersonal relationships." And Jesus said, "What?"Fr. Jaki also refutted the notion that quantum mechanics, probabilty theory, etc. did not have "the final answers" re science. Fr. Jaki carefully explained that certain events were beyond scientific explanation, and these rare events are miracles. Fr. Jaki critisized Neils Bohn (1885-1962) and Werner Heisenberg (1901-1976)who concluded that miracles do not exist. Fr. Jaki carefully explained the "gaps" that 20th. century physicists simply could not explain. Fr. Jaki showed the "shortcomings' of Max Planc's (1858-1947) view of determinism.Fr. Jaki credited those men who were devout Catholics such as Pierre Duhem (1861-1916)who was a scientific scholar and a devout Catholic. Duhem wrote about the achievements of devout religious men and women who contributed to scientific knowledge. Readers should read Duhem's work and/or Fr. Jaki's book re Duhem. Fr. Jaki remarked that determinists and scientific ideologues are so imbued with their theories that they want to write about nature as if there were no nature. One biblical passage that Fr. Jaki cited was Exodus 3:14-17 when God told Moses that He (God) is I AM WHO I AM. This is a profound yet mysterious statement and adds mystery to what we already know.Fr.Jaki's last section of the book is an attack of those who deny any possibility of miracles. For example, Fr. Jaki described the early Catholic martyrs who died agnonizing deaths in part because of their belief in miracles. No one dies like that for trite reasons. Fr. Jaki wrote about those miracles at Lourdes. Alexis Carrel (1873-1944)won the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1912 and was an atheist and cynic. Yet, he personally witnessed miracles at Lourdes which could not be explained and converted to Catholicism. When St. Bernadette (1844-1879) was questioned about what she experienced at Lourdes,she responded that her duty was to report what happened and not to make others believe it.Fr. Jaki should have condemned the phony "faith healers: and televangelists whose fakes give miracles a bad name. However, NO ONE can claim that Fr. Jaki, a brilliant man of science, was some sort of superstitious charlatan. The undersigned does not want to give the pretense that he understood all the physics that Fr. Jaki mentioned in this book. Yet, the book was well written that anyone with "residual common sense" can grasp the thesis of the book.James E. EgolfFebruary 20, 2013

Catholic bashers and those who deride Pope Pius XII should avoid Ronold J. Rychlak and his book HITLER, THE WAR, AND THE POPE. The author and the book destroys all the nonsense smears of Pope Pius XII and Catholcism. Rychlak, J.D., teaches Law at the University of Mississippi and demonstrated meticulous research in this book. Rychlak penetrated Pope Pius XII' careful thinking and Pius's courageous actions.Rychlak started this book with a brief account Eugenio Pacelli's (1876-1958), the future Pope Pius XII, career. Pacelli was an excellent student and very early in his life showed intelligence, class, strength of character, and undaunted courage. Pacelli was quickly promoted in the Catholic hierarchy, and impressed those whom he met whether or not they were Catholic.Rychlak wrote about Pacelli's courage while Pacelli was a Papal Nuncio in Germany just after W.W. I. Pacelli's mission was to help alleviate the suffering and hardship inflicted on the Germans after the First World War. A gang of violent communists threatened Pacelli's life and pushed a gun into his chest. Pacelli was not phased and shamed the gang members by reminding them that he (Pacelli) was on a mission of peace. He blessed his would-be murderers who left. Pacelli must have made a favorable impression because some of these communists returned and profusely apologized for their bad actions and behavior. Pacelli also showed that he followed Christ's message of forgiveness. Pacelli refused to cooperate with the police re questioning and probably knew that his attackers may "have learned their lesson."Rychalk cited Pacelli's warnings about the newly formed National Socialist movement whose future leader was Hitler. In 1921, 1923, and in 1926, Pacelli warned about this new political movement and its pagan, racist overtones. Readers should note that Pacelli was one of the very first to alert Europeans and Catholics the actual danger of the potential of the National Socialist movement.Rychlak also condemned the efforts of Big Communism to exterminate the Catholic Church. While the focus of the book dealt with Pius XII and the threat from the Germans authorites, Rychlak provided a brief summary of the mass murder of Catholic and Orthodox clergy in the Soviet Union. By 1922, over 8,100 Catholic clergy, monks, nuns, and monks were murdered. As an aside, some ambitious historian should write a book about the attempts to mass murder Catholics in the USSR and areas that came under Soviet  control.Rychlak then examined the Catholic Church in Germany in the 1930s. Hitler & co. were not happy with German Caholics whose voting mostly opposed National Socialist candidates. Pacelli and many Catholics were not fooled by Hitler & co.'s anti-Communism. These Catholics knew that National Socialism contradicted Catholic teaching, and they made their views well known at great personal risk. Pius XII' predecessor, Pope Piux XI (1922-1939)issued the Papal Encyclical MIT BRENNEDER SORGE in 1937 which was a stinging indictment of National Socialist ideology. Readers should note that Eugenio Pacelli, the future Pope Pius XII, wrote this document. In fact Vatican officials including Pacelli refused to host Hitler when he visited Italy.As noted above, Rychlak wrote about Pacelli's courage in German during the 1920s. Rychlak cited later examples. When German authorities threated Pius with arrest and placement in a concentration camp, Pius defied these authorities and was bluntly clear he was not the least bit intimidated. Pope Pius XII was well aware of plot via Hitler & co. to invade the Vatican and massacre the Curia and Pius himself if necessary. Yet, Pius refused all pleas to leave the Vatican for safe haven. The details of this plot are well doucmented in Kurzman's book titled A SECRET MISSION. When Rome and parts of the Vatican were bombed by the "allies," Pius absolutely refused to go to a bomb shelter and went to the affected areas to administer Last Rites and provide relief.Pope Pius XII's efforts to help refugees including Jewish refugees extended to Eastern Europe. Jewish historians Pinchas Lapide and Jano Levai thoroughly documented these efforts. Any Catholic clergy who collaborated with anti-Jewish authorities were defrocked and excommunicated. Pius was blunt about the mission and teaching of the Catholic Church and Catholic reaction in the midst of terrible evil.Rychlak wrote extensively of prominent Jews who were so very grateful of Pius' efforts to rescue Jews and relieve their suffereing. Many Catholics who made such couragous efforts did so at the risk of their lives, and some became martyrs in doing so. Rychlak etal. gave high praise to both Pius and those Catholics who showed calm reserve in the midst of such grave danger. In spite of orders from German and Italian authorities not to help refugess including Jewish refugees, the Catholics did so regardless of the risks. Rychlak provided humorous ruses used by Catholics to smuggle food and medicine as well as provide escape to those who were arrested.Rychlak wrote about Pius's tenure after W.W. II. Pius was praised by well known Jewish dignitaries, and Rabbi Israel Zolli, Chief Rabbi of Rome, converted to Catholicism. Rabbi Herzog who was the Chief Rabbi of Jerusalem offered such high praise. Many Protestants including the late President Eisenhower also offered praise and honor to Pope Pius XII. The testimonies and documents in praise re Pope Pius XII are overwhelming as are the bona fide documents.After Pius died on 10/9/1958, cowards tried to villfy him. Yet, these smears are easily refuted. For example, Cornwell's book HITLER's POPE has been destroyed by historians who rely on documents and not hysteria and hate. Cornwell's book jacket proved to be a lie. The cover has Pius XII meeting Hitler with guards wearing modern German uniforms. The photo is fake. The original photo was taken in 1929 when Pacelli met Von Hindengerg, and the guards  actually wore very traditional uniforms. In fact, Pope Pius XII NEVER met Hitler. Pius's detractors have been trounced in debates with Pius's defenders and have been reduced to whining that proof contrary to their lies hurt their feelings and made them angry. One should note Pius' detractors now avoid debate with those who have read the documents and know the truth.Prof. Rychlak wrote a solid book based on meticulous research. His notes and bibliography are comprehensive and more than enough to substantiate his thesis that Pope Pius XII was a great man whose courage, intelligence, and tact were rare during a time of evil and immense tragedy.James E. EgolfFebruary 11, 2013

Sister Marchione, Ph.D. wrote a passionately yet well documented book about Pope Pius XII's rare courage, intelligence, and compassion. While Sr. Marchione is an ardent defender of Pope Pius XII, she substantiated her enthusiasm by solid research and good writing. Much of what she wrote in this book can be gleanred from her other well written books on behalf of Pope Pius XII.Sister Marchione began the book with citations from LIFE MAGAZINE (December 13, 1954)which were glowing attributes of Pius's efforts during W.W. II to rescue refugees including Jewish refugees. She made use of a NEW YORK TIMES (October 15, 1945)feature in praise of Pope Pius XII.Part I of Sister Marchione's book gave a precis of Pope Pius XII's life. He was named Eugenio Pacelli and his life span was from 1876-1958. His parents were well connected to Vatican authorities. The Pacelli family had close friendship with the Mendes family who were Jewish, and Pius XII helped a family member escape Europe during W.W. II. Pacelli was an excellent student and decided early that he wanted to become a Catholic priest. His intelligence and thoughtfulness were noticed by Vatican officials, and he was appointed Bishop and sent as a Papal nuncio to Germany after W.W. I to help with relief efforts. Pacelli did so well that he was appointed as Cardinal and eventually was elected Pope.Sister Marchione further described Pope Pius XII as optimistic, very generous, courageous, and yet humble. Pope Pius XII had a serious concern for justice, and he also had a sense of humor. When Hitler's attempt to overthrow the Bavarian governmment in 1923 failed, Pacelli etal stated that Hitler would never come to power. Later when confronted with the fact that Hitler did rise to power, Pacelli was then Pope. Pope Pius XII joked that he was not so infallible in 1923. As Pope Pius XII said, "Laughter has no religion."As noted above, Pope Pius XII was a humble man. Sister Marchione commented that Pope Pius XII did not promote his good deeds, but others have done so. In 1987, Pope John Paul II publicly noted Pius's courage and good deeds. W.W. II veterans on "both sides" such as Leonardo Marinelli who was an Italian commander in Northern Italy made such mention in 1943.  A young Italian priest arranged for 300 Yugoslavian Jewish people to go to Switzerland.What may surprise some readers is that many Protestants also had high regard for Pope Pius XII. One Kansas Baptist family gave their tithe to The Holy See because of what Pope Pius XII did for their son during W.W. II. As an aside some French Socialists who were atheists wrote a tome on behalf of Pope Pius XII.Those who were in Europe and in Rome and are still alive gave further evidence of Pope Pius XII's compassion, kindness, mercy, etc. Sister Marchione cited a comment from Francis Paul DiBlasi, Jr. who was in Rome during W.W. II. which highly praised Pius XII. Sigrid Ruedel Crane of Virginia lived in Germany before and during W.W. II. She related that some of the Catholic priests were arrested and sent to concentration camps. Yet, she well knew of Pope Pius XII's efforts and determination to help the helpless. Sigrid made an important remark that those who attack Pope Pius XII were not alive at the time and make baseless claims with no sources or understanding. As an aside, this reviewer is amused at Pope Pius XII's detractors and Catholic bashers. When confronted with bona fide sources that refute their bias, they can only get angry and use ad hominem arguements makiing themselves look foolish an petty. That is all they do when confronted with truth.Not only did Pope Pius XII do all he could to help the defenseless in Italy and Western Europe, but Pius XII did all he could in Eastern Europe. Documents prove that Pius XII ordered his Bishops and Cardinals in Eastern Europe to do they could for refugees including Jewish people. The Jewish historian Pinchas Lapide noted this in his book titled THREE POPES AND THE JEWS. Jeno Levai, another Jewish historian made the same assertion.Sister Marchione had a section re Pope Pius XII's Encyclicals  which clearly condemned racism, persecution, and blind hatred. His Christmas messages between 1940-1943 were heard throughout the world and refutes the charge of silence. Pope Pius XII knew he would be attacked. He helped a member of the Italian Communist Party to avoid arrest and gave this man refuge. Yet, this Communist tried to smear the Pope after W.W. II.Sister wrote an impassioned yet accurate account of Pope Pius XII. As one historian wrote, too many cowards tried to use Pope Pius XII as a scapegoat for the moral failure of others. Sister Marchione's books and bonifide documents refute smears against Pope Pius XII. The problem is the the detractors and Catholic bashers refuse to read the books or sources. However, the sources and books are available for the record.James E. EgolfFebruary 9, 2013

Karl Keating, a learned and articulate "Defender of the Faith," published an anthology of his work both defending "The Faith" and himself from false accusations and fabrications. Keating also defended well known Catholics from historical falsification and attacks bsased on ignorance and "hot air."The first essay in Keating' collections was titled "When not to turn the Other Cheek." Keating recounted the  dispute between Charles Kingsley, a history professor at Cambridge, and John Henry Newman. Kingsley blundered when he accused the Catholic Church intellectuals of disregarding the truth and briefly accused Newman of the same charge. Newman defied Kingsley to cite where Newman ever argued against the truth. Kingsley made his situation worse by adding further fabrications against Newman who refused to accept Kingsley's false accusations and INSISTED that Kingsley cite where Newman EVER argued against the truth. "To make a long story short," Kingsley got hopelessly lost in adding "fuel to the fire." Newman did not engage in the dispute for his own reputation as he refuted Kingsley in the service of truth.This essay was followed by attacks on Keating himself. Keating used reason and humor to undermine false accusations against himself. Keating amused his readers with anecdotes which were illogical and humorously hysterical over a pamplet he has distributed when Pope John Paul II visited Colorado. Anyone who enjoys laugther would enjoy Keating's reason and wit in demolishing stupidty and petty hysteria.Keating had further remarks re Pope John II when the latter's view of evolution were altered by Professor Joy Stephen Gould who is a biology professor and populizer of the theory of evolution. Gould "put words into Pope John Paul II's mouth" re evolution. Pope John Paul II stated that evolution was a theory AND ONLY A THEORY. He never wrote that evolution was "the last word" but an aid, albeit and imperfect aid, in the study of biology. Keating contrasted  Pope John Paul II's remarks with Gould's misinterpretion of these remarks. In short, Keating "set the record straight.Keating then turned his attention re Internet use. Because Keating did not agree with the National Catholic Register and their "Sister L" list, Keating was advised he could not comment via the Internet to disagree with NCR. Keating was quick to respond that the NCR folks and other Internet users boasted of diverse debates and open discussion while insisting the Keating not be permitted to do so. Keating effectively and with a sense of humor critisized such inconsistency.Another anecdote that Keating used as example of truth was the recent debate over biblical sources especially the Gospels and The New Testament. Many biblical historians date the New Testament's completion as late as 90-100 AD. Relying on recent scholarship, Keating made the case that the Gospels and The New Testament may have been  completed c. 68 AD. Keating suggested that an Aramaic New Testament was the original source from which the Koine Greek New Testament was based. Keating DID NOT claim to be the final word, but he was impressed with the new possibility. What drew Keating into this topic was arrogance of establishment scholars when the  older view was challenged. This reviewer accepts the dates of between c.90-c.100 AD, but Keating's suggestion may be right. The undersigned would agree if a complete Aramaic source were found.Keating showed a concern for truth when he launched a deadly attack on Ayn Rand's 1967 essay titled ""Requiem for Man" in which she condemned the Catholic authorities and, at the time,  Pope Paul VI. Keating destroyed this essay. Rand wrote, among other things, that the Kremlin and the Vatican were akin in destroying man's mind. Rand altered some of Pope Paul VI's work and wrote as though no one would notice. Rand created history out of nothing in this essay. Rand condemned Socialism, Communism, and Fascism. However, she was not very good at history. Pope Leo XIII (1878-1903)condemned socialism in his encyclical titled RERUM NOVARUM. Pope Pius XI (1922-1939) condemned Big Communism, and Pope Pius XII (1939-1958) condemned Fascism. Rand's essay takes no note of previous Catholics who condemned authortarian political systems.As an aside, Rand argued that Catholicism controlled men's minds. What she did not know or want to know is that many recent scientific and mathematical achievements have been done by devout Catholics. Did Rand ever know about Father Gregor Mendel (1822-1884)who pioneered the study of genetics? Was she aware of Fr. Le Maitre (1894-1966)who created a mathematical model of the universe which Albert Einstein praised? Was Ayn Rand knowledgeable about the work of Fr. Stanley Jaki (1924-2009)who was a foremost physicist, mathematician, and astronomer? The Catholic authorities encouraged their work and highly praised these men and so much for Rand's silly remark that Catholicism wants to control "men's minds."Keating's essays on Catholicism in Japan and icons are just as interesting as the other essays in this book. Keatings keen obvervations of Greek Orthodox iconography are  graphic and clear. Keating wrote a depressing yet accurate account of the Catholic Church in Japan which was all but eliminated in the late 16th. and early 17th. centuries. When later Catholic missionaries visited Japan, they were surprised that residuals of Catholicism still existed.Keating's book is lively, terse, and interesting. Keating is a very learned man who is tough but not arrogant. This book is worth reading. The only complaint is that it does not have an index or bibliography. Readers should enjoy this book.James E. EgolfFebruary 5, 2013

Father Thomas Keating, who is a Cistercian monk and not to be confused with Karl Keating, wrote REWAKENINGS to show readers the "deeper meanings" of familiar Gospel stories. The book is clear without "over-simplifying" some of examples he uses to embellish spiritual life.One example is the story of Christ feeding the 5,000 plus. The apparent impossible situation is explained in the Christ "took a first step," and then He explained that the food was temporary when people should ultimately seek the "Bread of Life" which lasted longer than manna.Fr. Keating used the example St. Peter who lost faith and almost drowned re walking on water until he lost faith. He begged Christ for help which he got. What is the moral of the story? The moral is that people appeal and pray when they face "life's storms. St. Peter could be intelligent and alert to Christ's teaching, and at other times, St. Peter was severely admonished by Christ. St. Peter could be a coward or he could be a saint. Fr. Keating had  interesting remarks re Christ's "transfiguration". Peter wanted to build monuments, but Christ said no and returned to teaching. The message is that when people are transfigured, they need to set an example rather than "resting on their laurals."Fr. Keating often referred to renewal and redemption. He used insight re the leper and the blind. These poor souls, perhaps "dead souls," were physically cured and then had a spiritual awakening re mind and soul. Fr. Keating gave added intellectual dimension to the obvious narratives.Fr, Keating had more intelligent remarks about a nagging woman pleading her cause to corrupt judge who finally relented to her request just to avoid the constand nagging and not out of any sense of justice. The moral of this story is that God who is just will answer pleas even if at times the answer is NO.This reviewer was facinated by Fr. Keatings remarks re the incident re the "woman taken in adultry." Fr. Keating wrote that Christ was bored with Pharisees and "knew their game." If Christ agreed that according to Moses that the poor woman be stoned to death, He would betray His teaching of compassion, kindness, mercy, forgiveness, etc. If Christ refuted Moses Law, he could be accused of violating The Law of Moses. As stated, Fr. Keating wrote that Christ was bored with these Pharisees. He "had seen it all before." One must rhetorically ask how hard is it to find a "wayward woman?" Christ wrote something on the ground which may have been a report on the sins of the Pharisees. The same is true re the woman who washed Christ's feet and was forgiven. The Pharisee said Christ, as a prophet, should have know what sort of woman this person was. Christ blasted the Pharisee for being an ungracious host. As an aside, one may wonder how these self-rightousness Pharisees knew so much about "wayward women."Some of the essays dealt with Advent and Lent and the parable about alertness. Fr. Keating argued people should always be alert about Christ's teaching and example. Catholicism is a religion renewal, and Mass is celebrated every day to renew people to such alertness.Father Keating's book is readable helps readers to think more carefully about biblical anecdotes. This book is not popular religion, but any reader "with residual common sense" can profit from the book. The undersigned wishes that Father Keating would have included an index and bibliographyJames E. EgolfFebruary 5, 2013

Chandler A. Phillips, M.D., P.E. is an autodidact whose anthology re Aesop's Fables is a readable account with anecdotes that make serious readers think about "the human condition." Some of the anecdotes force readers to consider "the lesser of two evils." In other words, as bad as a situation is, the situation could be worse. Some of the anecdotes deal with deviousness, loyalty, and practicle advice.Dr. Phillips gave a brief background of Aesop (c. 558 BC) who may have been a slave. While little is know of Aesop, he may have been murdered or executed for theft.The Ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle (384-322 BC) and Greek historian Herodotus (484-425 BC) made brief reference to Aesop. The Ancient Romans also mentioned Aesop and either quoted Aesop or paraphrased him. The Ancient Roman physician Galen (c.129-216 AD)mention the problem of attricution re Aesop's work.Dr. Phillips introduced readers of how Aesop's Fables were preserved during "the Middle Ages" when learning was under constant threat. Phillips mentioned several sources of Aesop's fables such as the Florentine Codex (c.1300s) the Moscow Codex, the Dresden Leaf, etc. Those who read this book will have a thorough background of the history of editing and redacting Aesop's work. They will also know the problems in attempting to focus on what sources are reliable.Dr. Phillips divided  Aesop's Fables between those involving animals and those involving men, gods, and objects. The animal most often used in the fables was the fox whose guile and clever assessments make him an example what men are especially when they are trying to "out-fox" the naive and enemies.Some of the anecdotes give "food for thought." For example, Aeschylus (527-456 B.C.)wrote that Orestes' greatest foe was his conscience when he assassinated his mother who previously assassinated Orestes' father. In other words, "enemies" sometimes have outposts in our mind. Dr. Phillips used an anecdote that death can be a relief from life's burdens.As mentioned above, Aesop's work included animals. Dr. Phillips used an anecdote about cattle plotting a revolution against the butchers until an older bovine reminded the plotters that the current skilled butchers whose methods were painless and merciful could be replaced by novices who could make death very painful.The human examples that Dr. Phillips cited dealt with power, relations, and true friendship. Seneca (c.1-66 A.D.)wrote that those with power should use it lightly. Another anecdote stated the kindness and not kinship made bona fide parents. Socrates (c. 470-399 B.C.) was supposedly chided for building a large house to which Socrates responded the hoped he had enough friends to fill it. Cicero (106-43 B.C.) remarked that arms ought to give way to oratory.Other anecdotes and "words of wisdom" include a leopard and a fox regarding the leopard's verigated skin and the fox's verigated mind. People run fast to catch something but faster to escape danger. Dr. Phillips included an example of not drinking from an empty well which means people should learn only from the learned. To the wise, nothing is foreign. This comment may in line with St. Thomas Aquinas(1225-1274)who wrote that truth is wherever we find it. Pity those who fear to speak the truth. One anecdote this writer like was that we should love at random but not to be hated needlessly. Necessity is the last and strongest weapon-Livy (59 B.C.- 17 A.D.). Arrogance destroys lovers which can mean that "coaxing, not ordering, makes love sweet." A good example of "the human condition" is that  fools critisize others but omit their own faults.Dr. Phillips concluded this book with comments of those whose help he graciously acknowledged. The end of the book again cited problems of the historical accuracy of Aesop's work and those whose used his Fables. Those interested in Ancient History can benefit form the bibliography and the list of Ancient Greeks and Romans listed at the end of the book.Dr. Phillips is to be commended for writing and editing a book that is too often ignored in the name of modernity. The undersigned gleaned so much from this book and could write a book itself to include all the proverbs and fables. This book is to be read and digested by thoughtful people.James E. EgolfDecember 25, 2012
