There is just enough "give" to the filling to be able to sort of mold it around the shoulder and neck area and it holds it shape!I really only intended to take a quick 20 minute nap, but ended up falling SOUND asleep and didn't budge from my original position for 2 1/2 hours!!!This may not sound exciting to you, but for someone who wakes frequently with neck pain, it was right up there with a miracle!!!Upon close inspection of this pillow, the quality of construction is pretty amazing - not always the case with pillows even the very expensive ones.Since I thought may it was just a fluke that I slept a solid 2 1/2 hours without waking to make pillow adjustments, I tried it again that night and had the best night's sleep I've had in literally years.So, in conclusion, I can say without bias that this truly is the BEST pillow I've EVER used and will be buying a couple more!!!  The crazy thing is, this is not an expensive pillow to start with - $40 for a good quality, king sized pillow is VERY reasonable when you compare it to many out there on the market that make the claim that they are the worlds softest, most comfortable, etc....All I can say is TRY IT!  You have nothing to lose since it has a money back guarantee.If you have ANY trouble with sleeping because of pillow issues you will not be disappointed with this product.

While I'm sure this works great for gardening, I didn't buy it for that purpose.  I raise goats and twice a year, I have midwife duties to attend to out in the barn :)  This means I have quite a few supplies I'm toting back and forth and, in the past, I've used a 5 gal bucket plus a few bags to hold everything.  It's awkward and not the most efficient system!After searching for a cost effective solution, I found this awesome bucket apron that has ended up being the perfect thing!I put the puppy pads, blankets and towels inside the bucket inside a garbage bag to keep them clean.  The birthing supplies got into all the many pockets on the sides where I can easily reach what I need.The pockets are just the right depth and width to where I can get to the smaller items I need to grab quickly without the goats being able to pull them out!The canvas is sturdy and straps and attachments are  well constructed for a pretty inexpensive item.  The split side goes over the handle then the strap secures it around the bucket.  My only issue, which is a small one, is I'd like to see them make the canvas a darker color so the dirt doesn't show quite so easily.  I suppose you can wash it by hand.  I haven't tried that yet but will need to one of these days after the next kidding season :)Overall, this is a very helpful item for what I needed it for but could also be used for horse folks, crafters, painters, etc...anywhere that you have several mid sized items you need to keep within reach AND a bucket :)I was able to purchase this at a promotional price to test and give my honest opinion and feedback.I can happily say I would recommend it and have found it to be just what I needed for the task at hand :)Hope this was helpful info!Enjoy

3:09 Mins This is a pretty handy, functional light and much bigger than it appears in the photo (See video for a demo)  Thankfully, it's pretty simple to use because there were no instructions included as to how and where to insert batteries and the general operation!  It came from China so it took weeks to get here.It's a simple operation - just pull the handles up and the lamp comes on.  Push it back down to collapse and the light goes out.The lights are actually pretty bright for a small lamp and the handle on top is great for hanging inside a tent or on a tree for camping.  This produces enough light to play cards or eat at a picnic table while camping and also makes a good emergency light for the house if the power goes out.One thing to note on this lamp is the weight.  If you are a backpacker who is concerned about gear weight, this is probably not the lamp to take as it is rather heavy compared to other lamps available with the same brightness.Overall, this is a good little lamp!I was able to purchase this at a promo price to test it out and give an honest opinion and feedback.Hope this was helpful!

4:20 Mins We are avid campers, backpackers and kayakers so we've collected our share of gear over the years!  We have a set of items we use for backpacking which are ultra-light titanium, small and packable. The regular camping/kayak gear does not have to be quite so small and light as we have more space to work with when packing so we got this cook set for that purpose.I mentioned that because this set would not be what you hardcore ultralight folks call ...well..ultralight BUT, if you were only taking ONE set of cookware for two people, this set would totally work!The pictures just don't do this set justice which is why I did a video so you can see what this whole thing looks like "in person!"We were totally surprised by the quality of this set because of the low price.  It's a well constructed, coated aluminum with protected, fold away handles.  These sizes are perfect for frying up eggs, potatoes, a small fish with the larger one with the lid works great for soups, stew or dehydrated meals.You get a ladle, small wooded spoon, 2 cups and a pan cleaner that all nest inside. The net carrying bag is nice for keeping everything together and organized.We sort of stumbled upon this set through a special promotional offer with a discount for testing this out and giving our honest opinion and feedback!  Shopping for outdoor camping cookware can get confusing with so many choices and price points to consider.This set is proof you don't have to spend twice as much to get a good quality cookware set.  We are VERY pleased with this set and highly recommend it!! :)Hope this was helpful info :)Enjoy :)

As a hairstylist, I pay careful attention to hair care products - how they perform on a variety of hair types - so I'm able to recommend the proper products when asked.The idea of bar shampoo was interesting to me but honestly I really didn't have high expectations and assumed this would be rather harsh to use on fragile, color treated or damaged hair.  The reason I bought this is because I was looking for the most efficient product for the purpose of packing into a backpack or gear bag.I actually cut this bar up into 5 pieces (its a good sized bar) and wrapped the pieces in cling wrap.  There is one bar in each of our backpacks and one in both of our grab and go bags!  The fifth piece I used to test the product.What I found was it has a very nice, mild fragrance, it lathers well for not having all of the harsh ingredients. does a nice job of cleansing the hair and rinses well.The only issue, at least with my hair, is that if you have fine and/or color treated hair, you will want to use a conditioner after shampooing.  My husband, however, loved this bar!  Since his hair is rather short, he doesn't have to worry about tangles so he was quite happy with how the shampoo left his hair.I let our daughter use it and she has long, fine hair without color or highlights and her hair tends to get oily.  She liked how her hair felt and said her scalp was not as oily by the end of the day as is usually the case for her.I decided I liked this enough to have it be "the" shampoo for our gear bags and I'm solving the tangle issue by packing a small spray bottle of leave in treatment.After a couple of days of washing my hair with this I found I needed to use a conditioning mask since I have fine, highlighted hair and it was starting to feel flyaway.I think this product would actually be very good for use on children's hair since it is mild and easy to use :)Overall, I really like this and feel it would work well for many different hair types and really appreciate the minimal ingredients :)Through a promotional offer, I was able to purchase this at a discount to test and give my honest opinion and feedback.So, yes i recommend this and feel its a good quality product at a fair price.  Just be aware it may not work on all hair types :)Hope this was helpful info for you shampoo shoppers!Enjoy!

3:24 MinsPlease see the video review for a detailed look at this set of pans with additional info :)We do a lot of camping and kayaking and are always on the lookout for good quality, well made gear that is compact and not too heavy.  The problem is, it can get very expensive!We had the opportunity to try out this set at a promotional price to give our honest opinion and feedback so we jumped on it!Believe me, the product description and pics don't do this set justice!What a great surprise to open this up and find that, for less than $25, this set more than met our needs and expectations!You get 4 graduated sized pans which all nest inside each other - ranging from a coffee cup sized small pot to a large pot that is more than large enough to cook a large sized, dehydrated meal for 2!I think one of the  best parts about this set is that your gas stove fits right inside perfectly for storage which is crucial for saving precious space in your gear bag or backpack.The wrap around handles of each pot are coated with a type of plastic which helps protect your hands from heat BUT you need to know that these pots are really designed to be used with a camp stove rather than on an open campfire!  The plastic WILL melt off if you set these pots in the fire!!For you ultralight backpackers - while this is a sturdy, well constructed and well designed set, it is not ultralight like titanium.  Which, of course, is the trade off for the reasonable price.However, for the average camper, kayaker and backpacker, this is a GREAT set if you are not counting ounces with your gear.  Don't get me wrong, its not heavy by any means, its just not what can be classified as ultralight!BTW, I'm married to a hardcore, ultralight guy who cuts the end off his toothbrush and weighs EVERYTHING that goes in his pack to cut as much weight out of his gear as possible!  Seriously, he can survive in the wilderness for 2 weeks carrying a NINE POUND PACK which includes his food!!!So take a look at the video to actually see this stove set "in person" so you can get a good idea of the function and quality :)We have already used this for 2 weekend adventures and really love it and for sure can recommend this set!Hope this was helpful info :)Enjoy!

This is just what I was looking for to keep in the car for our weekend adventures to keep the iPad charged for photo processing while hubby drives :)We also charged the camera and an electric shaver with this.I like the compact design and the way it fits in our 2009 RAV4 console making it easy to access without getting in the way too much.This replaced a unit that was twice the size and bulky!Now that I've had a chance to test this out, I'm ordering a few for Christmas gifts for all of our tech-loving family!  I asked and nobody has one of these!I think for the price, the quality and function is great.  I like how this type of technology is getting smaller, more efficient and less expensive!We were able to buy this through a promotional discount to test out and give an honest opinion and feedback and, after trying this out, give it a thumbs up!Hope this was helpful :)Happy charging!

I had been reading about Phytoceramides for a while and finally got a chance to try it.  I have SUPER dry and sensitive skin and just can't get enough moisture externally so I thought this may help.Well, it has only been a couple of weeks and it sure seems my skin is less dry.  It actually feels more "plump" if that makes sense.I already take grape seed extract which is also good for skin but this seems to have given my skin an extra boost toward helping to retain moisture and even out the texture.  I firmly believe that your skin is only as good as the fuel and nutrients your body gets so this is a great addition to what I was already doing!The price is reasonable for the quality of the product and this is something I will be sticking with.  I will update the review if I see anything dramatic - like suddenly I get carded when I buy wine or something ;)I received a promotional price on this product to test out and give my honest opinion and feedback :)

Wow!  This is the real deal for a quality charger for our 2012 macbook pro!  Just in time too as our cord was about to give out right at the weakest point where it attaches to the computer.This appears to be the same exact cord as what came with our computer and I've been using it steadily for the past week or so and it is all systems go!Hopefully this outlives the computer!We received this at a promo price to test out and give an honest opinion and feedback :)I can for sure recommend this as a cost effective alternative to buying right from Apple!Hope this was helpful info!

I use ice packs on my worn out knees all the time and had yet to find a practical ice solution until I got this!  The shape is PERFECT to fit the knee and the strap holds the pack in place quite well.  Of course, you prolly don't want to run around the block with this attached to your knee, but it stays put!The gel, I have found, is really best for cold therapy as it stays cold for just the right amount of time that you should keep on - about 20-30 minutes.I have not tried to heat it yet since I mostly use just cold therapy but it looks like the seams are made well and would hold up to the microwave.  You never want to overhead these!  They will burst!I'm really happy with the design and quality of this knee wrap and have proven to be the best solution to ice therapy!  I'm actually buying another one so I can ice both knees at the same time :)I was able to try this pack at a promo price to test out and give my honest opinion and feedback and I can for sure give this 2 thumbs up!!!

We have a barn for our goats that has no electricity in it so I came across these lights to try as a source of light inside the barn!  Unlike solar, they can be used inside though they do require batteries.The nice thing about these is that they are motion activated so they will only come on when I walk into the barn which saves battery life.  They are very bright which surprised me!  I was able to use only one instead of both in one end of the barn and one at the other end which gives me plenty of light to see by.They seem to be pretty well made though there are other options of different brands for quite a bit more than these but they are heavier construction.  These were easy to mount using the provided hardware and the light comes off the mount when you need to change batteries which is nice.So far, they are working great!  Time will tell if they last but I will update if there is a problem.I've tipped these up enough to where the goats don't set them off all night and so they come on only when I'm out there.I'm actually going to order another set for inside our garage and shed!For the price, this is a good option if you need to light up an area and can't use solar lights :)We even were able to get a promo price on these to try them out and give our honest opinion and feedback but I would have paid full price for them as I think they are fairly priced for what you get :)Hope this was helpful info :)Enjoy!

I have purchased many items from this company and have been thrilled with every product!  This coconut oil is no exception...From the packaging to the customer support, this oil is far superior to other coconut oil I have purchased.We use this for so many different things from massage oil, carrier oil for essential oils to an additive for all of our lotions so this large, 16 oz size is wonderful!I even had a chance to buy this at a promo price so I could try it and share my honest opinion and feedback :)If you look at all the many options available for coconut oil, this brand really shines because of the quality and value.They have a customer for life :)

I have used HA for a couple of years and love it.  My skin is VERY dry and very sensitive so I have to be careful with products.With the first application, I could tell this is very different from the standard HA that I've used before.This is thicker and MUCH more hydrating!  I'm not sure how they make this, but it is BY FAR superior to the basic HA serum that's available out there.It takes just a small amount to do the job and you can immediately feel the moisture being drawn into your skin.  It even passed the fussy skin test and doesn't burn or cause flaking.I'm SO glad I found this brand!  Actually, I would have never known about this brand expect I was offered a promotional price to try this and give my honest opinion and feedback!  Yeah :)I will never used regular Hyaluronic Acid again...this is far superior and VERY reasonable price.Hope this was helpful :)Enjoy!
Convenient, as safe as can be for all ages, and delicious in Black Currant flavor.

Five stars for its genre.The ensemble cast gets better with every episode.Police work, by itself, can get pretty formulaic. What distinguishes this from shows like CSI, is the attention to character development and the myriad ways the cast members interact.No matter how compelling a story line, if I don't care about the people it ends up falling flat. These likable characters learn, change and grow. To me, that's truly fascinating, deep, and worth watching.

It's always a joy when something fairly straight forward like a slider top bag works. Because it's such a common product it's easy to take the design for granted. I used to think there was no difference in zip lock or slider lock bags like this, but there is. Slider top bags seem to work more reliably than zip lock bags. These are made of heavier plastic and will open and close perfectly time after time. If you use them for traveling, especially with a wet item like a swimsuit, this is no small feat. Ditto, if you are storing anything perishable and moist, like dried fruit.

This was quite quick and easy to assemble. In addition, it is fairly simple to change from the motorized brush head to the one for floors. That said, I am a bit lazy when it comes to doing things like that on a regular basis, so I would leave it in the mode I use most. You can also quickly separate the hand vac. All a big bother, as far as I can tell. However, if you live in an apartment and want the benefits of all three in one handy vacuum, this was designed for you.The bare floor attachment worked brilliantly, and this is what I was most interested in. It neatly dispatched any dirt from the tightest corners, far better than any other vacuum or soft mop I have ever used.As much as I love that feature, the vacuum is not light, so carrying it while you vacuum gives you an extra work-out. Fine for small jobs, but a bit cumbersome if you are doing a larger area.One minor design flaw is that the end of the plug does not fit the wrapped up cord, so when you are ready to store it the cord dangles. Silly.

I like this intermediate practice, but:The breath cuing is really disruptive for me as I take three breaths for the five they instruct you through.It feels like a rush, and I don't just mean the sun salutations. Savanna felt rushed, meditation felt rushed.The music is both very cheerful and intense; so, it's fun, but adds to that rushed feeling.I am a fan of Sharon and David and their beautiful messages. I just wish there had been no breath cues, and the pace had allowed for more time in some of the asanas.

The appearance is sleek and the colors appealing, but it doesn't keep water cold for 24 hours, even with a few ice cubes.Having a screw top means you need two hands to open it, which is not useful when driving or engaging in sports.
Incredibly well-written, organized, and researched, this book provides a treasure trove of information on trauma, it's history, sociological issues surrounding it, and treatment.

This product feels good on my skin, leaves no residue, and has a lovely small applicator tip I enjoy using as it allows me to get the exact amount I want. I trust the brand and have been using their sunscreen #45 for many years, an excellent product.Redermic day and night cream seems very good; however, I am not sure it's worth the price. I typically buy L'Oreal Brightening for day and Olay total effects for night time. I like this cream a lot. If it were less expensive I would give it four stars.Did I see any amazing results? Of course, not. No cream will erase six decades of life. My criteria are: is it smooth, does it go on easily, is it moisturizing? This product scores three out of three. My rating has more to do with the price and lofty claims.

I am a big fan of Rolf Gates' first book, MEDITATIONS FROM THE MAT.This is a different animal. More autobiographical.I like it, but don't love it. The tone feels different from "Meditations." But, perhaps, it is that I am different.I read that book after only practicing yoga for a few years. Now, in my 15th year of daily practice, after reading dozens of books on yoga, I realize I might not be the target audience for this book.I would give it four stars for someone who is in their early years of practice and three for a very experienced yogi. Of course, if you are simply curious about Rolf you might give it five stars.

I love the delivery system of this concealer. Just like a lipstick, it swivels up and is incredibly easy to apply.The texture is creamy, and the coverage is quite good. You may need a couple of applications, depending on what you are trying to conceal.Opal, the color I received, was a tad darker than I might have thought it would be based on their scale from light to dark. In spite of that discrepancy, it still blended with my skin tone and looked very natural.

I have tried gluten free mixes before and have not been happy with the results. This flour is different.I made a Peanut Chocolate Fudge Pudding Cake in my small slow cooker with it and it was just fabulous. (See recipe below.)There was no weird taste, nothing metallic, and no digestive issues, all things I have experienced in the past with gluten free baking mixes.In addition to the recipe below, I also made a basic cornbread in my mini-slow cooker and it came out perfectly.I would definitely use this again.Peanut Chocolate Fudge Pudding Cake Recipe4 servings.Lightly grease a 1 1/2 quart, small, slow cooker insert. Plug in and heat on high while assembling the recipe.In a small bowl mix:1/2 cup Bon Dea Gluten Free All Purpose Flour1 TBSP cocoa1 tsp. baking powderdash of sea salt2 TBSP sugarMix to combine.Add:1/2 tsp vanilla1 TBSP extra virgin olive oil or melted butter1/4 cup milk, any kind1/4 cup peanut butterMix to make a thick batter. (You may add a few TBSP of chocolate chips, I used Ghirardelli Milk Chocolate chips. You could also add a few TBSP of chopped nuts.)In a Pyrex measuring cup mix:3/4 cup boiling water2 TBSP cocoa powder1/4 cup sugar (I used real maple syrup)Put batter in bottom of crock pot, no need to level the surface. Pour liquid over batter.Cover and cook on HIGH for about 1 1/2 hours, or until a tester inserted near the center comes out fairly clean, with a few crumbs.This is very rich, so a little goes a long way. I served it warm with vanilla ice cream.

I have been using a Bose Wave Radio for many years and it has always provided me with great, reliable sound whether with a CD, radio, or through my ipod.This newest model is a bit more streamlined, takes up the same amount of space, and has no visible buttons. The remote is intuitive and easy to set up and navigate.I hooked up my ipod with a 3.5 male to male cable and it worked beautifully.The sound quality, whether listening to Janos Starker on cello, Mozart, Kirtan (yoga chants), Enya, harpsichord, synthesizer, or spoken word, was rich, full-bodied, layered, and balanced. Regardless of whether the decibel level was low or high, though the high range was fantastic.As they instructed, I placed the system a couple of feet from the wall, not in a corner. It filled the room evenly and fully.You might think this is a lot of money for "a radio," but it is far more than a radio, and may outlast you. Once you get used to the great sound other less expensive offerings sound thin, tinny, and electronic.If you are looking for something that will sound just as good 15 years after you bought it, I would recommend a Bose radio. I thought my first one was a fortune, but if I reflect on how many thousands of times I have enjoyed listening to it, and the pennies it cost me a day, it has been fully amortized.
Very drying.

I was very happy with the first part this series on conscious aging and the last few sections with questions from the audience. The other two thirds were fine, but less interesting to me as I found them more generic. Of course, generic Buddhism is still pretty great.These days, you can listen to fabulous free podcasts on iTunes by Tara Brach, Jonathan Foust, and others. You can borrow books and CDs by Pema Chodron from the library. In general, there is a plethora of wonderful Buddhist material to enjoy.This audio program was recorded years ago when there were fewer options.

I was a little dubious that these would be good after reading some of the reviews, but they worked well for me.Triple blades make cutting yourself less likely and seem to give a smoother shave.The colors are cheerful, and the price reasonable.I have tried other disposable razors and was disappointed.

This is one of my absolute favorite yoga nidra cds. Maalika's beautiful, soothing, hypnotic voice can truly transport you away from your thoughts into a realm of peace. It's also superb if you ever have insomnia.I also recommend Swami Janakanada's CD, and the free yoga nidra program from Elsie's yoga podcast on iTunes, episode #62.This is very powerful stuff and works cumulatively to restore your nervous system.Also immensely helpful for post-traumatic stress.(You can find a plethora of free help on "holistic divorce counseling dot com." Despite the name, it is for all life's issues and transitions, not just the cosmic hazing of divorce.)
Excellent product for a great price.

I would love this lipstick if it lasted. I put it on and without eating or drinking it barely lasted two hours.The color is great, a gentler red with a little pink in it. I liked the sparkle; just the right amount: subtle, not frosted.The scent is very light and neutral.If only it were long-wearing.

This is an excellent fermented product with benefits from probiotics and immunity boosting mushrooms.Personally, I like eating my fermented foods and mushrooms as a normal part of my day, but if you are a smoothie or juice lover this is a great addition to your healthy regimen. I also tried it plain with water. The flavor was citrusy and pleasant, though it didn't fully dissolve.I was happy to see that the use by date is 2017. This is especially helpful if you supplement for flare-ups from auto-immune issues.One more thing: SoTru's powder is very portable. Traveling with mushrooms, yogurt, and kefir can be a bit cumbersome.

I have been using this lipstick for quite a while and find it lasts well, though certainly not 14 hours.The color is not dark or light, more medium. The first application of the day is lighter than any subsequent ones. Perhaps, that' s because I am applying it on top of whatever residual layer is still there. If that happens, you can just use it once and apply a tinted gloss as it wears off during the day to freshen up.It does not dry out my lips, but I would not call it moisturizing.For some reason, this color is hard to find in stores and online.

One small application of this foot cream and I noticed a big difference. It is far better than anything else I have tried, even the creams with urea, and it doesn't leave a strange coating on my heels.The scent is barely noticeable, and smelled fresh.Yes, it may have Triclosan in it, as another reviewer pointed out, but it is far from the first ingredient on the list (which usually means there is only a tiny bit), and I will not need to use this frequently because it's so phenomenal.A really small amount, about 1/8 teaspoonful, was all I needed for each foot. With occasional use I might need even less. That also makes the price more reasonable.

Bose SoundTouch 10 is an excellent system that enables you to have music, podcasts, and audiobooks available at the press of a button in any room with wifi.The sleek black design is compatible with almost all decors, and is small enough to hide in a corner.You can access your content via preset buttons on the top of the device or by using the remote.Set up was easy at first and then got complicated because my PC was connected to the internet both through wifi and cable. Clearly, the cable was unnecessary, but I didn't know that. You only need one connection. I initially set up the system through my ipad air which was intuitive and only took about 10-15 minutes. The reason I had to contact customer support was I wanted to sync my iTunes library to the Bose SoundTouch. The person I spoke with was patient, knowledgeable, and solved the problem. (And, waiting for tech support only took about a minute.)I tried the sound qulaity with both classical music and PBS news. The music sounded resonant and rich and had plenty of volume. The speech was clear and easy to understand.NOTE: Day two. Apparently, my iTunes library is so vast (17,000 items) that it was hard to keep it synched with the Bose system. I could have synched it through Bluetooth, but that meant having to remember to Bluetooth on and off via my desktop, and I use the sound on that all the time; so, it wasn't a viable option. Another idea would be to spend $80 for a NAS drive but that didn't appeal to me, either. I will buy the 3.5mm male to male cable so I can attach my ipod directly to the speaker. It will do the trick, but is not the seamless experience I was hoping for.I can still listen to radio stations from around the world, i Heart Radio, Pandora, and anything that's downloaded through iTunes on my ipad.This is a great product if you use it with Bluetooth, or don't have an extensive iTunes library to sync.I hope to have it as long as I have had my Bose radio, which is more years than I can remember.

As someone who usually gravitates towards black, red, and brown rice, I was happily surprised to make and taste this white version. All the positive reviews were warranted. It cooks up beautifully with each grain intact, slightly chewy, and great for everything from fried rice to paella.I used my small Aroma rice cooker (a great deal on Amazon, btw) and it was done in a flash.

I like the mix of menthol, eucalyptus, camphor, lavender, and chamomile, though the predominant scent is definitely menthol. It is a gentle vapor in that the fragrance is not overwhelming. For my own purposes I would prefer a stronger version; however, for a child this would be lovely.The night light is activated by darkness and is a soothing blue color. You can also use this as a night light without the insert.The unit itself is nice looking and easy to use. Just be careful you don't touch the pad with your fingers as these oils can be irritating to skin and eyes (if you then brought your hand to your face).

In the past, I would move my USB cable from the outlet for charging to the computer for synching my devices. A small nuisance, but no big deal. Having this extra cable gives me the luxury of skipping that extra step, and it works just as it should.

The mixed scents of grapefruit, vetiver, star anise, lemon, orange, and clove make this wonderful for both men and women.I was concerned that this coffee bean scrub would be harsh on my skin, but it wasn't. The creamy base carried just enough ground coffee beans to exfoliate without feeling like sandpaper.Another plus was how easily this washed off.Thrive's scrub left my skin feeling smooth and refreshed.

This patchwork of remembrances, overheard pithy bits of conversations, friendships (both deeply connected and only tangentially), introspection, and musings is not going to be for everyone.  If you appreciate the literary, quotidian, poetic, and banal this could be your cup of tea.It's revealing without being confessional, quite a feat.
These look great and I love the design, but they are at least a half size smaller than they say. Maybe even a full size.

Yes, I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this book, and learned from it. Why? Because of some unfounded idea that a celebrity would write something vapid. Boy, was I wrong.This is not only a brutally honest memoir, but an excellent yoga sequencing book.My only suggestions would be to make it smaller, use less shiny paper, and add a spiral binding. Currently, it's a very large, heavy, unwieldy book with glossy pages that are hard on the eyes.

While I have used this on and off for years, and consider it very useful, it is not my favorite. Why? Because the ones I generally prefer have a warmer tone.They are: the free yoga nidra from Elsie's Yoga podcast, episode # 62, Amy Weintraub's Yoga  Nidra download on Amazon, and Swami Janakananda's CD because it's so authentic and different. There have been times when I liked Richard Miller's Yoga Nidra, too.

I have mixed feelings about using plastic cups, but there are times when it simply makes sense.For those few occasions I do not worry about the possible chemicals, as I am use them so infrequently.These are a good weight, hold 16 ounces, and I prefer them clear. Somehow, the red ones always feel more plasticky to me.

Five stars if it was made well. Two stars for now it's actually made these days.I sent back the last one. They replaced it, but this one only lasted two years.When they make one like the old ones I will be delighted.Fabulous time saver, but not reliable quality.Just bought another one of these because the last one that I had for a couple of years broke. Actually, the push lever broke off. I must confess, I use it at least once a day. So, 800+ cups of tea with no problem. Still, I don't like taking up land fill space and wished it had lasted longer.I was naturally skeptical of buying the same model, but I really love the convenience. The one I just received works perfectly.

I really vacillate on my opinion of this book. I read the five star reviews and the one star reviews and I veer more towards the latter. Very few people have the means to sell one house, completely renovate the other, and live without a steady income.Yet, there is something to be gained from reading this. We all know love hurts, getting fired hurts, and having your semi-adult children leave home hurts. Still, if we want to understand how our deeper connection to each other transcends money and privilege, this book can help.The writing is good, and just because she knows where her next meal is coming from doesn't make her story less human or touching.The only really annoying thing to me was the ridiculously unhealthy diet her doctor prescribed.

I like the scent, my clothes seem very clean, and it's certainly easy to just throw one of these pods into your wash before you put in the laundry. That said, they are not cheap. I can buy the liquid detergent on sale at my local drugstore for under two dollars for 32 washes. Are they comparable? I am not sure. My clothes don't get especially dirty. If I were washing clothes for a very active young family I might be able to really test this detergent against its cheaper rivals.

Some reviewers have noted this size bottle does not have a scent. The one I just received, 8-18-2015, is definitely scented. It rates on my scale as a very light slightly flowery aroma, and it didn't linger after my shower.I used it as directed, but did not wait to air dry. My skin feels soft. Comparable to a very good moisturizing lotion.It is a different routine from what I am used to, but I think it's actually faster than putting lotion on.Aside from the speed factor, it seems to be made with mostly natural ingredients; so, if that appeals to you it would be a good choice.
I agree with all the other reviewers about the scent of this conditioner. It left my hair very soft but it didn't seem to add a lot of body.Adding a styling product would fix that issue.

Not particularly crunchy and not much flavor. I guess the two stars are for the idea. Unfortunately, their execution of it left me unimpressed.The date was best by February 8th, 2016, so they weren't technically stale. Just not as crunchy as a regular pretzel.
I thought this sounded good, but it's not for me. Smells like something a Victorian lady would have loved.

I have no idea why this scent is so much more expensive than their others, but if you want a treat and use bar soap I recommend it.If you are happy with liquid body wash you can get a better deal for the same scent.
This is a very calming CD. Pleasant, easy to listen to, and soothing.
I keep wanting to drink the whole bottle it tastes soooooo good. Great Price too from Amazon! Can't wait for the next box.

I must say that this slightly edges out the recent Mark Wilder CD/Digital re master it's that good! The 200 Gram pressing is stellar, a true 'reference' album. Kudo's to Bernie Grundman on his Mastering. Nice Full sound and I actually can say that I'm listening to the master tape! Expensive but worth the money if you really dig this album!

German Box put out in 1980 containing all the Stones Decca era LP's and some German Lp's like 'Around And Around' which was a German compilation of their first singles and ep's. Sorta like the US's Decembers Children and 12X5. Comes with Frameable Glossy photo's of all five Stones and a booklet. No Covers on this box, just inserts. Record quality is Excellent, pressings are nice and quiet and the sound is right up there with the UK pressings. All in all, a nice way to pick up the early catalog if you can find it at a good price.

This is from a BBC produced 3 hour radio show, one of the first times rare BBC Beatles songs were ever played.As a 'radio show' it works very well, with interviews and a cohesiveness that's sorely missing in Apple's BBC issues. It alsoincludes some songs that weren't on the Official Apple BBC sets, like from their very first Radio show, Roy Orbison's 'Dream Baby'.Quality is very rough on that one, but it's nice they included it into this Radio show and it's very listenable. The majority of the rest ofthe songs are in Fantastic Sound Quality. And this was way before Digital mastering came really into play, so this is an All Analogue MasteredLp Set/Box. All in all, a great Sunday Morning listen. Well done to the BBC.This should have been released to the general public instead of the Apple issues, but at least a few of the Radio LP's still exist.Gerard Masters

Just put this turntable into service today. First album played: Miles 'Kind Of Blue'. I upgraded the stock cartridge to an Audio Technica AT100E. Excellent Sound! Not going to win any 'High End' turntable awards but for what it is it is well made, at least the one I got. I'm reading a few reviews from people who got a bad unit-motor/speed problems is the common culprit. Denon NEEDS to step up on this and not give people the run around.  My advice is this: when you get the turntable, play the heck out of it. The best way would be to lift the cueing lever up but without moving the tonearm over the middle of the platter, just move it enough to start the platter turning, and then leave it run for 3 days non stop-if the motor or belt is flaking out this should force it to do it within the return period. Again, do not hesitate to send it back to Amazon if it flakes out on you, that is why Amazon continues to be my favorite retailer.The Aluminum Platter is flat and machined perfectly-no wobble at all. This was not the case on the AT120 I bought 5 years ago where the platter actually wobbles back and forth while spinning. The Heavy Rubber Mat gives it some heft. Stock belt is serviceable but lightweight, installed an upgraded belt from LP Gear for $18 and the Platter spins with no audible flutter or noise. The  Auto function is incredibly smooth, much more than I would have expected from this price range. Very impressive. Also the torque of the motor is impressive, when I put the Discwasher on the record I did not detect much slow down from the motor! Almost felt like a direct drive. And the tonearm is very expensive looking, although, the 'finger' arch could be longer. Counterweight is impressive looking with gold type color. But the sound right out of the box is in line with my classic Pioneer PL 518, a nice feat! So for anybody looking to jump in, this is the sonic equivalent to the mid Music Hall decks like the 5.1 I had. And that thing costs me $875. But of course it's build quality was more substantial than the Denon. But all in all, a nice Budget deck, update the cart and your good to go.Oh, and I also put a drop of High Quality oil on the motor's top bearing and on the bottom of the platter spindle.Enjoy!gerard mastersJune 2015 update:Tonight I pulled the Denon out of the rack and put it on my test bench. I wanted to see what's inside. After opening the bottom plate I found a very well manufactured piece of gear here. The layout of the inside part of the turntable, which you don't see unless your a technician, is on par with the Japanese manufacturing practices of the 1980's and 1990's. In fact, comparing the Quality of this Denon TT against the $700 Pioneer PLX1000, well, this just blows that deck away. Here we have a professionally looking turntable, with parts nicely soldered, wires nicely 'dressed' and all the moving parts lubed and locked with locking glue (blue that is). I'll say it again, the construction quality of this $349 turntable BLOWS AWAY THE CONSTRUCTION QUALITY OF THE PIONEER PLX1000.With that said, I will stand by my original review. If you do as I say and run the unit for three or more days, the motor, if it is defective should give out, in which case you pack it up and send it back to Amazon as defective. BUT......I have to tell you that I got a good unit and it is in every way a high quality turntable. In fact, looking closely at the tone arm, both on top and underneath with the bottom plate removed, I would have to say that in order to get a higher quality tonearm you would have to spend over $1000.00 on a Pro-Ject or Rega TT. Denon, although budget, really did a great job on this turntable. But......if you REALLY want to go nuts, then buy the Audio Technica AT100E and replace the stock cartridge, even though it's very good, the 100E will bring you very close to 'AUDIOPHILE HEAVEN' on vinyl........now, back to our regularly scheduled programming.gerard masters

This Vinyl 3 LP Very Limited Edition (it was only made available at Best Buy Stores, no one else had it!) Album is the way to hear this show. Warm Full sounding analog record and the performances are great. It's so cool to hear some of the stories behind the songs. Highly Recommended, if you can find a copy, snag it! The vinyl version isn't even listed on EJ's website that's how rare this issue is!!gerard masters

Another Video momento of the Worlds Greatest Rock And Roll Band!4 dvd's worth of magical moments!!Highly recommended along with 'Sweet Summer Sun' from last years tour!gerard masters

Ah, Japanese One Run Pressing on SHM-CD! Sounds Stunning and the packaging is THE WAY THE BEATLES SHOULD BE PRESENTED!!!! Get one while their still under $100 because I have a feeling they'll rise in price pretty quickly.And here is an opinion from the Steve Hoffman Forums, it says it all:"I received today the White Album. The sounds is unveiled in a new light, without any shadows or fatigue, the music flows in a sweet constant attack: superior dynamics. For me the revelation is the bass, the bass...wow! I will get the rest of the set if I am lucky. Abbey Road showed me some clues, now this is the confirmation: is a different game".gerard masters

What a Magnificent Collection of the Real Who's albums. Long out of print but worth the hunt because these German Vinyl Pressings are Stellar! And the Analog Tapes were a lot 'fresher' than they are now. And the newer box pads out with two 'studio' Who albums: 'Endless Wire' and another one I don't even know the name of, but that's the Point! Those albums are Pete and Roger albums, they are not the Who in my opinion. So you get what you pay for, for me, I'll take this 1981 box with all the Original Who albums over the newer box anyday.gerard masters
A very High Quality Sounding PD collection of the Earl! Can't beat the value and You get hours and hours of great Jazz!Highly Recommended!gerard masters

Febuary 2015 and These SHM-CD'S of the Entire Beatles Stereo Catalog have sold out in Japan and there is no talk of a second pressing. Comments on the internet Beatles Forums Have it split: Some people claim to hear a real/Better fidelity difference compared to the 2009 cd's, and others say they sound the same. Packaging is what the 2009's should have been. They are beautiful and to these ears Do sound more cohesive/clearer soundstage than the Domestic Ones. But YMMV. As a Beatles collectable though, these can't be beat. They probably will go up in value as these just seem to be a 'one off' Pressing in Japan Only.gerard masters

Well I got this Yammy yesterday and popped it into my system to check it out and see what it does.I like another reviewer bought this mainly as an Universal 'Audio' player for SACD's.One surprise is that, although there is only ONE reference to it in the manual, It plays AND decodes HDCD's!Yes that's right, HDCD's. I don't know why Yamaha downplays this but it's a HUGE plus to us who have and really like the sound of HDCD'S.It loads discs quickly, very quickly in fact and that includes BluRay discs.It's not going to win any construction awards-it's light but solid-typical mass market china manufactured product, but I didn't expect anything more to tell you the truth, not for $219, which is how much I paid for a 'refurbished' one from A4Less.Like every thing I get electronic from china I popped the cover to see if all the screws inside were torqued properly, they were, which is unusual but nice to see. The circuit board construction is top notch, the disc transport on the other hand is definitely low budget, but in operation it does it's job silently and smoothly, again, even the budget stuff nowadays seems to operate like the premium gear from years past. How long will it last?? who knows, but for what it is and what it does, for a little over $200 it is good value and it sounds really really incredible.The remote is laid out well but really feels cheap, which again, it is. You do have to push the buttons firmly or it doesn't respond to commands.It does have a Texas Instruments 32 bit DAC, Be AWARE though that there is an older model WITH THE SAME MODEL NUMBER that used a 24 bit DAC. Yamaha's site doesn't help matters because if you do a google search for 'yamaha BD-S667BL the yamaha site it goes to is the older model, and on that site it say's that it's a 'Discontinued' model. How stupid Yamaha, really? This unit I got was manufactured in 2014-it tells you on the back panel-so I'm sure this is the 'newer' model.Now if you go to the yamaha.usa site and from their home page go to the blu ray players it's there that this newer 32 Bit model shows up.Laser speed is almost instant. On the Beach Boys 'Smiley Smile' cd, I went from track 1 to the last track, 28 in a fraction of a second.So a good solid unit that is not the most sturdy construction wise, but for the money it plays well with a number of different discs, plays HDCD'S and sounds excellent thanks to the Texas Instruments 32 Bit DAC. And I'm listening to Dave Brubecks 'Time Out' right now, the sound quality is stellar! One of the best sounding CD spinners I've heard, and I'm being serious when I say that.gerard masters
Mediocre. Could have been better but the flow just wasn't there.gerard masters

What is this you say???? Well it seems like it's all the Public domain tracks from 63 that slipped through the copyright thingy in England. But the logical running order and fidelity of even the before booted tracks make this a grand LP to slip on yo turntable and listen to. Even if it's not totally legit, it's a very nice vinyl addition to the early Stones catalog. Play the heck out of it, I am!Gerard Masters

Jason Bovberg, Draw Blood (Permuted Press, 2015)full disclosure: an ARC of this book was provided to me free of charge by the author. As this review is based on an ARC, minor details may be different between the copy I reviewed and the final release version.Jason Bovberg knows how to do this sequel thing. The middle book of a trilogy tends to be a quagmire for authors (just look at Tolkein, Lewis, and Hobb), but with Draw Blood, Bovberg found himself a perfect angle to play, and he played it well indeed.SPOILER ALERT: The synopsis necessarily contains spoilers for Blood Red. If you have not read that one yet and are planning to, skip the next paragraph.Draw Blood opens mere moments after Blood Red ends, which will not surprise anyone who's read Blood Red; it ends in such a way as to make that a given. But Bovberg switches points of view for the second book; we see this one through the eyes of Rachel's father, Michael, with the book starting as he wakes up from the coma he was in during the parts of Blood Red in which he appeared. This allows Bovberg to write from something of an unique* place here; he has the perfect excuse for the ‚Äúas you know, Bob‚Äù moments that are so annoying in many books. That said, he also manages to make them far more intelligent than usual. Michael is not a stupid guy. He puts things together quickly, and this does not seem out of place to us, since we already know stuff. We get to see the same characters, and a few interesting new ones, through Michael's eyes. There's also the possibility for post-apocalyptic romance; once Michael discovers the results of Rachel's first trip home, he rebounds pretty hard with (the obvious character, but I won't spoil it). I thought that would ring false. It didn't. But all of this is side material, really. The two main plot threads deal with (a) the continuing threat of the aliens and the possessed, and (b) the effects of the new information Rachel gleaned in one of Blood Red's last sequences‚Äîthat after injecting her ex-boyfriend with O-neg, he regained enough of himself to recognize Rachel and say her name. Can the possessed be saved? And even if they can, has the possession done too much damage to their bodies for them to come back without going insane immediately?It's all very good stuff, and if it's been done before in this way, I haven't seen it. There's not a great deal to say about either the technical aspects or the overarching plot that I didn't say in my Blood Red review, save that the plot unrolls at about the same pace here as it did there. The book is episodic, but I rush to add that this is not a knock against it; because of the structure and the events therein, it wouldn't really be possible to present a lot of this any other way. Interesting characters doing interesting things, with a solid hook and the continuation of a premise that combines the best things about the Autumn series, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, and Night of the Living Dead in one (surprisingly, given that comparison) coherent tale. If you liked Blood Red, Draw Blood will definitely not let you down. *** Ω* Yes, I know that is‚Äîsupposedly‚Äîincorrect. I am taking the position that at least in this instance, I know better than both Strunk and White.

Exactly what you think it's going to be. Antiviral (Brandon Cronenberg, 2012)The whole time I was watching Antiviral, the debut film from Brandon Cronenberg‚Äîif the last name sounds familiar, it's because Brandon is the son of revered Canadian filmmaker David Cronenberg‚ÄîI was thoroughly enchanted with it. I kept having to remind myself that, yes, the movie does have some shortcomings, and they kept it from rating higher than it did. But the movie's immense style made me want to gloss those shortcomings over. This is definitely a case of form over function, and in that, early Brandon is on the same track as early David was‚Äîand by ‚Äúearly‚Äù with David Cronenberg I'm talking about his earliest features, 1969's Stereo and 1970's Crimes of the Future, rather than the ‚Äúearly‚Äù stuff everyone's seen (Shivers, Rabid, and The Brood, by the last of which Cronenberg had already, as far as I'm concerned, reached the heights of body-horror greatness he would plumb until 1999's eXistenZ). When it comes right down to it, you're going to want to say you knew him when.Plot: Syd March (No Country for Old Men's Caleb Landry Jones) works for a near-future company that specializes in a new form of celebrity-worship; they harvest diseases from celebrities, culture them, and infect paying clients with the same strain of the same disease their heroes have. In any case, supermodel Hannah Geist (Dracula Untold's Sarah Gadon) is rumored to have a brand new disease that no one has ever seen before, and Syd's company is desperate to get their hands on some of it. Syd is on the case‚Äînot only because he's good at his job, but because, unknown to his company, he is obsessed with Hannah.Brandon does things the same way Dad does‚Äîbuild the characters well enough so that no matter how weird the situations, things remain somewhat plausible. Where Brandon differs is that it was pretty rare to find a pre-Spider Cronenberg film that seemed in any way realistic. In the days of ubiquitous reality TV and websites devoted to celebrity gossip seeing millions of hits per day, Brandon's near-future vision seems all too realistic. While there's an obvious body-horror aspect to what goes on here, this is more a movie about atmosphere, tension, and paranoia than it is about gross-out special effects, and it benefits tremendously from this. An tiviral is a touch unformed and maybe could've used one more rewrite to tighten up the plot, but it's stylish, creepy, and excels at portions of the filmmaker's craft that many journeymen have never mastered; a very good debut from a promising filmmaker. Can't wait to see what he does next. *** ¬Ω

Comforting Skin (Derek Franson, 2011)The first half-hour or thereabouts of Comforting Skin is annoying in the extreme. It feels like it's going to be just another mumblecore movie (not even a mumblegore movie because, you know, no violence). You know the drill. Annoying characters you can't stand doing things they couldn't afford in the real world without anything much really going on around them. And then Koffie (Good Luck Chuck's Victoria Bidewell), our main character, gets her tattoo. And everything changes.At the beginning, Koffie, co-worker Synthia (MVP: Most Valuable Primate's Jane Sowerby), and best-friend-who-Koffie-kind-of-wants-to-date-but-not-really Nathan (Road to Nowhere's Tygh Runyan) are exactly those people you loathe in the movies. Koffie and Synthia drink at the restaurant they both hate working at (they keep working there because, presumably, they can drink free‚Äîthey certainly can't afford the amount of alcohol they consume on tips), have endless conversations about life, try to decide whether Nathan's hot or not, discuss Synthia's parade of sugar daddies, you get the idea. Those of you who give up on the movie and turn it off during this section are missing out, though. Koffie, feeling insecure, gets a tattoo because she thinks it'll make her look sexy/mysterious/more attractive. And then it starts whispering to her.NOTE: the rest of this review will reveal, and then talk about, the major spoiler for the film. While you may well have guessed it from the brief synopsis above, if you are sensitive to that sort of thing and plan on seeing the film (you should), stop reading now.The final hour and change of Comforting Skin is as perfect a depiction of Koffie's descent into delusional anxiety and depression as one could ask for. I speak from experience; I was in the exact place Koffie ends up in the climax of this film a little less than seven months ago. So when I tell you that Franson (who also wrote) knows his stuff, well, it's fresh in my mind, delusions and all. The longer that section of the movie went, the more I could identify with her. While it doesn't allow me to excuse how shallow and horrible a person Koffie is during the first half-hour of the movie, it makes it a little more understandable, and you can put the first bit down to debut-film jitters. Especially since the rest of the movie belies the first part by making it hard to believe this is a first film. Franson seems to go from not knowing where to put a camera, and certainly having no clue when to cut a scene or to stop with the repetition of a theme, to being the guy who gets pace, tension, and the small, subtle points of perfect movie characterization better than at least half the big-name filmmakers working in Hollywood today. If only any character in Interstellar had been half as complex and realistic as Koffie in the last hour of Comforting Skin, it would have been the great film it thought it was.The dark side of getting it that right is, well, you get it that right. A lot of the last hour of this movie is going to be very awkward to sit through if you're normal. (To be fair, it's just as awkward if you get it, but at least you can vouch for its veracity.) And while I understand where Franson was going in one particular scene‚Äîwithout it being a major spoiler for one character, a lot of people had the same problem with Eric England going there in Contracted, though he knew what he was doing more‚Äîhe may have been setting himself up for a lot of righteous anger from some people who will see that scene as marginalizing. Take it as you will; be warned you might be offended by it. Me, I was riveted to the screen the entire last hour of the film. Your mileage may vary. *** ¬Ω

My Sucky Teen Romance (Emily Hagins, 2011)Despite only giving Emily Hagins' first feature, Pathogen, three stars (but let's remember, three is still ‚Äúabove average‚Äù on a five-star scale), I unhesitatingly recommended it in my review because, well, it's a zombie movie that was made by a twelve-year-old and, aside from having basically no budget and some problems with acting ability, was a clever, fun take on the genre. Hagins returned five years later with her third feature, My Sucky Teen Romance, a teen vampire comedy whose purpose is to make fun of teen vampire comedies. And my favorite thing about it is that in every way, it's obvious Emily Hagins took Pathogen as a learning experience. My Sucky Teen Romance is a much better movie technically, with much more solid acting and a clever script (written by Hagins). In short: if you like your teen comedies with more romance than raunch, My Sucky Teen Romance is for you.Plot: Kate (the gorgeous Elaine Hurt in her screen debut) is a shy teen with a hefty crush on comic-book-store employee Paul (Belleflower's Patrick Delgado). Kate convinces her best friend, society girl Allison (The Retelling's Lauren Lee), to go to a comic convention with her and a couple of nerdy friends, intending to run into Paul. What she doesn't know is that a few days beforehand, Paul was bitten by a vampire (Supernatural Activity's Devin Bonn√©e) and is in the process of changing. She also doesn't know that he feels the same way about her, but when the two of them are about to confess their feelings for one another, they're jostled in a hallway, and Paul's new fangs get jammed into Kate's neck. Which is all well and good, except that (a) they don't want to be vampires and (b) Kate's friends are all about staking the two of them before they turn for good. The two of them frantically try to hunt down the vampire that bit Paul before the process is irreversible.I'm not going to try and convince you that there's any boundary-pushing to be done here or anything like that. This is a genre movie that revels in its genre movie-ness. This is not necessarily a bad thing; after all, a genre movie that delivers on the promises of the genre is a success on most levels you could care to mention. You could probably make the argument that I'm cutting Hagins some slack, and I wouldn't argue with you, but in all fairness, I've probably given more positive reviews to comedies in the past year than I did in the decade before that. Maybe I'm just getting softer in my old age, but I had a very good time with this one. *** ¬Ω

White Dog (Samuel Fuller, 1982)There a number of directors who have become canonical over the years whose films I have simply never gotten. Woody Allen. Mario Bava. Sam Fuller. Every time I dig into a Fuller movie I try and see what it is that sets him apart, and every time I fail. My most recent attempt was with the 1982 racism melodrama White Dog, and I think that perhaps I've figured out what the canon sees in him. I still didn't get to the ‚Äúall that and a bag of racists‚Äù point with this one, but it's starting to make sense. The thing about Sam Fuller's strain of melodrama, if I'm right in my hypothesizing, is that in movies like Shock Corridor and Pickup on South Street, both of which left me kind of cold, Fuller was doing that gig first; Douglas Sirk and Grace Metalious and Russ Meyer and all that lot would come after and hone the genre, so that when Fuller returned to the fold in the eighties, he not only had his own base to work from, he had everyone else's, too. And I think that, more than anything, may be what impressed me about White Dog: Fuller wasn't afraid to build on the work of others, rather than focusing obsessively upon his own corpus.Plot: Julie Sawyer (Little Darlings' Kristy McNichol) finds what she believes to be a stray dog. Very attractive beast, if a little scraggly, so she takes him home, shows him a little TLC, and everything seems great‚Äîuntil all the sudden he attacks someone out of nowhere while she's walking him. Eventually, a pattern of behavior is established, and she comes to realize that he's not called a ‚Äúwhite dog‚Äù because of the color of his coat‚Äîthis is a dog who has been trained to attack black people. Believing that this behavior can be unlearned, she enlists the help of Hollywood animal trainer Keys (Terminator's late, great Paul Winfield) in retraining him. Keys, upon finding out (firsthand) the dog's conditioning, is reluctant to accept the job, but eventually becomes as obsessed as Julie with the idea that racism can be cured.These days, in hindsight, when we think of Kristy McNichol, we think about her memoir and the horrible things that happened to her and, tangentially at best, Empty Nest. She didn't make a huge number of features over the course of her career, and Two Moon Junction was a horrible choice for everyone involved, but if you go back farther than that, McNichol was very good at what she did. Pair her with a guy like Winfield, who could take a dead guy on a table and give a compelling performance, and you've got some bones to hang a movie on. A maudlin movie to be sure, nakedly manipulative and full of the kinds of characters who have all the depth of a Phoenix snowstorm, but every once in a while there are good guys, there are bad guys, and we're not supposed to disagree. Fuller's got himself a ready-made villain‚ÄîI mean, who trains a dog to attack black people?‚Äîand from there, your hero being a black dog trainer is obvious. That their characters have all the shade of a Joshua tree is kind of irrelevant.Not a bad little movie at all; my favorite of the Fullers I've seen by a pretty wide margin. Expect something closer to a disease-of-the-week TV movie than Kurosawa and you'll have a grand time with it. *** ¬Ω

The Evictors (Charles B. Pierce, 1979)There are a whole lot of directors at work in America today who should be sat down‚Äîwith as much force as necessary‚Äîand made to watch The Evictors, which is an excellent example of how to make a stylish, effective thriller on a basement budget. But since that's not going to happen, I can distill what they need to learn from this movie into a single sentence: look backward, not forward. Look, if you dare, at the plague of Asylum pictures and Syfy Original Movies and all that sort of dreck, and one thing you will likely notice is that everyone's waving around CGI like it's a brand-new toy they can't get enough of. It's a very loud, flashy toy, and it annoys the hell out of mom and dad five minutes after the box is opened. Now watch the opening sequence of The Evictors, which is filmed in sepia-tone; the sequence takes place in the thirties, and Pierce was going for that kind of look. It's very well-shot, it's obviously out of place, and it does what it sets out to do. If this movie was made in 2013, that sequence would probably be CGIed to death, and the movie would be the worse for it. This is not to say that The Evictors is a perfect film, not by any stretch of the imagination, but for what it is, it is a very good one.Ben and Ruth Watkins (Kill Bill's Michael Parks and Suspiria's Jessica Harper) are a newly-married couple who get transferred to a little town in the sticks for Ben's job. They're still not rolling in cash, so the local realtor, Jake Rudd (The Bad News Bears' Vic Morrow), shows them a cheap house not far outside of town. You've seen this movie before. As soon as they move in, the townsfolk start treating them oddly, and soon they begin hearing rumors that awful things have happened in that house. With most of the town unwilling to help them, can they figure out what's going on with their erstwhile dream home before they end up being another story the locals tell their kids to keep them from going out at night?A number of reviews I've read of the movie have as their main criticism that it isn't actually a horror movie. Compared to most of today's horror films, especially in America, it's easy to understand why people might raise this as an issue. Even something like the first half of The Descent, which has as its main fear-inducer simple claustrophobia, has a grittier, scarier feel to it than The Evictors. This is much more an exercise in atmosphere, tension, and suspense than it is horror. I do not in any way consider that a bad thing; quite the opposite. This is a horror film for people who appreciate B√®la Tarr and Krzyzstof Kieslowski movies. Better, then, to bring up some wooden acting‚Äîthe more I see of Jessica Harper, the more I wonder why she continued getting roles in movies‚Äîand some set decoration that was kind of silly even for a zero-budget movie. (Just wait till you get a load of the neighbor's sitting room.) Still, despite problems, there is a great deal about The Evictors to like. ***

Ruth F. Boorstin, Love Is Not Because (Lone Oak Press, 1998)Ruth F. Boorstin, the About the Author blurb tells us, was the wife‚Äîand longtime editor‚Äîof Daniel J. Boorstin, a Pulitzer Prize winner, Library of Congress librarian, seller of many, many books. You have likely heard of Daniel Boorstin. Unless you aware aware of the minutiae of his life, you have probably never heard of Ruth. Having now read the horrifying Love Is Not Because, I know why all too well.‚ÄúSo there's too much talk for you?One word is unspokenThe room is too smokefilled [sic] for you?The door is open.Love here is frail enoughCompared to doubtI'll blow a single puffSo‚Äîit is out!‚Äù(‚ÄúDismissal‚Äù, 31; this is the entire poem)I won't swear to it, but I'm relatively sure I remember some of my third-grade classmates turning in better work than this. Four-on-the-floor repetitive message doggerel that probably took about as much thought as the average political speech in the latter half of the twentieth century. This is one hundred sixty pages of some of the worst poetry you will ever read, if you have the misfortune to stumble upon it somewhere; its only redeeming quality is that, for the most part, it is not overtly offensive. Nothing in the book makes me despair as much as the fact that one of the back cover blurbs came from Ray Bradbury. I shed a few tears at that. *

Warren L. G. DeMills, Affections (No press listed, 2012)Had I been planning on giving this any stars, it would have lost them for incomplete information.Vanity-, POD-, and Self-published poetry comes in two flavors, with no middle ground: it's either really, really good or really, really bad. If you are familiar with vanity-published work at all, you are probably not surprised by the idea that 90% of the vanity-published books you will pick up are of the latter flavor. When it comes to poetry‚Äîand I will admit right up from that my criteria for what makes a great poem is far, far stricter than it is for prose‚Äîthat number tends to be closer to 99%. Now, why am I telling you all this? Well, there's the kicker. As I write these words at the end of September 2014, Affections has eight reviews at Amazon. One of them is a three-star review (which to me means ‚Äúlightly recommended‚Äù, since 2.5 is the average). All the rest are either four or five stars. So this has got to be one of the one percent, right?Well, no. Occupy CreateSpace is in full effect. But you don't need to take my word for it. But do yourself a favor and don't commit to the whole thing like I did. A quick perusal of the Look Inside function at Amazon will show you all you need to know. I mean, do you even need to know anything else about a poem called ‚ÄúDedicated to Cutie‚Äù? Well, maybe you do, since you might be thinking it's an indie rock reference.‚ÄúIf I could put you into natureYou'd be an exuberant sunRising above a colorless seaZealously waiting to captureYour beautiful reflection.‚ÄùI should mention, to add to the howls, that the two stanzas before it were of four lines and in relatively strict meter; that fourth line here exists simply because De Mills didn't spend enough time on this poem to get his third stanza into the same rhythm as the first two. Which leads to the inevitable question: why in the world are you even attempting to publish your work when you haven't even reached the level of mastery where you understand that if you're writing a poem with meter, the stanzas should all conform to that meter?I don't know what book those other eight people read, but I suspect it was not Affections, which is currently the leader in the race for worst book I have read this year. (zero)

Abandoned Mine (Jeff Chamberlain, 2013)Abandoned Mine started off with a bang‚Äîthere are some nifty filmmaking techniques that make it seem like you're going to get something much more than you are from this low-budget horrorfest. For some reason, however, Chamberlain abandons the pretense to the avant-garde once things get rolling, and we end up with a straightforward haunted-mine tale, mediocre but watchable.Plot: Brad (Pearl Harbor's Reiley McClendon) is a post-high-school layabout in a small rural town, bored out of his skull. His ex-girlfriend Laurie (Reservations' Saige Thompson) is back in town, so he cooks up an idea‚Äîthe two of them, Brad's current girlfriend Sharon (Spy Kids' Alexa PenaVega), Laurie's schoolmate Ethan (High School Musical 2's Charan Prabhakar), and Brad's best friend Jim (Radio Flyer's Adam Hendershott), will spend the night near the mouth of the legendary Jarvis Mine, supposedly haunted by the family of the Jarvis that the mine is named for. A thunderstorm drives them inside, and weird things start happening...Unfortunately, none of those weird things are terribly unpredictable; you should be on the right track relatively soon, and from there, aside from some appealing ambiguity as to what's really going on with one of the characters, it unfolds in paint-by-numbers fashion. This has a surprisingly high-powered cast for such a shoestring affair, and despite being stereotypes, the characters are at least affable (I waffled the whole movie on whether Ethan was offensive or the best character in the entire movie). I've seen far worse movies this year, but I've seen far better as well. **

Dossie Easton and Janet W. Hardy, The Ethical Slut: A Practical Guide to Polyamory, Open Relationships, and Other Adventures (2/E) (Celestial Arts, 2009)Perhaps the most important thing to know about The Ethical Slut, if you're just hearing about it for the first time, comes from Annie Sprinkle's blurb on the back. ‚ÄúThe Ethical Slut is one of the most useful relationship books you could ever read, no matter what your lifestyle choices.‚Äù This is indeed the case. Even if you're a committed monogamist (like most folks around the globe today who are in serious relationships), there is a great deal of information in here you can use; given that polyamory is simply an exponential projection of normal relationship dynamics, the books presents a masterclass on the same stuff about relationships that's covered in every other self-help book. And since they're looking at situations that most people will consider absurd, they're going well out beyond what the monogamous will think of as the worst case scenario.  As a result, simply put: this is the best self-help book, not only about relationships, but about anything, that you will ever read.Think of polyamory like cooking. The standard relationship we all think of, two people romantically involved, that's like making a souffle. It's not the easiest thing in the world to do, but as long as you're willing to adapt to your surroundings and follow a few rules, most of which are common-sense, you will end up with something good. Polyamory, well, with each new person you add, you're cooking another dish at the same time. Usually in a different oven, often in a different apartment in the building, and sometimes the equipment in the other place is stuff you're not used to and you end up having to tread very carefully or you're going to wind up with scrambled eggs instead. (You've seen this movie before.) And yet, somehow, thousands of people make it work every day. The levels of communication and empathy involved often feel superhuman to the monogamous, once they overcome the ‚Äúaren't you always jealous?‚Äù phenomenon. And that's where the ‚Äúthis is good advice for the monogamous as well‚Äù factor comes in. Dealing with, say, a breakup in a polyamorous relationship involves a whole bunch of support from other people who love you and take your feelings into account. How is that different from a monogamous relationship? They're friends, and sometimes we don't think to ask. Or if you're in a monogamous relationship and just never think to talk about a topic for some reason? Yeah, you'll learn how to cut that out, 'cause it's usually a bad idea. Learning to think about the idea of gender fluidity in a different way? Par for the course, bub. And these are just tip-of-the-iceberg examples.In short, it doesn't matter who you are, what kind of relationship you're in (including being asexual by choice), or anything else, you are almost guaranteed to find at least one piece of helpful advice in this book. Most will find it a treasure trove of great ideas well worth exploring, capable of taking their relationships to levels beyond anything they would have previously believed. I say it again: this is, as far as I know, the single best self-help book of all time. You need to read this. *****

Kathryn and Byron Jackson, The Big Elephant (Golden Press, 1949)The Big Elephant is one of those Golden books from when the company was still, I think, finding its feet and trying to come upon a winning formula for pre-lit. This one doesn't quite get there, though it's not as bad as some of their other experiments (have you read Polly's Pet? [shudder]). I should note, however, that the Jacksons, a year before this, came up with one of Golden's early winners, Busy Timmy, and note in passing that experimentation is a good thing. But this book's one big problem is its repetition, which is so pervasive, and so noticeable, it's the only book from this batch of six that we did not finish the first time through; it took another pass the second night to get all the way to the end of the book. Would have liked to see a rewrite of this one with some of the repetition fixed to see how much the book would have been improved, but almost sixty years later, I'm thinking that's probably impossible, at least with the original authors. **

Watty Piper, The Little Engine that Could (Platt and Munk, 1930)When I was a kid, I was pretty open to reading just about anything, really, and there were very few books I simply did not like. One of them was The Little Engine that Could. Well, a copy of it popped into our house tonight thanks to the mother-in-law, and I read it to the Bean tonight. Forty years later, my opinion of the book has not changed one bit. Repetitive prose, unlikable characters (in the engines who refuse), trite, inspirational resolution...I wouldn't have put things in those words when I was four, of course, at that time all I knew was that I was bored by it compared to other books in my collection of which I wore out multiple copies (Big Max, The Snowy Day, Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People's Ears, Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel, I could go on all day), but now, with a quarter-century of analysis and criticism behind me, I can put fingers on why the book rubbed me the wrong way so badly when I was young. And it still does. I know it is beloved of millions, but sorry, folks, I have never been able to get on this bandwagon, and at this point it's pretty obvious I never will. * Ω

Sebastien Braun, Digger and Tom (Harper, 2011)Okay, I don't get it. Why did the publisher feel the need to change this book, originally published in England, to have the title Digger and Tom instead of Digger and Skip? You can't seriously think that was a cultural reference that would not be glossed over by the intended audience (or their parents, so you really know anyone who doesn't watch at least one British import home show on TV? I mean, I don't even have cable and I know that one). One way or the other, though, out of the whack of books (six) that came home from the library with mommy and the Bean on Friday, this was the winner (Tubby was the only other one that came close). Digger is a small backhoe who works on a construction site with a number of other machines. The dump truck Tom is his friend, but the rest of the machines look down on him because he's kind of clumsy. When the team runs into a problem they can't solve, Ton encourages Digger to take a whack at it, because digging is his specialty. Pretty standard stuff, but for a construction-equipment-obsessed two-year-old it seems to be the best thing ever. If your kid takes a shine to it, expect to be re-reading this one a lot. Doesn't hold up to that all that well, but it's short and easy, so not a huge problem. ***

Nancy Shaw, Sheep Blast Off (Houghton Mifflin, 2008)Another of the Sheep books that doesn't measure up to the original (cf. recent review of Sheep Take a Hike), but that has the interesting side effect of revealing another facet of the original that makes it work so well. Obviously, if you've got a flock of sheep in a jeep with one driving, you're suspending a modicum of disbelief, but once you've gotten to that level, you don't need to go farther; everything works, everything is internally consistent. With Sheep Blast Off, on the other hand, it seemed almost as if Shaw was trying to outdo herself with every passing page with the silliness. On the other hand, the language is consistent and fun‚Äîif your child is already a fan of the Sheep series, take this one out of the library and give it a look. Else, start with the original (and still best) book in the series, Sheep in a Jeep. ** ¬Ω
