As a fan of the novel, I can't wait to read what the second book will be. All in all, a great read.

Princess Academy (the first book in the series) is a middle grade Newbury Award winning book from 10 years ago. I found it faced out at the library last summer, read it, and then picked up the sequel. This book is the final in the series, and it's no less delightful or engaging than the other two. It has high adventure and fun characters, humor and seriousness, good dialogue and good plotting. It's the kind of book I have no qualms recommending, rereading, and sharing with pretty much everyone in my life. (Granted, it's more a book for girls than for boys.) Highly recommended.

This novella leaves you wanting more, as much for its delightful writing as for the story it weaves. Picturing Mary as a REAL PERSON, one who struggles with some of the same things we do (like work, for example) is something we just don't often do. And while this book helps us do that, it does it by using storytelling as craft. You won't be able to put it down, and once you finish, you'll wish there was more. Highly recommended!

I was hugely leery of the price of this, and since I reviewed it for Amazon Vine, I didn't have to pay for it.That said, my mother-in-law was over when I took it out of the box, and she was beside herself about it. Even when I told her the price, she didn't care.This is made so sturdily, and it has a dual purpose ability:  you can close up the little drain thing and use it just as a rack, or you can use it to dry your dishes (which is why I was interested in it). It folds up, but without being flimsy about it.It's bigger than my standard dish drying rack was, and the dishes sort of sit down in it while they drain, so I'm going to have to wipe it out regularly. That said, did I mention it's sturdy? This is well made in a way I don't know that I've seen in a dish rack.The gray triangle plate rack thing folds down flat, if you want to use it that way, and there are legs on the back that can prop it up so it drains out (and if you snap them off, as I accidentally did, they go right back on and stay on without breaking!).I'm highly impressed. I suspect my mother-in-law's going to be getting one of these soon as a gift. Totally worth the money for what you get.

No one was more surprised than I was when Jeff Young wrote and asked me if I would endorse his new book, Around the Table with the Catholic Foodie: Middle Eastern Cuisine. Of all the people who know me, Jeff knows that I‚Äôm, uh, NOT a foodie. At. All.But I like to eat. (So when I have the chance to have Jeff cook for me, I‚Äôm ALL OVER IT.)Confession: I haven‚Äôt read the entire book. But I have drooled all over it, and I‚Äôm going to be trying more than a few of the recipes in it.But wait, it‚Äôs not just a cookbook. Far from it. This is a book that also journeys through the Holy Land: that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs focused on Middle Eastern cuisine!I cook because I have to, and Young‚Äôs book (and his Catholic Foodie apostolate) is an inspiration to me to try to make more of it. His goal? To get families around the table for dinner. And one of the ways to do that is to inspire great foods from them.This is a book that‚Äôs designed for all of us‚Ä¶and that makes it even more special than it would otherwise be, I think. It also makes it a great gift idea.

I got this for my husband, so all these comments are straight from him.Everything you need is in one handy case: you just grab the case and go. There are few times you can take your welder to your friend's house and go. A couple of rods and you're ready to go.It is also well-made. The case is very sturdy and the welder is great. It works well for small projects. I strongly recommend it, especially if you have to be mobile with your small welding projects.

This feature has been one of my favorites at CatholicMom.com, and I'm excited to have it bundled together at the start of the new year.Each day has a link to the daily Mass readings, then a brief reflection. It's followed with a "Ponder" that will make you consider how to apply the Gospel to your life and then a short one- or two-sentence prayer.Truly, this is a gem of a resource. Having it online was great, but now having it all in one place with this Kindle edition makes it invaluable, especially if you're busy and trying to find a way to fit Scripture into your life.

Jennifer Grant, in her new release Wholehearted Living: Five-Minute Reflections for Modern Moms, begins by outlining a few things that get my momsense stirring and my momtuition raving...in a good way.She calls the book "a 'pause' button for mothers who want to take a break from talk of juice boxes and snow pants in favor of confronting their fears or reconnecting with their dreams."The book delivers what it promises. I'll admit I didn't have the time to read all 365 of the daily reflections, but I did sample through them enough to know this is the kind of book that:1. Most moms need to read and dip into and out of.2. Will be a great gift for quite a few of the moms I know.3. Won't go out of style anytime soon.The book divides the year into three parts: Reflect, Risk, and Rest. You begin in January with reflection, and then, as May begins, you start to look at risk, and you end the year, just as school starts up in September, with rest.It's a pattern that spoke to my life, to the way the ebbs and flows of my own experience of momness.While Grant references talk that makes me think of moms with younger children, I don't necessarily think this book is limited to the scope of young moms or moms with young families. That's the place she's writing from, and it's a place many moms have been and/or are. It's a hard place, a crucible unlike any other.The reflections aren't long; their brevity is almost unparalleled in a book of this sort. And yet, as Grant herself notes, "a good five minutes actually makes a difference, affecting how we relate with others and how we perceive our lives for the rest of the day."Opening and using this book ‚Äî whether you dip into it or swim around for a while ‚Äî won't leave you with something else to do. Grant has explicitly avoided doing more than giving you a reason to sit and reflect with her for five minutes. She's planting a seed in those five (or less) minutes, one that may just sprout into more throughout your day.Though this book has many Catholic undertones, it's not explicitly Catholic in the way that many books I endorse and read are. You could as easily give this to any Christian friend (practicing or not), and she would appreciate the quote or scripture that opens each day, the short reflection, and the one or two reflection questions that close each day.This truly is a book, as Grant says in the introduction, "for moments when you feel drawn toward the divine, as well as for those times when you feel like your frailties are holding you captive and you really just want to stand in the corner, face the wall, and scream."

These are, simply, beautiful. They are sparkly metallic, and eye-catching on the table, even if you're just eating burgers or mac & cheese. They would go equally as well with a fancy dinner and if you're not careful, your grade school aged daughter may claim one or more to be a dance mat for their dolls.They're also flippable (which is handy if you have kids), so they're the same on both sides. They're also easy to clean up (I haven't been tempted...yet...to try putting them in the dishwasher, but I haven't had them on the table much with the kids yet, either).I'm glad I have them. I'll be using them and will report back if I have any other findings or experiences with them.

Trusting God is easier said that done, at least for me. I always seem to think I know better. Or that I can do it myself, which puts me at about the same level as my three-year-old.Over the years, I‚Äôve become quite a St. Therese fangirl, though I will admit that I struggle sometimes. Her Little Way doesn‚Äôt seem little in terms of effort or difficulty. Her philosophy trumps me. And yet I keep coming back to her.So I was intrigued by Connie Rossini‚Äôs new book Trusting God with St. Therese (Four Waters Press). Rossini seems to be a highly practical person, so I didn‚Äôt expect a lot of flowery advice that I won‚Äôt be able to follow anyway.Rossini manages to make St. Therese, the great Doctor of the Church, into someone accessible, and she does it in part by sharing her own story in conjunction with Therese‚Äôs. Suddenly the Little Flower becomes not just a saint who either bordered on whiny or who was so perfect I stand no chance of being inspired, but someone who I can turn to in prayer and maybe even hear speaking to me as I read about her.At the end of each of the 13 chapters, there are reflection questions that would be ideal if you were using the book for a study group or even for journaling inspiration. Rossini has also included at least two, and sometimes as many as four, practical suggestions at the end of each chapter, too.Reading about Rossini‚Äôs experiences through the lens of St. Therese was inspiring, true. Beyond that, though, it also motivated me to consider how my own experiences can be viewed in light of the saints who impact and inspire me.

How many times, asks the back cover of The Quick Reference Guide to the Catholic Bible, have you wanted some context and background about a book of the Bible but didn't have the time to wade through a long commentary?Well, I answer, plenty. Isn't that why we have the internet?Oh lo, the internet and the imperfections of searching for scriptural help online. It's a crapshoot at best and a dangerous game of roulette at worst.I didn't have time to give this book a complete and thorough reading; instead, I did a little dipping into it with a few of my favorite books of the Bible, starting with Ruth.Just as the back cover promised, there's a summary of the book, including a little bit about why in the world Ruth is even important in the context of scripture. There's also an At a Glance section that answers Who, What, When, Where, and Why in a sentence or two. Then comes a section on the structure of the book, a listing of the major themes found within it, authorship, and the literary form. There's also a part about key passages and the chapter on Ruth wraps up with food for thought.This is all well and good, and if you're like me, you've already thought of three people who need this as a gift. However, let me say this, and say it loudly: this book is written for the rest of us: the rest of us who are reluctant catechists, the rest of us who are parents seeking answers to hard questions, the rest of us who like the idea but not so much the practice of studying the bible.I'm glad I didn't try to read this book cover to cover, because I suspect I would have done it a disservice. This isn't a cover-to-cover read: it's a reference that will, I hope, encourage more than just me to snuggle up with my big ole bible and crack that cover. It's just enough reference to get me interested in reading the source material. I call that a success.

What I loved about this: - It's simple and elegant in design. Granted, it's in my CLOSET. But...there's something still appealing about how it looks. - It functions well. I fold my scarves, they stay in place.The one drawback: - I no sooner had one than I found I needed another. :)Very handy sort of thing to organize and keep your scarves.

What The American Catholic Almanac does is brilliant. One page per day for one person.None of the people highlighted are stuffy or boring. Most of them are either (a) people I hadn't heard of or (b) people I didn't know were so stinkin' interesting. Even with the people who are so well-known as to be patrons of my kids, I learned interesting facts that made them more human.And the history I've gotten out of this book! I can only compare it to when I read The Frontiersman many years ago at my husband's behest.I've never been much of a fan of history. It was nothing but boring in high school, so I skipped it in college.In the last 15 years or so, I've learned more from great stories than I ever learned in high school history, and I think The American Catholic Almanac would be well placed in a history classroom.I had NO IDEA the work and hardship that early American Catholics had to work through and put up with! I had NO IDEA what kind of investment mission priests and religious made in the United States! I had NO IDEA how many inter-stinkin-esting people there were in the annals of American Catholic history!Thanks to The American Catholic Almanac, I've had a taste. (In the interest of full disclosure, I'm not all the way through the book. Though I will be soon.)This isn't a book for the bookshelf. It is, however, a book to share and reread and quote. It's a book to learn from and be inspired by.

This is a daily flip calendar that can be used perennially. Each day has two entries: a Bible verse for your morning, with a little one or two sentence injunction from Fr. Larry Richards.I have a love-hate relationship with desk calendars. I love the idea of them, but I tend to not be consistent with them these days, in part because I do my work at my desk and at the table, on the couch, in the kitchen, at the library, at a friend's...you see how it is.But I love the idea of taking a little bit of scripture before breakfast and before bed. Says Fr. Larry in the introduction,"This perpetual calendar will help you begin and end each day with an encounter with Jesus Christ in His Word. I encourage you to pray to the Holy Spirit before you read the verse every morning and every night, so that it is God Himself who reveals His Word to you."Let's take a look at September 26 to get a sense of it. The calendar tells me that it's the feast of Saints Cosmas and Damian."Much will be required of the person entrusted with much." (Luke 12:48)We all have been given much‚ÄîJesus Christ‚Äîso much is expected from us!~ ~ ~I will be glad and exult in you; / I will sing praise to your name, O Most High. (Psalm 9:2, ESV)Let tonight be about praising God, not us. Pax.By my calculations, this calendar is asking for about two minutes of my morning and two minutes before bed. It's so simple that I can't help but think it's brilliant: many of my devotional failures are because I try to overcomplicate things.This isn't complicated. It's not hard. But it is an invitation to something very important.And if I fail...well, there's always the next day. And the next.

You don‚Äôt have to turn far to see a discussion of same sex attraction. It‚Äôs everywhere, and it‚Äôs heated wherever you turn. People who seem to be otherwise calm and orderly suddenly sprout extra appendages and the ability to use words you‚Äôve never heard.So I was interested to see a small publisher release a book early this summer tackling this topic. In 200 pages, The Lion‚Äôs Heart, by Dena Hunt, combined masterful storytelling with uncomfortable topic matter.The story: Paul‚Äôs a gay guy, and it turns out that so is Max, though he doesn‚Äôt know it until he meets Paul. Wrench: Max is happily married. Another wrench: Paul is friends with the family.Don‚Äôt roll your eyes yet, because I‚Äôve not only oversimplified, I‚Äôve also left out the excellent writing. This could be a terrible story (all the elements are there), but it‚Äôs truly one that was crafted. The reader isn‚Äôt just carried along, but has to do some thinking and concluding.The premise of the book is the love affair between two men, but it‚Äôs about more than just what I think we‚Äôve all come to expect. Instead of focusing exclusively on what‚Äôs wrong with these two men, Hunt explores the impact their adultery‚Äîbecause that‚Äôs what it is‚Äîhas on their families and the people around them. She takes a theory that many of us have heard‚Äîthat what we do matters to more than just ourselves‚Äîand weaves it into a reality that‚Äôs hard to deny.This book grapples a topic that‚Äôs not only hot but that gets people hot. You‚Äôre probably not going to let your teen read it, but you should. This is an honest, candid, painful look at the humanity behind the terms that are tossed around. These characters are people, not numbers. They have depth and believability. They have problems that most of us are only spitting distance from having ourselves.Hunt does what few authors are able to do, and even less do well, she leaves well enough alone and she leaves the reader alone to make some important decisions and conclusions.This book is one of the most honest books I‚Äôve read, and that‚Äôs what makes it one that I‚Äôll share. It‚Äôs not pretty, it‚Äôs not easy, and it‚Äôs not lying. There‚Äôs no shying away from the pain for any of the characters, but there‚Äôs also a glimpse at what the beauty of love can really yield. And I don‚Äôt think it will make you roll your eyes.

This is a quaint and yet heartening in its presentation of forgiveness. I've spent YEARS learning about forgiveness and experiencing it and trying to offer it and offer it and offer it. And yet, in under 30 pages and probably less than 100 words, Lataif sums it up and Betz gives it a series of images.It's a hardbound book with beautiful full-color illustrations that really accompany the text. It's the kind of book that you can read to your restless three-year-old boy and be interrupted about 20 times a page with, "That guy's MAD" and "Oooo, a SPIDER" and...well, you get the idea. Yet, you can also read it with your nine-year-old (who, by the way, can read it for herself and would never ever admit she liked you reading it) and see it spark some thoughts in her mind.This is a book I'll be sharing with others (adding it to my "Godchildren Gift Ideas" list now).

This notebook is standard-issue composition book, but with a crazy cover that's some kind of plastic. And it will hold up to bites, drops, and rain (though the interior, sadly, will not).Where was this notebook when I was in college? Well, it's here now, and I am SOLD.Not only that, but my kids will need a Sharpie to write over what I've designated (or to write their names, because it seems they need to write THEIR names on EVERYTHING) and they won't be able to just color on the cover. Except that there's no white box on the front.Pages: permanently bound, just like with every other comp book on the market.Downfall: it's no longer the inexpensive, easily justified notebook anymore either. So there's that. But...if you're a pro looking for a handy notebook, it's far less than the $20 I've shelled out for fancy-schmancy journals. So there's THAT.Guess it depends how you're using it, what kind of budget you have, and whether you like the colors. :)

At first, I wasn't sure about this having a soft cover, but in practice, it's pretty brilliant.The three-ring binder is firmly velcroed in and my beta tester (age 9) gave this the full run.On the "can it hold up to a week with her carting it around in her various bags," it scored a 5 out of 5. Not only did the Mead logo stay intact, but the pockets didn't rip no matter how much stuff she shoved into them.On the "how flexible is it going from a 37yo writer-mom to a 9yo girl who can't leave anything at home," it scored a 5 out of 5.On the "I can't find that important piece of paper so I put it in the outside pocket and then it poured as we were walking into the meeting," it scored a 4 out of 5. What can I say? It was some downpour and I should've had a briefcase.If you only need to take your tablet and a notebook, this is pretty stinkin' handy. Or if you're age 9 and you aspire to great things with pen and paper, it's also very useful. I hesitate to call this the Trapper Keeper for us grown-ups, but...well, there it is. I was reminded of junior high, but in a GOOD way. (Minus the annoying velcro opening sound.)

Over the years since I‚Äôve been reading and reviewing books, I‚Äôve been blessed to interact with a number of awesome Catholic authors.Randy Hain is one such person. He‚Äôs written a pile of books and he‚Äôs one of the dynamic duo behind Integrated Catholic Life. Randy‚Äôs latest book, Journey to Heaven: A Road Map for Catholic Men, is, in a word, GREAT. I don‚Äôt say that just because I like Randy, either. I‚Äôve read his other books, and they‚Äôre good. This, though, is something remarkable. I can‚Äôt help but think there‚Äôs a dose of Holy Spirit in it.Though this is, without a doubt, a book for every Catholic man you know, it‚Äôs also a book that I think benefits women. Dare I suggest that you buy it for the man in your life and then read it too? Yes, I do.In this book, Randy Hain has channeled some of the brightest and best conversation on what it means to be a man. This book isn‚Äôt just for men, though. It should be part of every wife, sister, and mother‚Äôs required reading, and a topic of discussion for all of us. I owe a thank you to Randy, for baring himself and sharing the points I want the men in my life to live. Keep your eye out for it and go ahead and pre-order it when it‚Äôs available.

I *was* just going to read the book one chapter at a time, but I found that it was just too good a book to put down.Which makes my earlier hesitation to even crack it open all the more hilarious, doesn't it?This book is one that (a) I know I'll be buying for my favorite bibliophiles, (b) I know I'll be raving about for at least the next 500 days or so, and (c) I know I'll be rereading. Maybe yet this summer.Look up "awesome" in your thesaurus and go ahead and just apply all the synonyms here. This book is all that, with whipped cream on top, a side of chocolate, and a hearty pot of coffee. It's not only a book I wholeheartedly and unreservedly recommend, but  it's one that I will probably not ever at all lend. Nope. Can't do it. Sharing's not an option with a book that could turn into a yearly read...Don't miss this book. You deserve it, especially if you've ever loved Jesus. This book will make you look at him more clearly, appreciate him more authentically, and find your faith more tangibly.

I have been meaning to read this book for...well, I think it's been almost a year. And last week, I did. It's a quick read (I read it in about a day, without really rushing myself), and it's not bad overall. I tend not to read romances, but this is as much about relationships, with a bit of a mystery-ish thrown in. It reminded me, in good ways, of when I was in high school and picked up Nicholas Sparks's The Notebook. I half wished I'd been sitting on a beach when I read it, because it strikes me as a definite summer read. You'll enjoy it, I think, especially if you like "chick-lit."

Even before I considered myself a writer, I had a "thing" for books about writing. I got this recommendation from a writer I admire and whipped through it (though it sat on my Kindle for a good little bit before I got to it). Though I don't write fiction (and don't intend to), I was nodding, because many of much of what Aaron says is true for any writing, including the nonfiction/freelance/web stuff I do. And hey, she's entertaining as all get-out. A fun read if you're so inclined.

This book is utterly delightful from start to finish. You have the option of reading it in a "pick and choose" sort of way, diving in where you want, because the essays are all stand-alone.I read it the way I read most things: cover to cover. I walked away from it with a clear picture of just who Jake Frost is and just how he got to be that way. He's the kind of guy I want my son to grow up to be: proud of his Catholicness, laughing about the foibles of life, and appreciating the blessings all around him.His essays are a glimpse at life from "the other side" (or is it just that I read more women than men?). What makes a dad tick? Well, I still don't know, but I know that I'm even more fascinated and intrigued by the wisdom that comes from these Catholic dad types.This is a book not to miss and one you'll share, whether you're a mom peeking in or a dad looking for inspiration.

I was pleasantly surprised by this book. While I'm a big fan of books that tie in things like sports with faith, I'm not a big hockey player or fan. So if this book hadn't landed in a pile I was committed to reading, I probably would have skipped it.And if I had done that, I would have missed out.Bishop Paprocki could probably write about just about anything and I would be following along enthusiastically, but I wouldn't have known that if I hadn't read this book. Paprocki writes in a down-to-earth, man-on-the-ice way, and he ties it in in a way that's decidedly not preachy. No, really.This is a book for the young men in your life and the older of the young boys. Bishop Paprocki makes his points unapologetically and does what I absolutely love: he makes the Catholic faith manly. I mean, what's not manly about hockey and a bishop who loves nothing more than getting out on the ice and taking some hits with a puck?Definitely a book to check out. I really enjoyed it.

Can you say "new favorite book for a Catholic you know"? Because that's my short review of this gem. If I was still teaching 5th grade religion classes, I would probably be petitioning to have copies of this for all my students. It might be geared a little young for my Confirmation students, but the content is GOLDEN, and probably right at a level most of the parents I've worked with could appreciate. (That's not a knock on them. It's a recognition of a reality I've experienced.)I consider this a must-have for all Catholic families with kids younger than 12. And for those with kids older? Maybe still worth checking out...

Now that my oldest, who's nine and in the third grade, is an avid reader, I'm always on the lookout for ways to introduce her to Bible stories, again and again. So when the Adventure Bible Handbook, by Robin Schmitt & David Frees (Zondervan, 2013) came my way, I was thrilled.I was even more thrilled by the way my nine-year-old took off with it and carried it around with her. Dare I hope that this might rate up there with the Magic Treehouse books?There are a few things I really, really liked about this book.It's pretty. The illustrations are reminiscent of what's in all the graphic novels that my daughter loves and the text is informative without being borrrrrring. You'll find beautiful maps in addition to the cartoonish stuff, photographs of Bible places, and paintings/illustrations that depict other aspects of Biblical life.The pages are full-color semi-gloss and it's a hardbound book. While that makes the price higher, it also makes it a book that will last. And that's a priority for me, because I want my other kids to enjoy it too.This is a way of making the Bible fun. The Word of God is the most important text we have, right? But...it's not always the easiest or most accessible text. That makes a book like this something I'm glad to have sitting around. Though I don't find the graphic novel stuff the easiest to narrate aloud to my younger kids, the many sidebars and extra stuff give it layersDid I mention there's not just one index, but three (and possibly four, depending on how you categorize things)? My kids may never use it, but the mom scholar in me loves that. There's a guide to reading the Bible, a scripture index, a subject index, and an image guide.All in all, I'm glad to have it.

I wasn't sure what to expect with this book. Would it be a business book? Or a spiritual book written by a business guy? Or a biography with business tips? Or...something altogether different?Turns out, the answer is yes.This is a book of lessons, yes, but it's also a book of insight. So much has been said about Pope Francis. The man can't say a sentence without people jumping in to interpret and explain.Lowney takes a different approach. He has Jesuit training and shares some important background with Pope Francis, so he uses that as the lens through which he considers what we can all learn from Pope Francis.It's hard to believe, really, that this is based off of a year. In some ways, that's the beauty of it.It's not overwritten or stretched out: this is a book that's tightly written and well-researched. It reads like a book off the NYT bestseller list, minus the snark and cynicism.I found myself appreciating Jesuit spirituality more, because Lowney explains it. In learning more about it, I suddenly have a view into Papa.This book is partly journey, partly lesson, partly fun reading. Highly recommended.

Confession: I wouldn't have picked this book up if I wasn't part of the Catholic Spiritual Direction book club. And oh! What I would have missed!Fr. Philippe hits a whole box of nails right on the head, puts the house together, and then roofs and sides it. (OK, I took the metaphor too far. But...that's what it felt like, reading it.) While he's dealing with some complicated matters of the spiritual life (ahem, the title says it all), he does so with language that my ten-year-old would understand. He's straightforward, tangible, and relevant.Don't be fooled by the slim size of this book. It packs a punch that's well worth the time you'll take to read, re-read, and share it.

I'm well aware that stains can reappear a few days or weeks after a carpet cleaning, but as of today my carpets look wonderful.  I used this on them yesterday, and followed the directions with care.  I bought the "gadget" to make application easier, and I really like that, too.

Works about as well as the Dollar Store version, but not at all like the regular Resolve High Traffic formula.  I returned my "extra" can and replaced it with the High Traffic formula, and re-did the carpet I'd used the pet formula on.  Also, it has a strong smell that may not bother most customers; but it's not a good feature for those of us with sensitivities.

It's been some time since the Mars-bound spaceship carrying Chief Engineer Henry Starrett vanished. In the book before this one, "A Doorway Through Space," Henry's wife - Captain Ellen Starrett - headed out in her ship hoping to find out what happened, only to vanish at the same coordinates. Their children, Donald and Lucy (from whose viewpoint most of the scenes are written), teamed up with a family friend and renowned but offbeat scientist to follow both Henry and Ellen in the belief that rescue was still possible. With their vessel destroyed, the trio wound up on board a one-man warship captained by a young military pilot named Scott, who as this second book opens has become Donald's best friend and Lucy's suitor. Yes, she's still in high school; but Scott is still a teenager himself, and the two find each other enthralling.Ellen Starrett and her crew were rescued from the alien planet where they'd been imprisoned and marked for execution. Rescued and rescuers returned to Earth in triumph, and all was well. But now, Ellen and Dr. Hartwick - the family friend whose scientific genius made the previous books' events possible - are working on a time machine. It's summer, and with Donald off on his own Ellen and Lucy find themselves saddled with Lucy's cousins, mischievous twins Romi and Remi. The site of the time machine project is in Italy, near Rome. Hear any echoes yet?Judith Bourassa Joy understood that if you show a gun in the first scene, it had better go off as the story progresses. Yes, there's meaning in those names. Yes, the time machine works. A surprisingly good story unfolds, and I found myself reminded of the great Robert A. Heinlein's novels for juveniles which were the mainstays of my own "YA" years. I won't give away particulars because I don't see how I can do so without spoiling the book for other readers, and I wouldn't do that for the world! I am sorry there will be no more books by Judith Bourassa Joy. This woman had great talent, and she's left us without having had time to reach her full power as a writer.

Three teenaged boys do what teenagers have always done, one night on a lake in northern Minnesota. They paddle their kayaks to a place that legend says is evil and dangerous, Windigo Island, so one 13-year-old can carry out his vow to spray paint a love message onto a rock that can be seen with binoculars from the lake's shore. Before they can leave, a tremendous wind comes up out of nowhere; and while his friends flee in terror, the boy wielding the spray paint breaks his ankle and finds himself trapped. He's sure he hears the Windigo - a flesh-eating monster of Ojibwe myth - call his name, and he's also sure he sees another monster, Michi Peshu, coming toward him out of the lake. What actually washes up on the shore, to be found by the rescue squad that retrieves him, is the corpse of a long missing teenaged girl.That girl vanished a year ago, in company with a friend who is related to former Tamarack County sheriff Cork O'Connor. Cork, who is one-quarter Ojibwe and very much committed to that heritage, now works as a private investigator and maintains a home for his daughter, Jenny, and her adopted 3-year-old son. He's still reeling from an attack by a vengeful stalker who put a paralyzing bullet into his 17-year-old son. Stephen is recuperating at a physical therapy clinic, where he's just learning to walk again. The last thing Cork needs right now is a client who can't pay him; but family is family, and he hates what he knows probably happened to the missing girl, Mariah Arceneaux. Jenny, who's in her late 20s now and working on a novel when she isn't managing the O'Connor family's summertime burger stand, comes along when Cork hears the story at the remote cabin of his long time mentor, an elderly Ojibwe healer called Henry. Jenny is so moved by Mariah's likely plight that she insists on joining her father when Cork heads for the Bad Bluff Reservation to see what he can do for Mariah's mother.What follows is a tale that explores the consequences of Ojibwe and other Native American tribes having their cultures shattered, and their lives defined by white men's values. It's a world within a world, where women expect to be used and where having a future means playing by someone else's rules. Henry's enigmatic response to Mariah's mother, a one-legged diabetic who hardly dares to hope for her daughter's safe return, puzzles both O'Connors and infuriates Jenny. We see parts of the story through her eyes, and I found it interesting to view Cork from Jenny's perspective. One of the best aspects of this novel, for me, was Jenny coming into her own and working beside her father - even when Cork did his best to prevent her from doing so.This is the sort of book that I can't put down in order to go to sleep. I started it in the evening, the more fool me; and I finished it at almost 2 a.m. In other words, an absorbing tale indeed!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Three young people gather in a southern Sweden nature reserve, a place where they can expect privacy at night, to celebrate Midsummer's Eve in costume. A fourth expected to join them, but can't due to sudden illness. For no reason that the reader can tell at that time, a man shoots all three to death and buries their bodies inside the reserve. As far as their parents and the rest of the world are concerned, the trio has vanished; but one mother insists that the post cards she subsequently receives from various cities in Europe, purporting to be from her daughter, are forgeries.Six weeks later, Ystad Detective Inspector Kurt Wallander wakes from his sleep certain that his colleague Svedberg's uncharacteristic absence from work on the preceding day - and failure to answer his telephone, or otherwise check in - means something is horribly wrong. When he goes to Svedberg's flat and gains entry, he discovers the man dead by shotgun blast and the flat obviously searched. Almost at the same time, a couple visiting the nature reserve discovers the six-weeks decayed corpses of the missing young people. Where were they during the time they were missing? Who sent the forged post cards, and why would their killer conceal their bodies (not to mention where) and then present them to be found?Wallander is reeling from his father's recent death, and he's also alternately denying and trying to cope with a diabetes diagnosis. The Ystad homicide squad's members find it difficult to investigate Svedberg's murder, and it's especially so for Wallander. No one imagines the murders of the young people in the nature reserve may be connected to Svedberg's killing. No one except Wallander, whose natural intuition has been finely honed by his decades of work; and who cares so much that he just may kill himself while getting the job done.This is gritty reading indeed, but I found it fascinating. Wallander's character, and that of the killer, are both gradually revealed through their behavior - we're shown, not told, what makes both tick. As usual with Mankell, Swedish culture in its then current state is more character than background. A fine installment in a series that continues to hold my interest.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Swedish detective inspector Kurt Wallander agrees to check on the odd situation because everyone else in his small town's police department is busy, and the elderly farmer who called in the report seems to need attention. There's a teenaged girl sitting in the farmer's rape field. She's been there ever since the farmer first looked into his field, at 5 a.m.; and when the old man tried approaching her, she fled to another part of the field. It doesn't look like much of an emergency to Wallander. Not until he approaches the girl himself, intending to ask her business and persuade her to vacate the farmer's property - because that's when she douses herself with petrol and strikes a cigarette lighter into flame.That horrifying scene was the first Wallander tale I encountered, in the PBS adaptation of this book. I've waited a few years before giving the novels a try, and now I've reached this fifth installment in the series. As should be the case with good fiction adapted for film or television, the books have more depth and tell a more complex, more nuanced story; but I now know that the scriptwriter did an excellent job. The Wallander books, this one included, tend to have many plot threads that ultimately come together. They can be - not difficult to follow, but perhaps challenging is a better word? Because I enjoy the complexity; it doesn't frustrate me. Wallander is an intriguing character, a reluctant hero who has done his best to break free from his increasingly unpleasant police career but who repeatedly discovers that he's doing the one thing with his life at which he truly excels. And at which his talents are desperately needed, too.One of the best installments I've read so far in a highly enjoyable series.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

On a rural road outside the small Swedish city where Chief Inspector Kurt Wallander works as a police detective, an estate agent tries to locate an unoccupied house and winds up stopping for directions at another house that is supposed to be vacant but isn't. The man whom she asks kills her with a single shot to the head. It takes time for the Ystad police to locate her body, and during that time the killer and those with him in the house have disappeared. The one clue left behind: a black man's severed finger.That's the beginning of a tale which shifts back and forth between Sweden and South Africa, a case that drives Kurt Wallander to the edge and then over it. Set in the time between Nelson Mandela's release from Robben Island and Mandela's becoming South Africa's first black president, it's a taut suspense yarn in which Wallander isn't present for at least half of the time; but in this case that's fine, because without hearing the South African characters' stories the action in Sweden would make no sense. Wallander faces his greatest fear, that his work may place the one person he loves most - his adult daughter, Linda - in peril. Will he have to face his work causing her death? And will Wallander himself survive, psychologically as well as physically?Mankell never leaves threads hanging, and I appreciate that. This book's ending leads naturally into the next volume in the series, but it does have an ending; and everything works despite the many shifts in viewpoint. My one question is whether or not the story works as well for a reader who doesn't remember the time about which Mankell is writing. I hope it does, because I enjoyed it thoroughly.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Patrolman Kurt Wallander is 23 years old, and he longs to leave the beat behind and join the Homicide Division as a detective. The first story in this anthology of five tales introduces him to the woman he will marry, and launches him on the career that already amounts to an obsession. The man he's becoming is already there, and that man develops through the subsequent stories until in the final one - the title piece of this volume, THE PYRAMID - he's familar to readers of the series, and to viewers of the PBS adaptation. We see him as a young father, as a bewildered husband on the verge of his marriage's breakup, and as his artist father's put-upon son. THE PYRAMID leads directly into the opening of the first novel in the series, FACELESS KILLERS.I'm sure most readers began long ago with the series itself, and that I'm unusual in having started with this book even though the author states it was put together last. My local library has it marked as Book One, and that's why I began with it when I decided to give Mankell a try. I'm now deep into FACELESS KILLERS. The first story didn't hook me, really; but the others did. Mankell's writing is very light on dialog, and he does a great deal of telling rather than showing; but somehow he makes it work despite ignoring those two supposed cardinal rules for the novelist. Wallander is a haunting figure, and my only dissatisfaction is that from time to time I get the feeling I'm hearing Mankell's political and social views as words put into the mouths of his characters. That jolts me when it happens, but it's by no means distracting enough to spoil the read overall.Looks as if I'll be reading the whole series!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

In 1650, the Spanish colonial city of Potosi sits above the treeline - so high in the South American mountains that European babies can't survive their first months of life in its thin, cold air. A woman who wants her child to live goes lower to deliver, and stays there until the baby is a year old. Potosi is a large and very busy city, in spite of its harsh location, because it's founded on the silver mines that are its only real industry. Now, though, the mines are starting to run out. The city's most powerful men, the mine owners, do not want this known. What has that to do with the mysterious death of a 15-year-old girl? Inez de la Morada died alone in her cell at the convent of Santa Isabella de los Santos Milagros, and because she locked herself inside the powers that be want to rule her passing a suicide. That will serve admirably the Inquisition's desire to declare Mother Abbess Maria Santa Hilda a heretic. They've been watching for such an opportunity, because Maria Santa Hilda makes no secret of her unconventional views on women's abilities in this society where a secular woman's only task is to produce children for the man she marries. Inez took refuge in the convent to escape her father's wrath; and so did the daughter of her father's bitter enemy, who came there to stop her own father from marrying her to a man he has chosen and young Beatriz doesn't even know.That's the setup for a debut novel that I found it hard to see as such. Alfieri writes with assurance, her setting rendered meticulously and her characters beautifully developed. It's a mystery, yes. But it's also a fine historical novel, one from which I learned a great deal while simply being entertained.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of "Granite Island"

Emily Allen began having the nightmares on Halloween, when she was 16 years old. She woke up screaming in terror, because the burning of a building with a six-sided cupola on top (surely it must be a church?) seemed completely real. It's years later now, and Emily is a former advertising agency employee who has quit her job for good reason and moved from Portland, Maine to the small town of Farley Bend. She's rented one of the first apartments to be renovated from the town's old, long abandoned mill, because the minute she drove into its parking lot the building felt to her like home. When she experiences the familiar nightmare on her first night in residence there, she's disappointed; she hoped that changing her life so drastically might stop the dreams permanently, instead of giving them a hiatus. But Farley Bend still seems like home, and Emily is determined to make it so. She isn't expecting what happens when she begins to research the old mill's history. That's when she learns that the fire in her dreams was a real one, and the building with the six-sided cupola isn't a church. It's the mill, as it was before fire destroyed all but the watchman's house where her landlady now lives and the structure that now houses her apartment.First-time novelist Lugner weaves an intriguing and sometimes eerie tale that mixes paranormal elements with mystery, enlivened by just the right amount of romance. Wisely, she refrains from trying to explain everything her characters experience. Instead she lets Emily and the people of Farley Bend, past as well as present, take her and her readers along on a nicely paced adventure. I found it a quick and thoroughly enjoyable read.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Chris Bohjalian began his career as a mystery writer, and has since found considerable success as a mainstream novelist. Those are meaty, thought-provoking books, rich in sense of place and characterization. This collection of his weekly newspaper columns (plus a few other things) is quite different, and yet hauntingly similar. I recognized the source material his Armenian grandparents provided for THE SANDCASTLE GIRLS, for example; but this book possesses a much lighter tone than the novels. It's a quick, enjoyable read, and it gave me a welcome glimpse into a new-found favorite author's life.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of "Love, Jimmy: A Maine Veteran's Longest Battle"

Victorian scientist Dudley Kynaston's household is short one ladies' maid on a morning when 13-year-old scullery maid Maisie goes outside at 5:45 a.m., performing her usual early morning chores, and discovers blood and clumps of hair on the back steps. There's no dead body, but the hair - torn out by the roots - looks like that of the missing ladies' maid, Kitty. Only because of Kynaston's importance to the government (he is a researcher into the possibilities presented by submarines) is this anything but an ordinary case for the police. But Kynaston is exactly that important, so Special Branch Commander Thomas Pitt must investigate.Pitt came to Special Branch from the regular London police, and he's still the best detective many people know. More often than not, the cases he investigates now are top secret and can't be discussed with Charlotte, his well-born wife; but this one he does talk about with her, and Charlotte sees an opportunity to involve her bored and unhappy sister, Emily Radley. Emily is the widow of a titled, wealthy aristocrat, and the current wife of a member of Parliament. She has access to the Kynastons' social class; and through her, so does Charlotte. As they did many times before, when Pitt was a police detective, the two women make their own inquiries. They learn a lot about the Kynastons' marriage, and some especially interesting things about Ailsa Kynaston, widow of Dudley Kynaston's beloved brother.I love Anne Perry's work. I had grown a bit tired of the Pitt series, though, because the saga of Thomas being forced out of his police superintendency and into Special Branch was just too rife with conspiracy theory for my taste. The book before this one promised things might get back on track; and this book really delivers in that respect. Victor Narraway, former holder of Commander Pitt's current position, has become an interesting character now that he's more illuminated and less mysterious, and the Pitts are once again behaving as they used to behave. The story resolves in a clear and believable manner, and Perry once again does what she's best at: she gives all of her characters multiple dimensions. The "villains" aren't entirely evil, and the "heroes" aren't entirely good.This one's a keeper!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Brian and Marcia Middleton sell their New York City apartment and purchase an old house in the hamlet of Deering, Vermont, to make a new start after Brian confesses to an affair and Marcia decides to forgive instead of leaving him. The locals make them welcome; but something about the house isn't right, and Marcia knows it on her first day there alone. After a well-meaning neighbor tells them the house's story during a Saturday night visit, Marcia awakens early Monday morning to find her husband missing from their bed...because he's hanged himself in the attic.Burlington detective J.P. Burrows grew up in another Vermont hamlet like Deering. The 30-something bachelor is initially unhappy about being assigned to investigate Brian Middleton's obvious (or so it seems) suicide, because he's forced to abandon another on-going investigation; but soon he finds himself not just interested, but positively obsessed. Not only does he learn intriguing bits of information from his retarded brother, who has worked in the house as helper for a renovation company and who briefly knew the victim; he also becomes powerfully attracted to the newly widowed and increasingly terrified Marcia Middleton.This is part ghost story, part mystery/suspense novel, and it's top drawer despite being its author's second published book. "Christopher A. Bohjalian" has since gone on to become Chris Bohjalian, writer of acclaimed mainstream and historical fiction. I'm loving his later books, but part of me wishes he had written more mysteries. This one kept me turning pages until I'd finished it, long after midnight, in a single session.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

In 1981 Vermont, 34-year-old midwife Sybil Danforth finds herself trapped by an ice storm at the home of a patient who needs to be transferred to a hospital. Sybil has never hesitated to take that step when it's been warranted, and the physician who acts as her backup has complete trust in her judgment after years of seeing her decisions proved sound. This time, though, the weather and inoperative phone lines conspire to keep Sybil's patient from getting to the hospital in time to save her life. So the midwife, who has no surgical training - she's never even seen a C-section performed - asks her assistant and the baby's father to bring her the sharpest knife in the house. Meanwhile, she verifies that the mother no longer has a heartbeat or respiration. The woman has died, and the only hope for her baby is to get it out as quickly as possible.That's what Sybil does. But just hours later, after the improving weather allows her to get both patients - deceased mother and living infant - to the hospital, her young and inexperienced assistant telephones the backup physician and unburdens herself: she thinks the mother may have been alive when Sybil cut her open. Soon the State Police are at the Danforth home, and Sybil finds herself charged with manslaughter that could be elevated to second degree murder.The story is narrated by Connie, Sybil's 14-year-old only child, who has since become an obstetrician. It's a tense tale, authentic to its rural setting and to the times when former hippies like the Danforths were raising their families and finding ways to apply their 60s values in a 1980s world. Part of the story is about Connie's maturing toward womanhood, and part of it is about Sybil. Is it about midwifery as a life's work? (I can't say "as a profession," since Sybil is unlicensed and apprenticeship trained.) To some extent, yes. But mostly, it's about how people with non-mainstream values perceive themselves and how the larger culture perceives and treats them.If gray areas make you uncomfortable, this isn't likely to be the book for you. But if you find them fascinating, as I do, then you just may enjoy it as thoroughly as I did.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Journalism professor, master's degree candidate, military wife for 13 years, mother of three young boys. Newspaper columnist Sarah Smiley has her hands full during the year of husband Dustin's deployment, and that's an understatement for sure. Navy Lieutenant Commander Smiley is stationed at the Bangor, Maine Naval Recruiting Center, so for the first time in her married life Sarah has no base with other military families to understand what her life is like and provide empathy as well as support. Actually, make that for the first time in her life, really; for Sarah is a former military "brat" as well as a Navy wife.Being the only adult in the house means never fully relaxing, even into sleep. "How do you do it all?" is a question Sarah answers, to herself at least, with another question: "How can I NOT do it all?" For there's no one else. She struggles with small things her husband always took care of before, like knowing when to tip and how much; but it's the big things, like having the sewer back up and flood the basement, that send her off the rails. Still, even from thousands of miles away in Africa, Dustin manages to give her a surprising amount of support. One thing he does even before leaving is encourage a random idea for helping his family pass the time constructively: Why not invite someone to fill his empty chair at the dinner table, one night a week? Someone interesting, who may be famous and important; or who may be important only to the Smileys, such as an elderly neighbor or youngest son Lindell's preschool teacher. They start with Senator Susan Collins, and before the year ends and Dustin comes home they've also entertained three former governors and a congressman. Not to mention a long list of others, some chosen for what they can teach the Smiley youngsters; and some for what the Smileys can give to them.This is an honest book. Achingly so, at times. At the end Sarah's afterword speaks about that honesty to her oldest son, for whom this was a preteen year - difficult enough even without his father being away. She also speaks about the photographer whose work illustrates the story, who became part of the family (a surprise to everyone, photographer Andrea included). Sarah Smiley writes engagingly, in her newspaper columns as well as here. This is nonfiction not to be missed.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of "Love, Jimmy: A Maine Veteran's Longest Battle"

Cherijo Grey Veil doesn't remember the past four years of her life, because during those years a new personality lived in her body. That personality called herself Jarn, and she was "born" when a head injury that would have killed anyone but the virtually immortal Cherijo wiped out the doctor's personality. But Jarn is gone now, and Cherijo is back. Her young daughter doesn't remember her, and quite understandably wants her mama, Jarn. Cherijo's husband, Duncan Reever, has profoundly mixed feelings because he fell in love with Jarn in a way he never had loved Cherijo. But others are delighted and relieved to have her back, and among those others is her "clanbrother" from her first marriage to a native of Joren. That marriage resulted in her adoption by one of Joren's clans, and eventually in her membership on the planet's ruling council.As predicted by Maggie, Cherijo's alien foster mother, the black crystal that has been growing on worlds throughout the galaxy now awakens. It is capable of devouring whole civilizations, and that's exactly what it is doing. Joren is inaccessible to the crystal - one of only two such planets - but that provides only a temporary reprieve; and in the meantime, Joren is overrun by desperate refugees. So Cherijo and Duncan set out on the starship Sunlace, and soon find themselves pulled through a rift into the far past of Maggie's native world. Can Cherijo now do what according to Maggie she was born to do, and find a way to defeat the black crystal? And if she can accomplish that near miracle, what is it going to cost both Cherijo and the family she loves?I've read the whole "StarDoc" series, of which this is the concluding volume, and I've come away surprised at how well the whole story arc worked. Some novels in the series are better than others, naturally; but the beginning and ending are both strong. Cherijo isn't always easy to like, but she's well drawn and believable as a person despite her fantastic origin and abilities. The worlds and cultures depicted are also believable, and even the most alien characters remarkably easy to understand. Well worth the read!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction ECherijo Grey Veil doesn't remember the past four years of her life, because during those years a new personality lived in her body. That personality called herself Jarn, and she was "born" when a head injury that would have killed anyone but the virtually immortal Cherijo wiped out the doctor's personality. But Jarn is gone now, and Cherijo is back. Her young daughter doesn't remember her, and quite understandably wants her mama, Jarn. Cherijo's husband, Duncan Reever, has profoundly mixed feelings because he fell in love with Jarn in a way he never had loved Cherijo. But others are delighted and relieved to have her back, and among those others is her "clanbrother" from her first marriage to a native of Joren. That marriage resulted in her adoption by one of Joren's clans, and eventually in her membership on the planet's ruling council.As predicted by Maggie, Cherijo's alien foster mother, the black crystal that has been growing on worlds throughout the galaxy now awakens. It is capable of devouring whole civilizations, and that's exactly what it is doing. Joren is inaccessible to the crystal - one of only two such planets - but that provides only a temporary reprieve; and in the meantime, Joren is overrun by desperate refugees. So Cherijo and Duncan set out on the starship Sunlace, and soon find themselves pulled through a rift into the far past of Maggie's native world. Can Cherijo now do what according to Maggie she was born to do, and find a way to defeat the black crystal? And if she can accomplish that near miracle, what is it going to cost both Cherijo and the family she loves?I've read the whole "StarDoc" series, of which this is the concluding volume, and I've come away surprised at how well the whole story arc worked. Some novels in the series are better than others, naturally; but the beginning and ending are both strong. Cherijo isn't always easy to like, but she's well drawn and believable as a person despite her fantastic origin and abilities. The worlds and cultures depicted are also believable, and even the most alien characters remarkably easy to understand. Well worth the read!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"P

Cherijo Grey Veil has lived her whole life, all 28 years, as her father - famous surgeon Joseph Grey Veil - wanted her to live it. She's known nothing but education and work, and she is now herself a brilliant surgeon. But Cherijo discovers something about her father that drives her out of his home and away from Earth, where he could still control her. She contracts her services to a colony world where Terrans are a small and not particularly valued minority of the population, and where she will be one of a pitifully small number of physicians caring for people whose species vary so much that some Cherijo doesn't even recognize as people until she's told that is what they are.Can she make it on her own? Can she learn how to treat nonhuman patients without receiving formal training - by figuring it out as she goes, sometimes at a breakneck pace? That would be challenge enough, but her father is determined to force her back to Earth. Then there's the epidemic that strikes the colony, a contagion which doesn't turn up on medical scanners and doesn't seem to care what species it attacks. Among the epidemic's victims is the handsome alien warrior whom Cherijo has swiftly come to love, to whom she has betrothed herself. Can she save his life, and stop the epidemic? And what will happen after she learns another and even more frightening of her father's secrets?This first novel in a series is crackling, fast-paced science fiction that reminds me of old-fashioned space opera. I won't speak to the science; other reviewers have already done so, and medical terminology isn't my field despite one long-ago college course. What I can speak to is story and characterization. Both are up to standard.A good, solid series debut, to which I've come years later. I'm definitely going to continue reading these books.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Ten years after her kidnapping and eventual rescue, Elizabeth Smart wrote this book (with ghostwriter Chris Stewart) to tell her own story. This is a different book entirely from the one published by her parents, and it should be. Elizabeth's viewpoint is that of the survivor, and "survivor" is the right word. "Victim" is not.I've read with interest some reviews in which readers express bafflement that Elizabeth should feel the need to defend her actions during her captivity. I don't find it surprising at all. Unfortunately, there were at the time - and there still are - far too many other people who express puzzlement that she didn't find a way to escape, or that she didn't take what seem to those people clear opportunities to ask for rescue. Elizabeth is clear with both herself and her readers: she did what she felt she had to do in order to survive. And she did survive. She also managed to heal. I'm not going to argue with how she did those things, because they worked for her. And that is what matters.With that said, the book is well written and well organized. Elizabeth understands what happened to her, and why; and she expresses herself clearly. It's difficult reading at times because of the subject matter, but ultimately it's a story of triumph. Love and faith were enough to bring this young woman through, and love and faith have also been enough to sustain her afterward.As for whatever she chose not to share with those of us reading her book - she has that right. I won't judge her for exercising it.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of "Love, Jimmy: A Maine Veteran's Longest Battle"

In 2004 Chicago, a long retired Parks Department employee buys an opera ticket and an antique gun - a German Luger - so he can complete a self-assigned mission. He wants to force opera patron, businessman, and beloved philanthropist Elliot Rosenzweig to admit he's really Otto Piatek, a Nazi war criminal. The twist is that the retiree, Benjamin Solomon, and Otto Piatek grew up as foster brothers. Seeing "Rosenzweig" on a PBS broadcast, and realizing the man who betrayed both Ben and his family is not only still alive but living a prosperous and respectable life in the same city where Ben has lived since emigrating after the war, is more than the old man can take. He has to prove, in public, that this civic leader is both a butcher and a thief.Attorney Catherine Lockhart works impossible hours for a top-paid law firm, representing corporate clients. She's only two years past a breakdown, and happy to have a job at all - let alone one as prestigious and lucrative as this. But when asked by her lifelong best friend, a private investigator who believes in Ben Solomon's cause, she first reluctantly hears the old man out; and then she becomes equally determined to bring Otto Piatek to justice.I'm surprised that this is a first novel, because the writing is competent the techniques the author uses work well. The story is a compelling one, and the characters - present day as well as presented to our view from Ben Solomon's memories - demanded that I care about them. A two-evening read for me, even though the subject matter was anything else but comfortable.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of "Love, Jimmy: A Maine Veteran's Longest Battle"

A criminal genius targets forensic psychologist and Washington, DC detective Alex Cross, delving into Cross's life without his knowledge and then using what he learns to torture Cross by kidnapping his family. That's become almost a tired device for this series, but - to my surprise and pleasure - it works very well in this book nevertheless.Is the man's name really Thierry Mulch? What does he look like without a disguise? Is he, with or without his partner and lover's assistance, responsible for one series of gruesome murders, or for two such series? Cross has been on Mulch's trail for weeks before the mastermind moves against Cross's family - 91-year-old grandmother, second wife who's also a D.C. detective, teen-aged son and daughter from his first marriage, and grade school son by a lover who's no longer part of his life. Mulch models himself on the protagonist of CRIME AND PUNISHMENT, and his goal is to convince Alex Cross that life has no meaning. That the only valid reason for anyone's actions can be stated as: "Because I can."By the time this book ends (sort of; it's actually a monumental cliffhanger), Munch has put Cross through the ringer. While I understand very well the reviewers who've come away from this read feeling angry and cheated, I came away feeling relieved by the direction the plot turned during the last few pages; and although I don't like having to wait for the next book, I'm more than willing to do so. The rest of this story ought to be a humdinger!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs" (full disclosure:  I borrow my James Patterson books from the library, so wasting money on "half a book" isn't an issue with me)

NYPD detective Michael Bennett arrested drug lord Manuel Perrine, and Perrine - who has since escaped from custody - intends to kill not only Bennett himself, but his family, too. So the 10 adopted Bennett children, their Irish nanny Mary Catherine, and Michael's grandfather Seamus (who entered the priesthood as an aging widower) have gone into the witness protection program. They're hiding on a remote high desert ranch, and in some ways Bennett's delighted with the effect of country life on his kids. But they all miss New York City, and the adults know that it's only a matter of time before Perrine's far reaching organization locates them. Nowhere is truly safe.Meanwhile, Perrine has declared war on the Mob. In a series of daring and terrifying raids, his people murder leaders who have angered Perrine by refusing to do business with him. The FBI decides it needs Michael Bennett's expertise, desperately enough to bring him out of hiding. They assign Federal marshals to protect his family, and Bennett goes back to work - only this time, it's for the Feds. Can he bring Perrine down before the drug lord's operatives find his family? That's the question.This is James Patterson at his best, in a fast paced, deftly plotted thriller that's all the more enjoyable for its depiction of the Bennetts. Lots of fun to read!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Belfa "Bell" Elkins grew up in Acker's Gap, West Virginia, and thought she'd never want to return. She and husband Sam headed off to Washington, D.C. with toddler daughter Carla, and not long after they settled there Bell became restless. So she went to law school, and joined Sam's profession. But Bell, unlike Sam, didn't want to spend her career taking care of lobbyists - she found herself needing to go home and fill the terrible needs in Acker's Gap for people with her training and her passion for justice. Now she's the county's prosecutor, and her closest friend is still the local cop who took her under his wing on the night 10-year-old Bell lost everything.People in Acker's Gap have long memories. Of course they know who Bell Dolan's people were. But the local cop who was a rookie when Bell was 10 years old is the sheriff now, and Bell herself has become an accomplished and respected professional woman. Her chosen battle is against the prescription drug trade that's brought big city crime to the hills, but even she doesn't at first view it as a likely motive when three old men are gunned down in a local eatery one Saturday morning. Carla Elkins, now a sullen teenager, is among the witnesses. Carla thinks she may have recognized the shooter. Does she tell her mother that, though? Or anyone in law enforcement? Of course not. She's a teenager, and she needs to do whatever she does on her own. She has no idea what kind of danger she's courting. Nor does Bell know how much danger she's placing herself in by pursuing her crusade.This is a rich novel, one that feels just as literary as mystery-like. Author Keller knows the people and place of her setting intimately, and she writes about them with an honesty that's both beautiful and frightening. Normally I'm infuriated by unresolved endings; but when this book came to its end, the ambiguity was perfect. I'm heading for the library tonight to pick up the sequel!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Claudine Burroughs, a well-to-do woman who childless marriage has proved to be loveless and frustrating, has found fulfillment working with ill and injured prostitutes at a clinic run by former Crimean War nurse Hester Monk. Claudine's position in society still requires her to attend a round of holiday social events that, while they often bore her, at least offer chances for her to raise funds for the clinic. She's at such a gathering when she happens into the company of poet Dai Tregarron, who charms her even though she's surprised to see him where he clearly does not fit. Soon afterward, a prostitute lies dead on her wealthy host's terrace. Three young men who do belong at the gathering according to their social class claim that they saw Tregarron attack the woman, and that it took all three of them to subdue him - too late to save her life. That isn't what Claudine believes happened. As Tregarron tries to stay ahead of the law, and Christmas rapidly approaches, Claudine takes on the job of investigating the crime (since the police aren't likely to consider any story except the one the socially prominent young men have told them) and hopefully proving Tregarron innocent. She seeks help in doing so from the Portpool Lane Clinic's bookkeeper, a former brothel owner who started out disliking her but who has over time come to accord her a grudging respect.This is a bittersweet short novel, with its protagonist looking back on her own life and acknowledging its errors as she does her best to help another woman avoid them. That thread makes the story work. It's a quick, easy read, but one that should make any 21st Century woman think about how fortunate she is to have been born to this era instead of to Claudine's.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Charlotte "Charlie" McNally, veteran investigative reporter for a Boston TV station, has just become engaged to private school teacher Josh Geltson. The two of them have plans to tell the divorced Josh's young daughter, Penny, about their decision; but as usual, Charlie's personal life has to take a back seat when she finds herself in possession of a possible scoop. She believes that someone is "cloning" auto VINs (vehicle identification numbers) in order to make stolen cars vanish from law enforcement's radar. She also thinks that rental agencies and used car dealers alike may be putting customers at risk of renting or purchasing cars with unresolved safety recalls, and cars that have had their air bags stolen and replaced with newspapers. Of course Charlie has to pursue the investigation. But in the meantime, she's moving from her condo into Josh's faculty housing on his private school's campus. There's something strange going on there, too. Josh doesn't want Charlie to investigate, and no one seems to want the police involved; but when threatening phone calls to staff and faculty members expand to include students' parents, and when two beloved members of the school's staff die mysteriously, Charlie can't help herself. As she told her mother when she was a little girl reading the final chapter of a Nancy Drew book first: "I hafta know!"Charlie at 47 has never before confronted the difficult job of balancing a partner and child's needs with the demands of her career, and she certainly has never before been a faculty spouse. Besides which, her producer, working partner, and dear friend Franklin is acting odd; and Charlie, who hates secrets, has to keep a huge one after her boss insists that she do so. Even from Franklin.This fourth novel in the series is the best one yet. Ryan's plotting and characterization are both deft, and the book's ending is both surprising and - as the ending of a good mystery ought to be - somehow inevitable. More Charlie McNally, please! Soon!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Charlotte "Charlie" McNally, investigative reporter for a Boston TV station, fights her way off an airplane awaiting departure because she thinks she's scented a developing story. When she learns that she's mistaken, and finds herself stranded overnight, she discovers the silver lining in the disappointing situation when a different story presents itself. She realizes that something strange is happening with baggage claims at Boston's Logan Airport. Also, a woman who's collecting luggage from the same carousel as Charlie lets the reporter know that she can buy designer purses (or rather, knockoffs of those designs) on the cheap if she attends a "party" in the small town of Great Barrington.Charlie and her producer, Franklin, plot to air their fashion espionage story even though it's not what Channel 3's management (as personified by "consultant" Suzanne) wants them working on. Meanwhile, Charlie and the divorced private school teacher who's been her lover for the past year hit inevitable conflicts in their developing relationship. Can Josh accept Charlie as she is, work life that eats up private time and all? Can Charlie find a way to balance her growing commitment to Josh and his young daughter, Penny, with the career she chose 25 years ago and cannot even imagine giving up?This third novel in the Charlie McNally series once again includes a romance, and it's pivotal to the main character's life; but the book itself isn't a romance novel, no matter how the publisher chose to classify it. It's a mystery, and a good one. Lighter than Ryan's Jane Ryland novels, but fast moving, well written, and not easy to put down.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Senator Kerry Kilcannon learned politics in his boyhood, tutored by his godfather. He never really knew his much older brother, James; but after an assassin's bullet brought Jamie down during his run for the presidency, Kerry stepped into the role. Now Kerry is fighting to win the Democratic Party's nomination. As he races from event to event, he's stalked - without knowing it, of course - by an assassin of his own. One who has history with Kerry.He also has a secret to keep. The incumbent vice president, his opponent, has learned through a counselor's confidentiality breach that several years ago, Kerry's affair with a lovely reporter ended in the woman's choosing to abort his child. Kerry is divorced now, but he was still married then. And now, once again, Lara Costello is covering his campaign. Both careers, the candidate's and the correspondent's, will go down if the Mason campaign leaks their past history to the press.Those are the two major plot lines of this political thriller that, while it didn't have me on the edge my seat, nevertheless demanded that I finish it. It's a fine book. I skimmed my way through much of the two later books in the Kilcannon trilogy, with enough interest in Kerry and Lara remaining for me to give this initial volume a try. I really did enjoy it. Well written, well plotted, excellent characterization. I'll have to give Richard North Patterson's less political novels a try, since I love his writing despite my lack of enthusiasm for political intrigue.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

TV reporter Charlotte "Charlie" McNally has her hands full, as usual. Her station's hired a consultant to implement changes meant to attract a younger audience, and that consultant decides to treat July as if it were the November sweeps for ratings purposes. Her mother's not only in town, but hospitalized at an upscale plastic surgery clinic where Mrs. McNally - who will soon remarry - has undergone several procedures at once. When she's contacted by attorneys from an organization dedicated to reversing the convictions of prisoners it believes innocent, she and her producer, Franklin Parrish, jump on the chance to interview a notorious convicted murderer. If Dorinda Sweeney confessed falsely to killing her husband, then interviewing her in prison could provide Charlie with top ratings. But what happens if Dorie doesn't want to be interviewed, and isn't interested in having her conviction overturned? Why do people connected with the now three-year-old case start dying, and is snoopy Charlie going to be next?This fast-paced mystery's subplot continues Charlie's romance (begun in "Prime Time") with Josh Geltsen, as the divorced teacher introduces his 8-year-old daughter to his girlfriend. Charlie has no idea how to get Penny to talk to her, much less warm up to her and accept her relationship with Josh. Author Ryan does a good job of weaving this conflict into the primary plot, using Charlie's conflicted relationship with her own mother as the link.Well written and well paced. I'm enjoying this series very much indeed.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Attorney Caroline Masters left her family's summer home on Martha's Vineyard over 20 years ago, and has returned this summer for a solitary sailing vacation. She hasn't, in all those years, visited the family's permanent and historic home on Masters Hill in Resolve, New Hampshire. Nor has she been in touch with anyone from her earlier life. She moved to San Francisco, put herself through law school, and didn't look back. She had powerful reasons for making that drastic choice - but now, she can do nothing else but answer her aging father's summons. Even though doing so for this particular reason puts her nomination as a Federal appeals court judge in jeopardy.Caroline's niece, Brett Allen, stands accused of murdering her boyfriend.
