As the story unfolds, we learn that Brett Allen is Caroline's niece by adoption; but she is also Caroline's daughter, born 22 years ago and given up to Caroline's sister and brother-in-law at the age of three days. Caroline has no intention of telling Brett who she really is, but she cannot do otherwise when her father and sister (and brother-in-law Larry, whom she once considered a friend) ask her to help the girl avoid being charged with the crime - or, if this does happen, to defend Brett in court. It's not wise for a lawyer to take on the defense of someone close, and the possible adverse publicity from doing so could cause the president to withdraw Caroline's nomination. Caroline knows all that. So does the retired judge who is her father. But she can't help herself; she must do all she can for Brett, at any cost.I made the mistake of reading a political book as my introduction to Richard North Patterson, and I almost decided he wasn't the right author for me. Still, that first book - "Protect and Defend" - included such an intriguing character in Caroline Masters that I wanted to read the earlier novel in which she's the protagonist. That's this novel, and it is superb. Long, yes; but no scene is wasted, and the story twists and turns as Caroline struggles with the moral dilemma of her life. Will she be able to protect Brett? Is Brett innocent or guilty? And how badly will Caroline have to tarnish her own integrity before she's fulfilled her duty to her secret daughter? An absolute page turner of a book. I still don't care much for political novels, but if Richard North Patterson has more works like this then I must read them!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

TV reporter Charlotte McNally needs a story that will bring her Boston station top ratings during the November sweeps. In her middle 40s now, Charlie knows that winning a series of Emmys doesn't mean she can stop worrying about someone younger and cheaper taking her job away for her. She'd better keep on winning, both awards and ratings. But one story keeps pushing other leads aside; and unfortunately, it's a story that her young boss has ordered her not to pursue.Charlie's producer and good friend, Franklin, proves to be her faithful ally as she investigates a series of mysterious e-mails that seem connected to the death of a man in an apparent single car crash. Refinancing spam, right? Wrong. So Charlie suspects; and as she becomes certain, she realizes that the car crash was murder, indeed. Figuring out exactly who's behind the mystery waits, though, until very close to the book's end.Hank Phillippi Ryan wrote this book long before her two wonderful Jane Ryland novels, and I ordered it doubtfully when I noticed it was classified as a romance. It does include a romance, one that's funny and poignantly easy to believe, but it is actually a mystery. A well-plotted, well-written mystery, not as deft as either Jane Ryland book but a highly enjoyable tale nevertheless. I'm going to read the rest of the Charlie McNally novels for sure.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

They're on their way to the Italian mainland from their base in Sicily. The year is 1943, and this planeload of nurses and medics from the 807th Medical Air Evacuation Transport Squadron expects to land, performs its usual duties, and then return to base. Instead, fierce weather conditions and a lack of the codes required to get help from the ground combine to send them far off course. Only after their crash landing in mountainous terrain do they learn that they've strayed all the way across the Adriatic Sea, and have come down in Nazi-occupied Albania. While no one has died, there are injuries; and a long, dangerous distance stretches between the stranded Americans and the coast. Friendly partisans appear right after the crash, but the conflict between Albania's two "freedom fighter" groups may prove just as deadly to the survivors as the winter weather and the lack of food for even the kindest villagers to share.After the war, the nurses and medics of the 807th - it's no spoiler to say that they were, eventually, rescued - kept silent about their ordeal. Not only had they been ordered to do so, orders that the war's end did not change; Albania in the post-war years remained a perilous place for those who had helped the Americans, and silence was the only way to protect them. Finally, though, came the collapse of Soviet Communism in Europe as well as in the USSR itself. At last the one remaining 807th medic, now an old man living in a retirement community, could talk to author Cate Lineberry. So could the survivors of the other former captives, as some of them discovered unpublished materials - even a completed memoir manuscript, in one case - left behind by their deceased parents.I've been reading World War II nonfiction since I was a high school freshman, and that was going on 50 years ago. This isn't the best written book of its sort that I've encountered, but it tells a previously unknown and important story well enough so that I gulped it down in an evening. I especially valued finding out what the post-war period brought to the partisans who helped the stranded Americans. The cost of their escape was a high one. As the daughter of a World War II Pacific theater veteran who until he grew very old also "just didn't want to talk about it," I value books like this one for what they capture while those who experienced this war are still with us to share their memories.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of "Love, Jimmy: A Maine Veteran's Longest Battle"

Claire Elliot moved to Tranquility, Maine several months ago, hoping for a new start with her teenaged son after the boy started getting in trouble. Noah didn't want to leave Baltimore, and both mother and son are still grieving two years after Claire's husband died of cancer. Tranquility does not take kindly to newcomers who move there year round. Although she bought the practice of the man who was the only local doctor, after his death, most of her patients have been summer visitors; and now, as winter approaches, Claire has far too open a schedule. She also has too few friends, but she knows she must keep her distance from the local police chief. Who is separated from his alcoholic wife, but still feels responsible for the woman - and who has, for Claire, the potential to become something closer than a friend.The town's teenagers grow restive as autumn wears on, and Claire finds herself patching up kids who have injured themselves or others in uncharacteristic outbursts of rage. When the outbursts turn serious, she starts wondering about rumors of something similar happening 50 years ago - so long that although the town's older residents remember it, the current generations of younger adults and children only know that they've been told to stay away from certain people. People like Claire's newest patient, an old man who comes to her notice during a very public seizure that causes his neighbors to draw away from him in terror instead of helping him as Claire knows they would anyone else. What is going on? Can she solve the mystery before it affects Noah, and before it gets her driven out of a town that would much rather ignore the mystery no matter what that may cost?Tess Gerritsen's competence as a writer made this book work quite well for me despite a final plot twist that I just couldn't accept. Someone else may be fine with that twist, though; and the story is well paced. I found the characters somewhat stereotyped, but not enough to ruin the read. Good, although not Gerritsen's best.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Boston medical examiner Maura Isles expects to spend a peaceful vacation with Julian "Rat" Perkins, the young man who saved her life in ICE COLD. Julian is a student at the Evensong boarding school in rural Maine, where every faculty member (Maura learns) belongs to the Mephisto Society. The students have one thing in common: every one of them has been the victim of violent loss. The three most recent arrivals have an additional similiarity. First, each survived the massacre of his or her family two years ago; and second, each has survived the recent murder of a foster family. Detective Jane Rizzoli, Maura's friend, is assigned to investigate the killings that happened in her jurisdiction. Then Maura calls her for help when strange and frightening things start to happen at Evensong, and soon Jane is putting together the pieces of a puzzle years old and spanning an ocean.Taut, well plotted, and intriguing, this book had me suspending what might otherwise be entirely reasonable disbelief. Its plot twists kept me engaged, and the final twist made sense even as it surprised me completely. Nicely done!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Sir Oliver Rathbone hasn't been a judge for long, and he's still adjusting to being separated - unwillingly - from his wife, Margaret. The unsavory case that cost him his wife's love does not appear to be harming his career, but the memory of it lingers. Arthur Ballinger, Margaret's father, operated a secret "club" for gentlemen who enjoyed forcing themselves on small boys. After Ballinger was convicted in spite of Rathbone's best attempt at defending him, Ballinger was murdered in prison. For that, Margaret blames Oliver, who has managed to protect her from knowing the worst about her father. Ballinger's final revenge was leaving his collection of pornographic photos to his son-in-law. Those photos were taken as the price of each member's admission to his "club," each photograph showing the would-be member performing an illegal act with a child.Rathbone often wishes he had destroyed the collection as soon as it was delivered to him, but so far he has not been able to give up the power over evil men that it represents. When a case before his court is clearly going wrong, with a clergyman who has defrauded and impoverished his flock about to be acquitted although Rathbone is certain of the man's guilt, the judge does what he knows he has no business doing. He takes from the collection an image of the defense's most vital witness, and uses it to influence the case; and he does so without recusing himself. Soon after that he finds himself under arrest for perverting the course of justice.River Police Commander William Monk and his wife, Hester, a former army nurse who operates a clinic for sick and injured prostitutes, have been Rathbone's friends for years now. They are also the foster parents of 13-year-old Scuff, who was a street urchin and one of Arthur Ballinger's captives. Helping Rathbone now is risky for them, but Hester played a key role in launching the case of the fraudulent clergyman; and Monk, by his nature, feels driven to seek the truth even after his superiors order him to have nothing to do with the accused and imprisoned judge. As for Scuff, the boy is still learning to trust his new parents' love and the safety their home offers. If they let Rathbone go down in order to keep themselves from sharing his disgrace, what lesson will they teach Scuff? That love is always conditional?My one criticism of Anne Perry's latest Victorian mystery is the amount of time it took to get to Rathbone's disgrace and arrest. For me the book dragged during the long courtroom scenes leading up to that moment; but I don't know how the author could have avoided those scenes, or shortened them, without sacrificing vital elements of her plot. After that point it was a page turner of the first rank. 4 1/2 stars rounded up to 5.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

It will soon be Christmas in northern Minnesota. In Tamarack County, an elderly woman - wife of a retired judge - disappears, leaving her car out of gas and abandoned. Her husband, who left the bench under a cloud, appears to be fast spiraling down into dementia. Private investigator Cork O'Connor, who used to be sheriff, doesn't immediately connect this possible crime with another that happens nearby, on the Ojibwe reservation. A friendly dog who's being cared for by the family of a man serving a short county jail sentence is lured with meat and then decapitated. One possible serious crime, assuming that Evelyn Clark hasn't simply become lost in the blizzard that closed down shortly after her disappearance, and one chilling but legally not-so-serious crime; both of which Cork investigates because that's what he does. When it becomes clear that the woman who was dog-sitting is being stalked, or that her teenaged daughter is the target (which, Cork can't immediately tell), the concern hits close to home because Cork's teenaged son is experiencing his first love with that pretty girl. Or is either the mother or the daughter actually the stalker's target? Meanwhile, Cork's middle child - daughter Anne, always the calm and sunny and grounded one - comes home early for Christmas, because she may be abandoning her long quest to become a nun. The widowed lawman is also unsettled by the loneliness and uncertainty of having a woman he may love, and who may love him in return, go away and not ask for or give promises. Not about how the two of them should behave during their separation, and not about when (or even whether) she'll return.This newest installment in Krueger's excellent series lived up to my expectations, and then some. It had the twists and turns I've come to expect from this author, and it also had first rate characterizations of not just the O'Connors and their long time associates; as usual, it also did well with characters newly introduced. Krueger's work always has a depth to it that goes beyond the bounds of genre. In this case, each plot thread takes a different look at what love is and how people - healthy people and twisted ones, both - express that emotion.Thoroughly enjoyable--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Quebec's top homicide investigator, Chief Inspector Gamache, has had a difficult year. First he nearly died in a raid that went wrong, and his beloved second-in-command - a surrogate son, and prospective son-in-law - became addicted to prescription drugs after being gravely wounded in that raid. Then, as Gamache wrapped up the case of a cloistered monk's murder, his relationship with Jean-Guy Beauvoir went completely off the rails. Beauvoir went back to pill popping, egged on and even supplied by none other than the Surete du Quebec's commander in chief - a man who proceeds to transfer Gamache's people, one by one, to other divisions or otherwise get rid of them. Gamache is being sidelined, and his new detectives treat him with disrespect that sometimes becomes outright contempt. None of it seems to bother Gamache, though. Is he finally getting ready to retire? That's what everyone seems ready to assume.Meanwhile, an elderly woman named Constance Pineault plans a second visit to the southern Quebec village of Three Pines. She fails to arrive, and the woman she was to visit contacts Gamache because he's an old friend. Digging into the disappearance, which quickly turns out to be murder, reveals that "Pineault" was what Constance called herself; but not her real surname. Which some of the quirky Three Pines villagers already know...but to others, the truth is a shocker when it's revealed.Gamache has two cases on his plate by then, as he realizes that the apparent suicide of a government clerk was actually a murder. A murder committed to hide a conspiracy decades in the making, that will - unless Gamache can unravel the mystery it presents in time - result in an act of domestic terrorism that could shatter the Dominion forever.I always enjoy two things in particular about Louise Penny's novels. First, I love her characters. They have layers and nuances; no one is a cardboard cutout, or even comes close to being one. Second, I love the way she draws apparently unrelated plot threads together so that by the book's end it is clear to me that they always were related. I just couldn't see it until the author was ready to show it to me.An elegant and touching read, as well as a fine mystery.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Seattle detective J.P. Beaumont works for the Attorney General's special homicide squad now, and he's happily married to a colleague there. He's come a long way from the alcoholic rookie detective who finally won over his first partner, a veteran cop nicknamed Pickles. When that man's daughter calls Beaumont on New Year's Eve and asks if she may bring him something she found while cleaning out her parents' home following her mother's death, Beau isn't expecting what the woman delivers. Pickles aspired to write a book about his career; and his daughter wants Beau to have the chapter about their partnership.That's the framing story for this novella that does a fine job of contrasting the young man Beaumont once was with the mature detective he eventually becomes. I read it at the hairdresser's; it's a quick one, due to its brief length, but it's a "don't miss" for series fans.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Sarah Fontaine wakes to a ringing telephone, and learns that her husband of two months has died in a hotel fire. The problem is that Geoffrey is supposed to be staying in London, on business; but the State Department caller says he died in Berlin. What is going on? Sarah sets out to answer that question, and soon Nick D'Arcy - the man who called her with the news - finds himself on involuntary leave, and following her as she heads for London in search of answers.This is definitely a romance novel, not a medical thriller. It's one of Tess Gerritsen's Harlequin titles, written before she changed genres; and taken on its own terms, it works fine. It's not a book for the reader who's expecting Gerritsen's more recent work, though.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Recently divorced Julia Hamill digs in the garden of her 1830s Boston cottage and finds a skeleton. While it's too old to be a medical examiner case, it's definitely a murder victim - but whose skeleton is it?In 19th Century Boston, medical student Norris Marshall struggles against an impoverished background to get his education and enter a profession for which he has both passion and aptitude. More aptitude, in fact, than some of his much wealthier classmates. In order to fund his studies, he assists a grave robber. That's how the medical school gets cadavers for its students to dissect. Norris watches the way women in the teaching hospital's maternity ward are treated with disapproval, sympathy, and even horror; for it's an era when doctors do not know they need to wash their hands. He takes an interest in immigrant Rose Connolly, who has come to the hospital with her married sister for the birth of the sister's baby. Aurnia dies following her daughter's difficult delivery, a victim of childbed fever - the infection doctors commonly spread from patient to patient, without knowing themselves to be the cause. Rose takes her newborn niece and runs when the hospital's head nurse informs her that she must give the child up; and Norris soon realizes there's more going on than charitable services deciding Rose isn't suited to care for a baby alone. Meanwhile, people in the hospital's neighborhood start dying. Rose, witness to one of the first in a series of murders, therefore has added reason to hide herself and Meggie.That's the setup for this story which switches back and forth between centuries, a device that works surprisingly well. The difficulty I had with this book was caring about its characters as I needed to care in order to enjoy it fully. I didn't get on board with that until a present-day octogenarian joined the cast. It did happen then, though!A good story overall, but not as compelling as other Gerritsen thrillers I've read.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Boston medical examiner Maura Isles has reached a turning point in her life. She knows it's time to end her clandestine love affair with a Roman Catholic priest who clearly isn't going to leave his church for her, and leaving town for a few days to attend a pathology conference in Wyoming gives her time in which to think about her future. It also prompts her to consider changing her usual careful way of behaving. When an old classmate from medical school invites her to join him, along with his 13-year-old daughter (he's divorced) and two of his friends who are a couple as they head for a ski lodge instead of flying home promptly after the conference's end, Maura accepts. She soon regrets it, though. Her old classmate insists on driving where the GPS in his rented Suburban directs him, and the result is the group becoming stranded high in the mountains as winter's first major snowstorm closes in. They take shelter in a settlement that's clearly designed for off-the-grid living, and wonder why its inhabitants abandoned it so abruptly that they find meals still on dining tables. Abandoned pets now long dead, and vehicles stowed inside garages. What can possibly have happened, and who were these people, anyway? And without cell phone service, how can Maura and her companions hope for rescue before the seasonal road reopens when spring arrives? Those questions are scary enough. But the worst part is that they're not alone in the valley, after all.This installment in the Rizzoli and Isles series has the usual taut suspense, and having both lead characters carry the story - in alternating chapters (or blocks thereof) - always works well. Jane Rizzoli and her husband, FBI agent Gabriel Dean, search for their friend even after everyone else has given up; and even when a charred body found in the wreckage of a Suburban is identified as Maura, Jane is sure something's wrong. The tale's ending has a tragic but effective twist, and characters introduced in recent books appear again here in ways that make real contributions. This a series I'll continue to follow for sure.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Mark E. Nickerson always wanted to be a Maine State trooper, like his father before him. His father wanted Mark to be a dentist. Mark followed his own chosen career, and now - many years later, as a retiree - he has written about it. I don't remember meeting him during my own many years an employee of the State of Maine, but I do remember the era; it was mine, too. That added to my enjoyment of this volume of reminiscences gathered from Mark Nickerson's newspaper columns, but I suspect I would still have found it an interesting read if I'd come to it without that common background.Being a trooper isn't like being a TV cop. Especially, being a trooper on patrol in rural Maine isn't like being a law enforcement professional elsewhere. The stories Mark Nickerson tells are unique, and his writing style is plain and down to earth. Recommended for anyone who enjoys memoirs.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

The Discovery Channel is filming as a Boston hospital donates the services of its CAT scan laboratory to the examination of a mummy discovered in the basement of a local museum, and medical examiner Maura Isles is on the scene as an invited guest. She soon goes into official on-duty mode, though, because the scan shows two things it shouldn't. First, the mummy has modern dental work; and second, it's got a bullet embedded in one leg. A mummy it may be, but ancient Egyptian it's not. So how did it get into the Crispin Museum's basement, and how long has it been lying there?Homicide detective Jane Rizzoli isn't on the best of terms with her friend Dr. Isles, because even though Jane doesn't believe in the Roman Catholic faith of her childhood she nevertheless disapproves heartily of Maura's more or less secret liaison with a priest. Still, the two women must work together as usual on this case that soon widens as more meticulously preserved bodies are found; and as investigation ties the corpses to disappearances of young women, all of similar appearance, over a wide geographic span and over a period of 25 years.This one cost me the best part of a night's sleep. I made the mistake of starting to read it in the evening, and I found myself unable to fall asleep until I'd finished. While the regular characters from the series were in good form, I found myself drawn in and held by the characters introduced for this story only. THE KEEPSAKE is a fine mystery, for sure. But it's even better as a study of mothers and daughters, and the ties that bind them to each other.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Two young women are dead, and at both murder scenes Boston homicide detective Jane Rizzoli has found apparently satanic symbols. The murders themselves are horrific and ritualistic; they definitely aren't the work of a killer who's simply become angry enough to snap. Still, the very earthbound Rizzoli doesn't buy it at all when a mysterious organization that calls itself the Mephisto Club involves itself in her investigation. Medical examiner Maura Isles doesn't buy it, either; she's a scientist, and does not wish to believe in anything she cannot prove through evidence. Yet the Mephisto Club wants Dr. Isles as a member, and the killer must be aware of her because he (or she?) marks Maura's house. What's the involvement of Lily Saul, a young American woman on the run in Europe? From whom or what is Lily fleeing; and is she right to be afraid?This book's graphic detailing of violence and its aftermath might well have overloaded me (I haven't the world's strongest stomach) if author Gerritsen had not made this material such a necessary part of the story she had to tell. While I found the ending a bit disappointingly convenient, it retained enough creepiness to keep me from feeling truly let down. It takes a lot of skill for a writer to mix speculative fiction with another genre such as mystery/suspense and pull it off. Gerritsen does so here, and in fine style, too.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

How could this have happened? Dr. Maura Isles, Boston's medical examiner, asks that question after she discovers that the inhabitant of a body bag in her morgue is alive. The public wants answers, too; but things really get interesting when, once in the hospital, the "corpse" proceeds to take hostages. One of those hostages is a friend of Maura's, homicide detective Jane Rizzoli. Jane is there as a patient - she's been admitted to have her baby. The "Jane Doe" with the gun (stolen from a security guard who wasn't actually employed by the hospital) has an Eastern European accent, and she means business. Jane Rizzoli's husband, FBI agent Gabriel Dean, insists on working with the Boston PD crisis team that takes command of the situation; but he soon discovers that he's not the only Federal agent on the scene. Something strange is going on, and Gabriel fears that whatever it is may get priority over keeping his wife and unborn baby alive.This thriller demanded that I read it straight through. I like the ways in which Maura Isles is being fleshed out, as she continues as a major character in the series that started with Jane Rizzoli alone. The plot's resolution seemed a bit over the top to me, but I have to admit that it worked very well nevertheless. It certainly kept me turning pages.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Dr. Maura Isles, Boston's medical examiner, already knows she's adopted. She knows nothing about her birth family, though; so when a woman who looks exactly like her is shot to death while sitting in a car parked in front of Maura's house, she's astonished. She had an identical twin, and never knew it.Now it's up to Detective Jane Rizzoli and the rest of Boston's homicide division to solve the murder of a woman whose very name proves to be a mystery. Was she even the killer's target, or was Dr. Isles the intended victim? Maura now not only wants to know everything possible about her background; she needs to know, because that may be her key to staying alive. As the murder investigation and Maura's own search proceed, the pathologist begins to realize that her birth mother may be a convicted and mentally ill murderer. That the blood of killers may be running in her veins. How can she, a law enforcement professional as well as a scientist, deal with such knowledge?This book is decidedly Isles-centered, and it's a fine thriller. I found it a bit too bloody for my taste, but I'm squeamish and I know it; other readers will no doubt take those scenes in stride. The mystery works well, and author Gerritsen is wise not to try to explain evil. I guessed wrong about the final plot twist. Good; I hate it when I guess right every time a particular author tries to fool me, which Gerritsen does with success. An excellent piece of work, with my one complaint being that something seemed off about the pacing.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Two nuns lie on the floor in the convent's chapel. The young one, a girl of 20 who had yet to take her final vows, has been beaten to death. The older one, age 68, is still alive despite the beating she's taken. Boston homicide detective Jane Rizzoli does not enjoy being inside a convent; she stopped practicing her family's Catholic faith long ago, and besides that she is dealing with a secret dilemma of her own. Medical examiner Maura Isles, who attended Catholic schools as a girl, feels the old awe of nuns as she does her own job in this ugly situation. Did the murderer believe he'd killed both victims? Why did this happen, anyway? And, after Dr. Isles performs the autopsy and discovers that the 20-year-old nun had just given birth, what happened to the newborn baby?Author Gerritsen presents the reader with several different, apparently unrelated plot threads, and brings them together in ways that seem inevitable when it happens. Jane Rizzoli grows as a character, not necessarily becoming more likable but definitely becoming far more understandable and human. And as for Maura Isles, this is the book in which the medical examiner develops from a minor character into a major one. Her friendship with Rizzoli also develops, and those aspects of the book are just as satisfying as the mystery itself. Another keeper.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Jane Rizzoli, Boston homicide detective, has learned fear from a serial killer nicknamed the Surgeon. A year ago she apprehended him, and he's now behind bars; but she remembers far too well what it was like to become prey. Pinned to a cellar's dirt floor by scalpel blades driven through her palms, helpless until the victim she was seeking to rescue managed to shoot and disable their assailant...Jane checks her apartment every time she enters it, now. She has nightmares. And when a case she's investigating starts to show similarities to the Surgeon's M.O., she recognizes those similarities and speaks up about them - to the consternation of both her lieutenant, and FBI agent Gabriel Dean. This new serial killer, nicknamed the Dominator, also has his own M.O.; but soon the two merge, not long after the Surgeon escapes from prison. Now Gabriel Dean knows Jane Rizzoli is the pair's target, as the two serial killers work together, and Rizzoli doesn't seem interested in protecting herself if the cost of doing so must be thinking of herself as a victim. Rizzoli has never done that. And she doesn't want to start now.This taut thriller follows THE SURGEON, and it builds on that book's story in ways that might make it an awkward stand-alone read. Jane Rizzoli gains added dimensions as a character here, and two new arrivals - medical examiner Maura Isles, and FBI agent Gabriel Dean - become part of her life. I found Rizzoli authentic as a woman working in a "masculine" profession, in a generation for which this makes her a pioneer. I know about that; I wasn't a cop, but I did that, too.Scary and well paced, and I loved the foreshadowing at the story's end. I don't normally appreciate an author who makes me read the next book in a series; it usually makes me feel manipulated. But Tess Gerritsen does it with so much style and menace that I reacted by picking up the next book and starting to read it, eagerly. Just excellent!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Boston homicide detective Jane Rizzoli has spent her lifetime battling for acceptance in male dominated settings. She's learned to fight hard for the credit, when a male detective would not have to worry about receiving it; and she's learned those women who appear to be victims get nothing but scorn. She's also learned that a woman's physical appearance matters more than her skills and abilities. So she doesn't much like Dr. Catherine Cordell, the beautiful and gifted surgeon who relocated to Boston from Savannah two years earlier. Dr. Cordell crosses Jane's radar when a series of homicides shows marked similarities to an attack on Catherine Cordell, one in which she became the sole survivor of a madman's killing spree that ended when she managed to shoot him dead. Dr. Cordell has told no one in Boston, not even her partner and friend Peter Falco, about Savannah. But now, just as she thinks she has found a new life she can live in safety, either the Surgeon (so-called) has risen from the dead or a copycat is at work. In any case, soon he's taunting Catherine in ways that make it clear to Jane Rizzoli and fellow detective Thomas Moore than Dr. Cordell is the killer's ultimate target.I had my doubts about reading a thriller written by a physician, because blood and gore doesn't appeal to me. However, a tautly plotted book with characters worth caring about appeals to me very much indeed; and that's what I found THE SURGEON to be. I enjoyed it thoroughly, and I immediately picked up the second book in the Jane Rizzoli series. Excellent!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

San Francisco homicide detective Lindsay Boxer gives birth at last, at the age of 40, to a beautiful daughter. She does this during a storm-induced power outage, at home with a crew of firefighters helping her. Husband Joe Molinari, former Deputy Director of Homeland Security, arrives after the big event; but he's the one who stays at home with baby Julie, after his consulting contract is canceled due to budget cuts and Lindsay shows signs of needing to go back to work as soon as possible. She's a distracted new mother nevertheless, and even the awakening from coma of a convicted serial killer doesn't hold her attention when Julie has to be hospitalized with a mysterious blood condition. This particular killer has become obsessed with Lindsay, and he promises to reveal the dumping ground where he left his victims only if she will participate. Is he playing with the cops in general, and Lindsay in particular? Probably. Yet Sergeant Boxer can't refuse even a chance of finding those missing bodies and giving closure to the women's families.Meanwhile, medical examiner Claire Washburn - Lindsay's best friend - has to step aside for a hopefully temporary replacement after a body disappears from her morgue. A security guard also vanishes, and the investigation goes nowhere. Lindsay and partner Rich Conklin investigate a professor who claims he can "see" murders before they are committed; and ADA Yuki Castellano prosecutes a man who's on trial for murdering his wife and his young daughter. The wife's body has been found, but the daughter remains missing.As usual, there's a lot going on in this latest installment of the Women's Murder Club mysteries. Lindsay Boxer's crisis with her newborn has harrowing moments, and the murderer who's trying to mess with her mind (and to some extent succeeding) is downright creepy. I have to give this one five stars because I read it straight through. Couldn't put it down, and that is the simple truth. But I do hate it when a book ends with a cliffhanger...and this book does. Darn it all!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

San Francisco homicide detective Lindsay Boxer is pregnant at almost 40, after finally agreeing to marry her long time lover, former Deputy Homeland Security Director Joe Molinari. She's supposed to slow down, take it easy, and stay safe. But Boxer loves what she does, and she doesn't know how to dial it back when she and partner Rich Conklin must investigate two cases at once. First there's the garden at a famed actor's mansion, where heads are buried. Many heads, and the police still wouldn't know about them if someone hadn't dug up a couple and left them on display for the housekeeper to find. Second, there's a string of executions of known drug dealers; and the evidence strongly suggests a rogue cop is the shooter. Boxer's boss, Lieutenant Jackson Brady, thinks the shooter may be Chief of Police Warren Jacobi, who's on medical leave following hip replacement surgery. Who's also Boxer's former partner, a friend so dear to her that he gave her away at her wedding.The rest of the Women's Murder Club gang is very much part of this story, of course. Medical examiner Claire figures into it on her own, while ADA Yuki Castellano tries to figure out how to deal with two things about her new love, Jackson Brady. First, he's Lindsay's boss. And second, he's married. Reporter Cindy Thomas is now living with Rich Conklin, and that means she's pumping two "unnamed police sources" in her quest for newsworthy information - friend Lindsay plus partner Rich.The resolution of one mystery felt awfully convenient to me, but the other was both logical and just plain tragic. Lindsay's relationship with Joe plays a large part in the story, and I was sorry when (mild spoiler alert, stop reading if you don't want to know! line break to help with that)the case was solved before Joe started working Lindsay's case in his role as outside consultant. I'd have loved to see how THAT played out.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

A teenaged girl stumbles along a remote road in the dark of night, clad only in a rain poncho and bleeding in the aftermath of giving birth. When passersby call 911 and she's safe in a hospital, she tells differing stories to San Francisco homicide detective Lindsay Boxer; and veteran investigator Lindsay is sure none of those stories is true. What she does know is that somewhere out there the girl's baby, a boy (that much remains consistent), may still be alive. If Lindsay can find him in time.Meanwhile, ADA Yuki Castellano - also one of the four members of what reporter Cindy Thomas has jokingly dubbed the Women's Murder Club - prosecutes a case that she's sure she can win, because the evidence against the defendant seems overwhelming. When Lindsay Boxer learns there's new information about this case, and follows it up because one of Lindsay's subordinate detectives handled the investigation, Yuki is incensed. She needs this win, and besides that - she's sure the right person is standing trial. But Lindsay isn't sure; and until she figures things out to her own satisfaction, she will pursue the case in spite of orders from Lieutenant Jackson Brady to stand down. Brady and Yuki Castellano are dating, and that makes the whole thing even more uncomfortable for Lindsay.This is the book in which Lindsay Boxer finally marries her long time love, former Homeland Security Deputy Director Joe Molinari. She's pushing 40, and her biological clock starts going off big time now that she has the right partner. So dealing with a missing newborn bothers Lindsay even more than it normally would; and it's just as hard on her best friend, Claire, San Francisco's medical examiner, who has a baby daughter of her own as well as two much older sons. The anniversary referenced in the book's title is that of Claire and Lindsay's friendship, and I liked the idea of celebrating a relationship that for these two women is one of life's enduring touchstones. The plot threads sometimes get a bit entangled in this one, but overall it's a great read.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Reporter Cindy Thomas has dubbed the cat burglar "Hello Kitty." Kitty strikes while the wealthy owners of each burglarized home are downstairs entertaining, and his or her target is jewelry kept in a bedroom safe upstairs. Wealthy people usually leave such a safe unlocked while the lady of the house is wearing some of her finery, so Kitty can take the rest without delay or difficulty - until the Dowlings, a famed actor and his wife, walk in during the robbery. Marcus Dowling takes advantage of what he sees as the perfect chance to shoot his wife and blame it on an honest-to-goodness intruder. Meanwhile, homicide detective Lindsay Boxer and her partner are charged with solving a nasty string of shootings. The victims are always a young mother and her infant or small child, the venue is always a public place such as a parking garage, and the killer leaves behind a cryptic message written in lipstick. What does he want? And what will it take to stop him?Lindsay's engagement to former Deputy Director of Homeland Security Joe Molinari carries the couple into a transition period in their relationship, as they live together now that Joe has changed jobs and relocated to be with Lindsay. Her relationships with others are in transition, too; especially the one she shares with her handsome and considerably younger partner, who's thinking about moving in with her good friend Cindy.I liked the way PTSD figured into this book's plot, and I found the ways in which the two cases tied in together more credible than is sometimes true for this series. "People aren't always what they appear to be" forms one of the book's themes. On to #10! This series has its flaws, but I'm finding it addictive just the same.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Once again the women who jokingly call themselves "The Women's Murder Club" have different cases to deal with. Assistant District Attorney Yuki Castellano is hoping her losing streak may end with the conviction of a woman who bludgeoned her father to death and left her mother for dead - how could that go wrong, since the defendant's mother has identified her assailant in a video shot just after the crime? Homicide detective Lindsay Boxer is investigating the supposed death of a missing adolescent, Michael Campion, at a prostitute's home and place of business. Michael Campion is the son of a beloved former governor, and the heart defect he's had since birth makes his death during his first sexual experience all too plausible a possibility. Lindsay also has a serial killer or killers on her hands, as someone is talking his or her way into the homes of wealthy couples and committing robbery followed by murder. Murder by arson, leaving the victims bound and helpless to escape. Medical examiner Claire and reporter Cindy are less involved in this book than in some others of the series, although Claire goes on performing autopsies despite her advanced state of pregnancy.Lindsay's personal relationships go up and down in this story. She's finally living with her lover, former Homeland Security Deputy Director Joe Molinari, and he's given her an engagement ring; but she cannot bring herself to wear it, and accept his marriage proposal. She continues to struggle with sexual chemistry between her and her new partner, who's 10 years younger but doesn't care because he has an almost overwhelming crush on her. Will she ever dare to commit to Joe, despite knowing that she really does love him? And if not, how long will he wait after changing his whole life in order to be a day-to-day part of hers?It's possible for even a reader who loves Lindsay's character to get a bit impatient with her, and where Yuki is going I don't know after this book. However, as usual the plot threads came together by the story's end; and I really liked the final scene, in which readers find out something that Lindsay presumably never does.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

She was once a student at an exclusive private school, the acknowledged although illegitimate daughter of a rich and powerful man. When her father died, though, "Pet Girl" and her mother learned he'd made no provision for them. Suddenly they were poor, and decades later the adult she's become must use her girlhood connections to make a living by doing dog walking and other errands for women who were once her classmates. None of them hesitates to let her know how much they despise her now. "Pet Girl" has plans for them...all of them. Plans she's only now beginning to carry out.Wealthy, prominent couples are dying mysteriously, and autopsy results confound San Francisco's medical examiner. Homicide detective Lindsay Boxer has never seen her best friend baffled before, but this time Claire hasn't a clue why the men and women on her autopsy tables are dead. Meanwhile, reporter Cindy Thomas - another member of the "Women's Murder Club" - investigates the death of a street person, a man nicknamed Bagman Jesus and apparently beloved by all the fellow homeless folk who knew him; and Assistant DA Yuki Castellano starts falling in love for the first time in years. She's not thrilled that this is happening to her with a physician from the staff of San Francisco Municipal Hospital, where her mother died and where Yuki hates to see anyone treated. But that's where the man works, and it's been far too long since she felt this way about anyone.The twists and turns in this book kept me turning pages, as novels in this series usually do. I found the resolution, at least the part that tied two of the cases together, a bit too convenient; but otherwise the plot worked well. Lindsay's feelings about partner Rich's attraction to Cindy surprised me a lot less than they surprised Lindsay, and I liked the way that part turned out. I'll find the next chapter in Detective Boxer's life very interesting, I think. I plan to start reading it tonight.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Lieutenant Lindsay Boxer of the San Francisco Police Department's homicide squad has multiple cases on her hands, apparently thanks to two serial killers. The "car girl" murders leave attractive young women dead of suffocation, dressed in expensive clothing and posed inside luxury cars whose owners have nothing to do with the crimes. Meanwhile, at San Francisco Municipal Hospital, patients admitted through the ER die when there's no good reason for them to do so. Most of them are like Keiko, mother of Lindsay's friend Yuki Castellano. The 55-year-old woman is recovering well and due to go home the next day when she suddenly dies due to an accidental dose of a blood thinner - a massive dose, that ends her life just as surely as an equally erroneous dose of insulin ends that of a boy who isn't a diabetic. Each patient who dies due to such mysterious "human error" has buttons placed on his or her closed eyes, buttons with the medical profession's symbol on them. The hospital does not want anyone to know about the buttons, and it presents the deaths as tragic but genuine cases of medical treatment gone awry. Lindsay suspects and pursues the ER's head physician, while successful defense attorney Yuki stops going to work and obsesses about her mother's death to the point where her friends fear for her health.This taut thriller has plenty of twists and turns, and I enjoyed getting to know Yuki better. The "car girls" case wraps up a bit faster and more neatly than I would have preferred, but the ER deaths case has just the right resolution. A good one, all in all.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Some time ago Lieutenant Lindsay Boxer asked her captain to put her back on the street as a detective, and let someone else command the San Francisco PD's homicide squad. When she finally gets her wish, though, she's no longer certain the demotion is what she wants - especially when the new lieutenant turns out to be her former partner and close friend, Warren Jacobi. She finds herself paired with the handsome young detective who was Jacobi's most recent partner; and when she breaks off her long distance romance with Deputy Director of Homeland Security Joe Molinari, sparks start flying that could burn both detectives. Meanwhile, there's a case to be investigated; and one of its victims is Lindsay's best friend, the city's medical examiner. Claire survives the shooting on board a ferry, but others aren't so lucky when a former mental patient uses his gun to right some perceived wrongs.Is the man sane in the legal sense, or is he incapable of understanding what he has done? That question proves vital as this story plays out. Meanwhile, Lindsay also investigates the kidnapping of a little girl whose father is the publisher of reporter Cindy Thomas's newspaper; and in Cindy's new apartment building, someone is killing anyone and anything that makes too much noise.Three plots sounds like too many to keep straight, but I didn't find it so as I read. For me this one was a real page turner. The romantic passages seemed, well, over the top; and that was distracting at times. Otherwise, though, I enjoyed it thoroughly.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

When her former partner comes to the restaurant where Lieutenant Lindsay Boxer is relaxing with friends, off duty and enjoying a few margaritas, she tells him that she's been drinking but is not impaired. He agrees with that assessment, and the two detectives head off in pursuit of the Mercedes that has been seen at an otherwise lead-free crime scene. The pursuit ends with the Mercedes crashing, and its occupants - two young teenagers - bursting into tears. The cops holster their weapons and start rendering aid to what they now see as a pair of terrified, injured accident victims. So when the 15-year-old driver pulls out a gun and shoots both detectives, Boxer has to get at her own weapon again and fire it from the ground. By which time the young passenger has also pulled out a gun and used it to put bullets into a cop.Boxer shoots the young girl dead, and the boy - the girl's brother - winds up paralyzed. Although Internal Affairs quickly determines her use of deadly force to be justified, and although Boxer's partner barely survives and Boxer is herself seriously wounded, the kids' parents sue for police brutality. As she awaits her trial, Boxer leaves San Francisco for her sister's home in Half Moon Bay. Caring for a vacant house while her sister and family are away on vacation, in a picturesque coastal town, sounds perfect. Unfortunately, though, Half Moon Bay has its own string of unsolved murders going on; and Boxer soon realizes they may have a connection to her very first murder investigation, which still remains open. She can't help meddling. Which, of course, puts her in danger as the killer realizes she just may be able to do what the local police can't.Sometimes I want to shake Lindsay Boxer for not being able to resist temptation. Yet in the end it all comes out well for her, every time; and of course if she did behave herself, there'd be no story (or not much of one) for me to read. This tale is well paced, has a good twist at the end, and does a great job of bringing in a new "Women's Murder Club" character to take over the empty spot following Jill's death.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Unemployed former banker Jonathan Southard can't stand it. He's married to a woman just like his mother, something he realizes as Esther lets him know she's leaving him - but not until his 401(K) pays out, so she can share in its proceeds. Jonathan believes his mother, Abigail, did the same thing to his father; and that's what makes him snap, and kill his family. He leaves Thousand Oaks, CA after turning his home's air conditioner down to preserve the bodies as long as possible, and he heads for Tucson, AZ, where his mother has settled and remarried. He's going to settle that score, on his own and his now remarried father's behalf, before he crosses the border to a new life in Mexico.Angelina Enos is four years old, and she's delighted that her mother's boyfriend has included her in an outing that will take them to the annual party for the botanical garden's Queen of the Night bloom. That's a cactus which looks dead and ugly until the one night of the year when it opens fragrant white buds, into flowers that close before dawn. Far out in the desert, Angelina hides in a parked vehicle while someone kills her mother and her mother's boyfriend because they've happened upon the scene of two planned murders - that of the former Abigail Southard, and her second husband.Meanwhile, retired sheriff Brandon Walker takes on the one case that his long time friend and fellow retired detective couldn't solve. "Geet" is dying now, and old though the case is he actually has a new lead that he's medically unable to follow up. Brandon has his own concerns as well as the case, which he takes up under the auspices of The Last Chance, a charitable organization which attempts to solve cold cases in order to give families closure. Brandon is desperately afraid that Diana Ladd Walker, acclaimed writer and his second wife for more than 30 years, is developing dementia. He knows what that looks like, because it caused his father's death. He's afraid to broach the subject even with Diana, despite the warning signs he's been seeing for some months now; and he certainly isn't ready to discuss it with his stepson, David, an attorney who's in the middle of a divorce. Nor with his adopted daughter, Native American medical doctor and medicine woman Lani Walker - who finds herself involved in the case of Angelina Enos, when an Apache border patrolman brings the little girl to Lani's hospital emergency room.Some of this story's resolution seems awfully convenient, but it works nevertheless. The characters are interesting and easy to care about, and I enjoyed seeing Lani learn to appreciate an individual who happens to be half Apache - the tribe so hated by her own people that their words for "enemy" and "Apache" are exactly the same. This is the tale that brings the Walker saga up to date, and while it isn't quite as compelling as DAY OF THE DEAD, it is every bit as good in its own way.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Dr. Larry Stryker and his wife, Gayle, have been honored by their community as man and woman of the year. They've long operated a charity called Medicos for Mexico - an organization that exists to provide free medical care to impoverished people who would otherwise never see a doctor. These are good people. Friends, as far as Diana Ladd Walker is concerned. So why does Brandon Walker, unwillingly retired former sheriff and Diana's husband, dislike and distrust them?The Strykers, we learn early in this novel that's billed as suspense and at times comes close (in my opinion) to horror, have had secret lives since 1970. That was the year Larry learned he had impregnated a mute Native American girl who was his patient, and the year when Gayle cleaned up after him by killing the girl and disposing of her body. Ever since then, the couple's relationship has become more and more perverted; and so have their pleasures. Now Gayle's lover for the past five years, a much younger man who owes his job and lifestyle to her patronage, decides he wants a normal life. Gayle can't allow any man to break off with her. She sets out to frame him, and the detective who investigates the case manages to do what the Strykers cannot imagine possible. Brian Fellows, partly thanks to his own investigatory skills and partly thanks to his close relationship with Brandon Walker, makes the connection between the 30-year-old cold case and the current one. For Brandon Walker has a new career at last, donating his time and skill to an organization that investigates cold murder cases; and it just happens that he's recently taken on that of the mute and mysteriously pregnant girl found dismembered in an ice chest.Yes, I know this book is rife with coincidences. Somehow I didn't care, and once I began reading I found myself unable to stop. I had to keep turning pages until I finished it, far into the night. Was it because I'm the same age as Brandon Walker is in the story, and I understand a little too well how this major character feels about finding new purpose in life? Was it because the Strykers came across as all too believable, to someone who knows how Native Americans were treated only a generation or so ago? I'm not sure. I just know that it grabbed me and held me. I found the two previous Walker family books worth reading, but this one I couldn't put down.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Lieutenant Lindsay Boxer, head of the San Francisco Police Department's homicide division, is out jogging when a house explodes in front of her. She fights her way inside after hearing someone crying, and she carries out a 10-year-old boy who's the only survivor. The subsequent investigation brings in the Deputy Director of Homeland Security, and it also pulls the "Women's Murder Club" - as the four friends call themselves - back together in crime solving mode. Lindsay is joined by Claire, a medical examiner; Cindy, a reporter; and Jill, an assistant district attorney. This time, though, something is wrong with Jill. Or has that something been wrong all along, and her friends are only noticing it now?As the case progresses, the mysterious organization that takes responsibility for the bombing commits other murders and makes sure the world knows it deserves the credit. Clues come in via e-mails and instant messages to Cindy at her newspaper. One of the four Women's Murder Club members becomes the very personal target for vengeance by someone killing on behalf of the radical organization. Very personal, also, is Lindsay's possible relationship with the visiting Deputy Director. Is she ready to let someone else into her life, after what happened to the last man she allowed herself to love?This third installment in the series drops some interesting threads, but picks up new ones as the plot weaves Lindsay's personal and professional lives together. The idea of 60s radicals returning to business decades later is an old and tired one, yet it works well in this book because it's approached in a different way. I found the way the plot resolved just a bit contrived, but that wasn't enough to spoil the read. Not by any means.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Diana Ladd Walker and Brandon Walker are about to celebrate their 20th wedding anniversary, and their long marriage isn't going through an easy phase just now. Diana's writing career has taken off with the publication of a book co-authored with Andrew Carlisle, the professor and madman who nearly killed her after his release from prison 21 years ago. Carlisle was mentor to Diana's first husband, Gary Ladd, who fathered her son David - now 27 years old, and just graduating from law school in Chicago, where he has lived in quarters provided by his father's wealthy mother. David is on his way home to Arizona now, to his mother and to Brandon Walker, the only father he has ever known. Of Brandon's sons by his first marriage, ex-convict Quentin is estranged from the family; and Tommy disappeared years ago. The couple's only child together is an adopted Native American girl, Lani, who's 16 now and beautiful. But not yet wise enough to recognize the danger is agreeing to pose for painter who has become familiar to her simply by being parked in his RV along Lani's daily route to her summer job - for Lani has no clue the man who seems perfectly all right to her, and who paints such realistic portraits, is Andrew Carlisle's long time cell mate and carefully trained successor. Carlisle died in prison, but Mitch Johnson is out now and bent on carrying out Carlisle's charge where the Walker family is concerned. When Lani disappears, the current sheriff isn't interested in pursuing the case any sooner than he has to - which means waiting 24 hours and even then starting with a simple missing person report. Brandon Walker, who used to be sheriff until he lost the most recent election, knows his daughter's disappearance needs to be investigated vigorously and immediately. So he starts calling in his markers from people who owe him, and as he works he becomes more and more convinced that Lani's vanishing is connected to the book - the evil book, in Brandon's opinion as well as that of local medicine man "Fat Crack" Ortiz - that Diana wrote with Andrew Carlisle.Fast paced and creepy, this is definitely a novel of suspense rather than a mystery. We readers know from the start who the villain is and what's motivating him. What we don't know is who will survive, or how. I found the flashbacks awkward to follow at times, but otherwise the structure worked well. I'll be interested to read the two succeeding books in this series, since these characters' stories definitely aren't over at this novel's end.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Inspector Lindsay Boxer of the San Francisco Police Department hasn't seen anything worse, and she's seen a lot in her career so far.  The killer came to the newly married couple's hotel room door, got inside on a ruse, and stabbed the groom to death before first stabbing and then violating the bride.  Boxer comes to the crime scene from a medical appointment at which her doctor tells her that she's ill with a potentially fatal blood disease.  As she pursues the case, and other newly married couples die in different cities around the country, Boxer struggles with treatment and with the knowledge that her illness may kill her.  She shares that knowledge reluctantly with three other women.  First there's the medical examiner who has long been her best friend; then a young reporter whom she's just met; and then a driven, brilliant assistant district attorney, someone Boxer has known for some time but to whom she's never before been close. The foursome works the case together, and they nickname themselves the Women's Murder Club.  Meanwhile, the new partner who's assigned to Boxer temporarily - and much against her will - turns out to be someone she just may be able to love, which she isn't willing to do if she can help it.  Partly because of the diagnosis hanging over her head, and partly because of the divorce from which she has yet to recover.I suppose that reviewers who claim the women are stereotypes may have a point, but for some reason I wasn't bothered.  I liked Lindsay Boxer and found her response to her personal situation realistic for the character as she's written.  The mystery ended with a nasty twist, one that I didn't really see coming even though I knew something still wasn't right.  Definitely a series worth following, now that I've begun to read it.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

San Francisco detective Lindsay Boxer returns to work after both medical issues and a serious personal loss, newly promoted to lieutenant and head of the homicide division. Her first case in that capacity feels close to home. The apparently random shooting of a little black girl is followed by the staged suicide of a black woman, and Boxer learns that both the girl's uncle and the woman's dead husband were San Francisco cops. And so the pattern continues, with Boxer's existence becoming complicated off duty by her father - former cop Marty Boxer - coming back into her life many years after he disappeared from it. What does he want from her now? Is it a relatively simple matter of an aging man searching for redemption, or is his reappearance connected to the case?Once again Lindsay Boxer calls on her three friends, a medical examiner, a reporter, and an assistant district attorney, to help her solve a dangerous and convoluted puzzle. The Women's Murder Club, as they've nicknamed themselves, is back in business. And someone wants at least one of them dead.This second book in a series moves along smartly, and each of its main characters has a very personal stake in the case's outcome. A good, solid mystery, with a protagonist who's flawed yet easy to care about. Definitely, I want to keep reading about Lindsay Boxer and her three friends.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Diana Ladd's life has been in limbo ever since her husband, creative writing graduate student Gary Ladd, committed suicide rather than face murder charges along with his professor, Andrew Carlisle. The pair stood accused of the torture killing of a young Indian woman. Carlisle was convicted, and he's been a model prisoner. Now he's out - released without any word to Diana, or to the victim's grandmother, either. That grandmother, Rita Antone (who was known in her girlhood as Dancing Quail), has become a beloved member of Diana Ladd's household and a second mother more than nanny to Diana's son, Davy, who is six years old now. Diana found out she was pregnant after Gary's death, so Davy did not know his father. But he's still on Andrew Carlisle's target list. Within two days of Carlisle's release, the body count stands at two; and the all too sane appearing madman finds it laughably easy to discover the current address of the three people he most wants to kill. But only after reducing Diana Ladd to abject and total submission.According to author Jance, this re-write of her first novel is her favorite among her works. It was published long after her J.P. Beaumont series made her a favorite with readers, and I am glad I didn't read it first. Had I not already been familiar with her writing, I might not have kept reading until this one pulled me in. It did that, but not at first; and that's because the characters seemed so unpleasant. It took awhile for me to get to know them well enough to start caring. Once I did get involved in the story, though, I had trouble putting it down. I particularly liked the way Jance handled the book's climax (which is violent and cathartic, indeed). Not like any of her other series, but very good reading on its own terms.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

J.P. "Beau" Beaumont, retired from the Seattle Police Department and now a member of the Attorney General of Washington's special homicide investigation unit, must find the person who gunned down a former (and wrongly convicted) prisoner when the man opened the door to his mother's home and was met with a fatal bullet. Beau's partner (both as an investigator and in the romantic sense), Melissa "Mel" Soames, must be kept in ignorance of what he's doing because that is the AG's personal order. Mel has her own case, attempting to tie cold murder investigations to missing persons. She quickly discovers that an unexplained number of released former prisoners are dying as they become murder victims. Is Beau's man, wrongly convicted though he was, one of those? It's difficult for him to keep what he is working on secret from Mel, whom he loves. For a time he uses being on bereavement leave to cover his activities, after his grandmother dies and he's willingly tasked with helping her second husband - who also happens to be Beau's AA sponsor - get through the loss. But with two veteran cops both living and working together, it's inevitable for their cases to come together.I'm so glad author Jance found a way to give Beau a new life after his long career with the Seattle PD hit its breaking point. Unconventional has always been the word for Beau; and in the AG's special unit, he can do what he does best without being boxed in. He can also work with the woman he's come to love so deeply, which certainly would not be possible anywhere else. I enjoyed the way the three cases in which Beau and Mel are involved here play out, and as always Beau's personal life sees developments, too. Plot and character drive each other. A gripping read!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

He's the grandson of the "First Gentleman" of Washington State. Josh lives in the Governor's Mansion, but his difficult background - including time spent in foster care - makes him an all too natural target for harassment from his supposed peers. How do the Governor's daughters, one older than Josh and the other younger, feel about this relative by their mother's marriage who lives with them but holds himself aloof? And where did the snuff film come from, that's found on his cell phone? By the time Josh commits suicide, leaving a note about not being able to "take it" anymore, Attorney General Ross Connors has already assigned two special investigators - retired Seattle P.D. detective J.P. "Beau" Beaumont and Beau's wife and working partner, Melissa "Mel" Soames - to the case. What began as an attempt to find out the source of the cell phone file and the identity of the apparent murder victim turns into a search for the causes of Josh's despair. For although his own hands knotted his grandfather's ties into the rope and he stepped off the chair by himself, someone is responsible for his death nevertheless.I figured out the mystery just about when I suspect the author meant for me to figure it out, and doing so only made the resolution of the story more enjoyable. Jance has noted somewhere - her website, I think? - that the difference between a mystery and a novel of suspense is that a mystery solves a puzzle, while a novel of suspense examines good and evil. The latter description fits this book perfectly. Intriguing, gritty, and difficult to put down.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

J.P. "Beau" Beaumont has retired from the Seattle Police Department, but he's still a detective. He now works for the Attorney General's Special Homicide Investigation Team (yes, that is exactly the acronym). When the AG himself assigns Beau to a repressed memories case, the seasoned investigator doesn't think much of the idea until he talks with the hypnotherapist and patient involved. "Freddy Mac" and Sister Mary Katherine, a mother superior who used to be called Bonnie Jean Dunleavy, were both Beau's high school classmates. Sister Mary Katherine has been experiencing screaming nightmares that wake the whole convent, and it looks as if they're due to the surfacing of memories she has kept buried for over 50 years. Since, as a small child of four or five years old, Bonnie Jean witnessed a murder. One that remains unsolved.Meanwhile, Beau's best friend and former partner - paraplegic Ron Peters, who's become second in command of Seattle PD's Internal Affairs Division - wants to plead guilty to the murder of his ex-wife. Someone stabbed Rosemary Peters to death soon after she filed a petition to gain full custody of her younger daughter by Ron, Heather. The older girl, Tracy, is too close to 18 for such a suit to work; but Heather isn't yet 15 years old. Rosemary's death ends the threat of Heather being forced to leave the only parents she has known - Ron and his second wife, Amy - and her sister and small half-brother. But will Ron and Amy's marriage survive this crisis, on top of the one already in progress thanks to Amy's difficult older sister taking up residence in their home and showing no intention of leaving?Beau is in top form here, as being ordered away from the case doesn't stop him from acting as a good friend to Ron and a good "uncle" to the two girls he's known since they were small and who are almost as dear to him as his own grown children. His initial disgust at the whole idea of hypnotherapy and recovered memories gives way to belief as the evidence mounts up, thanks to his determined pursuit - a pursuit that defies efforts of people still living to cover up what happened 50 years ago. Despite his determination never to work with a partner again, Beau also has a new one here: Melissa "Mel" Soames, a colleague who may be turning into something far more personal.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

Retired Seattle detective J.P. "Beau" Beaumont has a job offer on the table, from the Attorney General of Washington for a position on his elite homicide investigation squad. Beau may well accept that offer; but first he's agreed to go with his grandmother, Beverly, on her honeymoon. Beverly has married Lars Jenssen, Beau's AA sponsor, following the death of Beau's grandfather. The elderly lovers both think it wise to have a younger relative along on their Alaskan cruise, in case either should need help. Beau has always been a terrible sailor, but Beverly insists she has just the right remedy for seasickness. Which turns out to work, to Beau's agreeable amazement; and that's a good thing, since he soon finds himself working a case even though he's no longer employed. He just does not know how to stop being a detective, which means that fellow passenger Margaret Featherstone's disappearance sends him into investigation mode. The same thing happens a bit later in the story, when an Alzheimer's patient named Mike Conyers is pushed off the rear deck of a sightseeing train just as it enters a tunnel.Transitions are tough in fictional life as well as in the real version. Beau is making the one from active duty with the Seattle Police Department into retirement, which may or may not be something he wants at this point in his life; and Beverly and Lars Jenssen are making the transition from being widow and widower to being wife and husband. Neither transition avoids bumps in the road. I found the story a change of pace for one of my favorite fictional detectives, although the two plots didn't come together quite as smoothly as in some other books in the series. As for Beverly and Lars - they're a delight. Both together, and separately.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

It looks like a simple case of an old woman smoking in bed, setting her house on fire, and dying as a result. Things start to look different, though, when a search of the garage turns up a refrigerator stuffed with $300,000 in cash. Soon Detectives J.P. "Beau" Beaumont and Sue Danielson are investigating a case of murder, with arson as the cause of death and blackmail as the likely motive. They're also trying to solve the mystery presented by human bones found in a Seattle park, being used by a role-playing group in a most bizarre and disrespectful fashion. The bones may belong to a long dead Native American shaman; and if so, a visitor from the tribe tells Beau, everyone who has handled them is in serious danger. Meanwhile, Captain Powell's sudden retirement due to his wife's terminal illness places Beau's nemesis - Detective Paul Kramer - in the squad commander's chair. Temporarily, at least; and it may well become permanent.This book's events take Beau to a major turning point in his life. He's grieving for his former wife, Karen, who recently died of cancer; and he's worried about Sue Danielson, whose abusive ex-husband has resurfaced with a demand that she let him take their two sons (whom he has failed to support and failed even to contact for some years now) to Disneyland. Beau wonders what Richie Danielson will do when Sue puts her foot down, and refuses to let the boys miss several days of school because their father insists he can't schedule the trip during their vacation.Things come together explosively, with Beau making a major decision as a result. This decision sends his life in new directions both personally and professionally. I found BREACH OF DUTY riveting.--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

J.P. "Beau" Beaumont, Seattle homicide detective, has little difficulty learning the identity of the "floater" found underneath a pier on New Year's Day. No one's sorry the biotech executive is dead, and one person - an eccentric, wealthy, well-connected elderly lady - confesses to the murder, in a most public (and therefore embarrassing, since she's lying) manner. Nevertheless it proves to be a complicated investigation, and it gets more so when Beau visits the dead man's apartment and finds the man's estranged wife dead inside it. Who actually did the deed, or deeds (assuming the same person killed both husband and wife)? Who was the mysterious "wheelchair woman" shadowing the executive in the days and nights before he died? Those are just a few of the questions Beau needs to answer, and having Detective Paul Kramer - his nemesis - also assigned to the case doesn't help one bit.One of the things I love about J.A. Jance is how her characters change due to events in their lives, and "Beau" does a lot of changing in this book. The recovering alcoholic suffers a relapse, for one thing; and for another, he has to face the death of his first wife, who remains the mother of his children and a major player in his history despite the decade since their divorce. New characters, his widowed grandmother and his crusty and elderly AA sponsor, begin playing larger roles in his life here, too. The mystery is just fine, but Beau is what makes the whole thing work. I love this series!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

It's been a long time since Seattle homicide detective J.P. "Beau" Beaumont was a high school kid, but he hasn't forgotten the people of the neighborhood where his single mother raised him. Ballard is no longer quite the same enclave of Norwegian fishermen and their families, but the case to which he's currently assigned brings him back in contact with people he once knew. They include a former high school cheerleader who's become a widow thanks to that case, when someone handcuffed her husband to a table aboard his fishing boat and set the boat on fire after torturing him.Beau has a new partner here, Detective Sue Danielson, and he's in recovery from alcoholism. The trail the two detectives follow leads a long way back, all the way to World War II and its aftermath. Who was the murdered man, actually? Did even his wife really know that, or will what Beau finds out come as news to her? And what kind of danger does their young adult daughter face, now that death has brought her home after several years of estrangement?Forcing Beau to look back into his past, at himself as a teenaged boy, works well here for two reasons. First, he's at the stage of alcoholism recovery where looking into the past makes sense; and second, Sue Danielson is a single mother struggling with a difficult teenaged son of her own. The mystery interested me even more than usual because of its World War II background.
