I've been fascinated by that time and place in history since my early teens, and Jance has done her homework here. Top notch!--Reviewed by Nina M. Osier, author of 2005 science fiction EPPIE winner "Regs"

I have an HE top-loading washing machine. These detergent paks work wonderfully in my machine. The package says these paks are OK for HE machines, but I always have a bit of concern over any detergent paks dissolving completely. However, I have had no problems with that at all. This product cleans effectively and leaves clothes smelling clean, but with no strong scent of any kind. And I love the convenience of just tossing in one or two detergent paks.If you like using detergent paks and you want one that doesn't have a strong scent, this is a great choice.

I had heard of parchment paper but never used it until fairly recently when I tried a recipe that called for it. Then, I thought that since I had it, I might as well bake cookies on it to use the roll up. And that was the beginning of my love affair with parchment paper. This is the greatest stuff since sliced bread! The best invention since canned beer! I can't believe it took me so long to discover this product. I may never scrub a baking dish or pan again.This Reynold's parchment paper is easy to open and tearing off a piece with a straight cut is easy if you put your thumb on the roll to keep more paper from coming out when you start the cut. I highly recommend this product for anyone who does any baking.

Nine giant bars of Hershey's chocolate. This thing rates 5 stars on the basis of that alone. But, the gift wrappers are, much to my surprise, kind of a cool idea, too. I confess that I expected the "labels," as the product description calls them, to be kind of cheesy. But in fact, they aren't really labels, they're wrappers, or sleeves, that fold around the chocolate bar. The wrappers are good quality, heavy duty paper with crisp, clear printing.But, I'm kind of struggling with whether or not I would actually buy this kit and keep it around for emergency gift-giving situations. I mean, for one thing, me having chocolate around without eating it is very, well, not me at all. It would be a struggle. And I'm not sure I see myself handing someone a wrapped chocolate bar and saying, "Happy birthday," or "Congratulations." Where I can see using this wrapper idea is at something like a kid's birthday party where you want to give all the guests a party favor to take home. Or, maybe stick a chocolate bar with a "Happy Birthday" wrapper on a wrapped birthday gift.So, while the chocolate bars are great and the gift wrapper concept has merit, I'm not completely sold on the idea of a kit with assorted labels to keep around "just in case."

This review is for the dishcloth. These are not top-of-the-line quality, but I would call them a good mid-quality dishcloth. The stitching is solid and straight. There were a few pulls in the fabric prior to and after the first washing, but the cloths held their shape well during laundering and were all still square when I took them out of the dryer.The fabric is lightweight and rough textured, which makes these dishcloths perfect for washing dishes. The cloths are thin and small enough to stuff down inside a glass and the nubby surface is great for scrubbing off those little pieces of food that are stuck to your dirty dishes.If you're looking for some decent quality, inexpensive, everyday dishcloths, these are a good choice.

These cups are exactly what you need for tailgating and parties built around watching the game. The printing quality is good - the Gator logo on my cups is crisp and clear.The reason I gave these cups 4 stars instead of 5 is that they are a bit flimsy. I was expecting something more like the classic red plastic cups that I usually buy for picnics and casual gatherings, which are pretty stout. These cups are made from thinner plastic and are easily squished when holding a full cup in your hand.

This cushion does make your chair feel sort of like sitting on a balance ball. It does provide the "active seat" that the product description claims and it does make you use your core muscles if you sit up straight balanced over the center of the cushion.The cushion is made of sturdy material and I think it will old up well. It came already inflated. It was too firm for me and I found it uncomfortable to sit on for more than 5-10 minutes. But, after I let a bit of air out, I found it much more comfortable. But, it's still not as comfortable to sit on as an exercise ball. I think that's because with the exercise ball, you can roll it around a little bit to relieve pressure points. With this cushion in your chair, you can't really reposition your seat. Also, I did not like sitting on the knobby side. I flipped it over to the smooth side and liked that better.If you can't sit on an exercise ball at work, this cushion will give you some of the benefits. However, I think you are going to have to be pretty dedicated to using it to build up a tolerance for using it for extended periods of time. I think in most cases, it will end up tossed in a corner, unused.

First, I want to comment on all the Battlestar Galactica fanboys reviews blasting this novel for "ripping off" Battlestar Galactica. Apparently none of these BG fans are old enough to remember the fuss over the original BG "ripping off" Star Wars.  When BG first came out, Universal Studios was sued by 20th Century Fox for stealing ideas from Star Wars. Universal countersued, claiming that Star Wars stole ideas from Silent Running and Buck Rogers. And Isaac Asimov was quoted as saying "Star Wars was fun and I enjoyed it. But Battlestar Galactica was Star Wars all over again and I couldn't enjoy it without amnesia." (Quote courtesy of Google and Wikipedia)So yeah, maybe this book does "borrow" a few ideas from past science fiction novels/movies/TV shows. So what? It's not the first and won't be the last. And maybe a few things could be considered "paying homage," rather than "ripping off."Now, on to what really matters: is this book any good? I say "Yes. Yes, it is." I gave it 4 stars rather than 5 because I thought the initial chapters where we meet the captain and crew of The Constitution were a little rough around the edges. I was not sure I was going to bother reading the whole book. But, once the aliens showed up in our Solar System, the story really got rolling and I was hooked. I would describe this book as classic space opera. Lots of space battles, bad aliens, and heroic characters saving the day at the last minute. If that is your kind of story, I recommend this book.I can't wait for book 2.

I purchased this book from the author's web site so I could get an autographed copy.If you are considering purchasing this book, you should know:If you don't have a basic familiarity with the climate change debate, the IPCC, Michael Mann, and the lawsuits filed by Mann and Steyn, you may find this book a bit confusing.If you are considering purchasing this book based on your previous enjoyment of Mark Steyn's writing, be aware that this is a collection of quotes from climate scientists on the subject of Michael Mann and his hockey stick. Mr. Steyn introduces the different sections and provides commentary, but most of the material is not his writing.I loved this book. I thought I was fairly well-informed on this subject, but I learned many things I didn't know. I also thought I understood the degree of  dishonesty and unethical behavior exhibited by Mann and his closest colleagues, but I was shocked at some of the things brought to light in this book. I highly recommend this book to anyone who has an interest in and basic knowledge of global warming research and policy. Those who have embraced Mann's research and the resulting IPCC policies would truly benefit from reading this book - but only if they are open-minded and honest enough to allow their beliefs to be challenged.

This book is just OK. I did read the whole book, which earns it at least 3 stars, but never managed to rise above that level. The only compliment that I can pay the book is that the author did do a good job of describing the setting and some of the issues facing Israelis and Palestinians.Despite the fact that this should be a gripping thriller, there was never a moment when I had trouble putting the book down to go do something else. This was one of the slowest moving "fast paced" books I've ever read. Even events that passed in nearly the blink of an eye or would have been described by a person on the scene as "frenzied" slowed, on the pages, to a crawl.The main character is a bit of a superhero, which isn't, in itself, a big negative for me, but she, and all the other characters were one-dimensional. And to make things worse, most of the characters seemed bent on doing things that made little sense.Finally, the book contained too many points of annoyance for me to really enjoy it. For example, the main character, Raisa Jordan, makes her first appearance in Chapter 4. But, the author doesn't explain who she is! If I hadn't read the book jacket, which tells you that Jordan is an agent for the US Diplomatic Security Service, I wouldn't have known who she worked for.This is the author's first book and it seems to be setting the stage for additional books featuring Raisa Jordan. However, I have no interest in reading additional books and can't recommend this one.

When I took this watch out of the box, I was taken aback by the size. This watch is huge, as you can see from the picture of this watch and my regular watch, side-by-side on my wrist. The case is large and surprisingly thick. The band is wide and long.  I had to remove three of the links in the band and I am by no means a petite or small-boned individual. It is also really heavy, to the point of being somewhat bothersome. Due to the size and the fact that the watch is not particularly feminine in appearance, I was initially convinced that I had been sent a men's watch by mistake. But, a friend later assured me that "big" is the fashion for women's watches right now and that this watch was very likely indeed a women's watch.That aside, this is a nice watch. The quality seems good. It is very attractive and the black face nicely sets off the white hands, which also glow in the dark. The band is sturdy and the clasp has a safety latch that requires two steps to get it open, so you don't have to worry about it accidentally popping open - a good thing given the heavy weight of the watch. The bezel is fixed, so it's just there for appearances. I would say this watch is as much fashion accessory as it is time piece.The watch comes in a nice box and is presented well in the box, so it would make a nice gift - just maybe not the best choice for a petite woman or younger girl.I don't think I will wear this watch much because of the size and weight. But, if you are looking for an attractive, large, gender-neutral timepiece, this may be a good choice.

I'm editing this review and reducing it from 5 to 3 stars. The first bag was great, so I bought a second bag. But, not long after we started feeding out of the second bag, my dog started scratching again. I switched back to the dog food I had been using previously and the problem cleared up. So, no more Nutro for us.The two most important things I look for in dog food are that the dog likes it and that it doesn't make him itch. My dog is sensitive to grains and I'm not sure what else in some dog food and he gets flakey, itchy skin. This Nutro Large Breed Adult Dog Food is a winner on both counts. The dog loves it and prefers it over the dry food that I had been using. And, the bag I received to try is almost gone and there has been been no evidence of any effects on his skin.I will definitely purchase this dog food in the future.

Protocol Zero is a "turn your brain off" fast snowmobile dash across the Arctic tundra. Once it gets going, the story zips along at top speed, as Marine Colonel Dr. Joe Rush tries to figure out if a series of deaths are due to a natural epidemic or are murders in which the murder weapon is a virus. And, if the first, how the epidemic got started or, if the second, who is behind the deaths and why.The first part of the book was marred by the time spent on the relationship between Joe and his fiancee, Karen, which made me want to send each of them to their rooms to sit time out. I was having flashbacks to middle/high school. And in the end, none of it really mattered, so I was tortured for nothing.The biggest problem with this book, for me, is that after I finished it and got off the snowmobile ride, I realized that none of it made any sense. And the more I thought about it, the less sense it made and the more it annoyed me.I like the basic premise of this series. I like Joe and his buddy, Eddie. I liked the first book in the series. If the author writes a third book, I will read it. But, if the third has the same problems that Protocol Zero had, then I'm done.

This soup isn't bad, with lots of noodles and big chunks of carrot, but the spices used in the preparation are just not to my liking. The soup had a slight taste that I associate with the poultry seasoning my Mom uses in the dressing at Thanksgiving and it had a bit too much "bite" for my tastes (too much black pepper?).I like the packaging. It's definitely tough - the container was shipped to me via UPS in a barely padded envelope. I couldn't believe it survived intact. It is also easy to open if you follow the directions, although I admit it took me a moment to figure out exactly what corners I was supposed to pinch together.The container is supposed to be two servings. I ate the whole thing for lunch, with a little broth left over for the dog, and was satisfied - not overfull, but I didn't need anything else with it. So, it's probably a good size for two people having a "soup and sandwich" lunch.

I love this cup for so many reasons. However, none of them are the related to the way you can use the elastic bands to track your liquid consumption.1. The tall, thin shape makes it easy to hold and it fits perfectly in the cup holder in the center console of my car.2. The elastic bands make a great secure handhold. I like the way the cup feels in my hand.3. I have several of these insulated tumblers with screw-tops. It can be difficult to get the threads lined up so that the lid screws on straight. I love the simple snap in lid on this.4. I often use the single-serving drink mix packets made to dump into bottled water. This cup holds exactly the volume of a bottle of water, so I can fill it up from the drinking fountain and get exactly the correct volume of water for my drink mix.5. The cup is sturdy and well constructed.6. The little gray tab seals the hole where the straw goes from the underside of the lid, so when you're ready to start drinking it, you just poke the straw in.

The appearance of this chair is quite striking. Half the people in my office stopped to look at it and most sat down to try it out. Unfortunately, it is a classic example of a great concept with poor execution.On the plus side, the slightly stretchy web makes a very comfortable surface upon which to sit and lean. The pneumatic adjustment allows the chair back to recline and come forward easily and smoothly. And with the open webbing, the chair is much cooler than a regular office chair. I never noticed how my regular chair heats up until I sat in this one for comparison. Another thing I appreciated is that the seat of the chair is short enough that it doesn't dig into the back of my knee when I sit all the way back in the chair - with my relatively short legs this is a common problem in chairs, sofas, car seats...However, this chair has a fatal flaw that makes it useless to me as an office chair. Even with the chair raised as high as it will go, it is not high enough for me to comfortably use my computer keyboard. Now, my keyboard does sit about 4 inches higher than on a typical office desk with a keyboard drawer that hangs below the desk surface, but my current generic office chair raises up high enough for me to type comfortably without even being fully raised. This chair doesn't even come close.My other major complaint about the chair is that the lumbar support is no where near the lumbar area of my back. In order to sit comfortably in the chair for any length of time, I had to put a lumbar support pillow above the lumbar support on the chair, which kind of defeats the purpose of the stretchy web straps. I could get the lumbar support into the right spot be reclining the chair back, but by the time it hit the right spot, I was in "put your feet up and watch TV" position, not "work at your desk" position.I also don't like the way the arm rests swivel so easily. It seems like every time I put my hands on the arm rests for any reason, they swivel out. Not a big deal, but a minor annoyance.Assembly of the chair is well within the capabilities of the average person, but just difficult enough to be annoying. It's easier with two people.This chair was a disappointment. I really like the way it looks and I like the stretchy web seat and back. But, I'm not going to be able to use it as a desk chair.Edited to add that 5 other people in my office have now tried this chair and it has yet to find a permanent home. Most people had the same complaint I did - it doesn't raise up high enough to type comfortably. One said it didn't sit upright enough for a work chair.

I have a small house with a small kitchen with a small, one compartment sink. I use this collapsible tub as a dish pan. I can collapse it and store it out of the way under the sink when it is not in use. It is a vast improvement over the regular dish pan I was using before and has greatly improved the functionality of my sink.

I have wood floors throughout the house, except in the bathroom. I also have a cat and a dog, so lots of hair. I use a vacuum for serious floor sweeping and rely on a regular dry Swiffer for in-between sweeping, mostly to pick up pet hair. This "Sweep and Trap" sweeper works well for this purpose, better, in fact, than the plain old Swiffer because the hair balls get caught in the "trap" instead of simply being pushed around the floor.This sweeper is not good at picking up bigger debris from the floor. However, it does a great job of picking up crumbs and dust along with the pet hair. The tray of the trap is not very deep and it is easy to tip over when trying to remove it for emptying. You have to pay attention to what you're doing and hold the sweeper upright and still while removing the tray.I like this floor sweeper. It works better than the plain dry Swiffer for my purposes.

This is a fantastic set for the occasional recreational snorkeler.Fins: I wear women's shoe size 7.5-8. I selected size L/XL because I wanted fins big enough to fit over neoprene booties. The L/XL fit well with my booties and were comfortable. The straps are very easy to adjust, both tightening and releasing. However, if you really need size L/XL to fit your feet and you have wide feet, you might find these to be a bit of a narrow fit. I like the overall size of these fins - enough fin to be useful, but not so much that it's awkward to manage.Snorkel: I love the dry top and the purge valve makes it easy to get rid of any water that does leak in. The flexible neck is softer and more flexible than any of the other snorkels I own. I also really like the quick release mask attachment - one the snorkel has been attached to the mask, all you have to do is press the quick release button and the snorkel slides loose from the mask. My only dislike is that the mouthpiece itself is quite small and very flexible. I'm used to using a snorkel with a more substantial mouthpiece and this one didn't feel a secure in my mouth. This is probably something that isn't going to bother anyone who hasn't already formed an attachment to a different snorkel and may even be an advantage for someone who is petite and has a smaller face and mouth.Mask: I have kind of a round, broad face and this mask fit me well, forming a comfortable and effective seal. The visibility is good and the silicone around the mask is softer and more flexible than either of the two masks we already have. It is comfortable to wear and the strap is extremely easy to adjust - the easiest of any mask I've ever used. I don't really love that the silicone of the mask is black. I have another mask that is similar in design but has clear silicone and I prefer the "view" from that one.Mesh Bag: The mesh bag is really handy for carrying this set to the beach. The string handle is long enough to toss the bag over your shoulder, freeing your hands for coolers and beach chairs. The holes in the mesh are big enough that the sand easily falls out.I highly recommend this snorkeling set for people who like to do a little snorkeling while on vacation or coastal dwellers who like to keep a spare set of gear on hand for company.

This case is very good for what it is. It is well made, sturdy, and sleek. It is great for storing your small laptop and for carrying it to a meeting or down to your local free wifi coffee shop.However, I do think the manufacturer's touting of the case's "thick interior padding" and "hard EVA shell" is a little overblown. The padding isn't that thick and the shell isn't that hard. Yes, it will likely protect your laptop against minor dings (a valuable quality) and help keep it clean (unless, like me, you tend to eat a muffin at the coffee shop while surfing the internet), but I'm not sure it's much more protective than the padded laptop pocket inside my daypack.The two drawbacks to this case for me are the carrying handle and the lack of room to take along the cord.  The long strap that goes over your shoulder is fine, but the only thing to grab if you want to carry the case in your hand is a web strip along the back. I find it to be very awkward to hold. I do understand the design choice, because foregoing a more traditional handle keeps the case trim and sleek, so it may be perceived as a positive by some users.In addition, the case is just big enough to carry my 11.6 inch laptop. There is no room inside for the cord. My little chromebook has great battery life (my little Windows laptop, not so much) and there is no need for the cord if I'm just going to be using it for a few hours at a meeting. However, it causes me some anxiety to go off without the cord and it kind of defeats the purpose to carry an additional bag for the cord. Yeah, that's my own personal hangup, but there it is.  This also reduces the usefulness of the case for storing your small laptop at home because you can't keep the cord with the laptop.

Zero World is chock full of great ideas. I love the premise. On a technical basis (dialog, imagery, flow...), Jason Hough is a good writer. I enjoyed his previous series, the Dire Earth Cycle.In spite of all that, this book really fell flat for me. I couldn't get past the gaps in logic, losses of continuity, repeated use of serendipity as a plot device, and way too many things that just didn't make sense. Every time I thought, "Wait. What?," it took me out of the story and reduced my enjoyment. I also had a big issue with something that I won't mention here because it could be considered a spoiler, but I'll add it as a comment for anyone who is interested.

This product has exactly the same active ingredients as Frontline Plus for cats, so it should be equally effective. The fleas aren't very active right now, though, so I can't really speak to the product's effectiveness.I normally use Frontline, but really dislike the Frontline packaging. With Frontline, the small container that holds the liquid is sealed inside another layer of packaging. You cut the outer package open, remove the inner container, then snap the top back to dispense the liquid. I don't know if I'm just a klutz, but I rarely manage to get it on the cat without also getting some on my fingers. This Sentry product is packaged differently than Frontline, and, as is often the case with generic versions of a name brand, the packaging isn't as sturdy. But, I actually like it better. With the Sentry product, you detach the container from the others by snapping it off, then take scissors and cut the top off (the cutting line is clearly marked). I managed to get the container open and get the liquid applied to the cat without getting any of it on my hands.There was no obvious odor to the Sentry product and it caused no irritation to the cat. I would definitely consider purchasing this product in the future.

This veggie pasta is indistinguishable from regular elbow macaroni. The taste, the texture, the way it cooks, all exactly the same as regular macaroni. We ate it with butter and salt and with marinara sauce and thought it was good. I think this product is a good option for sneaking some extra veggies into your picky eater's diet. However, while I like this pasta, there isn't really anything about it that is going to cause me to switch from the tri-color rotini that I usually keep on hand as my "go to" pasta.

How much do I like this mattress? Enough to buy one for myself. I got this mattress for the twin bed in the guest room, where we were trying to compensate for an uncomfortable mattress with not just one, but two mattress toppers. My Mom slept on this new mattress for a week and I tried it out for two nights. We both loved it and slept very well on it. I usually wake up multiple times during the night to roll over or adjust the pillow, or rearrange the covers. With this mattress, I found that I slept longer and woke less frequently. I'm going to order one for my bed.This twin size mattress came in a box small enough to fit in the front seat of my truck. Because I had already read some reviews that commented about an odor when the packaging was opened, I took it out to the workshop and let it inflate and air out there for a couple of days. By the time I brought it in the house, the mattress itself still had a faint chemical odor, but once we put the mattress cover and sheet on it, you couldn't smell anything.With respect to the firmness of the mattress, I don't think you can use the terms "firm" and "soft" with memory foam mattresses in the same way you do with a regular innerspring mattress. I prefer a soft mattress, as does my Mom. But, while this mattress feels firm when you first lay down on it, you sort of settle in to the memory foam as you lay on it and I found it to be very comfortable, with none of the morning aches and pains I feel when I sleep on a firm mattress.Note that, at 6 inches, this mattress will sit much lower than something like a pillow-top mattress. It's not a problem, exactly, but initially it just looked "wrong."

My dog is really sensitive to fleas so during peak flea season, I use a monthly oral flea treatment and two weeks later, apply a topical flea treatment, usually Frontline Plus. This product has exactly the same active ingredients in exactly the same percentages as Frontline Plus, so it should be equally effective. The fleas aren't very active right now, though, so I can't really speak to the product's effectiveness.This Sentry product is packaged differently than Frontline, and, as is often the case with generic versions of a name brand, the packaging isn't as sturdy. But, I actually like it better. With Frontline, the small container that holds the liquid is sealed inside another layer of packaging. You cut the outer package open, remove the inner container, then snap the top back to dispense the liquid. I rarely manage to get it on the dog without also getting some on my fingers. With the Sentry product, you detach the container from the others by snapping it off, then take scissors and cut the top off (the cutting line is clearly marked). I managed to get the container open and get the liquid applied to the dog without getting any of it on my hands.There was no obvious odor to the Sentry product and it caused no irritation to the dog. I would definitely consider purchasing this product in the future.

Anonymous Soldiers is a scholarly account of the role of terrorism and terrorist organizations in the establishment of Israel.  It is meticulously researched, exhaustively referenced, remarkably even-handed, and impressively detailed. The latter is evidenced by the fact that well over half of the book is devoted to just the last three years of the struggle.In content, Anonymous Soldiers focuses narrowly on the activities of the two Jewish terrorist organizations, Irgun and Lehi, as an example of the impact a dedicated campaign of terrorism can have on a government's actions and policies. It is not a comprehensive history and the author makes clear in the preface that that was not his intention. I see this book as an essential addition to the libraries of serious scholars of either the history of Israel or the use of terrorism as a political tool. I found the book to be impressive, educational, and thought-provoking.With respect to my personal experience reading this book, I found it to be much more readable than I expected (feared?) it would be. I frequently found myself engrossed in the unfolding events. At times it was like watching a slow-motion train wreck - so many misunderstandings, missteps, and missed opportunities among the British, Arabs, and Jews in Palestine. However...somewhere around the 2/3 point, I got really bogged down. The level of detail began to become somewhat oppressive. I had to take a week off and come back to finish it. I think this book is best for readers who have a high level of interest in the subject.I dithered between giving this book 4 or 5 stars. As an addition to the body of scholarship on the formation and history of Israel, I think it warrants 5 stars. However, a rating of 4 stars better represents my personal reading experience. In the end, as you can see, I decided to go with 5 stars.

I selected this hay hook for two reasons: it was longer than the other ones I looked at and the handle is not a separate piece, so no risk of having it come off.I need this for two reasons: to pull small square bales off the truck and to tip big round bales up on end (using a rope and tractor or truck). It works perfectly for these uses.

I have mixed feelings about this microwave. I was really excited to be offered the opportunity to review it because, in my small kitchen, I have room for one, and only one, counter top appliance. I kept my microwave (and then put a toaster on top of it) but there are times that I really miss my convection/toaster oven. This unit offers multiple cooking modes and the possibility of getting my microwave, toaster oven, and convection oven all in one.I have thus far baked cookies using the convection oven setting, cooked frozen, breaded mushrooms using the SlimFry setting, and heated up leftovers and water for tea using the microwave setting. I've also experimented with, but haven't completely cooked anything, with most of the other modes of operation. I have been fairly underwhelmed by this "Jack of all trades, master of none" unit. Yes, it can bake cookies, but can it do so better and faster than my regular oven? Yes, I can make crispy breaded mushrooms with SlimFry, but is it better than just using my oven to bake them? I'm inclined to say, "No." I haven't yet decided whether or not to allow it to take up permanent residence in my kitchen.Things you need to know if you are thinking about buying this convection microwave:The instruction book is inadequate, at best. If you aren't comfortable with the concepts of "cook it until it's done" and "let's put that pan in there and see what happens," then you will not like this unit. The book also contains some contradictory information (e.g.telling you not to use metal in the microwave, but instructing you to use a metal rack and crisping pan for the SlimFry mode, even though it says that SlimFry is a combo of the grill, convection, and microwave modes).For some of the cooking modes, you cannot select a cooking time, just a food type, which is associated with a preset cooking time (and you don't know what that time is until after you select the food type). For example, when I used SlimFry to cook my mushrooms, I used the "frozen potato croquettes" preset because it seemed closest in food type (back to that inadequate instruction book) and it set a cooking time for me. I had to set my regular timer to check on them at intervals and ended up pulling them out about 2 minutes before the end of the preset time because they were definitely done.The "grill" mode should more properly be called a "broil" mode. A heating element in the top of the oven is used for "grilling." I did not grill (broil) anything because 1. it just seemed to me like it would create a huge mess inside the oven and 2. I wouldn't broil without an exhaust fan over top, and the only exhaust fan I've got in my kitchen is over the stove.This thing gets hot on the outside - really hot - when you use the convection oven, SlimFry, and grill modes (or any combo mode that uses convection or grill modes). You need to set it somewhere with plenty of clearance around it.It isn't a true toaster oven because it doesn't have top and bottom heating elements. You can toast bread in it, but you'll have to toast it one side at a time.The convection oven is supposed to bake faster than a regular oven. It doesn't. My sugar cookies came out perfectly, though. Nice and crispy, just the way I like them.The microwave works well.The cord is really short. You need to find a spot to put it where it is close to an outlet or use a heavy duty extension cord with a three-prong plug.Operation is not intuitive - prepare to keep the instruction book handy for a while.Would I recommend this counter top convection microwave? I'll give a qualified yes, because I can see some circumstances where this multi-purpose oven would be useful. If, for example, you have a tiny studio apartment that doesn't have an oven and you only have room for one counter top appliance. Or maybe an office break room, where the primary use would be as a microwave, but other cooking modes might be useful once in a while (hey, who doesn't occasionally have the urge to make some ready-to-bake chocolate chip cookies on a bad day at work?).However, for the average kitchen, I think you are better off sticking with a regular microwave, toaster, and regular oven.

This very short book is a collection of 12 different essays about the Civil War, 10 of which have appeared in other publications in the past. The individual essays are all quite good and cover a range of topics. I learned quite a bit and have a whole new respect for Abraham Lincoln and a much deeper understanding of the magnitude of the tragedy that was his assassination. The quality of the individual essays is why I rated this book 4 stars. I especially like Chapter 1, an essay that addressed the concepts of negative and positive liberty.However, I am much more interested in the "Why the Civil War Still Matters" part of the book's title than the "The War That Forged a Nation" part and in that respect, this book was a disappointment. In my opinion, only 3 (4 in a stretch) chapters of the book explicitly address "why the Civil War still matters." Any efforts to tie the other 9 chapters into this theme fall squarely on the shoulders of the reader. I would have been much happier if the author had either included a few extra paragraphs in each essay to tie them into this overall theme or penned a 13th essay in which the contributions of the individual essays were all pulled together in a discussion of why the Civil War still matters.I highly recommend this collection of essays to anyone who is interested in the Civil War and Abraham Lincoln. A lot of information is contained within this small volume. And, for students of Civil War history, two of the essays are devoted to countering the claims made by some other Civil War historians. However, if, like me, you are more interested in current political and sociological issues and this book caught your interest because of title's "Why the Civil War Still Matters," then you will likely not find this book particularly satisfying, although a couple of the individual essays are excellent.

White Plague is a medical mystery, espionage thriller, military novel set almost entirely in the Arctic. The book also gives us a dose of history and a bit about climate change. There is plenty of action and the author does a great job of describing the arctic environment. The plot twists and turns. I did not figure everything out in advance and the book managed to surprise me a time or two, which I really appreciated.In general, character development is good, although better for some than for others. My initial response to Joe Rush, the main character, was guarded - I wasn't entirely sure I was going to like this guy. But, I came to appreciate him as the story went on and look forward to future Joe Rush novels. One aspect that I did like with respect to the characters was that the author was willing to let them be complicated. Few of the characters were one dimensional "good guys" or "bad guys."The book was not perfect. I had a few quibbles with the science (e.g. chemical weapons are not the same thing as bioweapons, a vaccine is not a cure). The flashbacks were sometimes kind of clunky. But, for me, one of the big factors in deciding whether or not to give a book 5 stars is the "stay up late on a work night" factor. For White Plague, I stayed up late and on New Year's Day, I kept sneaking in to read another chapter or two. So, in spite of the few weakness, I really did love this book and can't wait to read more in the series.

I've used nothing but Dove soap for years. Like my regular Dove, this Go Fresh Revitalize Bar lathers well, even in my hard water, doesn't dry my skin, and leaves my skin feeling smooth and clean.So, if this soap performs just like similar Dove bar soaps, the decision to purchase this particular one will likely be based on scent. In my household, we fall into two camps in the scent: love it and hate it. I don't like strong scents. I prefer my soaps and lotions to be light and fruity and I found the scent of this soap to be overpowering and slightly unpleasant, close to veering into industrial air freshener territory. My Mom, on the other hand, prefers stronger scents in her lotions and perfumes and she loved the scent of this soap.Considering the soap aspect alone, this mandarin and tiare flower Go Fresh Revitalize Bar is great soap. If you like the other Dove soaps, you will like this one - unless you are sensitive to or dislike strong scents. If you are, then stay away from this soap.

Good things:The big handles make it easier to hold and push down to cut through fruits and vegetables. I've had a cheaper apple corer-slicer that was really hard to push though the apple because the handles weren't big enough to really get a grip on it.The interchangeable blades give you two options without having to buy two separate cutters.It works...mostly.Bad things:The blades are slightly recessed in the ring, which means that it doesn't cut cleanly all the way down to the cutting board. With the apple corer/slicer, it's not a huge deal because you can just pull the cutter  up off the apple and pull the slices apart. But, with the vegetable blade, the potato slices remain stuck in the blade. The easiest and safest way to deal with this that I could figure out was to take my measuring cup and push the bottom of the potato up into the blade so the blade cut all the way through. I still had to pull the slices out the top, but it was more manageable that way. Still kind of a pain, though.These blades are sharp. Really sharp. You cannot handle this gadget casually. You have to be careful and on your guard every time you handle it. My Mom cut herself twice in the space of two days - once washing it and once putting it in the cupboard. The second time was a pretty significant cut. There has to be a way to design something like this to reduce the likelihood of cutting yourself.Other comments:Perhaps I'm just not sufficiently coordinated, but I had to cut the end off the potato to get a flat end to make it stand up so I could slice it without tipping (possibly my fear of getting my fingers too close to the blades was affecting my slicing technique).In case I haven't yet made this point clear, the blades on this cutter are really sharp and very easy to cut yourself on. Honestly, I was ready to throw it in the trash after the second time my Mom cut herself. I'm storing it in a plastic container so no one reaches in the cupboard and accidentally touches the blades.

Blue Warrior, the second Troy Pearce novel, is both better and worse than Drone, the first book in the series. Better, because I didn't notice as much of the uneven writing quality that bothered me while reading Drone. Blue Warrior is more consistent and doesn't have as many eye-rolling moments as I remember Drone having.Worse because the author crammed too much into this book. There were way too many plot threads and I still can't figure out why the author thought some of them were necessary, since the story could have proceeded essentially unchanged without them. The author should have saved some of those good ideas for the next book or two.Overall, though, I liked the book. Like Drone, Blue Warrior is a fast paced techno-thriller with nearly non-stop action. The tech, especially the drone and weapons tech, is fascinating. I also found the computer hacking to be interesting since I just finished reading a on-fiction book on that subject - it's all kind of scary.I don't think it's essential to read Drone before you read Blue Warrior, but I think it would increase your enjoyment of the book if you did. I recommend this book to all fans of the techno-thriller genre, especially if you prefer them heavy on the tech. While there is some character development, the book is really all about the tech and the action, so if you prefer a more character-driven novel, this may not be your best choice.Blue Warrior wasn't quite what I hoped for as a follow-up to Drone, but I will definitely be looking forward to book 3.

Every time my neighbors mow their pasture, mice invade my shed. Mice usually also try to move into the shed a couple of times every winter. So, I was really glad to be offered the opportunity to evaluate this mouse bait station.I really like the design of the bait station and the fact that it is refillable. The bait station has a child-safe screw-off cap. The baits themselves have a hole in the middle. Inside the chamber where the bait is placed, there is a peg. You remove the lid, insert the bait block over the peg, which holds it in place, and then screw the top back on. Mice can enter the trap from both sides.Be aware that the bait station itself is quite large, compared to the disposable single bait stations I have purchased in the past. If you need to put a bait station in a tight space, this bait station is probably not the best choice.Like several other reviewers, I also noticed the odd packaging choice of leaving the bait blocks loose in the resealable bag while the bait station was wrapped in plastic. I think I might have made the opposite choice, wrapping the bait blocks in plastic and leaving the bait station unwrapped in the bag.I can't yet comment on the effectiveness of this bait station. I haven't seen any evidence of mice eating the bait, but I haven't yet seen much evidence of mice making their seasonal move into the shed, either. I will update when I have more to report.

These disposable washcloths are indeed unscented, something that is important to me. They are also thick, much thicker than the generic wet wipes I'm currently carrying in my car. And, as advertised, they do not leave any discernible residue behind, nor, to me, do they feel soapy. They are a bit smaller in size than a standard washcloth, but still have a substantial feel. Heating the wipes in the microwave before using does make the washing up experience more pleasant on a cold day.I can think of many situations in which I would find these disposable washcloths handy to have. I usually try to keep a package of wet wipes in the car for spills and sticky fingers associated with snacking and minor cleanups after visits to the park, barn, or beach. I also like to stick a package of disposable wipes in my briefcase for business travel for everything from cleaning off the drop-down tray on the plane to freshening up in the airport restroom after a long flight. These wipes are also substantial enough to do a quick clean up after a lunchtime walk or workout during my work day.I would definitely purchase these wipes to carry in the car, keep in my desk drawer at work (along with the toothbrush/toothpaste and antiperspirant I currently have stashed there), and stick in my briefcase before heading for the airport.

I can't yet comment on the tooth cleaning effectiveness of these treats since we've only been using them a few weeks. But, I can tell you that my dog LOVES these treats. He is always excited to get one and immediately settles down to chew it up.I also like these dog chews because they do not have a strong odor. One of the things I dislike about many dog treats is that they have an overpowering odor of meat and spices. I'm sure that helps make them attractive to the dog, but it bothers me to the point that I'm not a repeat customer for dog treats that turn out to have a strong odor.One thing that I see expressed often in reviews of dog treats is concern over where the treats are made. I checked the Milk Bone web site and found this statement:All Milk-BoneÆ Dog Biscuits and dog treats are produced at our facilities here in the U.S. The majority of ingredients are sourced from the U.S. Like most pet companies, we source a limited amount of minor ingredients, such as important nutritional supplements or preservatives, from other countries due to limited availability in the U.S. We want to assure you that our strict U.S. quality and operations standards apply equally to all of our ingredients, regardless of the country of origin.I would definitely purchase these dog treats in the future.

Before you order this product, look at the diagram and installation instructions shown above in the product description, then go take the top off your toilet tanks and make sure your toilet tank looks enough like the one in the diagram to be able to install the device. Mine does not (the connection of the tube to the overflow pipe is different). While I'm sure I could have made it work, just wasn't willing to get in there and start taking things apart.However, that ended up being a good thing, because I took the Kaboom Continuous Clean System in to work and put it on the toilet in my office, where it got a much more rigorous tryout. The tank of my office toilet looks exactly like the one in the diagram and installation instructions and I had no trouble at all installing it. Pull out the existing tubing, hang the cartridge on the back of the tank, attach the two new tubes, insert the cleaning tablets, and it's ready to go.I recommend using a pair of scissors to carefully cut open the wrapper holding the cleaning tablets. If you just grab it and rip it open, like I did, you will generate a little puff of dust, which you will then inhale. It's kind of like sniffing bleach. Not pleasant. Several other reviews have commented on this product leaving their bathroom smelling strongly of bleach/chlorine. I did not find this to be an issue during use. If you take the top off the tank, then yes, it smells quite strongly of chlorine. Also, if you stand right over the toilet when you flush, you can briefly smell it. However, in regular use, I never noticed it much.Now, I'm not willing to use this product instead of regularly cleaning my toilets with a brush and toilet bowl cleaner, but I do think this is a great supplement for between cleanings. I can tell that it's working, though. The toilet I installed it in is an old toilet and it had some blue stains from some previously used toilet bowl cleaner. Within a week or so, I noticed that the blue stains were beginning to lighten up. They are now just a shadow and I hope will disappear entirely over time.

I love these Cashel Crusader Fly masks for four reasons. First, they come in a wide range of sizes. I have them in 3 different sizes (draft, warmblood, and horse) to fit all of my equines.Second, they don't have any fuzzy stuff to get dirty and matted.Third, they have an opening in the middle to pull the horse's forelock out. I know that is a little thing, but I like being able to do it.Fourth, they stay on. Even my Houdini who has managed to shed many fly masks hasn't yet gotten out of this one.

If you have not yet read book 1 of this series, Timebound, do not read this book. You will hopelessly confused. If it has been a while since you read Timebound, you might want to read it again before you start Time's Edge. There were a number of times while reading Time's Edge where I was confused because the author assumed that the reader remembered some detail from book 1 that I had forgotten. For example, there were a couple of times when the characters would say, "we can't do/must do that," and I would be pretty sure I remembered that being addressed in book 1, but I couldn't remember exactly what was said so I didn't know why.And speaking of confusion...while reading this book, I was often reminded of one of my favorite Star Trek captains, who once said, "... the future is the past, the past is the future, it all gives me a headache." There was a lot - a lot- of hopping back and forth in time. I don't know how some of the characters were able to keep track of what they were doing and when they were doing it.In spite of a few minor complaints, I did enjoy reading this book, especially once Kate and Kiernan got started on their runs to retrieve the lost Chronos keys. I thought the beginning was a little slow, but it definitely got better as it went along. I don't think Time's Edge was quite as good as Timebound, but it is still a good book. If you enjoy time travel novels, I definitely recommend this series. I can't wait for book 3.

With respect to content, this book presents an important topic with wide-ranging implications and the author has clearly done a lot of research in order to pull this information together. Individuals, businesses, and governments are all threatened by hackers, who themselves run the gamut from anarchists to criminals to agents of foreign governments (both friend and foe) to agents of our own government. However, while I think understanding the potential for disaster is important, I have to confess that I most appreciated the descriptions of ways in which the cyber skills of the military and businesses were used to effectively combat attackers ranging from insurgents in Iraq to Chinese government hackers.With respect to the writing, I thought the author did a good job of creating a very readable account of a complex subject. I also appreciated the way that the author presented most of the information without passing judgment, leaving me free to pass my own. (I still can't decide exactly how I feel about the NSA.)I thought there was a bit too much repetition in the book, but, on the other hand, this subject is a bit of a tangled web and some repetition may be unavoidable. I did start wishing about 2/3 of the way through the book that I had a big flowchart tacked up on the wall to help me keep track of who was who, who did what, and when they did it. I don't see this as a fault of the writing so much as a by-product of the complex subject.In summary, I highly recommend this book to anyone who has an interest in cyberwarfare and what is going on behind the scenes in cyberspace. However, in spite of the fact that I consider this book to be quite readable, I do agree with the other reviewer who noted that you will need a pretty high level of interest in the topic to stick with it through the entire book.

Often, when I have the chance to review some brand name product, I like it, but end up going back to my usual cheaper generic version. I don't think that will be the case with these trash bags. The plastic is thick enough to stand up to heavy and oddly shaped trash. Even boxes with sharp corners haven't yet poked any holes in the bags. The scent is perfect. So many scented/odor-control bags have an overwhelming scent to them that I don't like, but these bags' scent is pleasant and mild. They also keep odors associated with the fishy empty cat food cans under control.While I like everything about these bags, it is one particular feature that sold me and will make me go out and purchase them: the stretchy drawstring top. Unlike my usual trash bags, these are both easy to stretch around the top of the trash can and fit snugly once I've got it around the top.I've looked at some of the other reviews in which people have complained about the drawstring breaking. I'm about half way through the box and have not experienced this at all. I will note that I do not use the drawstring to lift the full bag out of the trash can. I tie up the bag while it is still in the can, then grab it by the top of the bag and lift it out, so perhaps that is why I've had no problems with the drawstring.

The action in The Delta starts with a bang, then takes off running and never stops. The book is an easy read and flows smoothly. The characters are described well, as is the African setting. The main character, Sonja, is interesting and easy to root for. And, it was a treat to read an action-adventure novel in which the standard strong, silent, tough guy hero was replaced by an equally strong, silent, tough gal heroine.Another thing that I appreciated about The Delta is that the author managed to surprise me several times with an unexpected twist or revelation that, once revealed, made perfect sense (i.e. the good kind of surprise, not the kind that leaves you scratching your head and wondering where that came from).I stayed up late several nights reading this book. I hope that the publisher plans to release all of Tony Park's book to the US market, as I'm definitely interested in reading more of his work.

I've loved most of the previous Jack Reacher books and at least liked the few I didn't love. But, the past couple of books have left me less than fully satisfied, so I was very happy to find myself firmly back in love with Child's work in Personal. That said, Personal was a bit different from most of the previous books due to the introduction of Casey Nice, a rookie agent whose presence leads Reacher to take on the role of mentor. Because of this, Reacher does a little bit more explaining of how and why he does what he does than we usually get.However, in other ways, Personal is classic Reacher. Jack is tough, smart, and supremely pragmatic, not afraid to do whatever needs to be done. As usual, Jack manages to strip away the gray in most any situation, leaving us with the fundamental black and white. And I'll admit it, sometimes it just feels good to have the bad guys get what they deserve, while the good guys ride away in their white hats - no remorse, no regret, no second guessing.As usual, Lee Child's writing is crisp and clean, with good attention to detail. Personal is a fast, easy read that is hard to put down.I've read all of the previous Jack Reacher books in order, which is the way I recommend that people read them. But, having said that, Personal is probably not a bad choice for someone unfamiliar with the series who wants to jump in without starting at the beginning. And of course, if you are a Reacher fan, you will definitely want to read this book and you will likely enjoy it.

The company I work for used to give us a new pocket calendar every year, but several years ago, stopped. Now, many of my coworkers rely on their smart phones' calendars, but I still like the old fashioned pocket calendar. So, I was really pleased to be offered the opportunity to review this 2014 - 2016 "At-A-Glance" planner.This little calendar is perfect for me. It is small and thin enough to tuck in my purse or briefcase without adding any weight or bulk. The plastic cover provides protection and creates pockets on the front and back inside covers where you can tuck business cards and receipts on a business trip. There are 3 lined pages in the back for "Notes," and 4 for "Contacts."The individual squares on the calendar are fairly small. Sufficient to enter a few words for a reminder, but not big enough to write extensive explanations or details, so if you like lots of space, this may not be the best option for you. But, if you, like me, still like having an old fashioned paper pocket calendar, this is a great choice.

Like my T-shirt says, "Michigan is My Great Lake," so I was happy to have the opportunity to review this book, which is set on the shores of Lake Michigan on Wisconsin's Door Peninsula and Washington Island. Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy "North of the Tension Line" quite as much as I hoped.I do like the author's writing style and I thought she did a good job of describing the area and assembling a nice cast of secondary characters. There is humor, mostly related to the presence of Robert the goat, who was probably my favorite character. The story is low key and sweet, but very slow paced.However, while I liked the beginning and end of the book, getting through the middle was a miserable slog. Several times I considered not finishing the book. On top of that, I didn't really like the main character, Fiona. As one of the other characters in the book commented, "she hasn't got the sense God gave a goose." Fiona brings to life the phrase "muddling through" and, while I suppose some might find it charming, it mostly just annoyed me.I dithered between giving this book 3 and 4 stars. I settled on 4 stars because the parts that I liked, I liked very much, and I think that slog through the middle of the book could be fixed fairly easily by an editor who would ruthlessly trim excess material. While I wasn't completely thrilled by "North of the Tension Line," I would be willing to read another book by this author.

This is a beautiful fan. The "royal bronze" finish is more of a rich, deep brown. The fan blades reverse from a walnut color (my choice) to a weathered black finish. This is the smoothest, quietest fan I've ever seen. It comes with a balancing kit, but it wasn't needed. And, even on the highest speed, it is practically silent.The fan can be mounted in three ways: on a slant for sloped ceilings and straight for flat ceilings, either close to the ceiling or dropped down slightly. Anyone who is reasonably handy can mount this fan without professional help, especially since there is no light kit. However, the last time I replaced a ceiling fan myself, I ran through my entire vocabulary of curse words and skinned my knuckles, so this time I opted to have an electrician come and install it. He confirmed that it was fairly simple to install, and I never heard him curse once.I turn my fan on and off using a wall switch, but the speed has to be changed using the pull chain. I added an extra piece of chain (not included) to make it long enough to reach without having to climb on a stool. I am very pleased with the quality, operation, and appearance of this fan.

I selected this book to review based on the claims that it was reminiscent of The Three Musketeers. I love Dumas' books about the Musketeers. The comparison is sort of accurate, but I'd say Traitor's Blade is more like a David Lynch version of The Three Musketeers, complete with quirky humor and a touch of surrealism. And, since Twin Peaks is one of my all-time favorite TV shows, this is definitely a good thing.The history of the main character, Falcio Val Monde, and the Greatcoats is told in flashbacks as the main story line unfolds. I confess that after the first flashback, I groaned a bit because flashbacks do often interrupt the flow of the story. But, in Traitor's Blade the arrangement worked well for me. I liked this book from the beginning, but somewhere around the midpoint was where I really fell for story and got swept up in the action. Falcio and his two friends and partners, Brasti and Kest, were easy to root for and the villains were easy to hate. I suppose they, and especially the villains, could be accused of being 2-dimensional and there are certainly a few plot points that don't bear close scrutiny, but I liked the book enough to just let those things go by without too much thought.If you enjoy fantasy, swordplay, and epic quests, I highly recommend this book. If you've also got a quirky sense of humor and enjoy a little bit of weird, I recommend it even more. This book left me with a smile on my face and I look forward to reading future books by this author.

If you haven't read the previous books in this series, I highly recommend that you do before reading this one. Indeed, on the title page, the author recommends that you read the series in order. Thus far, each book ends by setting up the next book and the story  flows directly from one book into the next.I have enjoyed all of the books in the series and Obsidian Curse is just as good as the rest. The stories are set mostly in a small town in the midwest populated by interesting and quirky characters. Like the other books in the series, Obsidian Curse blends genres - mystery, romance, fantasy - and is alternately funny, suspenseful, and dramatic. Overall, the tone is light and this book is a great airplane or beach read.I'm looking forward to the next book in the series. Obsidian Curse wraps up quite a few loose ends and, it seems to me, brings Stacy to a more stable and settled point. Of course, like the previous books in the series, this one ends with a teaser to lead you into the next book in the series and I can't wait to see what happens next.

This lamp has many positives. It feels solid, produces a bright light, and is small enough to sit on the corner of your desk and not be in the way. It really will fit in a backpack or briefcase as the manufacturer's description says. I'd say that the small size is its number one selling feature. If small size is critical for you, this lamp would be an excellent choice.However, I own a larger natural spectrum lamp and missed some of the features offered by that lamp. In particular, I really like the timer and choice of light settings on my other lamp. For me, size is not critical, so I think I will stick with my larger lamp. I will probably use this one on my craft table.

The dog says that these deserve 5 stars because he loves them, even more than he loved the Milo's Kitchen Steak Grillers that we tried recently.I like the fact that these treats are small and soft enough to pull apart into even smaller pieces if I need to. And I love that my dog gets so excited about getting the treats.  Another plus is that the treats are made in the US, since so many people are concerned about feeding dog food and treats made in China. However, I don't like the smell. It isn't a bad smell, exactly. I think I've cooked spicy chicken dishes that had a similar scent. But, it's strong and overpowering when you open the package.I do like the Milo's Kitchen brand and some of their other dog treats, so while I will certainly buy Milo's Kitchen dog treats in the future, I probably won't buy these again.

First, if you haven't read the first two books in this trilogy, do not read this one - yet. You need to read Pines and Wayward before you read The Last Town. And, if you've already read and liked the first two books, you will definitely want to read this one. Pre-order it now, if you haven't already.Having already read and reviewed the first two books, I find myself at somewhat of a loss in attempting to review this one because I feel like I've already said it all. The characters are interesting and compelling, the action is non-stop, and the suspense will keep you turning the pages way past bedtime. And, once again, the author managed to surprise me with the end - I never saw it coming.Like the first two books, there are some plot holes, some things that don't quite add up, and some nagging little questions that occasionally tapped on the back of my head as I read The Last Town. But, the story whipped along so quickly and I enjoyed the ride so much that it was relatively easy to stuff all those things into a little box, close the lid, and toss it into a closet.I highly recommend this trilogy to anyone who ever watched and loved The Twilight Zone. That is what I was most often reminded of while reading Pines, Wayward, and The Last Town.

This 6 piece bakeware set is probably the best I have seen at a great price. It has everything you need for basic baking needs and makes a great gift for a new home or bridal shower. I moved into a new place and was looking for a good 'starter' set of bakeware.The 6 pieces are high quality and are easy to clean becasue of the non-stick surface. I love having a cupcake/muffin pan that makes 12 because my old one only made 8 . My only issue is that the loaf pan is a bit smaller than it looks. Other than that, this set gets plenty of use in my home!

Harry wanted a dog. Not just any dog, but a small dog. A cute little dog like the one he and his brother had when he was a boy. Her name was Queenie. Harry and his brother really loved Queenie, but they didn‚Äôt take very good care of her needs like feeding her and walking her, so their mom sent her away to live with another family.One day Harry came across a store that sold life-like mechanical dogs. Just out of curiosity, because Harry wanted a REAL dog, not some robot.. The salesman, Archibald Galdensen, seemed to be very well informed on how these robot-dogs worked. He told Harry that even though they looked and acted just like a REAL dog, they didn‚Äôt require any of the usual caretaking obligations like feeding and walking. They looked completely life-like, too. Nobody would tell Harry didn‚Äôt have a real dog.Mr Galdensen asked Harry what type of dog he prefered and what sex. Harry told him he wanted a cute little mixed breed and female. He basically was describing Queenie, the dog he had as a boy. Pretty soon, Harry was walking out with a new dog-a very expensive, mechanical, dog.Harry knew his wife Pam didn‚Äôt want any dogs. He knew he was going to have one hell of a time explaining to her why he came home with one. He also knew once his kids saw Queenie, as he name her, (after his boyhood dog), they would fall in love and Pam would not be able to say ‚Äúno‚Äù.As soon as Harry told her Queenie wouldn‚Äôt eat or poop like a real dog, she would accept Queenie into the family. Everything would work itself out.Harry was right. At first, Pam wasn‚Äôt happy that Harry brought home a dog without consulting her first, but after seeing how happy their two children, Ariel and her brother, Jackson were and how much they loved playing with Queenie, she agreed the dog could stay.For a while, things were great. Ariel and Jackson loved Queenie, and Harry finally had his dog. Then one day, something happened that shouldn‚Äôt have. After that things were a little off with Queenie. Things started to happen. Some things that just didn‚Äôt seem right.Was Queenie really just a computer run dog with a glitch? Or was something deeper and more sinister happening?Sal Conte writes horror that starts you off feeling confident you won‚Äôt be scared, but then builds a story that has you keeping the lights on at night. When I began Baad Dog, I felt like I was riding a roller coaster of reading, the story building, the tension getting greater. It keep me on edge, as most of his books do. It was clear to me Queenie wasn‚Äôt what Harry thought and that things would not end too well.Baad Dog is a novella that only took me about a day and a half to read. It had a pace that started off creeping along and then shot off into a nail biting suspense thriller. Beware the BAAD DOG!

All Of Me is the second book in the Covington Cove series by Kelly Moran, which began with book one: Return to Me.Though characters from book one are a big part of All Of Me, it centers on two new people not in Return To Me,  Alec, who is a best-selling writer of horror fiction stuck with a bad case of writer's block, and Faith, a young woman starting a new beginning for herself, away from her home.Alec is strong, but sensitive, a quality I very much appreciate seeing in a lead male.Faith is sweet, shy and a bit vulnerable.  I admit at first I was not sure I could see these two as a couple.Both Alec and Faith have come to Covington Cove in Wilmington, NC for their own reasons. Alec, for his brother's wedding and Faith to take on a position as a care giver for Mia Covington's younger sister.Mia was the heroine of Return to Me and it was nice to see her and Cole again and know their story continues to be a happy one.Now back to Alec and Faith. Both of these people have some heavy emotional baggage.Alec has been through a rough past which has caused him to withdraw from any real emotional connection with a woman. Faith has never felt loved by anyone, including her own parents.The connection between the two of them starts out slow, but builds as the story moves forward.I'm glad Kelly Moran knows how to write a realistic story and write it well, NO two people like Alec and Faith would come together in real life without some obstacles in their way and Ms Moran shows this in a way that is believable.I felt Faith's insecurities as if they were my own and I sympathized with Alec's plight.Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this sweet story about letting go of the past, moving on and letting your heart be your guide.

These are excellent oven mitts. I especially like the reinforced top of the mitt and thumbs. This really keeps your hands from getting hot and makes handling pots as well as fresh out of the oven dishes easier. They are a heavy duty quality, but still look nice enough for my home kitchen.

I have a Philips Sonicare Diamond clean rechargeable toothbrush and when I need replacement brush heads, I always just bought what came with the original brush kit. They worked well and I didn't think there was anything that would be better. After trying these adaptive clean heads, I know I'm not going back to the others.These are slightly larger than the original heads and not as soft, so if you prefer a smaller head with soft bristles, I would not recommend these. What I can definitely say is that they are quite powerful in deep cleaning. After the first use, I could feel a difference and my teeth felt cleaner than with the other brush heads.I have had some dental work done and I am always concerned that I'm not getting my teeth as clean after eating certain foods. The bristles really reach all the back areas of my mouth and I didn't feel I had to "double brush" as I sometimes felt with the others.The only thing I do not like (and it wasn't worth taking off a star for) is the brush cover. It fits on the front of the brush and not over the entire top, like the original diamond clean heads. Small sacrifice to make in exchange for a cleaning feeling mouth. I will be buying these from now on.

My hair's natural state lies somewhere between straight and wavy. It's very thick and I usually spend a lot of time getting it to look good. Living in a place with high humidity makes it hard to control my frizz and sometimes I just want to wash my hair and go without a lot of fuss.There are several brands of sea salt sprays out there, and I admittedly have tried quite a few. When Tresemme came out with their version, I knew it would be worth trying, since I use many of their products already with great results.Since my hair is not super straight, I followed the directions for wavy hair. I towel dried my hair to get rid of excess water and then applied the spray liberally over my entire head, including underneath. Then I lightly combed it through before scrunching a bit. After that, I let it dry naturally. My end result was indeed lots of waves that looked better than the frizz I am used to if I air dry alone. I ended up with loose soft waves, with a just a bit of stickiness that I was able to get rid of by scrunching up my hair a bit more.My hair is not real long, but I imagine if it was , the results would have been even better.This is something I would definitely use when I want a carefree, messy look to my hair and I don't want to spend a lot of time flat ironing it straight.The product has a light sent that is not really "beachy" but not unpleasant, either.

This is a great tablecloth for a large table. When I have my table leaf in, it fits great, but without the leaf, it does hang over on the ends. It's quite attractive. I like the two-tone effect. The material is linen-like in feel, but holds up well in the washer and dryer and did not require ironing! I might get the matching napkins , since I will mainly use this for special occasions or holidays

I already have a small air purifier that I keep in my bedroom because it seems to be the one room that always collects dust and I have allergies that cause me to wake up during the night congested. When I saw the AeroMax Air Purifier was created specifically for pet owners, I thought that might work better because I have a cat ,who sleeps on my bed with me. I was wrong. I'm not saying the AeroMax does not work at all, I just don't feel it is better than what I am using.First,it says on the box that it is quiet. Well, I can tell you that it's not THAT quiet. If you leave the fan set to low, it's not terribly loud, but my other purifier is quieter on the highest setting. I can actually hear this in my living room when I'm watching TV. I would never be able to set the fan to high, especially in my bedroom because it's keep me from falling asleep. I do NOT suggest it for bedrooms unless you aren't bothered by noise at night.Another thing that I am concerned with is the expense of buying TWO replacement filters. The HEPA and the carbon. I know having two filters probably makes it more effective, but these filters are not cheap. I am guessing my the amount of dust I already had to clean off them in little over a month, I would be buying them often.I don't really feel this product is worth the money it costs as well as for replacement filters, plus it doesn't seem to do that much better of a job than what I have , which is smaller in size and less noisy at the highest speed.What I did like is the fact it's black and less noticeable, but appearance is not as important as quality to me. Also, it did not come with any type of instruction manual. Just a fold out which didn't say much.This might work for someone with a larger house if you put it somewhere where the noise will not interfere , but it's not for me. I'll stick to what I have
See my review here https://www.nightowlreviews.com/v5/Reviews/Lisa-Mason-reviews-Second-Life-by-S-J-Watson

I've been using clumping cat litter for years and been pretty satisfied with the quality. My only issue was always the weight of the package made it difficult to transport from store to car to house.When manufacturers started to make these lightweight versions, I bought one of my usual brand to try. I was pretty happy with it, but am always open to trying a different brand to see if there is anything better or different about it.The Cat's Pride Fresh and Light is much darker in color than any litter I have ever used. It seems to have a finer grain to it. The scent isn't that bad and it's not too strong that it can be smelled outside of the room I keep the liter box. I think it's just enough to mask odor, without blowing you away with too much scent.What I did not like was that it didn't seem to clump as well as other ones I have tried. When scooping out the hard pieces, the ones that were not already broken up ,broke when I scooped them. I'm a little OCD about my box being as clean as possible and I try to clean out any waste as soon as I am aware my cat used the box. I was changing the whole box about once every other week because the previous brand I used clumped so tight, there was rarely any extra left in the box. With this litter, I had to change it after one week of use. For me, that's not cost effective. Also, I had to used an entire bucket to fill my box. With other brands, I was still left with some to "top off" after I took out waste. I think it's because the grain is so fine. I don't find it to be much lighter, either. Overall, It's not bad, just not better than my current litter.

Give Up The Ghost is book 2 in The Phantoms Trilogy, which centers on a team of investigators featured on a popular ghosthunting tv show.I had previously read book one, Ghost of  A Promise, and really enjoyed it, but I have to say I enjoyed this book much more.  The story centers on Paul , a researcher for the team and Kerry, one of the investigators.Paul and Kerry have been the best of friends for 6 years and when Kerry is faced which a frightening paranormal experience of her own, he is the first person she calls for help.  Paul rushes to Kerry's side. His is concerned as her friend, but also because unbeknownst to Kerry, Paul has been in love with her from the moment they met.As the team sets off on their next investigation in a small desert ghosttown, Kerry's experiences continue and Paul is drawn even closer to her. When he can no longer fight his feeling, he lets loose with a kiss. Kerry is surprised, but begins to realize that deep down, she has also felt something for Paul that extends beyond friendship.In most cases, all of this word be good news for two friends to admit their growing love, but it is clearly stated in both of their contracts, as with all the Phantoms team members, that any type of romantic interaction is prohibited and grounds for termination.Afraid of losing their careers, Kerry and Paul try to keep their secret for the time being and concentrate on the investigation at hand. As many frightening situations come about, it becomes harder, though, and Paul begins to think maybe his feelings for Kerry are more important than the TV show he has been a part of for the past 6 years.The writing has a perfect blend of the paranormal storyline mixed with the blooming romance between Paul and Kerry. I enjoyed reading about the teams investigation and discoveries so much, it would still kept my interest if it didn't include the romance. However, Kelly Moran is an exceptional romance author and Paul and Kerry's story definitely as interesting as the paranormal storyline.I'm not willing to give too much away, as I believe in leaving it up to the readers to find out for themselves how it all turns out in the end and trust me, it is well worth it. This book was a page-turner for me and I am quite excited to read the 3rd book as well. I image it will be just as good, if not better! Kelly Moran continues to be one of my favorite authors and her books are always at the top of my "to be read" list.

This shower curtain is much nicer then it looks in the picture.  Made from a very fine polyester material, in an elegant lattice  lace pattern. I was glad to see there is a clear plastic reinforcement under the top, because the holes for hooks are not lined with any type of metal grommets. The material itself is quite sheer, making it see through. I always use a liner with my shower curtains, but with this one, a clear one will look better then white.
