I have a family of 7 and most people in the home have more than one device.  This has greatly improved the situation where charging all those devices is concerned (the kids still find other reasons to fight).Previously I had a full power strip and was struggling to fit enough little bricks on it to charge all the devices.  Further most of the bricks provided 500ma charges resulting in longer charge times.  With this now we are able to charge all the devices at full speed.  Most of our devices are Apple based, so there is one port that is not as effective, but all the ports seem to charge apple devices with at least 1000mA, based on experience and other reviews.  I do not have the equipment to measure the current (not so lucky to be a Vine member).I also suspect that this device is much more efficient than individual power bricks.  When I get some time I am going to test that theory.In any case I am very happy with this charging station and whole-heartedly recommend it.

I recently read several SOLR books, brushing up my skills making sure that I was current with the technology.  This was the best of the three in this go and the best SOLR resource I have found yet.  That said it falls short of the "Mastering" title, in favor of catering more to the beginning user.  If I find a better resource, I reserve the option to knock a star off for these reasons.The books that I read in order of preference were:Mastering Apache Solr: A practical guide to get to grips with Apache SolrScaling Big Data with Hadoop and Solr (Community Experience Distilled)Apache Solr High PerformanceWhile this book needed additional editing and was rife with problems that reflected a lack of editorial oversight, it was by far the best of these three books.The book provides a complete tutorial with step by step processes to implement everything discussed in the book.  There are complete code examples, and even a section providing Java examples, of each of the API commands, something lacking even on the Internet.Chapter 1 provides an excellent overview of the SOLR project and Lucene core.  By the end of chapter 1 you will have setup a SOLR instance and indexed some documents and be ready follow along with the remainder of the book.Chapter 2 is a deep dive into schema.  Using the MusicBrainz data as an example it illustrates how to create a schema for this data step by step.  There is detailed coverage of each parameter with examples of when and when not to use each option.  There is a good introduction to Analyzers and Tokenizers.Chapter 3 covers importing from various formats.  This includes the commandline options to use the provided importers for XML and CSV, which facilitates loading the sample data for the exercises.  There is coverage on using Apache Tika to index binary document formats such as PDF, DOC or even DLL or JAR files.  There is brief coverage of deleting, committing and optimize.Chapter 4 covers querying.  The focus here is more on the various query arguments and parameters than the actual details of finding data.  That said it is a helpful overview of the various parameters and does well to cover how they can be used.Chapter 5 Advanced Querying does more to cover the actual details of building powerful queries.  It provides an excellent analysis of using DisMax eDisMax.  There is also good coverage of faceting, functions, highlighting, and geographical search.Chapter 6 covers Boosting Performance.  This chapter covers tuning Java heap, deactivating unused features, near realtime search, SOLR caching and replication.  The coverage here is good, but not great.  It is thorough in that it covers the options well, but falls short of really providing good guidance on the tradeoffs, and complications that come about in the real world.Chapter 7 Deploying SOLR.  I found this chapter to be a waste.  It is little more than copies of online setup tutorials.  It reaches too far trying to cover deployment in too many different containers, provides insufficient detail, and falls short of coverage of what is globally important when deploying SOLR.  What it did cover is left best to online tutorials for the various Java containers.  I would have much preferred coverage of the pitfalls of SOLR deployment in the real world.Chapter 8 Integration.  This chapter provides a good overview of performing basic operations in Java, PHP(PHP-Solr) and Ruby(RSOLR), with light coverage of other options.  I would have preferred better coverage of the REST interfaces, here, there was none though most of the operations were covered elsewhere in the book.  While Java was useful to me, I prefer Perl and Python to Ruby or PHP so that was of little benefit to me, though there are wide users bases of those libraries, documentation of these various interfaces is generally better than what is contained in this chapter.Chapter 9 SolrCloud is a good addition and provides the best coverage of SolrCloud I have seen in print.  It provided some details I could not even find online.  In particular it had good coverage of splitting shards.  However, it fell short in that it didn't fully cover how to reallocate those shards within the cluster.  It seems there are as of yet no good resources when it comes to balancing shards within SolrCloud.In summary it was a very good read and helped immensely, but ultimate I think it falls short of the "Mastering" title.  I think that some of the primers could be omitted in favor of deeper detail on some subjects as noted above, in a "Mastering" book.  As it stands this is a good intro to intermediate title, but will have useful information for SOLR users at all but the mastery level.

I recently read several SOLR books, brushing up my skills making sure that I was current with the technology.  This fell short of the others and the promise of its title.The books that I read in order of preference were:Mastering Apache Solr: A practical guide to get to grips with Apache SolrScaling Big Data with Hadoop and Solr (Community Experience Distilled)Apache Solr High PerformanceThis book contains what I consider to be one of the most bizarre inclusions, Chapter 1 shows how to install SOLR as a service on windows.  Why you would ever want to do that is beyond me, I can only assume that the offer felt this inclusion would make the topic more accessible to those on the Windows platform.  I certainly hope nobody intends to run a serious SOLR installation on the Windows platform.  This is a recipe for frustration.  If however you are insistent in running on Windows, this is the book for you.Chapter 2 provides excellent coverage of scoring and the various ways to leverage and control scoring within SOLR.Chapter 3 is about performance optimization.  This chapter is good, but really just talks about the features that make SOLR performant. It provides detail on how to configure and use those features, but it does not address what I have found in my experience to be the crux of the problem of SOLR performance, system tuning.Chapter 4 is labelled Additional Performance Optimization, but has little to do with performance and more to do with advanced SOLR features.  In fact use of most of these features can severely impact performance.  This chapter covers similar document queries, sorting by function, homophones, stopwords and word filtering.Chapter 5 is Troubleshooting.  This chapter covers some very common scenarios that will inevitably happen in a production SOLR environment.  If nothing else the list of scenarios can be very useful in creating your disaster recovery plan.  That said, the list is not really complete, and the coverage is light.  For example one of the sections is basically just covering the use of optimize, as though that is a troubleshooting technique, and not a regular best practice.  The section on garbage collection is a good start, but really any book on SOLR should have a chapter dedicated to GC.Chapter 6 is poorly named, "Performance Optimization with ZooKeeper".  It should have just been named "ZooKeeper".  ZooKeeper does nothing to improve the performance of SOLR, though it is a requisite stepping stone to the world of SOLR Cloud.  This chapter also does not discuss in detail making ZooKeeper performant.  Rather this chapter is a ZooKeeper tutorial, and a pretty good one.And the book abruptly ends.  No further coverage of SOLR Cloud.  No coverage of high performance indexing or data ingestion.  No discussion of tuning SOLR for large installations, scaling search, balancing memory allocations, and so on.  There is a smattering of information throughout about performance optimized schemas, but it is not collected or concise.  I feel like the author hit his deadline and submitted what he had.This book was a good start, but falls short of being more than an introduction to SOLR and certainly does not live up to its name.  This book provided very little in the way of code samples.  Most of the topics were covered at a very high level without significant detail.  For these reasons I rate it 3 stars.

I recently read several SOLR books, brushing up my skills making sure that I was current with the technology.  This was one of the more helpful as it specifically addresses some of the changes that come with SOLR cloud.The books that I read in order of preference were:Mastering Apache Solr: A practical guide to get to grips with Apache SolrScaling Big Data with Hadoop and Solr (Community Experience Distilled)Apache Solr High PerformanceThis book was good, though fell short of detail.  If you have little or know Hadoop experience and are interested in SOLR Cloud, this book provides a good primer on Hadoop to the extent needed to support SOLR Cloud.  The explanations and description of the various components of Hadoop were very accessible and clear.This book provided very little in the way of code samples.  Most of the topics were covered at a very high level without significant detail.  For this reason I cannot rate it 5 stars.  The book does contain command line examples to accomplish various tasks, but little in the way of detail in the options of those command lines such that if the example is not precisely what you need the book provides no guidance on how you would customize the command.The book provides good coverage of the configuration options for solr, both in the server config and schema.  There is light coverage of the various options when creating a schema but it is not complete.In total this was a good read but a little light on detail of SOLR.

So far I have enjoyed this book, however it falls short of what I would expect from a "Mastering" book.  As an ElasticSearch consultant I have some experience working with the platform and doing some advanced work.  While this book does a very good job of introducing ElasticSearch and providing a reasonably through platform to build on, there are many advanced topics that are not covered.  There were a few times where I went to this book to find further information and found major features not even existing in the index of the book.  Overall the information is good, but falls short.For instance, the term scan is not found in the index, indicating the book has no coverage of scan queries, a fairly important advanced topic which deserves coverage in a Mastering level book.  You cannot Master ElasticSearch without knowing scan queries.  Chapter 8 provides some coverage of the poorly documented Java API.  It contains code snippets, that are almost useful.  That is it shows how to get a result set for each of the API commands, but not how to use that result set.  While this is fine for say the delete index command, it is not so helpful with the get aliases command.  While often I would consider attempting to write about such in a book to be redundant, the current state of the ElasticSearch javadocs and the inconsistency of that API, demand that we need a more thorough source of information which users can reference when trying to do even simple tasks with the API.All in all however, if you were to ask which ElasticSearch book to buy, this is the one I would recommend today.

When I first started drip watering and bought a package of assorted parts, I saw the cute little elbows and laughed.  I thought surely there is no need for these, the hose is more than flexible enough, what could I possible need these for.  How wrong I was.I use drip watering in my garden where I have to remove it each year to till and amend the soil.  I then return the system and use it's flexibility to water each plant individually, automatically.  I have attached to my timed sprinkling system and have a 1" rigid pipe that acts as a backbone to my garden system.  This rigid pipe has a spigot every 20 ft to which I attach a 1/2" flexible tubing using barbs I attach 1/4" driplines with mini sprinklers or drippers to each plant.  When I started I used straigh barbs to pierce the 1/2" and attach the 1/4" lines.  When I went to remove it from the garden the next year I had a problem, the barbs started snapping due to the strain.It dawned on me that if instead of using the straight barbs, I used the elbows they would be able to pivot on the main line and would have less strain.  I have not had a problem with breaking barbs since I moved to the elbows instead of the straight barbs.  At the same time I have replaced nearly every straight barb I used  as they have all broken.If you are going to do drip watering you need the elbows, they are not for making neat corners in your tubing, they are for attaching the smaller 1/4" line to the larger 1/2" flex tube.

I have always enjoyed my Dell flat-screens and felt they were a grade above the alternatives in build quality.  As an IT professional I get hands on with many others and have not seen or used one that I preferred to my Dell.However, my Dell monitors have always been purchased by my employer, at significant expense.So when I needed a monitor due to taking a new job I went to work trying to find one that I would be happy with.  When I came across this one I was very happy to see that there was an option to have another Dell that would meet my needs, that I could afford.  I was very tempted to step up and buy the more expensive model to get the claimed color accuracy but am satisfied that I did not.After using this monitor for a month, I am very satisfied with it.  The screen is definitely larger than the one I was using before, I thought it was a 24 as well but perhaps not.  I am very happy that it is 1920x1200.  It pairs perfectly with my Dell 2007FP which is 1600x1200.  The 1680x1050 I was using before always annoyed me that it was larger but with lower resolution, I never understood that trend in the industry.  This monitor is notably brighter and whiter than the Dell2007FP it sits next too.  Out of the box I had to reduce the brightness, it was just too much.In summary I will say unless you are a professional in need of perfect color matching, I cannot see a reason that you would be disappointed with this monitor.

I have a red Cool Fire IV which I bought from my buddy who owns a vape shop here locally.  I am definitely considering getting another one of these bad boys, as the size is right and with the iSub tank or the iSub G tank both of these are from Innokin are small enough yet amazingly hold 4 mls for the iSub and 4.5 mls for the iSub G tank. The cool Fire IV and an iSub tank you have a killer combo that will have you blowing some big time clouds.  When your done creating the cloud bank in your living room you can tuck the device with the tank into a pocket, then play dumb when some body asks who made this fog bank?  Seriously though, this is an all around great little device, you can turn the device off one of two ways; firstly you can tap the fire button 3 times and it will power down the device.  Secondly; you can turn the switch on the bottom of the device to the off position and this will power down the device as well.  Just don't make the same mistake I did when I first got mine;  I knew about the switch on the bottom,from youtube videos I watched.  However when I got mine, attached an atty, tapped the fire button 3 times...nothing..tried it again...nothing, took my atty off, tried again...nothing.  By now I'm gettin pissed cause this brand new device isn't working...WTF over!!  It was then I remembered the switch..that little switch on the bottom that was the root of my problem, after that, I have never turned it off, no reason to as it gets used daily and I figure if I really need to turn it off I will just use the 3 clicks of the fire button.  Guess that about wraps up my review of the Innokin Cool Fire IV 40 watt box mod, small on size..big on power.  Be well, be safe, VAPE ON!

Bought this device about a month maybe 6 weeks ago from another online vendor, wanted a device that would be capable of at least 50 watts,60 watts is more preferable.  The MVP 3.0 Pro from Innokin is the cats ass, will fire down to a .2 ohm coil, up to around 3.0 ohms so this will work with the majority of tanks and clearomizers on the market today.  I have seen anything from a Protank, Aerotanks using a 1.8 ohm coil to a Stilare RDA, a Turbo RDA that has a small turbine fan in side.  The Turbo is probably my favorite RDA for the MVP 3.0, with my Stilare and Stilare V3 being my second choice.  I have also used a couple of my sub ohm tanks like my Atlantis, my Melo, or my STARRE sub tanks work well too.  With the MVP 3.o Pro being such a versatile device, nott only can you vape a day or two with the large 4500 mAh battery, you can with the integral micro USB cable can charge an Android phone, a digital camera, an Android tablet, any device that uses a micro USB end you can charge it up.  Heck..I've even used mine to charge up my Cool Fire IV also made by Innokin.  The battery on this lasts and lasts I can get 2-3 days in between charges with this device.  My only wish would be that they would have made the other end of the charge cable a lightening end so I can charge my iPhone 6+ or my iPad Air, not a big deal, as ther is a USB port on the bottom of the device and a switch so you can take your charge/data cable for your iPhone/iPad and charge it as well, s I have tried that as well.  Works well, and was able to charge my phone up enough to last me until I could get to my truck and plug in to a 12 volt system and charge my phone the rest of the way to full.  What else, I've covered the drippers, and clearos, the sub tanks, charging other devices while you vape.  Speaking of charging while you vape, once you have your MVP 3.0 Pro plugged in to charge, you can vape while charging or as it is more commonly called pass though...vape while you charge, makes it nice because if this is your only device..you would be s*** out of luck if you couldn't use this as a pass through device.  I any event, this in my humble opinion is probably Innokin's finest device.  I have been an Innokin fan from almost the time I started vaping, I have the iTaste v3 with the 800 mAh battery, had two, lost one, bought another, then my original iaste started acting up so I bought an iTaste v4 with the 1000 mAh battery, I've had the MVP 2.0, still have my original, plus another, I also have the 20 watt and now the MVP 3.0 Pro 60 watt device.  Innokin, always has been on the cutting edge and their products are second to none, the iSub tanks go well with this device, so there is another option  as well as a Kanger sub tank or any of the myriad sub tanks on the market today.  Thank you all for taking the time to read my review of the Innokin MVP 3.0 Pro 60 watt box mod. Get one for yourself, get one for a family member or your wife if she vapes, as this is the best that there is in this wattage range and for the price..you can't beat it.  Be well, be safe, VAPE ON!

I only have one of these batteries, bought from a local vape shop who did recommend this battery highly.  I was lucky as the day I bought mine he did have a couple left in stock.  Seems as though these fly off the shelf quicker than eggs through a hen, that said; I don't know if these are rewraps or if they are Samsung, LG, Sony..whatever.  All I care about is..does it work, if so..how well, how long does it last, etc.  This is what I have discovered with this battery; Currently this battery is in myy iPV mini running a 1 ohm coil in my Atlantis V1 at 27.5-30 watts, it does an exceptional job in that capacity.  I get at least a full day out of this battery, no errors, no nothing, it just works and works well.  So what if it has been rewraped..it works doesn't it..as long as the buyer is aware that this may be a battery that has a different wrapper than what you may think it should.  As long as you practice safe vaping and don't get stupid and try and have a build that is wayy too low for this battery/batteries to be safe, as long as when you insert this battery into whatever device it is that you are using, you have the battery in correctly and not backwards, that your device powers on and the atty that you have on your device is compatible who cares what it looks like, I could give a s*** less weather or not it had any wrap on it at all. Put some brown paper from a paper bag and call it what ever you want, buy a truck load rewrap them yourself sell them for just over what you paid for em, you'll have enough to buy more , then more, pretty soon you'll be the brown paper bag battery king or queen lol. Any way, I get good life out of this battery, it works every time I turn my iPV on and take a toke..hey I'm a happy camper.PS:  I must apologize for any grammatical errors, repeating myself, etc.  As a 100% disabled vet along with leg and back issues I also have memory and other...um...issues within the brain pan.  That said, I lok at each new day as a gift, lets all try and get along.  Be well, be safe, VAPE ON!

I've had my Melo tank for..gosh around 4-5 months and in all that time have had zero problems with it.  I get great flavor, great clouds,(depending upon the juice I use of course..I prefer max VG). The coils last forever it seems, I'm getting between 4-6 weeks on some coils, with no degradation of flavor.  However when the coil goes...it goes, you get that burnt nasty taste and you know its time to change the coil.  If I have one nit pick it would be that this tank is just a tad bigger, I think this holds around 2.8mls. maybe 3mls but no more.  If they made a tank that held 3.5-4.0mls that would at least put it on par with the Kanger sub tank mini, or even the Innokin iSub and iSub G tank series.  There is a fix for this, I found the Atlantis 5ml replacement tank will fit and work just fine on the Melo base, matter of fact the Atlantis coils are a great substitute for the Melo coils if you happen to run out.  Up until recently I had an Atlantis 5ml replacement and replaced that with the 7ml replacement tank.  Both worked superbly with no issues what so ever.  I wound up buying a couple of clone Atlantis bases and a 5ml glass tank, and now have 3 Atlantis V1 clone sub tanks, put the original tank back on the Melo base and have the Melo tank.  I also recently won a Kanger Tech Subox mini kit which is very nice indeed.  So I have a Kanger sub tank mini, and recently traded a Kayfun clone for a Kanger sub tank V1 the 6ml version, the sub tank plus the latest version holds 7mls, 6ml and 4.5ml is enough for my Kanger setup...for now.  Eventually maybe all the Kanger sub tanks, but for now..the Melo sub tank is a winner in my book.  You get great flavor, can create a fog bank in your living room...ask me how I know this!  My wife came in and said to me..you do know there is a fog bank in our living room, I looked up from my laptop..sure enough our fairly large living room had a cloud bank that was um...quite thick, especially in and around my couch.  Any way, I can brag on this tank all day, until you get one and see for yourself and see for yourself what a really nice tank this is, all my talking doesn't mean squat.  Get one, you'll thank me eventually.  Be well, be safe,VAPE ON!PS: In my photo I have my iStick Melo sub tank on an Elitel 50 watt box mod this device is produced by a company called Luxyoun in China..where else.  This device is a little wonky, its no Siegelei by any stretch, but it does OK for my needs.  I'm running a 0.5 ohm coil at 33 watts giving me around 4 volts, for me that good at this time, who is to say an day from now I won't have it up to 35-40 watts, but for now, its all good.  VAPE ON!

WOW..what a kick ass little mod the Kanger Subox is!  I did not purchase mine from Amazon, I actually won mine from a contest on ecig.com.  I will say that the new version of the sub tank mini is a hell of a lot better than the original version.  I had the first gen sub ohm tank from Kanger, it was a decn't tank, and I could do a decent build on the RBA deck, but this latest version is killer!  Now I will add a caveat to my statement concerning this new and improved version of the subtank.  While it oes blow some great clouds using the standard coils that come with this tank.  I also have the original sub tank, not the plus, but the first gen sub tank from Kanger, consequently I also have coils for the first gen that can be used in any version.  However; what I am finding from my own personal experience and use is that the older stock OCC coils are decnt, they are no match for the new 2nd gen version of the OCC coils.  The new coils offer much better flavor and clouds than the 1st gen OCC coils.  My advice, find a local vape shop or shop on line get you some Kanger OCC coils V2.  They will work in all the Kanger sub ohm tanks and I belieeve they do the Kanger sub tanks much better justice.  Not that the original OCC coils are bad...they are not, ya just gotta drop your wattage down a bit to between 20-35 watts depending on the juice you are using.  I'm sucking on mine right now using a 1st gen OCC coil with Rocky Top Vapor Audio Fog Mabgo Melon max VG juice at about 25-27.5 watts and its doing just fine.  Much more than that and it starts tasting burnt..you might get to 30 watts with this juice but no more.  Id this was one of the new coils I could crank this up to around 35-37 watts with no problem using a 0.5 ohm coil.Now, as for the box mod itself...what a gem!  The nice thing about this is the fact you can just pop a fresh battery in whenever the one you are using is depleted.  Or, knowing that your battery is getting low, you can always take the the micro USB cor that comes with this package, plug one end into the mod, the other end into a wall adapter, or a free USB port on your computer.  I do prefer plugging in to the wall, or just replacing the battery with a fresh one.  Using your computer will take entirely too long and personally I feel an exercise in frustration. On a positive note though, if you are plugged into your computer you can vape while you are doing whatever it is you're doing on your computer.  At 50 watts..this box mod gives you plenty of power in a small package that is easily hid in a shirt pocket or for you ladies; in an outside pocket of your purse.  So; you get a 50 watt box mod a sub ohm tank that will hold 4.5mls of your favorite juice, an RBA deck so you can build your own coils.  You also receive a 0.5 and a 1.5 ohm coil V2 some small squares of organic Japanese cotton so you can build a coil or two.  A micro USB cable to charge your device.  Only other things ya gotta buy is a good high drain battery of at least 20 amps.  I have 2 of the Efest purple batteries that are 2100 mAh  30A IMR 18650 3.7 volt Li-Mn batteries, also have 4 VTC-4 batteries which I really like.  Pretty much any IMR high drain 18650 Li-Mn 20-35 amp battery will work.  Just make sure it is rated at 20 amps or better,and you'll be fine, these kits can be had far and wide on the internet for about $60-$100.  While this is a great kit, kicks ass every which way it can, I don't feel this is a $100 mod, just my humble opinion, I could see about $80-$90, which I think if I had to pay for mine was around $85.00.  Get yerself one this is a great bit of kit no reason now to not sub ohm vape.  Be well, be safe, God bless VAPE ON!

This item I've had for..roughly 2-3 weeks now, it is nice, made of delrin therefore will hold up to my use and some time abuse, whenever I screw up and my mod rolls off whatever its on and lands on the floor...that kind of abuse.  Unintentional abuse..how about that..works for me.  That said, I can really only give it 4 stars, because yes this will fit on my Plume Veil, but not my Stilare, nor will it ft on my Stilare ver 3.  Let me rephrase that last statement, or make things a bit clearer; it fits, just not well, very very loose on my Stilare bot the first gen and ver.3  the Plume Veil, fits on and works very well, really wanted one for my Stilare and the ver 3 Stilare.  I do have a couple other drippers that this will kinda work with as well.  I really wanted this for the Stilare, figured if it worked then I would order another so I could use it with my other Stilare.  well...ya win some and ya loose some.  Can't say as I lost, I at least have an additional one for my Plume Veil and can use it with that attomizer when the mood strikes.

My daughter thanked me, so I thank y'all.  This battery which is heads above the one that came with my daughter's netbook.  She can use her netbook all day and still have battery left at the end of her day.  Good deal, thank y'all so much. great battery, inexpensive, and works, and works very well.

This is one small, flat, biggest readout multimeter that I've seen.  Get you one of these..if you are like me and space is a real concern..you could do worse than to get one of these VOM or by its better known name..a multimeter.  What I like about it is the compactness of it and the many features it carries other than reading voltage, ohms,etc. For me and the many uses I have for a multimeter this one I can throw i my pocket and go, not have to worry about am I gonna break it or not.The display readout is awesome, large numbers,large enough for my eyes to read it so that is sufficient for me.  I have a large multifunction multimeter, that has the ammeter or amp readings, so all ya gotta do is push the button it opens a set of hands or pinchers ya stick around the wire an it will show you what kind of load you are pulling, etc.  Its nice, but every time I build a coil for my E Cigarette, I don't want to have to dig that big ol honkin thing just to read what the ohm or what the sub ohm reading is.  This is spot on and is accurate as my bigger multi meter.

These are nice 10 amp batteries, I needed a button/nipple top 18650 for my one tube mech mod.  Got these in last week, it is 6/18/15 think they arrived this past Saturday the 14th, After getting them a full charge put one into my onetube mech mod...how about that..the damn thing DOES work.  Great batteries for what they are.

Just received these a couple days ago, wasn't real sure what to expect however when they did arrive I thought...COOL!!  Its about time someone thought up something that is efficient, small and lightweight and works like it supposed to.  Enter...Vapor Nutz a new product that personally I think is as easy as it looks to use and works damn well.  I find that although I don't use my eGo batteries much any moree I am letting my daughter use the smallest of the lot as she uses the small batteries and has some juice laced with Kratom and helps with her pain levels.  My daughter like myself is a disabled vet, she is at 60%, I'm at 100%.  My daughter like this as it will hold her cigalike..no, its better than a cigalike but it the same size any way, it holds her little battery and she is a happy camper.For my use..I like the XL size, use it for my tube mech mods and it works...that's it..it just plain works.  Could used something like this a year ago, that was before I knew anything.  Been vaping 2 years now and this by far is the best little device for holding your mod in place and not havin it with your nice new Lemo tank and the whole mess rolls of the table and the little glass tube explodes!! It happened to me just about a month ago.SO, THE XL SIZE WORKS BEST FOR ME!!Thank y'all for making a product that is inexpensive, lightweight, ad works like a charm!  Will definitely look y'all up and check ut your website to see what other products y'all have.
Great batteries, just what I need for my brass Manhattan mech mod or my Stingray, and my Nemesis mech mods.  Will definitely buy again.
This works extremely well, I use this when building coild for my RBA atomizers and my dripper atomizers.  This gets right up to the posts can cut the excess wire off flush if need be.
Good stuff, I use this when wicking my RBA's and RDA atomizers.

Its a piece of crap.  I got it to fire up once, after that I needed a lighter or some other fire to light it.  Even then, the flame isn't much more than a 1/4" like a pilot light..light.  Stay away from this piece of junk.

Absolutely!!  This is great stuff, just the right diameter for most of my coil building.  It is inexpensive enough, which is why I bought two rolls of it.  Hopefully it will be enough to keep in coils for some time to come!

These are 3.7 volt 1200mAh Li-ion type batteries.  For me I use them in my mini Lambo battery mod for vaping.  The 900mAh battery that came with my mini Lambo is decent enough , but I wanted something a little longer lasting.  Can't say one way or the other....yet.  These 2 and my 900mAh battery all last about the same length of time.  Although I can usually go all day with one of thes batteries and my 900mAh will give me most of a day.Bottom line; these would work extremely well in an l.e.d flashlight or a camera, but will do a yoemans job for pretty much any of your vaping needs.  These are relatively inexpensive enough so get 2 sets and you'll be good to go.

As the heading states...WOW...what a sharpener!  This has exceeded my expectations, when I used this on an old...I mean really old hand ax I had lying around.  I figured just for giggles and grins I would attempt to sharpen this old hand ax, what turned out a half hour or so later was a nice sharp hatchet.  Now, I'm not sayin this was razor sharp, or anything like that, but it was sharp enough to trim some limbs of a tree that was in need of trimming.That said, the sharpener arrived as always quickly, well before the stated date of delivery.  I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a quick ax,machete, hatchet quick sharpener.  This will never replace the age old method of sharpening an ax, but for a quick sharpen..this is it.  Do yourself a favor and get one!

Well, how do I begin...as you can see by the stars above I love it!  This is a really, really nifty neat stylus/pen combo, I was a bit taken aback when I first saw this stylus out of the package.  I had expected something..I don't know..a bit longer perhaps.  I was expecting a full size pen, with the stylus making up the cap portion of the pen as I have seen others in the stores at 2 and 3 times the price of this pen/stylus.  So, I'm sitting here wondering if I had made a mistake in ordering this, so, with trembling hands I opened the package took the pen out and tried the stylus on my Galaxy SII smartphone.  WOW, this is really nice, smooth, can go up, down, left, right, any way in between without the stylus sticking to the screen for an instant like some of the styluses I've had in the past.  OK, so it works on my phone, what about, my Galaxy Tab, my 7" first gen tablet..works well with this tablet, what about...my Asus TF-300T 10" tablet?  How well with this dinky little stylus work with a full size tablet.  I figured there would be something, some kind of glitch that would cause a problem.  But no, it worked perfectly, no glitches, no sticking to the screen, just smooth operation from start to finish.  Y'all gotta realize, I did not test ALL my equipment in one day, In all, I guess it was about 3 days it took me to test the stylus on my equipment.  The pen on the other hand, didn't really get to the pen for a week, 10 days later.  I knew the pen would write, that wasn't the question, I scribbled on piece of paper so I knew the pen worked.I am a bit finicky about my pens, some I like to have fine point, others a medium point. This is somewhere in between I think, not real sure.  I like the pen, I know there isn't an "in between" point on pens, either fine, medium, or heavy I think is the term.The pen writes very nice..for me, others may or may not like it, but me personally, I like the way this pen writes, when it comes time for a refill, you can bet I'm gonna be lookin on Amazon.com.  Overall, its a small package that does a big job, very well. Each part compliments the other, if there has to be a dislike, I guess it would be that the stylus isn't part of the cap like I have seen others of this type.  For now, when you take the cap off its off, then it is small, almost too small.  Fortunately I don't have big hands, nor are they small either. I know sooner or later I will be using this somewhere or someplace and will forget it or forget where I put it, when..not if, when that happens, I will come right back to Amazon and purchase a new one, I probably should any way, just so I have an extra one..or two.The vendor for this device is easy to deal with, ships promptly.  This item, for whatever reason was on hold or back ordered,which just goes to show how popular this item really is.  Get another one..or two..or more....YOU BETCHA I will.  If you have a smartphone, or tablet or both, hell, even one of these new touch screen computers they have now, this will in all probability work on it as well.  Get one, try it out and let me know!  Great litlle device, I highly recommend this device.  Thank you all for taking the time out of your busy schedule to read my post.

This is a pretty much self explanatory app.  You set it up per your user preferences, if you are originally from say......Kansas City, Kansas, and you're living in LA now, you can set this app up to get broadcasts from Kansas City PD, the fire dept, weather, even amateur radio repeaters from your home town.  This is one of those apps that has its place for all of us that wish we were part of the action, but glad we're not.  After 25+ years in law enforcement, and have owned several scanners in my time, and although I don't currently own the latest in a digital spread spectrum top of the line scanner.  I still have a digital scanner in my pocket thanks to scanner radioYa gotta love those guys and gals who of there own free will take the time to set up there own scanners and allow those of us that want to listen can listen.  I would hazard a guess that most of us have a favorite or two or three set frequencies if you will, well, with this app, you can set up your favorites list and you can just pick and chose which one you want to listen to for the first hour or two.  Or maybe one of your favorites is quiet tonight, you take a chance and see whats going on in the land down under, yep, we can listen to the brave men and women in uniform in Australia.  While its no hand held scanner that you can set up, program, have an antenna on the roof of your home and all, bt this isn't a bad substitute, try it, couldn't hurt, you may just be the next action junkie.  Have fun with this, don't become an ambulance chaser, you may wind up being the topic of discussion for that evening, not sayin, just sayin, be smart and be safe, enjoy the app for what it is.

I am so thankful for the smartphones we have on the market today, for if there were no smartphones, there would be no Amazon Mobile app.  That said, I have this app on all 3 of my devices, my Samsung Galaxy SII  Epic Touch 4G/D710, my Samsung Galaxy Tab 7" tablet, and my Asus TF300T Transformer 10" tablet, its one of those apps that you never knew how you lived without it.  For me, when ever I am out and about, and I may per chance find something I am looking for.  Well now, I just bring up my Amazon Mobile app, being as the app will work on 3/4G and/or WiFi, I'm never without my trusty Amazon Mobile app.  I can open open the app, log on, search for whatever it is I'm drooling over at the time, if I can get it cheaper on Amazon, and chances are I will, if it is something I absolutely have to have, I can order it on the spot, and have it in my hands in a matter of days.If you are on the go, or out and about, if you are anything at all like I am, and this goes for you guys, tools, yea Amazon has ALL kinds of tools, electronic gizmos and gadgets, which I'm a sucker for, Amazon has all kinds of electronics too.  Now you don't need to be on your home computer to satisfy those impulse purchases, or that late night gift for your wife or girlfriend.  You can do it all from the comfort of your smartphone.

Here i went and bought this and didn't pay attention to the size of this thing.  To that end, these are great for gardening, at least that is what my wife tells me.  I wanted the full size etool like I had when I was in the Army, instead I bought & got this, I was a little disappointed at first, then thought, wait, my wife will love this, she use this in her gardening chores, or when she's just "playing" in the yard.

I know there are some of these that have 12' of para cord, over mine which has 9' of paracord.  That said, I feel that here is another one of those day to day items we never think about that could wind up saving a life.  Maybe you need some cord to tie up a splint, or you in the boonies, you need to survive, read eat, this can be a way to manufacture a snare to trap something to eat, read survive.  Besides, its cool, I get asked about my bracelet several times a week, and its fun to say, oh..this, this is my survival bracelet.

Here is another one of those GOTTA haves for your bug out bag.  Haven't tried mine yet, hopefully I wont have to, but if the need should arise then I am glad I have this handy gadget.  At some point in time I want to be able to get one that I can use to filter more than for one person, something that can do a quart or better at a time.  However, until such time a couple of these, one for every member of the family, should be in every ones bug out bag.

These matches are one of those GOTTA have items that every bug out bag should have in it.  Weather or not you need them now, or a year, or even 3 years from now, these should be in every body's bug out bag, preferably more than one box.

No volume to it.  If your phone is like mine, you volume only goes so hi, even with all the volumes at max you don't get much in the way of an air horn.  Maybe, just maybe, if you use an external speaker you might get a little better volume out of this app, otherwise, leave it alone.

Haven't had the need to use it yet, hopefully I wont anytime soon, but this WILL get a fire going in relatively short order.  It is basically cotton wrapped tight with some fraying on either end so you can get fire to it.  It will work for when SHTF arrives.  There are other things that can be used as tinder, but for quick light this will work rather well.

If you have a subscription to PopSci, this app goes great with your subscription.  Can't say much more cause my subscription has expired and I barely have time to read much of any thing at present.  This is definitely advantageous if you have a current subscription.

I have seen way better, its OK if you like this type.  There are a few girls herein that have very healthy lungs too be sure.  But for 99 cents, I don't know as if I knew what I know now, weather or not I would buy this.  Again..its OK, but there are better.

Oh man, this book is just way too funny, a lot of what Justin's dad says I can relate to from my own dads bits of wisdom.  If you have the time sit down and read a few pages, a few chapters, whatever, soon you'll be laughing so hard you'll about pee yourself..get it..its that freakin funny!

This is definitely a good read for any of you aviation fans out there, or if you even have a passing fancy in aviation this is still a good read.  Seems like every time I start this book, I get interrupted for something or other, by the time I get back around to reading it again...time has gone by and I have to start over again.  That said, what I have read is great, just wish I could be left alone so I can finish the damn book already!

I have this charger, for not only my Kenwood TH-F6A but my newly acquired TH-D72A dual band HT with built in TNC & APRS capabilities as well.  Lets face it, in todays day & age with so many hand held gadgets about, it only makes sense to have a car charger.  Most of you have a car charger for your smartphone or cell phone as the case may be don't cha, well, being out and about as much or as little as I am, it only made sense to get a car charger for my HT as well.  Originally I bought this for my TH-F6A, fortunately, when 6 weeks ago I bought my TH-D72A dual band HT, the 2 HT's shared the same house charger, so I wondered weather or not the two HT's would share the same car charger, fortunately they do, so that is one less expense for me.  I can honestly say, that any device I own that operates on rechargeable batteries, I have a car charger for it.  My 2 HT's, my smartphone, my 7" Samsung Galaxy Tab tablet, and my Asus 10" tablet, I have car chargers for each and every one of em, cheap insurance if you ask me.  Here in Fl. we are often in the way of hurricanes, we are fortunately rarely hit by one, however, past experience has taught me the benefit of having car chargers, so when power fails, I can still charge my HT's which will be of more use than my smartphone other than amusement which the smartphone can keep me amused for hours.That said, this charger is sold at a very decent price, less than what you can get it for at any of the amateur radio stores either in person or on line.  Yes, definitely, any of you out there have a TH-F6A or a TH-D72A HT...get this charger, you can't go wrong on it.

This is a replacement, had one of these previously, when a couple of weeks ago my Galaxy SII developed a serious problem.  My phone would not charge, I couldn't charge my phone in any way shape or form, something in the charging circuit, or something with the phone itself prevented the phone from charging.  When I took the phone in, I was told the charging port was toast and I would need a new phone.  All I can say on that...thankfully I had insurance on my device, cause there is NO way I would have been able to buy a new phone.  So, for the next week I had to take my batteries in twice a day...not to get charged.  The very first day I took my batteries in, (I actually found the stock battery for my phone) to be charged, the guy at the Sprint Service store put my extended battery on charge, the charger kept beeping, and when they checked my extended battery was toast as well!  I said to the service tech, how can this be, I don't think I've had this battery a year yet, well between the two of us, we deduced that there was something going on inside the phone other than the charging port being bad, like maybe the entire charging circuit as I had said before, don't know, but these batteries are killer.  For 11-12 bucks vs the fifty something you pay at Best Buy for the extended battery, ya can't beat em, these batteries are rock solid last me all day, where as the standard battery will get me 3-6 hours depending upon usage, these extended battery will give me ALL day!  I can surf the web, check my email, play a game or two or 6, and watch a movie if I like, and this extended battery will see it through.  Yea, I do have to charge the battery by the end of the day, but at least my battery gets me through the day.

Ahhh, now I can, once I get everything installed onto my Samsung Galaxy Tab 7" tablet (1st gen) I can give this gadget a try, along with my purchase of the micro usb OTG adapter for my Samsung Galaxy SII smartphone. But for the product itself....couldn't be happier, this little device opens a whole new field of experimentation, am looking forward to many a days use from this little gadget.

Here I go again going off half aware of what is right in front of me.  Saw this app the other day, and said to my self...self, that looks like something you could use.  Truly says I, so, I spent the 99 cents to get this app, only to my horror after downloading I see in bold lettering I missed the first time,(Kindle Tablet Edition). Greetings, as a ham radio operator I can and probably will put these items to good use here at home, and in the field. I have been needing a car charger for my Asus TF300 T "Transformer" tablet for some time now.  When I happened upon this charger here on Amazon.  The price was right, about $20 I think it was, no more than $25 for sure, heck, even if it was rtwice the price I probably would have sprung for it.  This is cheap insurance folks, every thing I have, if I can, I have a car charger for it.  My cell phone, a Galaxy SII, my Asus tablet, my Samsung Galaxy 7" tablet, my 2 ham radio hand held transceivers, I have car chargers for each and every one of these.  Why, cause here in Florida we have those nasty storms they call hurricanes, and besides, I am on the go, maybe not as often as I would like, but I still do get out and out of town with my wife its nice to not have to worry about weather or not my tablet is going to have juice or not when ever we get to where we are going.  Just cheap insurance is all. This works on my tablet fine business, no issues, just plug into your cars cigar lighter socket, plug the other end into you tablet, and you are charging...OH..it works to charge the keyboard as well, so that way when ever you're on a trip, you wont have to worry, your tablet and keyboard will be charged up and ready to go.The item arrived way faster than I would have thought given the first approximate date of arrival, which I think was 3 or 4 weeks hence, this charger arrived within a week, so can't complain at all on that end,  Yes, I will definitely when the time comes for me to purchase another odd or end for mt tablet or phone to purchase from this seller again, thank you all for taking the time to read my review, hopefully this will help those who can't decide weather or not to go ahead and get this nifty little charger.

I bought these to use for toner.  They are thicker than I wanted, but I now use them to remove eye makeup.  They are very smooth and soft.  I think it is easier on your eyelids than regular cotton pads.I use top quality cotton rounds and have had the experience of small bits of hard cotton, or cotton husk that scraped my eyelids.  I also had a broken blood vessel in my eye once from not being careful and having some hard bits in the cotton.I plan to use these Shiseido pads from now on for my eyes.
